KERR--Sister Rita K.,SFP, a Franciscan Sister of the Poor and past administrator of Schervier Nursing Center, passed to God on March 23, 2014. Wake service at Schervier Nursing Center Chapel Today starting at 11am. Liturgy of the Resurrection to follow at 4:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations directed to the Chapel Fund of Schervier Nursing Center.

SWAN--Kenneth G.,Professor of Surgery for over 40 years, and Combat Surgeon for multiple tours in Vietnam and the First Gulf War, died suddenly on March 22, at his home in South Orange, NJ. He was 79. Dr. Swan is survived by his wife of 50 years, Betsy, whom he met when she was a nurse at New York Hospital, his brother, Bruce, his children, Stephanie Barbagiovanni, KG Swan, and Debbie Wright, and his seven grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend a Celebration of his life at Wyoming Presbyterian Church, Millburn, NJ on Friday at 10am. Interment Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. Visitation will be held at Preston Funeral Home, South Orange on Thursday, 2-4pm and 6-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Wyoming Presbyterian Church in his memory would be appreciated.

MARKELSON--Stephen, How will we remember Stephen? A man with a big intellect, a big heart, a quiet elegance and so much more. A real friend, never to be forgotten. Linda and Stuart Schlesinger and Family

SCHARF--Jay. Dearest Roz and Danny, my heart is filled with grief for you and your entire family. As always I am by your side, we have shared so many years and so much history. Lorraine Sosnow Aaron and Family

MULLER--John H.,Jr. Entrepreneur and Philanthropist, John H. Muller, Jr., (Jack) resident of New Canaan, CT and devoted husband of recently deceased Marie (Taffy) Sisk Muller, died on March 18, following complications from a stroke. Muller resided in Darien, CT for 42 years prior to his move to New Canaan in 2005. Born in West Orange, NJ on May 17, 1924 to the late John H. Muller and Adelaide Hannon, Muller attended Princeton University prior to serving as an officer in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He received a BS in Engineering from Cornell University, an MBA from Harvard Business School (infamous class of '49) and an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Babson College. Muller began his successful career with R.H. Macy & Company and General Foods Corporation (KRAFT) in senior marketing and merchandising positions. With his business background and strong entrepreneurial instincts, he founded General Housewares Corporation in 1969 with the financial backing of Laird & Co., a pioneering, New York-based private investment banking firm. Under Muller's leadership, General Housewares became a leading manufacturer in the housewares industry, competing in a variety of categories, including recognized brands, like OXO kitchen gadgets, Chicago Cutlery and Colonial Candle of Cape Cod. By 1982, Muller had grown General Housewares to the point of becoming a New York Stock Exchange company. Muller served as Chairman of the Board and CEO from 1969-1995 and remained on the Board of Directors until 2000 when the company was acquired by KKR, a prominent private equity firm. An active business leader, Muller was a Director at several other NYSE companies, including Capital Cities/ABC (Disney), Collins & Aikman and Sea-Land Corporation. For 35 years, Muller devoted most of his philanthropic efforts to Babson College, beginning when his son enrolled there as an undergraduate. He was Chairman of the Board for 10 years and a driving force in spearheading a capital campaign, raising over $122 million supporting facility, faculty and curriculum development . CUNNIFF--Richard Trolan, died of complications from congestive heart failure on March 23, 2014, at his home in Lloyd Harbor, NY. He was 91. Rick was born on January 20, 1923, in the Bronx, New York, the son of Frank George and Florence Trolan Cunniff. He graduated from South Side High School in Rockville Centre, NY in 1941 and enrolled in Colgate University just in time for America's entry into World War II. As a proud part of the Navy's V-12 program at Colgate, he completed his officer training and was posted to Pearl Harbor in 1944 to serve aboard LCI(G)451, one of the Navy's Landing Craft Infantry (Gunnery) ships. These vessels played a key role in protecting the first waves of amphibious troops from shore-based enemy fire. Rick served in several combat operations including the Battle of Leyte Gulf and the landings at Lingayen Gulf, Luzon, and Okinawa. In 1946 he was released from active duty as a Lieutenant (jg). Rick entered Harvard Business School in 1948, and in June 1949 he married Marilyn P. Feld (also of Rockville Centre). He and Marilyn were anticipating the celebration of their 65th wedding anniversary this coming June. Rick received his MBA in 1950 and began his career working for investment firms including Kidder, Peabody; Ferris & Co.; Sterling, Grace & Co.; Keswick Corp.; MacKay-Shields; and Andresen & Co. In 1969, Rick joined with William J. Ruane to found the investment firm of Ruane, Cunniff & Stires (Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb today), and they created the Sequoia Fund the following year. In his heart, Rick always considered himself a securities analyst. Passionate about the importance of rigorous research, Rick and the firm achieved a well-earned reputation for integrity, and in the years since its founding the firm has been able to achieve one of the most outstanding long-term performance records in the mutual fund industry. He was especially proud that his daughter Carley joined Ruane Cunniff & Goldfarb in 1989 and went on to serve as Executive Vice President and a Director of both RCG and the Sequoia Fund. She was an important part of the firm's growth until her illness in 2001. Rick was a corporate director of Sturm, Ruger & Co. from 1986 to 2007 and a Trustee Emeritus of Colgate University, to which he devoted boundless energy and generosity throughout his lifetime. Rick's other interests included sailing, golf, and politics (even at 91, he was still reading four newspapers every morning). Known for his wonderful sense of humor and willingness to help others in both professional and personal matters, Rick will be deeply missed by many. He is survived by his wife Marilyn; his childen Richard Cunniff Jr., Peter Cunniff (Felicia), Hilary Cunniff, and Jeanne Foussard (Phillip); grandchildren Daniel and Claire Foussard, Lily Cunniff and Gareth Cunniff; and son-in-law Andy Baxter. He was preceded in death by his daughter Carley and brother Frank. A memorial program will be held at The University Club, 1 W. 54th St., NYC on April 29 at 11:00am. Contributions in Rick's memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice of Suffolk (505 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768) or to Colgate University (13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, NY 13346).

MARX--Hilda Fisher. passed away on March 4, 2014, surrounded by her cherished and devoted children Jonathan Marx, Timothy Marx, and Alison Marx. She is survived as well by adored grandchildren Alyssa Marx Gray, Ariel Marx, Sophie Marx and Benjamin Marx, step grandsons Benjamin Lackner Marx and Joshua Lackner Marx, and her loving daughters-in-law Nan Simons Marx and Johanna Lackner Marx. Born Hilda Fisher in the Bronx on September 22, 1923 to Nathan and Miriam Fisher, she graduated with distinction from Hunter College and earned her Masters from Columbia University. She became an editor at Current History magazine, then Scholastic, Simon and Schuster, and, later, Prentice Hall. She married Herbert Lewis Marx, Jr. in 1948 and raised three children, settling in Teaneck, NJ for nearly 30 years. There she established many friendships with other extremely sharp and witty women, inspiring her family to appreciate lively debate and shared experiences. Her signature hobby was keeping proper grammar alive and well in her offspring. Always well read and a student of the world, she kept the family up-to-date with current events and what happened "on this day" in years past. Through the American Field Service, she sent a son to Japan, her daughter to Switzerland, and hosted international students in her home. In retirement she enjoyed the NYC skyline from her Hackensack apartment, traveling to visit family and editing book compilations and reprints. She relocated near her daughter and became known as the trivia champion at the Quadrangle Senior Living Center in Haverford, PA. The family carries her legacy of respect for history and language, high ethical standards, and speaking up for what is right. Predeceased by brother Sol Fisher, sisters Mildred Fisher, Florence Mandelkorn and brother-in-law Milton "Cap" Mandelkorn, she was eulogized and buried at West Laurel Cemetery in Bala Cynwyd, PA. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Reach Out and Read or Sea Garden programs at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. Her spirit lives on in family and friends, as we will always remember her with great love, good humor and deep gratitude.

KATZ--Norman. 88, died at home in Milford, CT on Monday, March 24, 2014, after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Sandra Hendricks Katz. Devoted father of Stephen (Donna) Katz and the late Ira Katz. Loving grandfather of Ilana Katz. Cherished brother of the late Joseph Katz and the late Jay Katz. Loving uncle and cousin. His career as an apparel executive spanned more than 60 years as a principal of John Weitz Juniors, At Home Wear Inc, and I. Appel Corp. Born to Paul and Dora Katz in Zwikau, Germany, Norman and his family arrived in New York City on April 1, 1940. He attended Columbia University prior to serving in the U.S. Army. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Fashion Institute of Technology, on the Board of the Intimate Apparel Council and was Chairman of the American Apparel & Footwear Association. He was a sustaining member of Congregation Talmud Torah Adereth El in New York City. His many awards and distinctions include Anti-Defamation League UJA Honoree in 1987, Under-Fashion Club Femmy Award in 1988, Congregation Talmud Torah Adereth El Man of the Year Award in 1993 and the AAFMA Intimate Apparel Council Award in 1995. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Congregation Talmud Torah Adereth El, 135 E 29th St, New York, NY 10016. Services today, March 26th at Abraham L. Green and Son Funeral Home in Fairfield, CT. Interment at King Solomon Memorial Park in Clifton, NJ.

HANRAHAN--Sister Virginia, OP of the Dominican Sisters of Hope, Ossining, NY, died on March 21, 2014 at the Wartburg in Mount Vernon, New York. She was 78 years of age. The daughter of the late Joseph and Catharine (O'Neill) Hanrahan, Virginia was born June 23, 1935 in Woodside, New York. Sister Virginia is survived by her three sisters, one brother, nieces, nephews, and by her sisters in the Dominican Sisters of Hope. Sister Virginia (formerly Sister Catherine Joseph) entered the novitiate of the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor in September 1953 and soon earned her BS in Nursing from Hunter College and later, an MS in Nursing from Catholic University. She was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters from the College of New Rochelle in 1980. Upon completion of her studies, Sister Virginia served as community health nurse and Assistant Supervisor with the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor in the Bronx. She then became a team nurse and later, the Director of Nursing at Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Neighborhood Health Center in the Bronx. From 1994 until her retirement in 2009, Sister Virginia faithfully served as President/Chief Executive Officer of Dominican Sisters Family Health Service, Inc. She was a pioneer in home health care in New York State -- serving as a compassionate and passionate advocate for patients and their families throughout her time with the agency, as well as in the years that followed. Her hard work and leadership helped facilitate the agency's home health care certification in the 1970's. This certification enabled DSFHS to continue the work that Mother Mary Walsh and the Dominican Sisters of the Sick Poor had begun in the 1870's -- providing compassionate health care to all those in need. Sister Virginia's pioneering work with the then small agency helped set the foundation for the kind of quality care that DSFHS delivers today to patients and clients throughout the New York Metropolitan Area. In 1998, Sister Virginia received the Ruth F. Wilson Award, the Home Care Association of New York State's highest accolade and in 1999, she was awarded the Ellis Island Medal of Honor for "exceptional humanitarian efforts and outstanding contributions to our country." A viewing will be held on Wednesday, March 26, 2014 from 4:00 to 7:00pm at the Ossining Center of Hope/Mariandale Retreat and Conference Center. There will be a wake at 7:00pm in the same location. A Mass of the Resurrection will be held on Thursday, March 27, 2014 at 10:00am in the Chapel at Mariandale and a burial will follow in the Sisters' Cemetery. Donations can be made in Sister Virginia's memory to Dominican Sisters Family Health Service, 299 North Highland Avenue, Ossining, NY 10562. The Board of Directors, Leadership Team, Staff, and Volunteers of Dominican Sisters Family Health Service will miss Sister Virginia dearly.

GARRETT--Robert. The managing directors and staff of VCFA Group (Venture Capital Fund of America), are greatly saddened by the loss of our advisor and friend, Robert Garrett. CUNNIFF--Richard Trolan. Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb mourns the passing of our co-founder and longtime vice chairman, Richard T. Cunniff, at the age of 91. Rick was the consummate stock analyst, a true gentleman and a proud veteran of World War II. Rick's life was profoundly affected by his military service. As a 21-year old Ensign and later Lieutenant (jg) on an amphibious ship, he participated in some of the most intense naval battles of the war, including Leyte Gulf in October 1944. His ship made landings at Lingayen Gulf and Luzon in the Philippines and Okinawa in 1945. In later years, Rick would occasionally remark that no stock market disturbance could compare to being 21 years old on the deck of a small vessel in the Pacific, surrounded by enemy ships and kamikaze planes, taking fire. Rick completed his degree at Colgate in 1945 and graduated from Harvard Business School in 1950. Upon graduation from Harvard, Rick joined Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York City, where he met his future business partner William J. Ruane. Rick advanced through a series of Wall Street positions until the late 1960s, when he and Ruane decided to start their own investment firm. In 1969, they opened Ruane, Cunniff & Stires. They launched what would become their flagship mutual fund, Sequoia, in July 1970. Both the Fund and the investment manager, now known as Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb, have thrived. Forty-five years later we remain proudly independent and thankful for the many contributions of our co-founder. Rick was married for 64 years to the former Marilyn Feld. She survives him, as do four of their five children: Richard Jr., Peter, Hilary and Jeanne Foussard. His beloved eldest daughter Carley, who worked beside him at Ruane, Cunniff for many years and was a director of Sequoia, died in 2005. Always courteous, pleasant and patient, Rick was a rigorous stock analyst, a generous mentor to younger colleagues and an admired regular presence in our office into his late-80s. We send our deepest condolences to Marilyn and his family.
MARKELSON--Stephen. Words fail to express our sadness at the death of Stephen. Our thoughts are with Anne and the family during these difficult times. Anne Marie and Stephen D. Haymes

CULLMAN--Louise Bloomingdale. 95, passed away in her Jamaican home surrounded by family members on March 24, 2014 following a short period of ill health. An avid conservationist and animal lover who enjoyed creating paintings for family and friends, she served on the board of the Wildlife Conservation Society, and with her late husband, Edgar Cullman Sr., was an ardent philanthropist. Her grandfather Lyman along with his brother Joseph were co-founders of Bloomingdale's and Louise was a fourth generation New Yorker. Her most important legacy was her love for her family and her welcoming homes in Stamford, New York, Jamaica and Canada. She is survived by her three children: Lucy, Edgar, and Susan as well as their three spouses, Mike, Ellie and John in addition to nine grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.

CLIFFORD--Mary Lawrence, died peacefully in her home on March 15th, 2014, surrounded by family. "How could they fit so much pizzazz into such a small person?" That is the sentiment most commonly expressed by the legions of people who loved Mary Clifford, but most of all by her adoring husband of nearly 60 years, Donald K. "Obie" Clifford. Mary was a devoted lifetime mom, not only to her own five children, but to so many others who needed a mother in their lives. She was a loving grandmother to her fourteen grandchildren, delightful friend and relative, lover of dogs and other furred or feathered creatures, creator of beauty out of nature's offerings, enthusiastic athlete, voracious reader, and playful initiator of fun and games. Mary was a natural leader, rising to leadership roles in many volunteer activities the Nature Conservancy's eastern chapter, Emma Willard School, The Big Wolf Lake Association, The Wild Center, Rusticus Garden Club and book groups. In her unassuming way, Mary was a builder of people and institutions. She left every person and organization enhanced and buoyed up through her attentions and no-nonsense support. She will be deeply missed and will remain, always, a bright light in our hearts. A service of remembrance will be held at the Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Elmsford, NY on Saturday, March 29th, 2014, at 11:00am. Longtime resident of Mt. Kisco, NY, Mary was a graduate of Emma Willard School and Vassar College. In lieu of flowers, Mary's family would deeply appreciate gifts to The Wild Center, 45 Museum Dr., Tupper Lake, NY, 12986; wildcenter.org.

BIDDLE--Nancy Harris. Died peacefully at home surrounded by her family on March 21, 2014 at the age of 84. A sassy, beautiful woman of great charm, style and humor, she will be dearly missed by her many friends, her son, George and his wife Leslie; her daughter, Lucile and her husband Jay Herbert; and Pandora Biddle and Janis Borie. Her much-loved son, Lewis "Buzzy" Preston predeceased her in 1992. She was beloved Gogo to Nicholas, Lewis, William, Theodore, Clementine, Nathaniel, Yvie, Jason, and Marisa and Kevin. Her enthusiasm, generous nature and devotion to friends and family will make her unforgettable to everyone she loved. She adored animals and wanted to befriend every dog that crossed her path. She had a life-long commitment to helping people in need and donations in her memory can be made to The Nico Fund, 784 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10021. A service of remembrance and thanksgiving will be held on Friday, April 4th at 2pm in the chapel at St Bartholomew's Church at 325 Park Avenue at 51st Street.

SUSSMAN--Katha Diddel, wife of David Sussman and mother of Paul, Thompson and Kiki Warren, died at home in Greenwich, CT, Tuesday, March 25, 2014, surrounded by her family. She was 56. A graduate of Brown University, Dalton and The Hotchkiss School, she founded and served as the CEO of Katha Diddel Home Collection. Katha was a competitive athlete and became a celebrated world-class triathlete, representing the US in the 2012 World Triathlon Championships while undergoing cancer treatment. Katha also completed an Iron Man Triathlon, the Alcatraz Triathlon, was named to the Triathlon All-American team, and ran the Boston and NYC Marathons. Katha "podiumed" in almost every competition she entered. Katha was born and raised in New York City. One of Katha's greatest joys was marrying the love of her life, David Sussman, and adding two daughters, Jane and Becky Sussman, to the family she adored. She is survived by her mother Kathryn C. Diddel, her two brothers, Glenn Diddel (Dr. Roberta), Scott Diddel (Suzanne Michaud), her sister Heather Diddel (Sam House), nieces and nephews Gregory, Andrew and Matthew Diddel, and Emily and Nate Diddel House. Katha was predeceased by her father Andrew G. Diddel II. A service will be held at Stanwich Congregational Church, 202 Taconic Rd, Greenwich, CT at 2:00 on Friday, March 28, 2014. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Katha Diddel & Warren Family Fund for Genome Research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, http://mskcc.convio.net/site/ TR?pg=fund&fr--id= 1590&pxfid=33493.

CUNNIFF--Richard Trolan, died of complications from congestive heart failure on March 23, 2014, at his home in Lloyd Harbor, NY. He was 91. Rick was born on January 20, 1923, in the Bronx, New York, the son of Frank George and Florence Trolan Cunniff. He graduated from South Side High School in Rockville Centre, NY in 1941 and enrolled in Colgate University just in time for America's entry into World War II. As a proud part of the Navy's V-12 program at Colgate, he completed his officer training and was posted to Pearl Harbor in 1944 to serve aboard LCI(G)451, one of the Navy's Landing Craft Infantry (Gunnery) ships. These vessels played a key role in protecting the first waves of amphibious troops from shore-based enemy fire. Rick served in several combat operations including the Battle of Leyte Gulf and the landings at Lingayen Gulf, Luzon, and Okinawa. In 1946 he was released from active duty as a Lieutenant (jg). Rick entered Harvard Business School in 1948, and in June 1949 he married Marilyn P. Feld (also of Rockville Centre). He and Marilyn were anticipating the celebration of their 65th wedding anniversary this coming June. Rick received his MBA in 1950 and began his career working for investment firms including Kidder, Peabody; Ferris & Co.; Sterling, Grace & Co.; Keswick Corp.; MacKay-Shields; and Andresen & Co. In 1969, Rick joined with William J. Ruane to found the investment firm of Ruane, Cunniff & Stires (Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb today), and they created the Sequoia Fund the following year. In his heart, Rick always considered himself a securities analyst. Passionate about the importance of rigorous research, Rick and the firm achieved a well-earned reputation for integrity, and in the years since its founding the firm has been able to achieve one of the most outstanding long-term performance records in the mutual fund industry. He was especially proud that his daughter Carley joined Ruane Cunniff & Goldfarb in 1983 and went on to serve as Executive Vice President and a Director of both RCG and the Sequoia Fund. She was an important part of the firm's growth until her illness in 2001. Rick was a corporate director of Sturm, Ruger & Co. from 1986 to 2007 and a Trustee Emeritus of Colgate University, to which he devoted boundless energy and generosity throughout his lifetime. Rick's other interests included sailing, golf, and politics (even at 91, he was still reading four newspapers every morning). Known for his wonderful sense of humor and willingness to help others in both professional and personal matters, Rick will be deeply missed by many. He is survived by his wife Marilyn; his children Richard Cunniff Jr., Peter Cunniff (Felicia), Hilary Cunniff, and Jeanne Foussard (Phillip); grandchildren Daniel and Claire Foussard, Lily Cunniff and Gareth Cunniff; his sister Lesley Ketzel, and son-in-law Andy Baxter. He was preceded in death by his daughter Carley and brother Frank. A memorial program will be held at The University Club, 1 W. 54th St., NYC on April 29 at 11:00am. Contributions in Rick's memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice of Suffolk (505 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768) or to Colgate University (13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, NY 13346).

CUNNIFF--Richard Trolan. Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb mourns the passing of our co-founder and longtime vice chairman, Richard T. Cunniff, at the age of 91. Rick was the consummate stock analyst, a true gentleman and a proud veteran of World War II. Rick's life was profoundly affected by his military service. As a 21-year old Ensign and later Lieutenant (jg) on an amphibious ship, he participated in some of the most intense naval battles of the war, including Leyte Gulf in October 1944. His ship made landings at Lingayen Gulf and Luzon in the Philippines and Okinawa in 1945. In later years, Rick would occasionally remark that no stock market disturbance could compare to being 21 years old on the deck of a small vessel in the Pacific, surrounded by enemy ships and kamikaze planes, taking fire. Rick completed his degree at Colgate in 1945 and graduated from Harvard Business School in 1950. Upon graduation from Harvard, Rick joined Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York City, where he met his future business partner William J. Ruane. Rick advanced through a series of Wall Street positions until the late 1960s, when he and Ruane decided to start their own investment firm. In 1969, they opened Ruane, Cunniff & Stires. They launched what would become their flagship mutual fund, Sequoia, in July 1970. Both the Fund and the investment manager, now known as Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb, have thrived. Forty-five years later we remain proudly independent and thankful for the many contributions of our co-founder. Rick was married for 64 years to the former Marilyn Feld. She survives him, as do four of their five children: Richard Jr., Peter, Hilary and Jeanne Foussard. His beloved eldest daughter Carley, who worked beside him at Ruane, Cunniff for many years and was a director of Sequoia, died in 2005. Always courteous, pleasant and patient, Rick was a rigorous stock analyst, a generous mentor to younger colleagues and an admired regular presence in our office into his late-80s. We send our deepest condolences to Marilyn and his family.

ABBOTT--Muriel M. Macpherson, of Maplewood formerly of New York City and Upper Montclair, NJ, passed away peacefully at Winchester Gardens, Maplewood, on Monday, March 24, 2014. CULLMAN--Louise. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Louise Bloomingdale Cullman, a great philanthropist and champion for animals, conservation, and the Bronx Zoo. Mrs. Cullman served on the WCS Board of Advisors in 1979 and served on the WCS Board of Trustees from 1980 to 1997. She served as a WCS Honorary Trustee from 1998 to 2006, and in 2007, she was named a WCS Life Trustee. In 2002, she and her late husband, Edgar Cullman Sr. were the honorees at the WCS Annual Gala. Mrs. Cullman visited the Bronx Zoo often and supported its work with New York City schoolchildren, its dedication to world-class wildlife exhibits and education, and many of its experiences, including the Congo Gorilla Forest. In addition, she supported wild dog conservation and many other initiatives. Mrs. Cullman and her family were major supporters of the successful WCS Gateways to Conservation campaign and will always be remembered for their support of the Cullman endowment fund for education and support of the WCS Explorers' Party, attended by four generations of Cullmans. We extend our deepest sympathy and appreciation to Mrs. Cullman's three children -- Lucy C. Danziger; Edgar M. Cullman Jr.; and Susan Rita Cullman.

KHONSARY--Dr. Mohammed Ali, 75, beloved father, brother, friend, and physician, died on March 21, 2014 in his home in New York City. Throughout his 20 month struggle with pancreatic cancer, he faced each day with courage, dignity, humor, and a deep appreciation for life. Born in Iran, he came to the United States as a young doctor and became a long time resident of Bergen County where he practiced medicine first in New Milford and then in Oradell. Throughout his life, he was a tireless defender of human rights and social justice as well as a devoted father to his daughter, Zhaleh, and his two sons, Kaveh and Zhian. He also leaves behind his sister, Lili Khansari, and brothers Ali M. Khonsari and Dr. Alireza Khonsari. According to his wishes that his death not be mourned, family and friends are invited to gather on Saturday, April 19, 2014 from 3 to 5pm at the Central Paramus Unitarian Church (156 Forest Avenue) to celebrate his life and honor his memory.

IRVING--Clarence, Sr. We mourn the passing of Clarence Irving, Sr., long-time supporter of our College. Clarence's dedication to preserving the rich history of music in Queens has enriched the lives of all of us in the community. His memory will live on in the York College Black American Heritage Foundation Music History Archive, which he founded. Dr. Marcia V. Keizs, President York College/CUNY

SILBERSTEIN-STORFER--Muriel, died peacefully in her home at age 90 with the grace and dignity which so characterized her long and productive life. Beloved mother of Wendy Simons, Jeffrey Silberstein, Charles Silberstein, and their spouses, adored grandmother of Tali, Dov, Truda, Oliver, Elizabeth, and Miller, and great-grandmother to Jared, Benjamin, and Joshua. She is also mourned as a cherished member of the Storfer family. A pioneer and advocate for art education, Muriel devoted herself to helping others discover the gift of their own creativity. Her legacy includes serving as President of the New York City Arts Commission, the creation of Parent/Child Workshops at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she served on the Board of Trustees, as well as founding Doing Art Together, which brought art education to the community at large. Services will be held on Sunday, March 30th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, at 11:00am. Donations in her memory may be made to either the Education Fund at the Metropolitan Museum, or to Doing Art Together.

SCHER--Nathan, of Sharon, MA, and Boynton Beach, FL, affectionately known as "Nat", passed away on March 19 in Delray Beach, Florida. He was born on September 15, 1925 in Hrubieszow, Poland. After the invasion of Poland and at the age of 13, Mr. Scher began an odyssey of surviving seven different concentration camps before being liberated by the U.S. Army on April 25, 1945. Of his immediate family, only he and his older brother Josef survived. Mr. Scher owned several men's clothing stores in Connecticut, including Natsin's in Bridgeport, The Brass Rooster in Stratford and New York Leathers in the Trumbull Shopping Mall. He was known for his incredible kindness and philosophical outlook, keeping and maintaining friendships with many wonderful people throughout his life. He loved to spend time with his family and friends, speak Yiddish, swap stories, travel and play golf. He leaves behind his loving family, his wife, Malya Scher, his son and daughter and their spouses and five grandchildren: Steven and Lisa, Sam, Natalie and Isaac Scher of Brookline, MA, Cynie and Paul, Jonah and Tori Simon of Needham, MA, his older brother and sister-in-law Josef and Judith Scher of Pompano, FL, and two nephews, Scott and Jeffrey Scher and their families. Services were private. Expressions of sympathy may be made in his memory to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum at http://donate.ushmm.org

GERMAIN--Lawrence. 23rd Anniversary I wished upon a star last night I dreamt that it came true What I wished for was an hour just to sit and talk to you You have crossed the golden river to a shore forever green Each day I long to see you But God's river runs between As long as hearts keep beating As long as our eyes shed tears I will always love and miss you No matter how many years No one knows the heartache of what your parting cost but God in all His glory has gained what i have lost By your ever loving wife Sheila

McALINDEN--John C. The Board of Managers and staff of East Side House Settlement express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our good friend John "Jack" C. McAlinden, a member of the Board since 1970, serving as its President and Chairman from 1993-2001. As a teenager, Jack was a participant in East Side House Settlement programs and, throughout his adult life, remained committed to supporting the work we do on behalf of New York City's most vulnerable youth. His generosity, dedication and especially his friendship will be missed. Thomas H. Remien, PresidentEast Side House Board of Managers;John A. Sanchez, Executive DirectorEast Side House Settlement
TRENT--Bertram J. March 28, 2007. Seven years today. Forever loved, forever missed. Geraldine, Bruce and Michael

SILBERSTEIN-STORFER--Muriel, died peacefully in her home at age 90 with the grace and dignity which so characterized her long and productive life. Beloved mother of Wendy Simons, Jeffrey Silberstein, Charles Silberstein, and their spouses, adored grandmother of Tali, Dov, Truda, Oliver, Elizabeth, and Miller, and great-grandmother to Jared, Benjamin, and Joshua. She is also mourned as a cherished member of the Storfer family. A pioneer and advocate for art education, Muriel devoted herself to helping others discover the gift of their own creativity. Her legacy includes serving as President of the New York City Arts Commission, the creation of Parent/Child Workshops at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where she served on the Board of Trustees, as well as founding Doing Art Together, which brought art education to the community at large. Services will be held on Sunday, March 30th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, at 11:00am. Donations in her memory may be made to either the Education Fund at the Metropolitan Museum, or to Doing Art Together.

ROTHSCHILD--Fred, born in Bruchsal, Germany, and formerly of Amsterdam, Montreal, Riverdale, NY and Fort Lee, NJ passed away peacefully on March 27, 2014 in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 92. He is survived by his beloved sons Stephen and Peter (Laura), adoring grandchildren Lara (Bryan), Alexander and Jennifer, and cherished great granddaughter Emily. His devoted wife Lilo predeceased him on October 13, 2013. Fred left Germany at an early age and met the love of his life, Lilo, in Amsterdam in 1933. Separated by WWII and the Atlantic Ocean, Fred and Lilo corresponded between Montreal and London during the war. They married in London in 1946, not having seen each for seven years. While in Montreal, Fred earned Bachelor's and Master's Degrees in Commerce from McGill University. Fred was the long-time Chairman and CEO of GENtech Industries, Inc., Chairman of Closure Systems, Inc. and past President of FIPAGO (the International Association of Gummed Tape Manufacturers). In retirement, he devoted himself to various social and community organizations, and his beloved grandchildren. Private services will be held graveside. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Fred's memory to UJA-Federation of NY, The Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County or McGill University.
RABINOFF--Dorothy. The Brooklyn College Alumni Association deeply mourns the passing of Dorothy Rabinoff '51, life-long, dedicated and beloved Board Member.

PIERSON--W. Lee. The Rye Country Day School community mourns the loss of former headmaster W. Lee Pierson. During Dr. Pierson's tenure from 1979-1993, the school flourished, expanding its campus and educational offerings. He will always be remembered for his careful stewardship and his warm, personal style. The school sends its deepest condolences to Lee's wife, Andree, his children, Glen and Christina, and his grandchildren.

LOW--Ed. To the Low family, my deep condolences on the passing of your beloved husband, compassionate father, adoring grandfather, Poppy, and tenderhearted great-grandfather, the true Patriarch. I will cherish our friendship and intimate times together along with the wisdom you shared. Your dedicated interest in my life was astounding. The phone call I received from you after many brisket sandwiches was a thrill and privilege for the chance to speak to you. Love, Dennis Kalick

MILLER--Joan, dancer, choreographer, educator passed on March 23, 2014. In 1970 she formed Joan Miller's Dance Players known for its bold social satires. Joan was the founding Director of the Dance Division at Lehman College in the Bronx.

STARR--Deena (Nathanson), peacefully at home, on March 27, 2014. A daughter of the late Ziporah and Moshe Nathanson, Cantor Emeritus at the SAJ in Manhattan, she was an alumnus of the High School of Music and Art and City College and worked for Seventeen Magazine. She is survived by her devoted and beloved husband Jay Starr, twin sister Nomi Brettler, several nieces and nephews and many adoring friends around the world. She was predeceased by her children, Neva and Adam Starr, her niece Kim Nathanson and her brother Yaron (Gary) Nathanson. Graveside services on Monday, March 31, 2014, at Mount Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne New York at 11:00am. Family will receive at home on Tuesday, April 1, 2014 from 1pm to 7pm. Further information at Plaza Memorial Community Chapel, (212) 769-4400. "The better days of life were ours; The worst can be but mine."

GOLDMANN--Eva Petschek, was born in Prague, Czech Republic, in 1920 and came to the United States via Canada in 1938. After training as a nursery school teacher, she practiced in Detroit and New York. She was a fine pianist, but too modest to enter the career professionally. Having studied education in England, she became an early education teacher at the Roeper School in Detroit, MI, and taught piano to young students. After moving to New York City, she became associated with the Diller-Quaile School of Music as a volunteer. Eva married the journalist Robert B. Goldmann, immigrant from Germany, in 1948. At that time, Robert was an announcer in German for the Voice of America. They shared a multilingual past, and a deep love of classical music, with emphasis on Mozart, Schubert, and Beethoven, as well as Verdi's operas and Wagner's music dramas. Verdi's Otello, Wagner's Walkuere, and most of all Die Meistersinger von Nuernberg, were their common super-favorites. Bob's journalistic work - chiefly with the International Herald Tribune, while Bob and Eva lived in Paris, representing the Anti-Defamation League in Europe - was a new phase in their joint re-exploration of Europe, where they had spent a terror-filled-or-feared youth. Why couldn't the Europeans think of living as a community earlier, Eva would ask, in full knowledge that the time just had not been ripe. Eva loved her new country, and often encouraged Bob to do more exploring of the American landscape, which they did, but Bob, still yearning for a trip across the Atlantic, with Eva's in our time justified distrust of flying led her to cross on the QE2. Underplaying the distinguished past of her family in Prague, it was because she didn't have to show off, she never did. Her husband, children Peter, Andrea and Judith and six grandchildren mourn her and will never forget her.

KOSMAN--Audrey Lois, 81, of Tenafly, NJ lived from March 22, 1933 until March 26, 2014. She was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend. Audrey was born in the Bronx to Charles and Bernice Scheinblum. She was a proud graduate of Barnard College, Class of 1954, and retained life long friendships with a number of her college classmates. Audrey married Walter Kosman in 1955 and together they raised two children, Joel and Debbie. Later on, she became grandmother to Charlotte, Emmy and Sophia. Her boundless love, support and dedication to her family knew no limits. Audrey worked in a variety of positions, and was consistently promoted against her will. She loved her work, but she loved her family and friends more. Audrey was a dear friend and ray of sunshine to those around her. She will be greatly missed. Her funeral will be held at 12:30pm on March 28, 2014 at Gutterman and Musicant in Hackensack, New Jersey. Donations in her memory may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY 11714.

KHONSARY--Dr. Mohammed Ali, 75, beloved father, brother, friend, and physician, died on March 21, 2014 in his home in New York City. Throughout his 20 month struggle with pancreatic cancer, he faced each day with courage, dignity, humor, and a deep appreciation for life. Born in Iran, he came to the United States as a young doctor and became a long time resident of Bergen County where he practiced medicine first in New Milford and then in Oradell. Throughout his life, he was a tireless defender of human rights and social justice as well as a devoted father to his daughter, Zhaleh, and his two sons, Kaveh and Zhian. He also leaves behind his sister, Lili Khansari, and brothers Ali M. Khonsari and Dr. Alireza Khonsari. According to his wishes that his death not be mourned, family and friends are invited to gather on Saturday, April 19, 2014 from 3 to 5pm at the Central Paramus Unitarian Church (156 Forest Avenue) to celebrate his life and honor his memory.

KLEIN--Dr. Lester, of Scarsdale, NY, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, March 25th. He was 91. He is survived by his wife Nancy Weiss Klein, children, Elizabeth Baker (Joel), Amy Worth (Robert) Jonathan Klein (Beth), six grandchildren, one great-grandson, an older brother David Klein of La Jolla, CA, and many nieces and nephews. He was the son of Samuel and Fanny Klein. He graduated from Boys High School, NYU and Chicago Medical School. He practiced dermatology in Yonkers for over 50 years and was the Chief of Dermatology at St. Johns Hospital in Yonkers. Donations may be made to Chicago Medical School -Rosalind Franklin University of Medicine and Science, Hadassah Medical Organization, or Temple Israel Center, White Plains. Shiva at home Friday 2-5, Sunday, Monday 2-5 and 7-9.

AXELROD--Edward, on March 26, 2014 after a brief illness. Survived by his daughters Susan and Elizabeth and grandchildren, Lauren, Jeffrey and Brian. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 30, 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

DAMSON--Iris Gerber, 76, of Manhattan, formerly of Scarsdale, NY died suddenly Wednesday. The daughter of the late Nathan and Bertha Gerber and the sister of the late Edward Gerber, Iris was a proud graduate of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, Mercy College, and the Columbia University School of Social Work. Iris's love and light brought sunshine to all who knew her. Her presence was healing and her joy infectious. Despite a lifelong battle with cardiac disease, she lived each day to the fullest with great hope and expectation. She wore her scars with pride and never gave up the fight. The world is a profoundly better place because she was here. Iris is survived by her loving partner, Paul Batista of Sag Harbor and Manhattan and her three devoted children: Blair Damson of Parkland, FL; Laura Damson Lazarus of Stamford, CT; and Bethany Damson Constance of Brentwood, NH, along with their spouses, Sarah Blumer Damson, Bruce J. Lazarus, and Mark S. Constance. She is also survived by the lights of her life, her grandchildren Olivia, Charlotte, Eliya-Quaye, Revan, Linden, and Caleb and her nephews, Bradford Gerber, Mark Gerber and Eric Steel. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Iris's honor to the American Heart Association and Operation Smile. A celebration of Iris's inspiring life will be held on Sunday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 9:30am. Please dress in festive attire.

EISENBERG--Morton S.,M.D. aged 93 years died on March 27th 2014 at home in Manhattan. Cause of death complications arising from prostate cancer. Born in Harrisburg, PA to John and Lena Eisenberg, he graduated from Temple University School of Medicine in 1944. After serving with the U.S. Army in Japan as a military psychiatrist where he also served as a consultant to the International Military Tribunal for the Far East, Dr. Eisenberg went on to private practice of psychiatry and psychoanalysis in New York City and later in East Hampton, NY. He was on the staff of Weill Cornell for 30 years. Dr. Eisenberg is survived by his wife Joan and sons Larry of NYC and Jon of Israel from previous marriages and two grandsons, Zevy and Elisha also of Israel. He is also survived by a brother, Ted of Philadelphia, PA and a niece and nephew of Newton, MA and Philadelphia. Dr Eisenberg divided his time between New York and East Hampton, NY where he spent some of his happiest days with Joan and many friends. Dr. Eisenberg will be cremated followed by burial in Shaarey Pardes, Accabonac Grove Cemetery, East Hampton.

LEVINE--Emanuel, on March 21, 2014. "Manny" a nonpareil birder who survived 10 years of home care. This was due to an amputation that occurred during WWII in the ETO on December 13, 1944, in the Hurtgren Forest in Germany. Manny was the least vain or self-aggrandizing person and honest to a fault. His disability did not restrain him from birding on trips to the tropics and foreign lands eager to see new species. Married to wife Mickey for 70 years and father to three children, Barbara, Roger and Kenneth. Grandfather to Jennifer, Ethan, Rebecca, Samantha, Jacob and Ben. Great-grandfather to Vienna, Logan and Mara. Services Sunday 2-3pm at Gutterman's 175 N Long Beach Rd. Rockville Centre. Contributions may be made to NYSOA.

BOND--Elisa, passed away on March 26, 2014 after a long and courageous battle against cancer. In her brief span of 39 years her compassion, spirituality, humanity, wit, intelligence and love brought joy, hope and inspiration to all who she engaged, met and befriended. She was the core of the Bond, Delgado, and Tomei families. Part of her legacy was and always will be her transparency and trustworthiness. Survived by her daughter Sadie, and devoted and adoring husband Nathan, Elisa's soul will continue to live on in the countless hearts of all who knew, supported and loved her. Funeral services will be held at Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79th Street at 13th Ave, Brooklyn, NY on Saturday, March 29th, 2014. Services at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Sadie Bond Educational Fund or The Avon Walk Fund.

CUNNIFF--Richard Trolan, died of complications from congestive heart failure on March 23, 2014, at his home in Lloyd Harbor, NY. He was 91. Rick was born on January 20, 1923, in the Bronx, New York, the son of Frank George and Florence Trolan Cunniff. He graduated from South Side High School in Rockville Centre, NY in 1941 and enrolled in Colgate University just in time for America's entry into World War II. As a proud part of the Navy's V-12 program at Colgate, he completed his officer training and was posted to Pearl Harbor in 1944 to serve aboard LCI(G)451, one of the Navy's Landing Craft Infantry (Gunnery) ships. These vessels played a key role in protecting the first waves of amphibious troops from shore-based enemy fire. Rick served in several combat operations including the Battle of Leyte Gulf and the landings at Lingayen Gulf, Luzon, and Okinawa. In 1946 he was released from active duty as a Lieutenant (jg). Rick entered Harvard Business School in 1948, and in June 1949 he married Marilyn P. Feld (also of Rockville Centre). He and Marilyn were anticipating the celebration of their 65th wedding anniversary this coming June. Rick received his MBA in 1950 and began his career working for investment firms including Kidder, Peabody; Ferris & Co.; Sterling, Grace & Co.; Keswick Corp.; MacKay-Shields; and Andresen & Co. In 1969, Rick joined with William J. Ruane to found the investment firm of Ruane, Cunniff & Stires (Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb today), and they created the Sequoia Fund the following year. In his heart, Rick always considered himself a securities analyst. Passionate about the importance of rigorous research, Rick and the firm achieved a well-earned reputation for integrity, and in the years since its founding the firm has been able to achieve one of the most outstanding long-term performance records in the mutual fund industry. He was especially proud that his daughter Carley joined Ruane Cunniff & Goldfarb in 1983 and went on to serve as Executive Vice President and a Director of both RCG and the Sequoia Fund. She was an important part of the firm's growth until her illness in 2001. Rick was a corporate director of Sturm, Ruger & Co. from 1986 to 2007 and a Trustee Emeritus of Colgate University, to which he devoted boundless energy and generosity throughout his lifetime. Rick's other interests included sailing, golf, and politics (even at 91, he was still reading four newspapers every morning). Known for his wonderful sense of humor and willingness to help others in both professional and personal matters, Rick will be deeply missed by many. He is survived by his wife Marilyn; his children Richard Cunniff Jr., Peter Cunniff (Felicia), Hilary Cunniff, and Jeanne Foussard (Phillip); grandchildren Daniel and Claire Foussard, Lily Cunniff and Gareth Cunniff; his sister Lesley Ketzel, and son-in-law Andy Baxter. He was preceded in death by his daughter Carley and brother Frank. A memorial program will be held at The University Club, 1 W. 54th St., NYC on April 29 at 11:00am. Contributions in Rick's memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service & Hospice of Suffolk (505 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768) or to Colgate University (13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, NY 13346).

LOW--Edward, loving husband of Hannah for 65 years, adoring father of Claire, Joey, Shelley and Debbie; loving father-in-law to Bob, Carol, Marty and Michael; incredible Poppy to Jamie, Tina, Arie, Crystal, Danielle, Stevie, David, Daniel, Andrew, Tanya, Emily, Sammy, Matthew, Max, Julia and Alex; and great-grandfather to Isabelle, Charlotte, and Maddy. He will forever be in our hearts. The funeral will be held on Friday, March 28th at 9:30am at the Ramaz Middle School located at 114 East 85th Street, New York, NY.

BRAHAM--Marquise Alexander. The Penn State University, Altoona, freshman who was pursuing undergraduate studies in bio-medical engineering, tragically passed away on Friday, March 14. Helping people is a character trait Marquise exhibited throughout his short life. He was always in service to others. He volunteered at Kellenberg Memorial High School in Uniondale, NY, where he was on the honor roll, assisting elementary school children with their class lessons and homework. He also volunteered at Sensational Kids in Queens, NY, the Parker Jewish Geriatric Institute, Winthrop University Hospital and Ronald McDonald House. Marquise's love of God was literally born in the stars. He made his world debut on Easter Sunday 1995 in New Hyde Park, NY. He leaves behind his parents, Richard and Marie-Yves Braham, younger siblings Selene and Sebastien, a grandfather, Maurice, and a host of aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. Wake is Friday, March 28 2-5p and 7-9pm at Park Funeral Chapel, Garden City Park. Funeral Mass is 10am, Saturday, March 29 at Our Lady of the Snows Church in Floral Park, Queens.

CULLMAN--Louise. The Board of the Tryall Fund mourns the passing of Louise Cullman, our founder, inspiration and mentor. In her spirit of caring we will continue the work she started fifty+ years ago on behalf of Jamaicans in the Parish of Hanover. We send our sympathy and condolences to her devoted family.

BROOKS--Howard R. March 25, 2014. Beloved husband of Paula, cherished father of Karen Brooks Hopkins (Ron Feiner) and Ronald Brooks (Bobbie) grandfather of Matt (Annie), Dan (Marilyn), Mason, and Hayley; great-grandfather of Adrienne, Natalie, and Caroline; brother of Arline Brown and the late Merle Hartstein. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Brooklyn Academy of Music or Visiting Nurse Service of New York, Hospice and Palliative Care are appreciated.

CARNAHAN--Sarah Kelly, 53, of Dobbs Ferry, NY died March 25, 2014. Sarah is survived by her husband Alfredo S. Quintero, three daughters, Anna Mary, Elizabeth Nadia and Natalie Margaret Quintero; her parents John H. and Mary F. Carnahan; brother Paul A. Carnahan (Eve); sister Susan C. Vodrey (Wil-liam); mother-in-law, Nadia Quintero; brother-in-law Andrew Quintero (Sheri); five nieces and nephews. Funeral service Sunday, March 30, 2014, 1pm at Irvington Presbyterian Church, 25 N. Broadway, Irvington, NY. Memorials to the Irvington Education Foundation P.O. Box 93, Irvington, NY 10533. www.iefonline.org

BROOKS--Howard R. The Board and staff of the Brooklyn Academy of Music mourn the passing of Howard R. Brooks, beloved father of BAM President Karen Brooks Hopkins. We wish to express our heartfelt condolences to Karen and to Paula Brooks, Ronald Brooks, Arline Brown, Matthew and Annie Hopkins, Dan and Marilyn Brooks, Mason Brooks, and Hayley Brooks.

CULLMAN--Louise. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Louise Bloomingdale Cullman, a great philanthropist and champion for animals, conservation, and the Bronx Zoo. Mrs. Cullman served on the WCS Board of Advisors in 1979 and served on the WCS Board of Trustees from 1980 to 1997. She served as a WCS Honorary Trustee from 1998 to 2006, and in 2007, she was named a WCS Life Trustee. In 2002, she and her late husband, Edgar Cullman Sr. were the honorees at the WCS Annual Gala. Mrs. Cullman visited the Bronx Zoo often and supported its work with New York City schoolchildren, its dedication to world-class wildlife exhibits and education, and many of its experiences, including the Congo Gorilla Forest. In addition, she supported wild dog conservation and many other initiatives. Mrs. Cullman and her family were major supporters of the successful WCS Gateways to Conservation campaign and will always be remembered for their support of the Cullman endowment fund for education and support of the WCS Explorers' Party, attended by four generations of Cullmans. We extend our deepest sympathy and appreciation to Mrs. Cullman's three children -- Lucy C. Danziger; Edgar M. Cullman Jr.; and Susan Rita Cullman.
D'VORZON--Berenice, 82, of New York, NY died March 26, 2014. An extraordinary artist, environmentalist, and feminist. She will be missed.

CUNNIFF--Richard Trolan. Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb mourns the passing of our co-founder and longtime vice chairman, Richard T. Cunniff, at the age of 91. Rick was the consummate stock analyst, a true gentleman and a proud veteran of World War II. Rick's life was profoundly affected by his military service. As a 21-year old Ensign and later Lieutenant (jg) on an amphibious ship, he participated in some of the most intense naval battles of the war, including Leyte Gulf in October 1944. His ship made landings at Lingayen Gulf and Luzon in the Philippines and Okinawa in 1945. In later years, Rick would occasionally remark that no stock market disturbance could compare to being 21 years old on the deck of a small vessel in the Pacific, surrounded by enemy ships and kamikaze planes, taking fire. Rick completed his degree at Colgate in 1945 and graduated from Harvard Business School in 1950. Upon graduation from Harvard, Rick joined Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York City, where he met his future business partner William J. Ruane. Rick advanced through a series of Wall Street positions until the late 1960s, when he and Ruane decided to start their own investment firm. In 1969, they opened Ruane, Cunniff & Stires. They launched what would become their flagship mutual fund, Sequoia, in July 1970. Both the Fund and the investment manager, now known as Ruane, Cunniff & Goldfarb, have thrived. Forty-five years later we remain proudly independent and thankful for the many contributions of our co-founder. Rick was married for 64 years to the former Marilyn Feld. She survives him, as do four of their five children: Richard Jr., Peter, Hilary and Jeanne Foussard. His beloved eldest daughter Carley, who worked beside him at Ruane, Cunniff for many years and was a director of Sequoia, died in 2005. Always courteous, pleasant and patient, Rick was a rigorous stock analyst, a generous mentor to younger colleagues and an admired regular presence in our office into his late-80s. We send our deepest condolences to Marilyn and his family.

DIDDEL SUSSMAN--Katha, wife of David Sussman and mother of Paul, Thompson and Kiki Warren, died at home in Greenwich, CT, Tuesday, March 25, 2014, surrounded by her family. She was 56. A graduate of Brown University, Dalton and The Hotchkiss School, she founded and served as the CEO of Katha Diddel Home Collection. Katha was a competitive athlete and became a celebrated world-class triathlete, representing the US in the 2012 World Triathlon Championships while undergoing cancer treatment. Katha also completed an Iron Man Triathlon, the Alcatraz Triathlon, was named to the Triathlon All-American team, and ran the Boston and NYC Marathons. Katha "podiumed" in almost every competition she entered. Katha was born and raised in New York City. One of Katha's greatest joys was marrying the love of her life, David Sussman, and adding two daughters, Jane and Becky Sussman, to the family she adored. She is survived by her mother Kathryn C. Diddel, her two brothers, Glenn Diddel (Dr. Roberta), Scott Diddel (Suzanne Michaud), her sister Heather Diddel (Sam House), nieces and nephews Gregory, Andrew and Matthew Diddel, and Emily and Nate Diddel House. Katha was predeceased by her father Andrew G. Diddel II. A service will be held at Stanwich Congregational Church, 202 Taconic Rd, Greenwich, CT at 2:00 on Friday, March 28, 2014. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Katha Diddel & Warren Family Fund for Genome Research at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, http://mskcc.convio.net/site/ TR?pg=fund&fr--id= 1590&pxfid=33493.
HAWKEY--Marion K.,born Riordan, of North Massapequa, died March 27, 2014. She leaves her husband of 64 years, Richard. For visitation hours call Chapey and Sons 516-731-5600.

FRANTZ--Edward. All of us at LGD mourn the sudden loss to cancer, February 22nd, of our dear friend and long-time colleague Ed Frantz, at the home of his cousin Holly and her husband, Dr. Gordon Bell, in York, PA. A graduate of Parsons School of Design and the Instituto Europeo di Design, Milan, Ed worked with us for over 20 years and we will sorely miss his delightful dry humor, his unfailing creativity, and his many important contributions to our work. Our condolences to his sister, Jane Bers and her husband and family, and to the many friends who rallied to help him in his final weeks. Lebowitz Gould Design, Inc.

KRONOVET--Helen. Died peacefully on March 27 at her home in Palm Beach, FL. She was 98. Beloved wife of the late Meyer Kronovet. Loving mother of Jane Platzek and the late Harriet Gross; and mother-in-law of Mitchell Gross. Cherished grandmother of Diane (and David) Hess; Nancy (and Ari) Mayerfield; Steven (and Claire) Platzek; Daniel Platzek; and Alex Gross. Adoring great-grandmother. We will remember her for her devotion to her family; zest for life; and love of Jewish tradition. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, March 30 at Beth Moses Cemetery, 1500 Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY at 11:30am.

SWEETNAM--Elizabeth Ann, died on March 21, 2014 after a brave fight with breast cancer. Her husband and friends were at her side. She was 66 and lived in SoHo and Shelter Island, NY. Elizabeth was born in Vancouver, Canada. After graduating York University in Ontario, she did post-graduate work at Brown University. Liz was a founding member of the University of the New World at Valais, Switzerland. While teaching High School English, she co-produced the independent documentary "Shopping Bag Ladies" in the 1970's, Elizabeth was very proud of the many stories that she edited at CBS "60 Minutes". She loved the arts and cared deeply about people and the environment we live in. Elizabeth is forever in our hearts and is survived by her husband, Vincent Novak, her brother, Gerry and many other family members and friends across the U.S. and Canada. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to the VNSNY Haven Hospice in NYC.
MAHONEY--Michael P. It has been ten years since you left us. We miss your smile and fun every day. We trust you are in a happy place. Dad, Eleanor , Margaret, Marc and Melissa

SCHER--Nathan, of Sharon, MA, and Boynton Beach, FL, affectionately known as "Nat", passed away on March 19 in Delray Beach, Florida. He was born on September 15, 1925 in Hrubieszow, Poland. After the invasion of Poland and at the age of 13, Mr. Scher began an odyssey of surviving seven different concentration camps before being liberated by the U.S. Army on April 25, 1945. Of his immediate family, only he and his older brother Josef survived. Mr. Scher owned several men's clothing stores in Connecticut, including Natsin's in Bridgeport, The Brass Rooster in Stratford and New York Leathers in the Trumbull Shopping Mall. He was known for his incredible kindness and philosophical outlook, keeping and maintaining friendships with many wonderful people throughout his life. He loved to spend time with his family and friends, speak Yiddish, swap stories, travel and play golf. He leaves behind his loving family, his wife, Malya Scher, his son and daughter and their spouses and five grandchildren: Steven and Lisa, Sam, Natalie and Isaac Scher of Brookline, MA, Cynie and Paul, Jonah and Tori Simon of Needham, MA, his older brother and sister-in-law Josef and Judith Scher of Pompano, FL, and two nephews, Scott and Jeffrey Scher and their families. Services were private. Expressions of sympathy may be made in his memory to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum at http://donate.ushmm.org

SCHEIN--Rose, 84, loving mother, grandmother, and aunt passed away on March 21 in Denver, Colorado. Born and raised in Philadelphia to Zelig and Dora Rubinstein. Sweet, curious, caring and socially conscious. Respected and dedicated social worker and teacher serving the Russian immigrant community and New York City school children. Former resident of Arden, Delaware and New York City. She was a founding member of the Grasmere commune in Rhinebeck, NY. Rose was the loving wife of the late Dr. Lawrence Schein, her husband of 52 years. She is survived by daughter Julie (Tim), son Robert (Paula), and grandchildren Sean, Megan, Vianne and Ella and nieces and nephews.

SCHMERTZ--Howard, passed away peacefully on March 27 in Port Washington, NY. Beloved husband of Judith (nee Silman); loving father of Amy Weinstein (Howard) and Carol Katz (Fred); devoted grandfather of Lindsey and Jenna Weinstein and Joshua and Daniel Katz. A veteran of Army service in World War II, Howard graduated from Columbia College and Columbia Law School. He retired in 1991 from the law firm of Huber Lawrence and Abell, where he was a partner. Howard's greatest passion was the Millrose Games and his involvement in the sport of track and field. Succeeding his father, Fred, he served as Millrose Meet Director from 1974 to 2003; he also officiated at meets all around the country. He was a friend and mentor to many in track and field. His highest honor, among many awards received, was his induction, along with his father, into the National Track & Field Hall of Fame in 2012. Howard's memory will be cherished by his family and many friends. They will remember him with great love and affection, and they will miss him dearly. Funeral service Sunday, March 30, 2pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY.

ROTHSCHILD--Fred, High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Fred Rothschild. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary
WILENTZ--Jacqueline Malino. December 15, 1927 - March 29, 1989 After a quarter of a century, still profoundly missed by her children, James, Amy, and Thomas Wilentz

BAUM--Phil, died March 27th, after a long hard battle. He loved life as he loved all he believed in. He lived for lively discussions, his books and the beauty of language. He was a true renaissance man and will never be replaced. He will live in my heart forever and I am and always will be his Bette.

RAPOPORT--George, on March 27, 2014, beloved father, husband, grandfather, and friend, passed away, peacefully, with his family by his side. For many years, George was the very popular, sole proprietor of Ar-Bee Men's Wear, an institution on the Upper East Side in the 1970s and 80s. Among many things, he will be remembered for his playful sense of humor, inquisitive mind, and generosity. He will be greatly missed. For those wishing to pay tribute to George's life, the family asks that you make donations to the NYC Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association. Memorial services will be held on Sunday, March 30, 2014, at the Plaza Funeral Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, (at 91st Street), at 1:30pm.
RABINOFF--Dorothy. The Brooklyn College Alumni Association deeply mourns the passing of Dorothy Rabinoff '51, life-long, dedicated and beloved Board Member.
CLEMENT--John H.,IV "Jack", 59. On March 23, 2014. A memorial service is to be held at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St), NY, NY. Family to receive friends at 4pm. Service at 5:30pm.

ROTHSCHILD--Fred, born in Bruchsal, Germany, and formerly of Amsterdam, Montreal, Riverdale, NY and Fort Lee, NJ passed away peacefully on March 27, 2014 in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 92. He is survived by his beloved sons Stephen and Peter (Laura), adoring grandchildren Lara (Bryan), Alexander and Jennifer, and cherished great granddaughter Emily. His devoted wife Lilo predeceased him on October 13, 2013. Fred left Germany at an early age and met the love of his life, Lilo, in Amsterdam in 1933. Separated by WWII and the Atlantic Ocean, Fred and Lilo corresponded between Montreal and London during the war. They married in London in 1946, not having seen each for seven years. While in Montreal, Fred earned Bachelor's and Master's Degrees in Commerce from McGill University. Fred was the long-time Chairman and CEO of GENtech Industries, Inc., Chairman of Closure Systems, Inc. and past President of FIPAGO (the International Association of Gummed Tape Manufacturers). In retirement, he devoted himself to various social and community organizations, and his beloved grandchildren. Private services will be held graveside. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Fred's memory to UJA-Federation of NY, The Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County or McGill University.

BRICKNER--Philip W.,MD. The New York Academy of Medicine community mourns the passing of Dr. Philip Brickner, a member of the Age-friendly NYC Commission with a special lifelong commitment to older adults, the homeless, and New York's most vulnerable populations. We send our condolences to Dr. Brickner's family. Jo Ivey Boufford, MD, President

GOLDMAN--Naomi S.,age 89, of Rockville Centre, NY, on March 25. Survived by children Martha and John Goldman. Predeceased by brother Robert and sister Lenni. An independent, intelligent woman of varied interests, she will be greatly missed by family and friends and all whose lives she touched.

BOOTHBY--Willard S.,Jr., died at the age of 92 on March 22 in Hobe Sound, FL after complications from a fall. He was the devoted husband of 68 years to Florence (Gigi), loving father to Willard Sands Boothby III, Richard Cheney Boothby, and Ann Boothby LeBreton, their spouses Linda, Melen, and David, adored grandfather of Elizabeth, Will, Kate, Jay, Sarah, Hadley, Colby, and David, and great-grandfather Lilly, Bennett, and Eloise. Born and raised in Philadelphia, he graduated with a BS in Engineering from Lehigh University. He joined Eastman Dillon in Philadelphia in 1950, became President and CEO of Blyth Eastman Dillon in New York in 1971, continuing as Chairman and CEO until 1980. He was Chairman of the Securities Industry Association, and on numerous boards, including Burlington Industries Inc, Georgia-Pacific Corp, Getty Oil Co, and Sperry Rand Corp, and a Director and Trustee of Glenmede Trust for 22 years. He was a civic leader in Philadelphia, serving on many organizations, including as President of the Academy of Music for eight years, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, Chairman of the Committee of Seventy, Chairman of the Century IV Committee organizing the Philadelphia Bicentennial Celebration, and on the Board of Overseers of William Penn Charter School. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. A memorial service was held on March 28 on Jupiter Island. A memorial service will be held May 17 at 11:30am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 22 East Chestnut Hill Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19118. In lieu of flowers, please direct contributions to The Academy of Music Restoration Fund, Attn: Claire Allamby, The Philadelphia Orchestra Association, One South Broad St., 14th fl., Philadelphia, PA 19107.

LASKOW--Dr. Alan E.,72, Neuropsychologist 35 years, passed away March 9th. A memorial service will be held at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleeker St. on Tuesday, April 1st at 10:30am. He will be deeply missed by the patients he has helped and friends who loved him.

LOW--Edward. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend Eddy "Poppy" Low. He was a man of integrity and great character, a loving husband, father and cherished grandfather, great-grandfather and friend. We will greatly miss him and all of his wisdom and he will remain forever in our hearts. We extend our sincere condolences to his warm and loving wife, Hannah, the Lows and their entire extended family. The Entire Rudin Family

LEVINE--Emanuel, on March 21, 2014. "Manny" a nonpareil birder who survived 10 years of home care. This was due to an amputation that occurred during WWII in the ETO on December 13, 1944, in the Hurtgren Forest in Germany. Manny was the least vain or self-aggrandizing person and honest to a fault. His disability did not restrain him from birding on trips to the tropics and foreign lands eager to see new species. Married to wife Mickey for 70 years and father to three children, Barbara, Roger and Kenneth. Grandfather to Jennifer, Ethan, Rebecca, Samantha, Jacob and Ben. Great-grandfather to Vienna, Logan and Mara. Services Sunday 2-3pm at Gutterman's 175 N Long Beach Rd. Rockville Centre. Contributions may be made to NYSOA.

DAMSON--Iris Gerber, 76, of Manhattan, formerly of Scarsdale, NY died suddenly Wednesday. The daughter of the late Nathan and Bertha Gerber and the sister of the late Edward Gerber, Iris was a proud graduate of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, Mercy College, and the Columbia University School of Social Work. Iris's love and light brought sunshine to all who knew her. Her presence was healing and her joy infectious. Despite a lifelong battle with cardiac disease, she lived each day to the fullest with great hope and expectation. She wore her scars with pride and never gave up the fight. The world is a profoundly better place because she was here. Iris is survived by her loving partner, Paul Batista of Sag Harbor and Manhattan and her three devoted children: Blair Damson of Parkland, FL; Laura Damson Lazarus of Stamford, CT; and Bethany Damson Constance of Brentwood, NH, along with their spouses, Sarah Blumer Damson, Bruce J. Lazarus, and Mark S. Constance. She is also survived by the lights of her life, her grandchildren Olivia, Charlotte, Eliya-Quaye, Revan, Linden, and Caleb and her nephews, Bradford Gerber, Mark Gerber and Eric Steel. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Iris's honor to the American Heart Association and Operation Smile. A celebration of Iris's inspiring life will be held on Sunday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 9:30am. Please dress in festive attire.
BEERS--Francine, passed away March 27, 2014. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 30 at 9am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.).
BAUM--Phil. An extraordinary man of rare brilliance, passion and integrity. He left an indelible mark on colleagues who admired and loved him. Belle Faber and Judy Golub

BAUM--Phil. American Jewish Congress is deeply saddened by the passing of its former Executive Director. Phil's impact as a pathfinder, innovative thinker and mentor to many, was decisive and profound. An inspiring and vigorous advocate on behalf of the Jewish people and Israel, and a staunch defender of civil rights and social justice, his scintillating intellect and acute perceptions on a wide range of issues were unsurpassed. Phil's contributions and his presence were unique. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Bette. Jack Rosen, President AJCongress Staff

AXELROD--Edward, on March 26, 2014 after a brief illness. Survived by his daughters Susan and Elizabeth and grandchildren, Lauren, Jeffrey and Brian. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 30, 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

NETTER--Alice. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of our dear friend and ardent supporter, Alice Netter. Together with her late husband, Kurt, the Netter family has demonstrated an unwavering commitment to Selfhelp's historic mission of providing life with dignity to survivors of the Holocaust. We extend heartfelt condolences to her children, Nadine, Ron and Fred, all of whom carry on their parents' tradition of leadership and philanthropy to Selfhelp with distinction, as well as her many grandchildren. Raymond V.J. Schrag, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO
