RAPOPORT--George, on March 27, 2014, beloved father, husband, grandfather, and friend, passed away, peacefully, with his family by his side. For many years, George was the very popular, sole proprietor of Ar-Bee Men's Wear, an institution on the Upper East Side in the 1970s and 80s. Among many things, he will be remembered for his playful sense of humor, inquisitive mind, and generosity. He will be greatly missed. For those wishing to pay tribute to George's life, the family asks that you make donations to the NYC Chapter of the Alzheimer's Association. Memorial services will be held on Sunday, March 30, 2014, at the Plaza Funeral Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, (at 91st Street), at 1:30pm.

SCHMERTZ--Howard, passed away peacefully on March 27 in Port Washington, NY. Beloved husband of Judith (nee Silman); loving father of Amy Weinstein (Howard) and Carol Katz (Fred); devoted grandfather of Lindsey and Jenna Weinstein and Joshua and Daniel Katz. A veteran of Army service in World War II, Howard graduated from Columbia College and Columbia Law School. He retired in 1991 from the law firm of Huber Lawrence and Abell, where he was a partner. Howard's greatest passion was the Millrose Games and his involvement in the sport of track and field. Succeeding his father, Fred, he served as Millrose Meet Director from 1974 to 2003; he also officiated at meets all around the country. He was a friend and mentor to many in track and field. His highest honor, among many awards received, was his induction, along with his father, into the National Track & Field Hall of Fame in 2012. Howard's memory will be cherished by his family and many friends. They will remember him with great love and affection, and they will miss him dearly. Funeral service Sunday, March 30, 2pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY.
FUDIM--Murray. 3/19/07. Missing the twinkle in your eyes with love. Marilyn

REED--Ruth Sublette, passed away peacefully on March 24, 2014, after a long illness. Born in Montgomery, AL in 1926, came to New York City in 1945, prominent in fashion modeling, editing and forecasting at Conde Nast, Celanese, others. Former wife of Curtis Roosevelt. Predeceased by husband, Robert Reed, survived by loving family Dana, Kristin, Darren and Kaela Reed. Memorial service to be held in June.

RIMAWI-THEIS--Maysoun. Arab-American, world traveler, loving wife, loyal friend, brilliant chef, kick-boxer, Samurai sword expert, and walking definition of the word chic, left the world far too early on March 20, 2014 after a long and brave battle against lymphoma. She is survived by her husband of 38 years, Bob Theis, his sons Kevin (Sara Nichols) and David (Susan Martinson) and their children, Miranda, Gwendolyn, Parker and Sydney, and her adored siblings, Malak Hasa, Suhair (Manfred) Jasevicuis, Maher (Thuria) Rimawi and Samir Rimawi. Jerusalem-born and Jordan-educated, Maysoun's early career was in advertising and film production in Chicago, where she met her husband. On her morning walk to the office, Maysoun would quite literally stop traffic on Michigan Avenue with her startling and exotic beauty. After moving to New York with Bob in 1976, Maysoun spent 25 years at Royal Jordanian Airlines - a career that allowed her to experience the one great love she had outside her marriage: travel. London has lost a great theatre-goer. Paris has lost a great diner. Rome has lost a great shopper. Sardinia has lost a beautiful sunbather. New York has lost a relentless gym rat. Maysoun lived, worked, and worked-out in New York City for over thirty-five years. After retiring in 2000, she and Bob purchased a small Sardinian villa in Porto Rafael, overlooking the Mediterranean. In 2011, Maysoun and Bob returned to Chicago, and Maysoun continued her kickboxing and Samurai sword training several days a week. In Chicago she developed close friendships with many dear and wonderful people who stood by her until the end. In lieu of flowers, please make a charitable donation to the Leukemia Research Foundation, Midwest Palliative and Hospice Center of Glenview, or Prentice Women's Hospital.

REISDORFF--Kenneth, of New York City, owner of the Broome Street Bar for 42 years, and a beloved personality in the Soho community, died February 26th while on vacation in Florida, after having a Margarita, a nice lunch and a swim in the hotel pool. He was 92. Kenn, as he was known, was a gentlemanly fixture in the neighborhood, recognizable by his custom made Cowboy Hats, turquoise jewelry, cowboy boots and friendly demeanor. Kenneth Reisdorff is survived by his daughter, Julie Reisdorff-Parker and husband Curtis Parker, and daughter Andree Reisdorff. Berry, his wife, pre-deceased him in 2010. He is also survived by the Broome Street Bar, and the adoring friends, customers and employees he leaves behind, with stories and tales of a long ago New York City.

NETTER--Alice D.,born Alice Dreyfus, of Basel, Switzerland, passed away on Thursday, March 27 in White Plains at the age of 93. She came to the United States in 1940 and settled in New York City where she attended Julliard School of Music and graduated in 1944. In 1942, she met Kurt Fred Netter, her husband and love of her life for over 60 years. His unexpected death in 2003 was a huge loss for her. A lifelong competitor, she particularly enjoyed ice skating and tennis as a child, skiing, tennis, golf as an adult. She continued to be an avid concert goer and life master bridge player until her final days. She had three children: Nadine Levy of Palm Beach Florida, Fred Netter and his wife Judi of Croton-on-Hudson, NY and Ronald Netter and his wife Susan of New Haven, CT. She also leaves her five grandchildren, Sarah Boone, Kate Levy, Gus Levy, Ben Netter and Rebecca Bloomquist who were all the object of her ongoing interest and affection. She also leaves four great-grandchildren who were the love of her life. Donations in her name should be sent to Selfhelp Community Services at 520 8th Ave, NYC, 10018. A funeral service will be held at Congregation Kol Ami on Monday, March 31 at 10am.

STEIN--"Sammy", age 20, died March 27th. Beloved son of Dr. Gregg and Dena Stein. Precious brother of Zachary and Joshua. Darling grandson of Al and Leila Lewis. Cherished nephew and cousin. His beautiful smile and loving nature lit up all our lives. Donations may be made to Sulam-Li, 845 Channel Road, Woodsburgh, NY 11598.

NETTER--Alice. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Alice Netter, and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President

SILBERSTEIN-STORFER--Muriel. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Muriel Silberstein-Storfer, a cherished Trustee Emeritus, colleague, and friend with a deep commitment to art education and to the Museum. She served as Trustee representative of the borough of Staten Island from 1971 to 1976, and since then as Trustee Emeritus, always involved and passionate in her committee work on education and community programs, modern art, and external affairs. She was a gifted teacher who ignited the love of art--and of creating art--in generations of parents and children, many of whom participated in her renowned workshops, which took place for decades at the Met. We will remember her unflagging advocacy of art education and her belief that in art, "everything is possible," and we extend condolences to her entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Dir. and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President

STEVENS--Edward, passed over and joined his wife Lorna on March 22nd after battling cancer at the age of 78. He will be remembered for his love and dedication to his local communities. His legacy lives through his daughters Sheila and Kirin, grandchildren Liam, Patrick and Sean, and best friend Eddie.

SWEETNAM--Elizabeth Ann, died on March 21, 2014 after a brave fight with breast cancer. Her husband and friends were at her side. She was 66 and lived in SoHo and Shelter Island, NY. Elizabeth was born in Vancouver, Canada. After graduating York University in Ontario, she did post-graduate work at Brown University. Liz was a founding member of the University of the New World at Valais, Switzerland. While teaching High School English, she co-produced the independent documentary "Shopping Bag Ladies" in the 1970's, Elizabeth was very proud of the many stories that she edited at CBS "60 Minutes". She loved the arts and cared deeply about people and the environment we live in. Elizabeth is forever in our hearts and is survived by her husband, Vincent Novak, her brother, Gerry and many other family members and friends across the U.S. and Canada. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to the VNSNY Haven Hospice in NYC.
FISHMAN--Julius G. 34 years. We miss and love you. Hug Mommy & Susie. Children and Grandchildren

Music is an auditory experience, yet much of what complements and surrounds it is visual. Album covers are the most obvious example, but musical notation itself is a graphic language. Graphic artists create pictorial compositions that have melodic sensibilities, and interpreting music through image is so common that some visual artists are said to orchestrate their works. These books show a range of musical inspirations, derivations and exaltations.
 
Walls of Sound
LIFTON--Nat. Always on our minds, always in our hearts. Your Family

NOLAN--Frank W.,Jr., of Roseland, NJ, formerly of Essex Fells, NJ, died peacefully on March 26, 2014 after a brief illness, surrounded by his family. Born September 2, 1924, to Frank W. and Gertrude (Smith) Nolan. He earned a degree in Marine Engineering from MIT in 1944 and was commissioned in the U.S. Navy, serving in the Philippines and China as a Seabee officer. Married to Anne Gannon Nolan from 1948 until her death in 2004. Survived by seven children: Francis X. Nolan, III (Deborah); Mary Louise Alter (Robert); Anne Marie Nolan Martin (Thomas); Gerald Nolan (Colette); Sheila O'Rourke (Bernard); David Nolan (Nikki); and John J. Nolan; predeceased by son Paul R. Nolan. Also survived by 18 grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Predeceased by his sister Gertrude Lair. Survived by his brothers Robert J.; John J.; Rev. Paul J. Nolan. Also survived by his loving companion, Eileen Degnan Callaghan. Mass of Christian Burial on March 29 at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Church, Roseland, NJ. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Church Building Fund.

PESELOW--Eric D.,MD, of Brooklyn, New York, devoted son of the late Rose and Samuel Peselow, passed away on March 22nd. He was a devoted husband and is survived by his wife Naomi. Eric will be remembered for his dedication to his patients, his research and his teaching in his specialty of psychopharmacology. A memorial service will be held on Sunday April 13, 2014 at 2:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W 76 St. NY, NY.

THOMPSON--Howard. Son of Samuel and Rebecca Thompson, brother of Arthur Thompson, he was born in Brooklyn, New York on June 14th, 1927 and died in Port Washington New York, on March 6th, 2014 at the age of 86. Howard was predeceased by his first wife of 37 years, the late Ronnie Thompson, and was the husband of Betty Gassner for 23 years, father of Lawrence Thompson and Andrew S. Thompson and grandfather of Renee Thompson, Joshua Thompson and Jane Thompson. He enlisted in the armed forces and became an ensign in the US navy at a time during WWII, just after Germany had surrendered and while the Japanese were still an active foe. A civil engineer by education, Howard founded the Structural Engineering firm of Thompson & Czark in 1957, from his home in East Meadow, New York. Over the 40 years that his firm was active, it was responsible for designing and ensuring the structural integrity of over 2,000 buildings across Long Island, including schools, houses of worship, municipal buildings, banks, and parking garages. Howard was an avid golfer and world traveler. After a full life, may he now rest peacefully.

NETTER--Alice. Selfhelp Community Services deeply mourns the passing of our dear friend and ardent supporter, Alice Netter. Together with her late husband, Kurt, the Netter family has demonstrated an unwavering commitment to Selfhelp's historic mission of providing life with dignity to survivors of the Holocaust. We extend heartfelt condolences to her children, Nadine, Ron and Fred, all of whom carry on their parents' tradition of leadership and philanthropy to Selfhelp with distinction, as well as her many grandchildren. Raymond V.J. Schrag, President Stuart C. Kaplan, CEO

SEELIG--Phyllis F.,on March 28, 2014, at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Michael, loving mother of Patty and the late Kenny, dear aunt of Karen (Roger), Nina (Michael) and Susie (Rick) Freedman, and great aunt Leah, Cara, Aaron, David, Sarah, Allie (Peter), Daniel and Liza, great-great-aunt of Lionel. She was the best.

LIGHTSTONE--Ron. Ron loved life and lived it to the full with his devoted wife Nancy and loving daughter Dana and son-in-law Jeff Bernstein. He was a playful grandfather to Zoe, Lilia and Lev and a loyal friend to many. It has been one year of fond memories and missing Ron. Isabel Fortunoff and the Lehrer Family

PANETH--Janice, MSW. The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board, the staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Social Work Services, and the faculty of the Division of Social Work and Behavioral Science in the Department of Preventive Medicine in the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, are deeply saddened by the death of Ms. Jan Paneth. From 1956 - 1981, Jan was a supervisor, Assistant Director, and then Associate Director in the Department of Social Work Services. From 1968, she was an Assistant Professor in the Division of Social Work and Behavioral Science. Since 1981, Jan has been a consultant to the Auxiliary Board, advising, guiding and mentoring each member with an unswerving devotion to help the Board achieve its time-honored mission: the enhancement of care for all patients. Jan was an extraordinary social worker, mentor, colleague, and friend. She will be deeply missed and remembered by all who knew her. Jennifer Price, President Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board Susan R. Bernstein, DSW, LCSW Director, Department of Social Work Services Gary Rosenberg, PhD, LCSW Edith J Baerwald Professor

SCHEIN--Rose, 84, loving mother, grandmother, and aunt passed away on March 21 in Denver, Colorado. Born and raised in Philadelphia to Zelig and Dora Rubinstein. Sweet, curious, caring and socially conscious. Respected and dedicated social worker and teacher serving the Russian immigrant community and New York City school children. Former resident of Arden, Delaware and New York City. She was a founding member of the Grasmere commune in Rhinebeck, NY. Rose was the loving wife of the late Dr. Lawrence Schein, her husband of 52 years. She is survived by daughter Julie (Tim), son Robert (Paula), and grandchildren Sean, Megan, Vianne and Ella and nieces and nephews.

MARX--Hilda Fisher. passed away on March 4, 2014, surrounded by her cherished and devoted children Jonathan Marx, Timothy Marx, and Alison Marx. She is survived as well by adored grandchildren Alyssa Marx Gray, Ariel Marx, Sophie Marx and Benjamin Marx, step grandsons Benjamin Lackner Marx and Joshua Lackner Marx, and her loving daughters-in-law Nan Simons Marx and Johanna Lackner Marx. Born Hilda Fisher in the Bronx on September 22, 1923 to Nathan and Miriam Fisher, she graduated with distinction from Hunter College and earned her Masters from Columbia University. She became an editor at Current History magazine, then Scholastic, Simon and Schuster, and, later, Prentice Hall. She married Herbert Lewis Marx, Jr. in 1948 and raised three children, settling in Teaneck, NJ for nearly 30 years. There she established many friendships with other extremely sharp and witty women, inspiring her family to appreciate lively debate and shared experiences. Her signature hobby was keeping proper grammar alive and well in her offspring. Always well read and a student of the world, she kept the family up-to-date with current events and what happened "on this day" in years past. Through the American Field Service, she sent a son to Japan, her daughter to Switzerland, and hosted international students in her home. In retirement she enjoyed the NYC skyline from her Hackensack apartment, traveling to visit family and editing book compilations and reprints. She relocated near her daughter and became known as the trivia champion at the Quadrangle Senior Living Center in Haverford, PA. The family carries her legacy of respect for history and language, high ethical standards, and speaking up for what is right. Predeceased by brother Sol Fisher, sisters Mildred Fisher, Florence Mandelkorn and brother-in-law Milton "Cap" Mandelkorn, she was eulogized and buried at West Laurel Cemetery in Bala Cynwyd, PA. Contributions may be made in her memory to the Reach Out and Read or Sea Garden programs at The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia. Her spirit lives on in family and friends, as we will always remember her with great love, good humor and deep gratitude.

JONAS--Dorothy (Dottie), nee Ziselman, passed away on Saturday, March 22, 2014, at Applewood Estates, Freehold, NJ after a long illness. Born Dviora Ziselman in 1918 in what was then the Bessarabia region of Romania, she emigrated to this country in 1920. Dottie grew up in the Boro Park section of Brooklyn, over her father's kosher butcher shop. A bright student, she graduated from New Utrecht High School at the age of 15. Her agile mind was evident throughout her life including when she adopted computers, the internet, and email in her 80s. She celebrated her 90th birthday with microphone in her hand, entertaining family and friends. While she would likely have attended college had circumstances been different, instead she worked as a bookkeeper for businesses in the garment trade. Always stylish, as a young woman she bore a strong resemblance to a young Bette Davis. She married Charles Jonas on March 23, 1941. Moving from Brooklyn in 1951, they raised three children in the Green Acres neighborhood of Valley Stream, NY. Dottie and Charlie were quite the couple on the dance floor. Although neither Dottie nor Charlie had the opportunity for higher education, the education of their children was a priority. All three of their children graduated from college with son Marc graduating from the University of Pennsylvania and then the University of Pennsylvania Law School; and son Jeffrey from Amherst College and Harvard Medical School. She was tragically preceded in death by her beloved daughter, Susan Jonas Koren, a graduate of Queens College. Dottie was devoted to her family and provided loving care to her husband Charlie, until his death from complications of Alzheimer's Disease. Dottie is survived by sons Marc D. Jonas, Esq., Dr. Jeffrey Jonas, daughter-in-law, Claudia D. McCarron, Esq., grandchildren, Susan, Serena, Zachary, and Zoe Jonas, and step-grandchildren, Meghan, Alex, and Meredith McCarron. The family invites contributions in her name to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society and to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America.

CLEMENT--John H.,IV "Jack", 59, on March 23, 2014. A memorial service is to be held Monday, March 31st at 5:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St), NY, NY. Family to receive friends at 4pm.

KELTY--William H.,93, of Chappaqua, NY died March 28, 2014. Graduated 1940, University of Minnesota, Writer-editor editorial pages, Minneapolis newspapers, radio broadcaster and magazine article writer. During World War II he was with The Office of War Information, NBC and Newsweek. In 1945 joined Reader's Digest International Editions, becoming a vice president of the company. In 1971 he became consultant to British and American publishers and a director of Hammond Inc. His daughter, Lee Hannah, died 1992, his wife of 58 years, Madoline, in 2002. He is survived by his son Douglas and daughter-in-law Joann of Millstone Township, NJ. Memorials to University of Minnesota, P.O. Box 70870, St. Paul, MN 55179-3854, marked College of Liberal Arts- William Kelty Scholarship.

EPSTEIN--Wallace V.,M.D December 10, 1926 - February 19, 2014. After a short illness, Wallace (Wally) Epstein M.D., Professor Emeritus of the University of California School of Medicine, passed away in his home.

KLEIN--Dr. Lester, of Scarsdale, NY, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, March 25th. He was 91. He is survived by his wife Nancy Weiss Klein, children, Elizabeth Baker (Joel), Amy Worth (Robert) Jonathan Klein (Beth), six grandchildren, one great-grandson, an older brother David Klein of La Jolla, CA, and many nieces and nephews. He was the son of Samuel and Fanny Klein. He graduated from Boys High School, NYU and Chicago Medical School. He practiced dermatology in Yonkers for over 50 years and was the Chief of Dermatology at St. Johns Hospital in Yonkers. Donations may be made to Chicago Medical School -Rosalind Franklin University of Medicine and Science, Hadassah Medical Organization, or Temple Israel Center, White Plains. Shiva at home Friday 2-5, Sunday, Monday 2-5 and 7-9.

CULLMAN--Louise. Bloomingdale. A woman of valor and pillar of strength to her family and all those whose lives she touched.Our thoughts are with the entire Cullman family. With loving memories. Sherry and Gene Zuriff

CULLMAN--Louise. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Louise Bloomingdale Cullman, a great philanthropist and champion for animals, conservation, and the Bronx Zoo. Mrs. Cullman served on the WCS Board of Advisors in 1979 and served on the WCS Board of Trustees from 1980 to 1997. She served as a WCS Honorary Trustee from 1998 to 2006, and in 2007, she was named a WCS Life Trustee. In 2002, she and her late husband, Edgar Cullman Sr. were the honorees at the WCS Annual Gala. Mrs. Cullman visited the Bronx Zoo often and supported its work with New York City schoolchildren, its dedication to world-class wildlife exhibits and education, and many of its experiences, including the Congo Gorilla Forest. In addition, she supported wild dog conservation and many other initiatives. Mrs. Cullman and her family were major supporters of the successful WCS Gateways to Conservation campaign and will always be remembered for their support of the Cullman endowment fund for education and support of the WCS Explorers' Party, attended by four generations of Cullmans. We extend our deepest sympathy and appreciation to Mrs. Cullman's three children -- Lucy C. Danziger; Edgar M. Cullman Jr.; and Susan Rita Cullman.

HUBERT--Selmar, a Holocaust survivor who spoke extensively about his childhood in Nazi Germany and his escape on the kindertransport, passed away on March 16, 2014. After putting himself through college and serving in the Air Force, he worked in executive compensation for ITT and Hewitt Associates. He was the beloved husband of Hilda Hubert for over 50 years, the devoted father of Linda and Jon Pressman and Steven and Randy Hubert and a cherished grandfather.

LASHLEY--Allen. The Brooklyn Bar Association mourns the passing of our Past President Allen Lashley who lead our Association and Foundation from 1992-1993 and who was recognized with our Annual Award in 2012. Andrew M. Fallek, President Avery Eli Okin, Esq., CAE Executive Director

LOW--Edward. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of Edward Low, a respected Jewish communal leader, who together with his beloved wife, Hannah, a former member of the Ferkauf Graduate School Board of Overseers, was a Yeshiva University Guardian. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Hannah and their children, Claire, Joey, Shelley and Debbie and children-in-law Bob, Carol, Marty and Michael and to their grandchildren and great grandchildren. May the memory of Edward Low, so admired for his kindness, philanthropy and aristocratic demeanor, be a source of blessings for all his loved ones and those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

COHEN--Burton, age 91, died on March 27th and lived an exciting, wonderful life. He is and always will be the beloved husband of Anita Cohen (nee Audie Glazer). He was an exceptional father to daughter Mindy Rosenthal and son Peter, and an amazing grandfather to Sara and Laura Rosenthal. He will be deeply missed by whose lives he touched and will be in our hearts forever.

Greenberg--Donald, 87, died on March 27. Beloved husband to Helen, devoted father to Mavis, Howard and Stephen. Loving grandfather to Sky, and Ben. Services Sunday, March 30 at 2:30pm, IJ Morris at Star of David Cemetery of the Palm Beaches.

KAWAKAMI--Marilyn.,71, a resident of New York City, died in Los Angeles on March 27, 2014. Marilyn had a long and successful career in the fashion industry, having been President of Ralph Lauren Womenswear, Bill Haire, Anne Klein, and Anne Klein II. She led international marketing and merchandising for Giorgio Armani-LeCollezione, and later for Valentino, Ungaro and Montana. Subsequently, she became a partner at Songmasters, LLC for merchandising and apparel. Marilyn broke ground for women in both fashion and leadership throughout her career and became a founding member of the Belizean Grove, a prominent professional organization for women. Her many "sisters" will miss her greatly. Marilyn was a warm, generous and caring friend and family member. She loved travel, dance, politics and the simple pleasures of life, especially her friends. Her passing leaves a hole in our hearts, and we wish her a swift and beautiful passage to her next journey. Marilyn leaves behind her mother, Mary Kawakami of American Fork, UT (aged 101), her sister Smiley Sciume of Los Angles, CA, her two brothers, Ben Kawakami of Oakland, CA and Paul Kawakami of American Fork, UT, and their families. She leaves countless dozens who loved her beyond words and will carry her permanently in our hearts. Memorial services will be scheduled in New York City in the near future.

LORANT--Fortunee, nee Arnaud. Born in New York City, passed away on February 27, 2014, in her beloved city of Paris, France, at the age of 82. She is survived by her two children: Andrew and AnnaB, her three grandchildren, and her brother, Anthony. Much loved and very missed by all whose lives she touched.

LORANT--Fortunee, nee Arnaud. Born in New York City, passed away on February 27, 2014, in her beloved city of Paris, France, at the age of 82. She is survived by her two children: Andrew and AnnaB, her three grandchildren, and her brother, Anthony. Much loved and very missed by all whose lives she touched.

LOW--Frank H.,86, died in his Chappaqua, NY home on March 13, 2014. Survived by Clara Barnes (Everett) Low, his wife of 65 years. Frank earned degrees from MIT, Harvard and Harvard Business School and spent his career in marketing and consulting for nuclear medical instrumentation. He worked for TracerLab, Picker X-Ray, Philips Medical Systems, Harvest Ventures, and Health Advancement Inc., and spent the latter portion of his career negotiating international mergers. He is also survived by his son William, his daughter Jocelyn, and three grandchildren. Memorial service April 12, 3:00pm at St. Mark's Church, Mt. Kisco, NY. Donations may be made to Hospice Care in Westchester and Putnam, 540 White Plains Rd, Ste 300, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

LEIBO--Stanley Paul, Ph.D.,April 8, 1937 - March 25, 2014, renowned biologist, professor and researcher died of cancer in Austin, Texas. Leibo was born in Pawtucket, Rhode Island and soon moved to Providence, where he attended Classical High School, then received his Bachelor degree from Brown University. At the University of Vermont, he earned two Master's degrees. Subsequently, he pursued and achieved his Ph.D. in Biology from Princeton University. Leibo moved to Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee in 1963. In 1972, along with colleagues Peter Mazur and David Whittingham, the trio of scientists became the first to successfully preserve embryos of mammals that had been frozen using liquid nitrogen and helium. This critical work laid the foundation for the current widespread use of freezing embryos in human fertility clinics around the world. In 1981, Leibo moved to San Antonio, Texas, to head up Research & Development at Rio Vista International. While there, he invented a one-step process (subsequently patented) for the transfer of cattle embryos, which revolutionized the industry. In 2009, Leibo received the IETS Lifetime Achievement Award for his numerous and important contributions to the field of cryobiology and its benefits to the world of reproduction. Predeceased by his wife, Leibo is survived by his son and daughter and their families.

CULLMAN--Louise Bloomingdale. 95, passed away in her Jamaican home surrounded by family members on March 24, 2014 following a short period of ill health. An avid conservationist and animal lover who enjoyed creating paintings for family and friends, she served on the board of the Wildlife Conservation Society, and with her late husband, Edgar Cullman Sr., was an ardent philanthropist. Her grandfather Lyman along with his brother Joseph were co-founders of Bloomingdale's and Louise was a fourth generation New Yorker. Her most important legacy was her love for her family and her welcoming homes in Stamford, New York, Jamaica and Canada. She is survived by her three children: Lucy, Edgar, and Susan as well as their three spouses, Mike, Ellie and John in addition to nine grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.

de BLIJ--Dr. Harm. (1935-2014). As one of America's most distinguished, articulate, charismatic geographers, he served on the National Geographic Society's Committee for Research and Exploration for more than 20 years, was founding editor of its journal National Geographic Research and was awarded National Geographic's Distinguished Geography Educator Award and lifetime membership for his advocacy of geography. He received the highest recognitions from the Association of American Geographers, the American Geographical Society and the National Council for Geographic Education. Blessed with a unique ability to communicate to young and old alike, Harm influenced two generations to "think globally." We celebrate his remarkable life and his contributions to our organization. National Geographic Society

FREEBURG--Josephine Stout, beloved wife, mother, grandmother, friend, and psychologist, passed away on February 22, 2014. Jo possessed a rare combination of fierce independence, warmth, quick wit, and tremendous intelligence. She was born in 1918 in York, PA to Abe and Sophie Singerman. She worked her way through New York University, graduating summa cum laude. Jo obtained her PhD in psychology from Yeshiva University and worked at Bellevue, Karen Horney Clinic, and in private practice. In 1969 she moved to Lubbock, TX, where she continued private practice. After retiring at age 79, she moved to Pennsylvania where she enjoyed antiquing, travel, tennis, and crossword puzzles. She is predeceased by her four siblings and her husbands, William Stout, PhD, and Charles Freeburg. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Drs. Wendy and Michael Irwin, her grandchildren, Ashley and Tyler Thompson, her stepson Eric Freeburg, his wife Sonia, and his daughter Angelica.

FARREN--George, 96, of Geneva, NY. Husband of Nancy; father of Richard, David, Thomas and Peter; grandfather of Elizabeth, Robert, Adam, Douglas, Cait-lin and Hudson; great-grandfather of Alexander Piro.

McALINDEN--Jack, died on March 26th, at 77, of lung cancer. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Anne, his son Douglas, his daughter-in-law Sarah Piel, and his beloved grandchildren Griffin and Zoe. Jack was an innovator in the field of communication skills coaching. He founded McAlinden Associates in 1972, and over the last four decades helped thousands of people build their confidence and capabilities across the intellectual, emotional and physical aspects of communication. He also had a lifelong commitment to East Side House Settlement and served on the Board for 44 years. For more information please see: mcalinden.com/jack.

GOLDMAN--Naomi S.,age 89, of Rockville Centre, NY, on March 25. Survived by children Martha and John Goldman. Predeceased by brother Robert and sister Lenni. An independent, intelligent woman of varied interests, she will be greatly missed by family and friends and all whose lives she touched.

MARKELSON--Stephen. Died peacefully, March 22nd, 2014 with his beloved wife at his bedside. He is survived by his wife Ann, sons George and Jeffrey, daughter-in-law Zana, and grandchildren Lia and Matthew. Stephen lived his life to the fullest, enjoying time with his family, tennis, a good book, fine dining, a vodka rocks, and being surrounded by friends at the card table. His family and friends were his world, and he will be missed dearly by all who had the privilege of knowing him. The family will be sitting Shiva on Wednesday, March 26th from 6:00 - 9:00pm at The Harmonie Club, located at 4 East 60th Street, NYC.

BIDDLE--Nancy Harris. Died peacefully at home surrounded by her family on March 21, 2014 at the age of 84. A sassy, beautiful woman of great charm, style and humor, she will be dearly missed by her many friends, her son, George and his wife Leslie; her daughter, Lucile and her husband Jay Herbert; and Pandora Biddle and Janis Borie. Her much-loved son, Lewis "Buzzy" Preston predeceased her in 1992. She was beloved Gogo to Nicholas, Lewis, William, Theodore, Clementine, Nathaniel, Yvie, Jason, and Marisa and Kevin. Her enthusiasm, generous nature and devotion to friends and family will make her unforgettable to everyone she loved. She adored animals and wanted to befriend every dog that crossed her path. She had a life-long commitment to helping people in need and donations in her memory can be made to The Nico Fund, 784 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10021. A service of remembrance and thanksgiving will be held on Friday, April 4th at 2pm in the chapel at St Bartholomew's Church at 325 Park Avenue at 51st Street.

BAUM--Phil. American Jewish Congress is deeply saddened by the passing of its former Executive Director. Phil's impact as a pathfinder, innovative thinker and mentor to many, was decisive and profound. An inspiring and vigorous advocate on behalf of the Jewish people and Israel, and a staunch defender of civil rights and social justice, his scintillating intellect and acute perceptions on a wide range of issues were unsurpassed. Phil's contributions and his presence were unique. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Bette. Jack Rosen, President AJCongress Staff
BENNETT--Beth Bourne. October 30, 1970 - March 25, 2014. Age 43, of Greenwich, CT, died Tuesday, March 25, 2014 at Columbia-New York Presbyterian Hospital.

BRIGGLE--Stockton, passed away after a long and valiant fight with cancer, in Beverly Hills, on Saturday, March 22, 2014. Stockton was a force of nature and continued to be so throughout his 79 years. From producing Ethel Merman, Ann Miller and Selma Diamond in concert, to directing Rock Hudson in Camelot and Dick Van Dyke in Damn Yankees, as well as international productions of Man of La Mancha, plus Sian Phillips in the West End's Spine Chiller, he was known for not only his amazing talent, but also for the trust that his stars bestowed upon him as director. Stockton's longtime associations with Constance Towers, Fannie Flagg and Rock Hudson, were examples of that trust. He is best known for directing the television mini series, "The Alamo" starring Alec Baldwin and Raul Julia and "The Road To Silence" starring Marlee Matlin and Lee Remick. In later years, Stockton became an interior designer, commuting from his native Texas to Beverly Hills. His love affair with cooking also resulted in various cooking tours and lectures throughout the country as well. Along with his late partner Steven Willig, they founded Briggle/Willig productions in Miami in the 1970's. Stockton lived in New York City during the seventies and early eighties before moving to Beverly Hills. He is survived by his husband, Mark Tillman-Briggle, three brothers, William, Tony and Michael and their families. His loyalty, caring and friendship to those he loved, was unparalleled. Jon Wilner
BAUM--Phil. An extraordinary man of rare brilliance, passion and integrity. He left an indelible mark on colleagues who admired and loved him. Belle Faber and Judy Golub

BOOTHBY--Willard S.,Jr., died at the age of 92 on March 22, 2014 in Hobe Sound, FL after complications from a fall. He was the devoted husband of 68 years to Florence (Gigi), loving father to Willard Sands Boothby III, Richard Cheney Boothby, and Ann Boothby LeBreton, their spouses Linda, Melen, and David, adored grandfather of Elizabeth, Will, Kate, Jay, Sarah, Hadley, Colby, and David, and great-grandfather of Lilly, Bennett, and Eloise. Born and raised in Philadelphia, he graduated with a BS in Engineering from Lehigh University. He joined Eastman Dillon in Philadelphia in 1950, became President and CEO of Blyth Eastman Dillon in New York in 1971, continuing as Chairman and CEO until 1980. He was Chairman of the Securities Industry Association, and on numerous boards, including Burlington Industries Inc, Georgia-Pacific Corp, Getty Oil Co, and Sperry Rand Corp, and a Director and Trustee of Glenmede Trust for 22 years. He was a civic leader in Philadelphia, serving on the boards of many organizations, including as President of the Academy of Music for eight years, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, Chairman of the Committee of Seventy, Chairman of the Century IV Committee organizing the Philadelphia Bicentennial Celebration, and on the Board of Overseers of William Penn Charter School. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. A memorial service was held on March 28 on Jupiter Island. A memorial service will be held May 17 at 11:30am at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 22 East Chestnut Hill Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19118. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Academy of Music Restoration Fund, Attn: Claire Allamby, The Philadelphia Orchestra Association, One South Broad St., 14th fl., Philadelphia, PA 19107.

BELKNAP--Robert. A most distinguished and loyal Buckley and Exeter classmate. He was especially helpful to Columbia's undergraduate education as Acting Dean of Students, following the 1968 uprising. He helped them realize that their long term futures would be much brighter if they put aside their grievances and studied hard to attain value and substance of a Columbia degree. Dr. Paul Cushman, Dr. Richard N. Pierson. Buckley '44, Exeter '47, Columbia '55.

BRICKNER--Philip W.,M.D., physician, advocate for the medically unreached, mentor, and bibliophile, died peacefully at home on March 24 at age 85. Graduate of The Fieldston School, Swarthmore College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Combined 40 year-career as Chairman of the Department of Community Medicine at St. Vincent's Hospital and Director, Tuberculosis Studies at Mount Sinai Hospital. Cherished husband for 63 years of Alice, father of Jed, Nell, and Maude, grandfather of Daniel, Nora, Lily, Grace, Ariel, Harry, and Simon and brother of Marian and the late Richard. Also survived by daughter-in-law Wendy Weitman and sons-in-law Mitch Eakin and Rock Miller. Plans for a memorial service to follow.

BAUM--Phil, died March 27th, after a long hard battle. He loved life as he loved all he believed in. He lived for lively discussions, his books and the beauty of language. He was a true renaissance man and will never be replaced. He will live in my heart forever and I am and always will be his Bette.

CLARK--William P.,M.D. Born Mt. Vernon, NY, Graduate of Notre Dame and NYU Medical School. Past President Westchester County Medical Society and Lawrence Hospital Medical Staff. Practiced Medicine for 36 years in Eastchester, NY. Survived by a sister, six children, four grandchildren. Friends may call Sunday, March 30th from 2-5pm at Green Funeral Home, Danbury, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, March 31st, 10:30am at St. Edward the Confessor New Fairfield, CT. Condolences may be offered at leopgallagherstamford.com

BRICKMAN--Harvey, 84, passed away peacefully Saturday morning, following a short illness and concluding a long and impressive life. A man defined by a boundless capacity for empathy and generosity, Harvey spent his final weeks as he spent the preceding eight decades -- meeting the world and those around him with grace, kindness, and humor, especially on the rare occasions he made it through one of his own jokes without laughing. Harvey is survived by his children Alan, Neal, Bonnie and Mindy; by his grandchildren Adam, Noah, Ben, Elly and Nathan; and by a crowd of friends, relatives, colleagues, bridge partners and admirers indicative of a life extraordinarily well-lived. Born July 20, 1929 in the Bronx, Harvey was a graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and Columbia University. He married Miriam on December 24, 1952 and spent the next 61 years laughing, traveling, and living with a true life-partner. Harvey was also known for the patience and steadiness that could have only been acquired via a lifetime of rooting for the New York Knicks, Giants, and Mets. A memorial service will be held this Wednesday, April 2nd at 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, located at 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family asks friends and relatives consider making a donation in Harvey's name to The VNSNY Haven Hospice Specialty Care Unity at Bellevue Medical Center, the staff of which brought him companionship and comfort in his final days.

PORTNOF--Paul R.,Beloved husband of Michelle. Devoted father of Robert, Joshua and Blake. Adored son of Jessica. Dear brother of Heidi Kleiner. Devoted friend to many, known for his generosity and kindness to all. He will be dearly missed. Contributions may be made in his memory to the North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, LI. Services Monday 10am at Gutterman's 8000 Jericho Tpk. Woodbury, LI.

HAUT--Rivka, beloved mother, sister, grandmother, and teacher, died on March 30, 2014, after a short battle with cancer. Haut was the world's leading agunah activist, the co-author of four books, including Daughters of the King, Women of the Wall, Shaarei Simcha: Gates of Joy, and a forthcoming book about agunot, religiously chained women. Haut was a pioneer of all-women's prayer groups and an Orthodox Talmud teacher. On December 1, 1988, Haut organized a women's prayer service at the Western Wall and an international committee for Original Women of the Wall. She was married to Irwin Haut for 37 years until his death in 2001. Rivka is survived by her daughters, Sheryl Haut and Tamara Weissman, her six grandchildren and her sister. Haut will be loved and missed by the many people whom she helped and inspired. Notice placed by Dr. Phyllis Chesler and Susan L. Bender

SEELIG--Phyllis F.,on March 28, 2014, at the age of 92. Beloved wife of the late Michael, loving mother of Patty and the late Kenny, dear aunt of Karen (Roger), Nina (Michael) and Susie (Rick) Freedman, and great aunt Leah, Cara, Aaron, David, Sarah, Allie (Peter), Daniel and Liza, great-great-aunt of Lionel. She was the best.

PANETH--Janice, MSW. The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board, the staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital Department of Social Work Services, and the faculty of the Division of Social Work and Behavioral Science in the Department of Preventive Medicine in the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, are deeply saddened by the death of Ms. Jan Paneth. From 1956 - 1981, Jan was a supervisor, Assistant Director, and then Associate Director in the Department of Social Work Services. From 1968, she was an Assistant Professor in the Division of Social Work and Behavioral Science. Since 1981, Jan has been a consultant to the Auxiliary Board, advising, guiding and mentoring each member with an unswerving devotion to help the Board achieve its time-honored mission: the enhancement of care for all patients. Jan was an extraordinary social worker, mentor, colleague, and friend. She will be deeply missed and remembered by all who knew her. Jennifer Price, President Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board Susan R. Bernstein, DSW, LCSW Director, Department of Social Work Services Gary Rosenberg, PhD, LCSW Edith J Baerwald Professor

REISDORFF--Kenneth, of New York City, owner of the Broome Street Bar for 42 years, and a beloved personality in the Soho community, died February 26th while on vacation in Florida, after having a Margarita, a nice lunch and a swim in the hotel pool. He was 92. Kenn, as he was known, was a gentlemanly fixture in the neighborhood, recognizable by his custom made Cowboy Hats, turquoise jewelry, cowboy boots and friendly demeanor. Kenneth Reisdorff is survived by his daughter, Julie Reisdorff-Parker and husband Curtis Parker, and daughter Andree Reisdorff. Berry, his wife, pre-deceased him in 2010. He is also survived by the Broome Street Bar, and the adoring friends, customers and employees he leaves behind, with stories and tales of a long ago New York City.

BEINFIELD--William H.,M.D., died peacefully on March 28, 2014 at the age of 95. Beloved and devoted husband of 57 years to the late Nancy Irle. Cherished and loving father of Robert Beinfield and Linda Hoffman. Adored grandfather of Sam, Noah, Brett and Owen. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, April 2nd at noon. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. www.themmrf.org

BRAHAM--Dr. Stanley B.,Beloved father of David, Tor and Nancy. Dr. Braham was a world renowned urologist, and among the most gifted urological surgeons ever to practice at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. As a revered Associate Professor of Urology, Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, Dr. Braham helped train many of the most accomplished urological surgeons now practicing in New York and around the world, and was an innovator in surgical techniques. Dr. Braham was also a passionate golfer and was a co-founder of the The World of Golf, which grew to become the largest golf retailer in New York City. Dr. Braham loved New York City where he lived for 60 years, and was an impassioned follower of the Knicks and Rangers. Dr. Braham graduated from Columbia College and medical school at Columbia University at the age of 21. He never stopped learning and was fascinated by absolutely everything. He will be missed by his family and his many friends and patients in New York City, which he felt was the center of civilization. Dr. Braham was 90. Private services were held over the weekend. A small memorial is being planned in New York City in the next few weeks.
GRAY--Jessica. Beloved friend, rest in peace. John and Lois Barbara and Bernard
KATZ--Lawrence, 75, of Momouth County, NJ died Saturday March 29, 2014. Mr. Katz was an owner of Siperstein's Paint Stores in New Jersey.

HUBERT--Selmar, a Holocaust survivor who spoke extensively about his childhood in Nazi Germany and his escape on the kindertransport, passed away on March 16, 2014. After putting himself through college and serving in the Air Force, he worked in executive compensation for ITT and Hewitt Associates. He was the beloved husband of Hilda Hubert for over 50 years, the devoted father of Linda and Jon Pressman and Steven and Randy Hubert and a cherished grandfather.

Greenberg--Donald, 87, died on March 27. Beloved husband to Helen, devoted father to Mavis, Howard and Stephen. Loving grandfather to Sky, and Ben. Services Sunday, March 30 at 2:30pm, IJ Morris at Star of David Cemetery of the Palm Beaches.

BRICKMAN--Harvey, 84, passed away peacefully Saturday morning, following a short illness and concluding a long and impressive life. A man defined by a boundless capacity for empathy and generosity, Harvey spent his final weeks as he spent the preceding eight decades -- meeting the world and those around him with grace, kindness, and humor, especially on the rare occasions he made it through one of his own jokes without laughing. Harvey is survived by his children Alan, Neal, Bonnie and Mindy; by his grandchildren Adam, Noah, Ben, Elly and Nathan; and by a crowd of friends, relatives, colleagues, bridge partners and admirers indicative of a life extraordinarily well-lived. Born July 20, 1929 in the Bronx, Harvey was a graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and Columbia University. He married Miriam on December 24, 1952 and spent the next 61 years laughing, traveling, and living with a true life-partner. Harvey was also known for the patience and steadiness that could have only been acquired via a lifetime of rooting for the New York Knicks, Giants, and Mets. A memorial service will be held this Wednesday, April 2nd at 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, located at 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family asks friends and relatives consider making a donation in Harvey's name to The VNSNY Haven Hospice Specialty Care Unity at Bellevue Medical Center, the staff of which brought him companionship and comfort in his final days.
The actor talks about his post-“Harry Potter” career and his new play, “The Cripple of Inishmaan.”
Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the actor Daniel Radcliffe.
Part 2: The actor recalls what drew him to theater acting, and explains the difference between American and British theater.
Part 3: The actor reflects on living in New York City, and talks about why he chose “The Cripple of Inishmaan” for his next project.
Part 4: The actor talks about transitioning away from the Harry Potter role and finding himself as an adult actor.
Part 5: The actor explains how his experiences in theater have changed him as a performer.
Part 6: The actor discusses his film “The Woman in Black.”
Part 7: The actor shares who he thinks has influenced his career the most.
Part 8: The actor talks about his film “Kill Your Darlings.”
Part 9: The actor recalls what he learned working alongside the veteran performers in the “Harry Potter” series.
Part 10: The actor reflects on the role that “Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban” played in his own development and career.
Part 11: The actor reveals his favorite and least favorite “Harry Potter” films.
Part 12: The actor discusses his upcoming film “What If.”
Part 13: The actor describes how he connects with challenging roles.
Part 14: The actor reflects on the experience of working with several different directors over the course of the “Harry Potter” series.
Part 15: The actor recalls how he prepared as a singer for his role in the stage musical “How To Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.”
Part 16: The actor reveals his favorite scene in the entire “Harry Potter” series, and explains why acting in CGI-heavy films is easier for younger actors than it is for older actors.

PILMAR--Howard. 1956 - 1996 Tonight we observe your Yuertzeit. It is 18 years since your brutal murder. We miss you and pray for justice. Love, Dad and Carol

MORGAN--Priscilla. We mourn the passing of Priscilla Morgan, a woman of rare vision who believed in the interconnectedness of the arts and the bringing together of many creative people including architects in their endeavor to create better public spaces. With respect and admiration- Marvel Architects.

PEERS--Judith Thelen, 71, beloved sister of David C. and Karl E. Thelen, devoted step mother of Peter S. and Stephen R. Peers, passed away on March 19th at her home. Her dance career spanned from Radio City Corps de Ballet, New York City Ballet, to the Metropolitan Opera, after which she worked as a physical dance therapist at Wards Island. Mrs. Peers was an unwavering source of support and inspiration to those around her. She was loved by her family, is greatly missed, and her memory treasured. She now dances lead with the Angel Corps de Ballet of Heaven.

PEERS--Judith Thelen. In loving memory of my beloved step-mother, Judith Thelen-Peers, she was our closest confidant and we cherished her. Those who knew her loved her. She brought so much joy to the world with her dancing career; an accomplishment few could claim. She will be truly missed by both the Thelen and Peers families and as we mourn our loss together, we take comfort in our wonderful memories of her. Peter S. Peers
BEINFIELD--Dr. William H. In loving memory of Bill, an exceptionally gifted student of medicine, financial markets and life. I will miss my friend, confidant and advisor. David

CAMPBELL--William Reason, 85, of Brewster, NY died Sunday, March 30, 2014. Born in Wauseon, OH, son of Leila (Rockwood) and Reasin (Solomon) Campbell. He was a graduate of Harvard University and the author of the memoir: "Dead Man Walking, Teaching in a Maximum Security Prison" He is survived by his daughter: Sarah, his son: Morgan, his grandson: Ryan and his niece: Cynthia Shaughnessy. The family will receive friends on Tuesday, April 1 from 6:00 to 9:00pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY. The funeral service will be held 11am on Wednesday, April 2 also at the funeral home. Burial will follow at Ivandell Cemetery, Somers.

GIBBONS--Barbara Halloran, Syndicated columnist ("The Slim Gourmet") Barbara Halloran Gibbons died March 26, 2014 in Dallas, TX. Born in Newark, NJ, she lived in New Jersey through the mid 1990s, and wrote the three times weekly low calorie cooking column featured in over 200 newspapers throughout the 1970s-'90s, as well as a similar monthly column in Family Circle magazine. The author of 16 cookbooks, including two Tastemaker Award winners, she was also a travel photographer and writer and a member of the Travel Journalists Guild. She was the wife of the late WI Gibbons and partner for 30 years to Gerald T. Gallagher, mother of Susan Gibbons Gillespie of New Jersey and grandmother to four: Daniel and Isaac Gillespie, both of New York, Christopher Gillespie of Washington, DC and Benjamin Gillespie, of Omaha, NE. Memorial Service at 3pm, April 6, at Trinity Covenant Church, 343 East Cedar St., Livingston, NJ.

MORGAN--Priscilla Miner. Born in Poughkeepsie, New York on October 10th, 1919, Priscilla died peacefully at home in Manhattan on March 30th, 2014. Great aunt and great friend. She studied at Vassar College and served as a WAVES officer during WWII. Priscilla began her ground-breaking career in show business as a producer of radio and early television. She became an agent, representing Julie Harris, Jerry Herman, Tad Mosel, Gian Carlo Menotti, Fred Coe and Arthur Penn at Liebling & Wood, the Priscilla Morgan Agency and the William Morris Agency. Priscilla then joined Menotti in Italy as associate director of the Spoleto Festival, which she brought to the United States. A founding board member of her friend Isamu Noguchi's Garden Museum in Long Island City, she devoted her last decades to furthering artistic causes and nurturing friendships across many generations. Memorial contributions, if desired, may be made to the Children's Aid Society. "To love with all one's soul and leave the rest to fate."
Rosenman--Phyllis, died March 30, 2014 after 94 full years of life. She was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt and mother-in-law. She will be forever missed.

MORGAN--Priscilla. The Trustees and staff of The Noguchi Museum join with the many who mourn the passing of the indefatigable and ever charming Priscilla Morgan, a founding member of the board and our first Honorary Life Trustee. A force of nature she stood loyally and steadfastly for all she believed in. Precise and high standards defined her and she brought these to the relationships and organizations she so dedicated herself to. Key amongst these was her love for Isamu Noguchi and by extension his Museum which she not only assisted in founding, but continually affirmed, and in her inimitable way helped lead. Her sparkle, her great stories, her mercurial ways and underlying warmth touched all who knew her. She will remain a guiding light to the Noguchi Museum as we move forward. We shall miss her inexplicably. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Jenny Dixon, Director

MORGAN--Priscilla. Legendary and generous supporter of the arts leaves an enduring mark on the organizations and lives of so many individuals that she helped cultivate and enrich. She passionately and fastidiously honored the legacy of Isamu Noguchi (1904 1988) through the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum in New York, pioneering the transformation of Long Island City into an arts destination. After nearly 30 years, we will miss collaborating with Priscilla on the Noguchi Foundation and museum. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to all who knew her. Susan Dunne, Arne and Milly Glimcher and the entire staff of Pace Gallery

SILBERSTEIN-STORFER--Muriel. We, at the Mount Sinai Health System, are deeply saddened by the passing of Muriel Silberstein-Storfer, an arts advocate and gifted teacher whose passionate approach to arts education helped several generations of children uncover their own artistic creativity. Her unique programs were applauded by three New York City mayors and educators throughout the world. A pioneer, she served as the first representative from Staten Island on the New York City Arts Commission, and later, its first female president. She created Parent-Child workshops at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1971, which continue today, and served many years on the Museum's Board of Trustees. By founding Doing Art Together, she brought her distinctive hands-on teaching format to school children throughout New York City and became a popular and passionate lecturer at schools around the world. Her first edition of Doing Art Together, authored at age 60, is considered a classic text in art education. We extend our condolences to her children: Jeffrey Silberstein, Chief Administrative Officer, Mount Sinai Health System and Chief Operating Officer, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai; Charles Silberstein, MD; and Wendy Simons, and their spouses; grandchildren; great-grandchildren; other family members, and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD, Chief Executive Officer and President, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

Her sparkle, her great stories, her mercurial ways and underlying warmth touched all who knew her. She will remain a guiding light to the Noguchi Museum as we move forward. We shall miss her inexplicably. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Jenny Dixon, Director

ROSS--Arnold S.,died peacefully one day after his 81st birthday, having celebrated the occasion surrounded by his beloved family. A graduate of the Peddie School in Hightstown, NJ, Arnold received his B.S. in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School. Arnold was Founder, President and CEO of The Ross Companies, a consultancy in life insurance, executive compensation and benefits, and personal financial planning. He was an advisor to CEOs, boards of directors, and compensation committees of a wide range of businesses and the co-author of the book "Executive Employment and Compensation." A pioneer in business, Arnold distinguished himself as an innovative and trusted advisor. Cherished husband for 60 years of Lila, father of John, Catherine, Norman and daughter-in-law Barbara, adored and adoring grandfather of Nathan, Alex, Justin and Jordan, Arnold will be profoundly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him. An inspirational leader in business, Arnold was a bibliophile, sports enthusiast and supporter of the arts. He was a smart, sophisticated, dapper and poised individual possessed of an enormous, first class mind and an equally large heart; wise and generous with his time and advice, helpful to all who sought his wise counsel. His loyalty, munificence, friendship and caring to those he loved was unparalleled and he will be profoundly missed and always remembered by the many who loved and knew him. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St., Thursday, 11:30am.

SUDARSKY--R. David, of North Ocean Blvd.,Ft Lauderdale died last evening at the age of 88. He grew up in Hartford on Canterbury St., the youngest son of Charles and Dora Sudarsky. His parents recognized his unique scholastic ability and sent him to Loomis School and then to Yale. He served in the Navy during the Korean War. He had an accomplished career. After graduating Yale Medical School, he did his eye residency in Boston at the Mass Eye and Ear Infirmary, followed by a retina fellowship with Charles Schepens. He brought innovations in retinal surgery to New York when he joined the staff at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. He served as chief of staff, and was president of both the New York and Manhattan Eye Societies. Numerous publications and medical device patents bear his name. A generation of ophthalmic surgeons cherished him as a mentor. His interests were broad and encompassed contemporary art, American crafts, clock tinkering, music, and optical instruments. He had a love of furniture and was a dictionary maven. Talented, kind, and generous, David drew people to him in every circle. A devoted patron of the arts, he was a regular at the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Museum, MOMA (where he enjoyed a 73 year membership) as well as other museums near his New York office. He was well known about the city where he practiced more than 40 years prior to his retirement. He is survived by his lifelong partner, Frank Tosto, with whom he shared his love of travel and the arts. He is also survived by his adoring nieces and nephews: Lewis Sudarsky, John Rudy, and Betty Sudarsky of Boston, MA, Deborah Sudarsky of Brooklyn, NY, Peter Wortman of Glastonbury, CT, and Rachel Wortman of Campobello, SC and Charles Sternberg of Somers, NY. He was a treasured uncle. Devoted to his family, David was the youngest of four siblings. Miriam Rudy and Joseph Sudarsky are recently deceased. In an unexpected turn of fate, he died hours after his sole surviving sister, Ruth Wortman of Manchester, CT. There will be a graveside service at the Emanuel Cemetery, Wethersfield, CT Thursday, April 3rd, 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Eye Bank of New York.

MORGAN--Priscilla. We mourn the passing of Priscilla Morgan, a woman of rare vision who believed in the interconnectedness of the arts and the bringing together of many creative people including architects in their endeavor to create better public spaces. With respect and admiration- Marvel Architects.

STERNGASS--Adele Hillman Starr, died peacefully on April 1, 2014 at age 91. Devoted mother of Amy Starr, Jonathan Sterngass and Karen Weltman. Loving grandmother of Laura Schechter and Vicente Garcete, David Schechter, Rachel and Anatoly Brekh- man, Eli and Aaron Sterngass, and great-grandmother of Camila and Andres. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, April 3 at noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions, if desired, can be made to Emily's List.
MARGULIES--Herbert. April 2, 2009. 5 years today, still loved and missed by family. Suzy Sankel

BROOKS--William R.,Jr., on March 30, 2014. Beloved father of Alexander. Brother of Sean and Christian. Advertising executive for many years in New York and Los Angeles. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St, on Thursday at 4pm. A celebration of his life will be announced at a later date.

FEIST--Mary Regensburg, artist, on March 31, 2014. Wife of the late Leonard Feist. Survived by daughters Linda (Roger Junnila) and Betsy, grandsons Noah Wallace (Jennifer Mullins) and Eli Wallace (Karen), step-granddaughter Jennifer Kearns (Taylor) and seven great-grandchildren. Contributions to ACLU, 125 Broad Street, NY, NY 10004.

ROSENBAUM--Ruth Bettina, (nee) Van Dyck, died peacefully on Tuesday, April 1, 2014. Dazzled with her intellect and beauty. Died peacefully at Fritz Reuter Lifecare, New Jersey, after a valiant battle against Alzheimers and Parkinsons. Born in Danzig, Germany in 1920, Ruth was a 40 year resident of Englewood, NJ. A whiz on Wall Street she edited "Who's Who in Banking." Ruth is predeceased by Harry, her husband of 60 years. Survived by her devoted daughter, author/educator Helen Rosenbaum of Manhattan and Ruth's cherished friend, Madeline Liberatore and family of Bergen County. Services at Leber Funeral Home, Union City, NJ, on Thursday, 1:30pm. Conducted by Rabbi/Cantor Jill Hausman of the Actor's Temple, Manhattan.

HADDA--Annemarie, nee Kohn. June 4, 1922 to March 30, 2014, after a prolonged decline. Born in Germany, she left there for England in 1939 in order to escape Nazi persecution. Despite losing her parents and her homeland, she always considered herself lucky, counted her blessings and embraced life in her new homes, England and the United States, where she arrived in 1948. Annemarie married her adolescent love, George Manfred Hadda, M.D., in 1942. He predeceased her in 1984. She is survived by cherished children Janet (Allan Tobin), Ceri (Lloyd Gelwan), and Kathy (Michael Andrews). For the last nine years she was cared for with affection and kindness by the wonderful Abie, Gloria, Jackie, Jennifer, Mavis, and Samantha, as well as by the excellent medical team at Lenox Hill Hospital and Drs. Sherri Sandel and Mitchell Chandler. Funeral was April 1 at Plaza Memorial Chapel. Interment followed at Maple Grove Cemetery in Queens. Donations may be made to VNS Hospice. Always a lady, she will be missed.

REFKIN--Phyllis, on March 31, 2014. Beloved wife of Martin, devoted mother of David (Ilene) and Lois (Louis Alvarez). Cherished grandmother of Julie, Erica, Rachel, Isaac and Leo. Services today, April 2nd, 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

KOGAN--Mathilda, 90, of Roslyn, NY, died Tuesday April 1, 2014 at home surrounded by her loving family and extraordinary caregiver. Wife of the late Louis for 61 years. Survived by children Ronald (Arlene), Jeffrey (Faith), Melanie (Scott). Grandchildren Matthew (Renee), Alex, Jenna, Ian, Eric, Dylan, Kyle and Fallon. Great-grandmother to Eliana and Jadyn. She will be forever missed. Services today 11am at Temple Beth Shalom, 401 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, NY.

MORGAN--Priscilla. Legendary and generous supporter of the arts leaves an enduring mark on the organizations and lives of so many individuals that she helped cultivate and enrich. She passionately and fastidiously honored the legacy of Isamu Noguchi (1904 1988) through the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum in New York, pioneering the transformation of Long Island City into an arts destination. After nearly 30 years, we will miss collaborating with Priscilla on the Noguchi Foundation and museum. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to all who knew her. Susan Dunne, Arne and Milly Glimcher and the entire staff of Pace Gallery
BEINFIELD--Dr. William H. In loving memory of Bill, an exceptionally gifted student of medicine, financial markets and life. I will miss my friend, confidant and advisor. David
