GREENBERG--Frances L. (Huberman), passed peacefully on April 1, 2014 at the age of 90. She joins her adored husband George who died in 2012. Survived by her beloved children Marilyn (Mark Morril), Maury (Judy) and Robert (Benedicte) and grandchildren Matthew, Scott, Ben, Steven, Peter, Adrienne, Jane, Gregory and Sam. She was a devoted sister to Harry Huberman and loving aunt to Bobbi, Laura and Ellie. Ever at the side of George, the longtime Chairman, CEO and President of Loehmann's, she was a woman of style who thrived in the world of fashion and design in New York and later in Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hadassah.

SUDARSKY--R. David, of North Ocean Blvd.,Ft Lauderdale died last evening at the age of 88. He grew up in Hartford on Canterbury St., the youngest son of Charles and Dora Sudarsky. His parents recognized his unique scholastic ability and sent him to Loomis School and then to Yale. He served in the Navy during the Korean War. He had an accomplished career. After graduating Yale Medical School, he did his eye residency in Boston at the Mass Eye and Ear Infirmary, followed by a retina fellowship with Charles Schepens. He brought innovations in retinal surgery to New York when he joined the staff at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. He served as chief of staff, and was president of both the New York and Manhattan Eye Societies. Numerous publications and medical device patents bear his name. A generation of ophthalmic surgeons cherished him as a mentor. His interests were broad and encompassed contemporary art, American crafts, clock tinkering, music, and optical instruments. He had a love of furniture and was a dictionary maven. Talented, kind, and generous, David drew people to him in every circle. A devoted patron of the arts, he was a regular at the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Museum, MOMA (where he enjoyed a 73 year membership) as well as other museums near his New York office. He was well known about the city where he practiced more than 40 years prior to his retirement. He is survived by his lifelong partner, Frank Tosto, with whom he shared his love of travel and the arts. He is also survived by his adoring nieces and nephews: Lewis Sudarsky, John Rudy, and Betty Sudarsky of Boston, MA, Deborah Sudarsky of Brooklyn, NY, Peter Wortman of Glastonbury, CT, and Rachel Wortman of Campobello, SC and Charles Sternberg of Somers, NY. He was a treasured uncle. Devoted to his family, David was the youngest of four siblings. Miriam Rudy and Joseph Sudarsky are recently deceased. In an unexpected turn of fate, he died hours after his sole surviving sister, Ruth Wortman of Manchester, CT. There will be a graveside service at the Emanuel Cemetery, Wethersfield, CT Thursday, April 3rd, 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Eye Bank of New York.

ROSS--Arnold S.,died peacefully one day after his 81st birthday, having celebrated the occasion surrounded by his beloved family. A graduate of the Peddie School in Hightstown, NJ, Arnold received his B.S. in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School. Arnold was Founder, President and CEO of The Ross Companies, a consultancy in life insurance, executive compensation and benefits, and personal financial planning. He was an advisor to CEOs, boards of directors, and compensation committees of a wide range of businesses and the co-author of the book "Executive Employment and Compensation." A pioneer in business, Arnold distinguished himself as an innovative and trusted advisor. Cherished husband for 60 years of Lila, father of John, Catherine, Norman and daughter-in-law Barbara, adored and adoring grandfather of Nathan, Alex, Justin and Jordan, Arnold will be profoundly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him. An inspirational leader in business, Arnold was a bibliophile, sports enthusiast and supporter of the arts. He was a smart, sophisticated, dapper and poised individual possessed of an enormous, first class mind and an equally large heart; wise and generous with his time and advice, helpful to all who sought his wise counsel. His loyalty, munificence, friendship and caring to those he loved was unparalleled and he will be profoundly missed and always remembered by the many who loved and knew him. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th St., Thursday, 11:30am.

SMULEWICZ--Renate G. Beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend, passed away on Wednesday, April 2, 2014. She was a Holocaust survivor and former microbiologist. She joins her husband, Kuba, son, Dani, father, Henryk Grzes, and mother, Helena Offner. She is loved by Hedda, Gregory, Alexa, Irka, Rysiek, Moti, Ellen, Ari, and Vava. She was the strongest woman we have ever known. There will be a memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:15am on Friday, April 4th.

FINKELSTEIN--Shirley. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Shirley Finkelstein, mother of Leni May and Alan Finkelstein, and mother-in-law of Peter May and Susan Finkelstein. Shirley's legacy of generosity, leadership, and a strong commitment to philanthropy will live on through her beloved family. We extend our deepest sympathies to Shirley's children, grandchildren, and entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

STERNGASS--Adele Hillman Starr, died peacefully on April 1, 2014 at age 91. Devoted mother of Amy Starr, Jonathan Sterngass and Karen Weltman. Loving grandmother of Laura Schechter and Vicente Garcete, David Schechter, Rachel and Anatoly Brekh- man, Eli and Aaron Sterngass, and great-grandmother of Camila and Andres. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, April 3 at noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions, if desired, can be made to Emily's List.

GRANT--Dr. B. David, on April 2, 2014 of Wynnewood, PA; husband of Roseanne (nee Zerner); father of Julia Barol (David), Betsy Kaperonis (George) and Kate Webster (Peter); grandfather of Jared, Morgan, Galen, Lilly, Callie and Zoe. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Sunday, 1pm at Adath Israel, 250 N. Highland Ave., Merion Station, PA 19066. Interment at Haym Salomon Memorial Park. Shiva will be observed at the late residence. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Philadelphia Chamber Music Society (215-569-8587, (gifts@pcmsconcerts.org) Services by Joseph Levine & Sons (levinefuneral.com).

SPRINGER--Ursula, PhD. (1922-2014), owner and president of Springer Publishing Company from 1970 - 2004, died peacefully on Sunday near her home in Tuxedo, NY. After the death of her husband Bernhard Springer in 1970, she left her position of Professor of Education at Brooklyn College to take over the publishing company that he had founded in 1950. As a publisher, she continued her husband's development of books in psychology and nursing, and laid the ground work for innovative publications in the fields of gerontology, social work, public health, and rehabilitation that helped to expand these health and mental health sciences. She mentored and groomed innumerable future scholars, authors, educators, and practitioners and respected those who brought their knowledge to her publishing endeavors. The company continues to thrive today. Serving 34 years as owner and president of Springer Publishing Company, Ursula Springer was elected a member of the Board of Directors of the American Publishers Association. She received honorary membership in the honor society in nursing, Sigma Theta Tau, the Gerontological Society of America, and some regional groups. She became the first honorary fellow in the newly established American Academy of Nursing. In 2004, Dr. Springer established The Ursula Springer Leadership Professor in Nursing Chair in the College of Nursing, New York University. She was also an active supporter of the American Association for Aging Research (AFAR), the Goethe-Institut New York, and The Wagner Society of New York with whom she established the Ursula Springer Endowed Fund. Dr. Ursula Springer's commitment to education, social justice, and philanthropy was influential beyond the publishing world. Her work and vision was inspiring, as it will continue for generations to come. Ursula Springer is predeceased by her husband, Bernhard Springer, and sister, Dorothea Yale, and is survived by her brother, Walter Pietzschmann, and nephew, Cornelius Grossmann. A small service will be held, Friday, April 4 at 2:30pm, St. Elizabeth's Chapel, Tuxedo Park, NY. Plans for a memorial celebration will be announced at a later date. Charitable donations may be made to The Wagner Society of New York, or New York University College of Nursing.

EVDOKIMOVA-GREGORI--Eva. Today marks the fifth year you began your new journey. Our hearts will always beat forever in unison. My love, admiration, respect, adoration for you grows each day as I have no doubt you know. I will always be your "Rock of Gibraltar." Your standing as Prima Ballerina Assoluta is a beacon and the gold standard forever. Your selflessness, forever helping everyone especially your courage and dedication to destroy the Iron Curtain and literally bring down the Berlin Wall is beyond what one person could even imagine. All of these stories and your films will be released shortly. We have always kept every promise and you know I will never waver. We are together always. My true and only love. My beloved wife. Michael

FINKELSTEIN--Shirley, on April 1, 2014, at the celebrated age of 96. Beloved wife of the late Jerry, loving mother of Leni and Peter May and Alan and Susan Finkelstein. Dear grandmother to Jon and Juliana May, Leslie and Andrew Blauner, David and Laurie Finkelstein, and Andrew and Gina Finkelstein. Wonderful great-grandmother of ten. She was a beautiful woman and she will be missed but always in our thoughts and hearts. Funeral services will be private. The family will be receiving friends on Friday, April 4 from 5 to 8pm, at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, New York City.

COOPERMAN--Sidney. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our honorary Trustee, Sidney Cooperman, whose leadership and generosity as Chairman of the Board benefited the Synagogue and the establishment of our day school. We also note the recent passing of his beloved wife Lorraine and tzedakah partner. To his daughters Diane (Stephen) Wander and Sandy Cooperman (Stephen Edelstein), and the entire family our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, Chairman

ROSENBAUM--Ruth Bettina, (nee Van Dyck), dazzled with her intellect and beauty. Died peacefully on April 1, at Fritz Reuter Lifecare, New Jersey, after a valiant battle against Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Born in Danzig in 1920, Ruth was a 40 year resident of Englewood, NJ. A wiz on Wallstreet, she edited "Who's Who in Banking." Ruth is predeceased by Harry, her husband of 60 years. Survived by her devoted daughter, author/educator Helen Rosenbaum of Manhattan and Ruth's cherished friend, Madeline Liberatore and family of Bergen County. Service at Leber Funeral Home, conducted by Rabbi/Cantor Jill Hausman of the Actors' Temple, Manhattan.
SCHWARTZ--Alan J.,12/13/33 - 4/3/12 . Loved and missed for eternity. Pat and Family

MORGAN--Priscilla. Legendary and generous supporter of the arts leaves an enduring mark on the organizations and lives of so many individuals that she helped cultivate and enrich. She passionately and fastidiously honored the legacy of Isamu Noguchi (1904 1988) through the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum in New York, pioneering the transformation of Long Island City into an arts destination. After nearly 30 years, we will miss collaborating with Priscilla on the Noguchi Foundation and museum. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to all who knew her. Susan Dunne, Arne and Milly Glimcher and the entire staff of Pace Gallery

LEVY--Ronald Irwin, LLB, NYU '56, passed away at the age of 81 on April 2, 2014. Dear husband of Muriel (Gerstenfeld) for 57 years. Proud father and grandfather of Irwin (Susan Werman) and Noah; Robert, MD (Sally Tucker) and Rebekah and Andrew; Matthew (Deborah Flicker) and Joshua and Zachary. Brother-in-law of Bruce Gerstenfeld. Donations in his memory to the IRP of the New School or your favorite charity. Graveside services are Friday April 4, 11am at New Montefiore Cemetery.

LEVY--Albert N.,Roslyn, NY, died on March 31, 2014. Beloved and dedicated husband of 64 years to the late Terrie Levy. Devoted father of Mitchell (Lucy), Jeffrey (Amy), Gregg and Robin (Michael Love). Loving grandfather of Meredith and Stephanie. Survived by brother Hyman. Enjoyed a long and illustrious career as a dress manufacturer in New York City. He will be deeply missed and remembered by his family and friends.

BEROL--Mary Perrotty, known to all as "Honey", died peacefully at her home in Memphis, TN on March 31, 2014. Mary was born in Coxsackie, NY on August 20, 1916. A lifelong New Yorker, she dedicated her amazing energies to numerous civic and philanthropic causes, including the Kips Bay Boys Club in New York City and the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, New York. Her circle of friends in the New York area was wide and deep, spanning multiple generations and geographies. Mary moved to Memphis in 2006, at the age of ninety, to begin a new chapter in her life, surrounded by children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Her life in Memphis was rich and active. She instantly immersed herself in the Memphis community, becoming involved in the city's civic and cultural life and amassing many new friends. Mary loved traveling, she loved bridge, she loved parties and she deeply loved her new home in the "heartland." Mary was proud to be a great-grandmother to ten wonderful young people. She was indeed "great" and "grand" to all who knew her "great" in the love and loyalty she showed her family and "grand" in the expansive, ever-curious way in which she lived her rich, full life. She is survived by her daughter, Dina Smith, and son, Michael Del Balso, her grandchildren, Barbara Hyde, Jenny Achuthan, Michael Rosser, Ian Del Balso and Eric Del Balso, and ten great-grandchildren, privileged to have had "Honey" in their lives, as were we all. Funeral services will be 2:00pm on Friday, April 4 at St. John's Episcopal Church, 3245 Central Avenue, Memphis, TN. There will be a visitation at 1:00pm preceding the service in the Parish Hall. The burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Arts Memphis, 575 South MendenHall, Memphis, TN 38117, www.artsmemphis.org, or Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, 139 Girdle Ridge Road, Katonah, NY 10536, www.caramoor.org

JARKOWSKI--Lueza Wanda Born on October 2, 1994- Died on April 4, 2011. Beloved daughter and sister. We love you and miss you. Jody Gelb Jacek and Dora Jarkowski

GRANT--Dr. B. David, on April 2, 2014 of Wynnewood, PA; husband of Roseanne (nee Zerner); father of Julia Barol (David), Betsy Kaperonis (George) and Kate Webster (Peter); grandfather of Jared, Morgan, Galen, Lilly, Callie and Zoe. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Sunday, 1pm at Adath Israel, 250 N. Highland Ave., Merion Station, PA 19066. Interment at Haym Salomon Memorial Park. Shiva will be observed at the late residence. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Philadelphia Chamber Music Society (215-569-8587, (gifts@pcmsconcerts.org) Services by Joseph Levine & Sons (levinefuneral.com).

MASLOW--Sylvia, of Delray Beach, FL passed away on April 2, 2014 at the age of 93. She was born Annette Sylvia Leisten in Newark, NJ. Respected by all, she possessed a sweetness and generosity which she gave freely to her family and friends. Sylvia was a caring, dedicated and charitable member of her community. Along with her late husband Murray Maslow of 55 years she co-founded the Maslow Family Counseling Center of UJA MetroWest in Florham Park, NJ. She was "Queen of the 9 Holers", an avid mahjong player and a gifted bargain hunter. She gave everything to her family, survived by her brother Charles Leisten, son Richard Maslow, daughters and sons- in-law Ilene and James Robbins, Mary Beth and Jeffrey Davidson, grandchildren Jessica, Leslie, Jordanne, Gregory and Spencer and dear friend Nana Kavtaradze. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Jewish Family Services of MetroWest for The Maslow Family Counseling Center of Florham Park, NJ. Funeral Service Today 11am at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ.

GIBBONS--Barbara Halloran, Syndicated columnist ("The Slim Gourmet") Barbara Halloran Gibbons died March 26, 2014 in Dallas, TX. Born in Newark, NJ, she lived in New Jersey through the mid 1990s, and wrote the three times weekly low calorie cooking column featured in over 200 newspapers throughout the 1970s-'90s, as well as a similar monthly column in Family Circle magazine. The author of 16 cookbooks, including two Tastemaker Award winners, she was also a travel photographer and writer and a member of the Travel Journalists Guild. She was the wife of the late WI Gibbons and partner for 30 years to Gerald T. Gallagher, mother of Susan Gibbons Gillespie of New Jersey and grandmother to four: Daniel and Isaac Gillespie, both of New York, Christopher Gillespie of Washington, DC and Benjamin Gillespie, of Omaha, NE. Memorial Service at 3pm, April 6, at Trinity Covenant Church, 343 East Cedar St., Livingston, NJ.

MINICHIELLO--Peter. The warmest, funniest, consummate friend and godfather, connoisseur and lover of film, books, music, newspapers, conversation and food, and a man with the recipe for how to lead a wonderful, meaningful life, died March 31, 2014, leaving spectacular memories and an unfillable void behind. For anyone who knew him, if they could choose one friend to be shipwrecked with on a desert island, it would be Peter. Time in his company was a gift. May he have had a safe and joyful journey to reunite with those he loved who have gone before him, his family and close friends, and his beloved German Shepherd, Hannah. Funeral will be held April 5th at noon at Church of Saint Joseph, 1820 Route 9, Stuyvesant Falls, NY, reception to follow. A memorial service will be held in New York City this spring. Alexandra Anderson, Allan Appel, Suzanne Boorsch, Melanie Brandston Classic Lyric Arts, Suzanne and Jake Davidson, Larry Roth, Perri Beth Irvings Thomas Erben, Diane Jacobs, Molly Schaefer, Dan Slott, Elizabeth Spahr

PAISNER--Gilbert David, died peacefully on April 3, 2014. A small business owner with a big heart and a generous spirit. He was predeceased by his wife and best friend Ruth. He is survived by his children Lauren, Daniel (Leslie), Caryl (Mikel) and Jonathan (Wendy), and his grandchildren Jacob, Hana, Rose, Zachary, Rebecca, Ruby, Elias, Talia, Elizabeth and Zoe. He will be missed, mourned and loved by all who knew him. Funeral services noon on Friday, April 4th at the Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore, 1001 Plandome Road, Plandome, NY (516) 627-6274.

ROSS--Arnold. The Harmonie Club is saddened by the passing of Mr. Arnold Ross, an esteemed member of the Club for 38 years. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Lila and their entire family in this time of sorrow. In Sympathy, Stephen M. Brecher, President, The Harmonie Club.

MORGAN--Priscilla. Legendary and generous supporter of the arts leaves an enduring mark on the organizations and lives of so many individuals that she helped cultivate and enrich. She passionately and fastidiously honored the legacy of Isamu Noguchi (1904 1988) through the Isamu Noguchi Foundation and Garden Museum in New York, pioneering the transformation of Long Island City into an arts destination. After nearly 30 years, we will miss collaborating with Priscilla on the Noguchi Foundation and museum. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to all who knew her. Susan Dunne, Arne and Milly Glimcher and the entire staff of Pace Gallery

ROSENBAUM--Ruth Bettina, (nee Van Dyck), dazzled with her intellect and beauty. Died peacefully on April 1, at Fritz Reuter Lifecare, New Jersey, after a valiant battle against Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. Born in Danzig in 1920, Ruth was a 40 year resident of Englewood, NJ. A wiz on Wallstreet, she edited "Who's Who in Banking." Ruth is predeceased by Harry, her husband of 60 years. Survived by her devoted daughter, author/educator Helen Rosenbaum of Manhattan and Ruth's cherished friend, Madeline Liberatore and family of Bergen County. Service at Leber Funeral Home, conducted by Rabbi/Cantor Jill Hausman of the Actors' Temple, Manhattan.

SULLIVAN-RICKEY--Mary Ellen, 58, of St. Paul, MN, died peacefully on March 28, 2014 after a brutally short journey with cancer. She was surrounded by her husband and life-partner of 32 years, Philip Rickey; son, Owen, 23; daughter, Nora, 19; beloved dog, Lulu; and many friends. A Celebration of her life will be held at the Convent of the Visitation School, DeSales Auditorium, July 12, 2014, Mendota Heights, MN, 55120. In lieu of flowers, please see the longer obituary in either the Pioneer Press or The Star Tribune newspaper web-sites. Cremation Society of MN, csminnesota@aol.com.

STIEBER--Pearl G.,formerly of Monroe, NY, died peacefully at her home in Parkland, FL on March 25 at age 93. She is survived by her children, Michael Stieber of New York City and his wife Corinne Berezuk, Robin Hlavacek and her husband Jeffrey of Short Hills, NJ, and her grand children, Daniel, Hannah and Jack. She was married for 53 years to her husband Jack, who predeceased her in 1996. She will be loved, missed, and remembered by those near and dear to her. Memorial service to be held at 10:30am on April 27 at Star of David Memorial Gardens, 7801 Bailey Rd, N. Lauderdale, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests donations to New Haven Residential Treatment Center for Adolescent Girls, Attn: John Stewart, 2172 E. 7200 S., Spanish Fork, Utah 84660. Please note Pearl's name on the donation.

SMULEWICZ--Renate G. Beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, and friend, passed away on Wednesday, April 2, 2014. She was a Holocaust survivor and former microbiologist. She joins her husband, Kuba, son, Dani, father, Henryk Grzes, and mother, Helena Offner. She is loved by Hedda, Gregory, Alexa, Irka, Rysiek, Moti, Ellen, Ari, and Vava. She was the strongest woman we have ever known. There will be a memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 11:15am on Friday, April 4th.

GERRY--Miriam (nee Taishoff), 91, of Trumbull, CT, formerly of New York City, on April 2, 2014. Wife of the late Walter J. Gerry. Mother of Alexandra Gerry, Thomas Gerry and Patricia Campbell. Sister of Sally Cleveland. Grandmother of Dylan, Kaitlyn and Alexander. Great-grandmother of Angelina and Dylan, Jr. Funeral Services Saturday, April 5th at 4pm at Green Funeral Home, 57 Main St., Danbury, CT. Visitation Saturday from 2-4pm at the funeral home. Contributions to C.H. Booth Library, 25 Main St., Newtown, CT 06470

FINKELSTEIN--Shirley, on April 1, 2014, at the celebrated age of 96. Beloved wife of the late Jerry, loving mother of Leni and Peter May and Alan and Susan Finkelstein. Dear grandmother to Jon and Juliana May, Leslie and Andrew Blauner, David and Laurie Finkelstein, and Andrew and Gina Finkelstein. Wonderful great-grandmother of ten. She was a beautiful woman and she will be missed but always in our thoughts and hearts. Funeral services will be private. The family will be receiving friends on Friday, April 4 from 5 to 8pm, at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, New York City.

BRICK--Richard Ashur. September 20, 1945, died April 2, 2014. Beloved husband of Sara Bershtel, father to Noah, and father-in-law to Erin Thompson. A memorial will be held Sunday, April 6, at 1pm at the Columbia University Faculty House.

ZAPPETTI--Mary Ann, passed away peacefully on March 31st. Beloved wife of Thomas, mother of Dawn and Dana, cherished grandma of Brendan, Owen and Nicholas. She is also survived by her sister Dorothy Quigley and brother Andrew Chiodi as well as sons-in-law Patrick Sullivan and Nicholas Lakoumentas. Educated at the Cathedral School in Manhattan, she graduated from St. Joseph's College and held master's degrees in school district administration from Long Island University and school psychology from St. John's University. She served as a school psychologist, as the long time principal of Bluepoint Elementary School and as Assistant to the Superintendent for Pupil Services. Throughout her career she was a pioneer in expanding the educational opportunities for students with special needs. She will be remembered as an educator and champion of children, touching the lives of thousands of families during her twenty-five year career in the Bayport-Bluepoint School District. The world has lost a gracious and generous soul. Donations in Mary Ann's name may be made to the American Heart Association.

SCHLOSSBERG--Ronald, of Bedford, NY. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend passed away on Thursday, April 3, 2014. Funeral services on Sunday, April 6 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Ron's name to the Katonah Museum of Art.

FREDERICKS--Ruth, 93 years, of New York City, passed April 2nd. Ruth was an intelligent, fiercely independent woman with a passion for life that touched her many friends and family. She has left a void in the lives of those she left behind but remains a shinning example of a life lived with dignity and joy. Memorial Service: Friday, April 11th at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker St., New York, NY from 10:30am12:30pm, 212-431-6712. Burial to follow immediately at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

EISENBERG--Morton. The members of the New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute mourn the loss of our esteemed member and colleague, Dr. Morton Eisenberg. We extend our condolences to his family. Ian D. Buckingham, MD, President

GINSBERG--Toni Axler, New York, NY. A woman of substance. Beloved daughter, wife, mother, sister, aunt, cousin and friend. Funeral service at Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Sunday, 11:15am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to American Cancer Society or VNSNY Haven Hospice.

RASCOFF--Dr. Joel H.,passed away on March 31, 2014. He left this world as he lived in it: with integrity, courage, and gratitude for his many blessings. Born in Brooklyn in 1941, he was raised there and in Rockaway Beach, NY. He was educated at Columbia College, Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, where he studied mathematics, and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. After further medical training and work in the Public Health Service, he practiced nephrology for decades in the Bronx and Queens, bringing wisdom, respect, and compassion to the care of thousands of patients. A polymath whose interests ranged from cosmology to foreign policy, he was also a passionate botanist, woodworker, and photographer. His greatest devotions were to his family, his Jewish faith, and his community. Diagnosed with pancreatic cancer eight years ago, he defied the odds through a combination of excellent medical care and determination. He is survived by his sweetheart and wife of 46 years, Barbara; his devoted brother Joseph; the sons and daughters-in-law he adored, Henry and Carina, Samuel and Lauren, and Matthew and Emily; and the grandchildren he cherished, Raffaella, Gabriella, Jordana, Jonah, and Roselle. Donations in his memory can be made to Amit or to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

EBERSTADT--Vera. Died April 2, 2014 at home. Born May 5, 1928 in Vienna, Austria, the only child of Ignaz von Kuffner whose family owned the Ottakringer Brewery there and Helene von Kuffner, nee Dreyfus, whose family founded the Basel, Switzerland-based bank of that name. Vera's childhood came to an abrupt end in 1938 when, just two weeks after the death of her father, she and her mother fled Vienna to escape the Nazis, traveling via Switzerland and England to settle in New York City in 1940. She attended the Birch Wathen School and received her BA from Vassar College in 1948 and a Masters in European History from Columbia University in 1950, where she also worked as assistant to the historian Jacques Barzun. She was a talented sculptor and member of the Art Students League in New York City, creating modern forms inspired by Jean Arp, with whom she apprenticed in Paris. In 1964, she married the investment banker Walter Eberstadt. For almost 50 years, she joined in his business and civic activities, traveled the world and collected art with him, supported educational and cultural institutions with him through the Eberstadt-Kuffner foundation, and took loving care of him until his death, just one month before hers. She loved her sons Michael and George, adored her grandchildren Max, Zoe, Maya, and Esme, and was devoted to her daughters-in-law Nina Beattie and Cynthia Young. Their summer home in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard and their community of friends there were her great joy. Vera had a deep capacity to understand people, which made her both a wonderful listener and an enthralling storyteller, which she did with a bracing lack of varnish. She was the steadiest, most caring of friends, and she loved to bring her friends together. Her family and many friends will miss her so. Donations may be made in Vera's memory to the Frick Collection and to Doctors Without Borders. A memorial service will be held soon please contact George or Michael for information.

GINSBERG--Toni. She will be profoundly missed by all of them and by her devoted sister, Debra Unowitz. Graveside service 11am, April 6 at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

GLAZEBROOK--Otis Allan, IV, age 65, of East Hampton on March 28th. Son of the late Otis A. Glazebrook III and Suzanne Ewing (nee Howard). Dear brother of Zina, Michael, Larkin and his wife Cece. Also survived by two nephews Larkin and Otis. Loving Life Partner of Mary Trabona. Visitation on Saturday, April 5, 1:00pm-2:30pm. Services to be held at 2:30pm at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 91 Hampton St., Sag Harbor, NY 11963. In lieu of flowers, Memorial donations may be made to Fountain Valley School, 6155 Fountain Valley School Rd., Colorado Springs, CO 80911 or to Alpha Tau Omega Foundation, 32 E. Washington St., Suite 1350, Indianapolis, IN 46204.

MacCORMICK--Alexander M.C.,of New York and Locust Valley, born April 16th, 1930 in Point Piper, Sydney, Australia passed away on April 1st after a long, fought battle with prostate cancer. He is survived by his six children, Fiona Austin of Sydney, Australia, Alexander MacCormick of Locust Valley, NY, Jill Kelsall of Avon, CO, Robert MacCormick of Norwich, VT, Catriona Burns of San Francisco, CA and Malcolm MacCormick of Fort Collins, CO, as well as thirteen grandchildren and his sister, Lee MacCormick Edwards of NYC and Sydney. He is predeceased by his wife Monica who passed away on March 2nd, 2006. An avid croquet, court (real) tennis player and sailor, he was member of many clubs including Piping Rock, The Creek, Racquet & Tennis, Royal Sydney Golf Club in Australia, and Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron, as well as a former member of Coral Beach and Hillsborough Clubs and in various clubs in the UK. While he considered himself more of a student in these disciplines, he proudly earned himself many titles, including a 3rd Place in 1965 in the Canadian Finn Championships. He attended Tudor House and The King's School in Australia. He graduated from Union College in Schenectady, NY in 1952, and earned his MBA at NYU in the early 70's. He spent many years as a Director of SI Group, Inc. (formerly known as Schenectady Chemicals, Inc), a multinational chemical conglomerate started by his grandfather Howard Wright in 1906. His paternal grandfather, Sir Alexander MacCormick, was a highly-regarded surgeon and yachtsman who served in the Boer and First World Wars. Many thanks to his doctors, his caregivers Augustine, Dextina, David and Ben, as well as the amazing Marina. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Amercian Cancer Society and/or Hospice NYC.

BRICK--Richard Ashur. September 20, 1945, died April 2, 2014. Beloved husband of Sara Bershtel, father to Noah, and father-in-law to Erin Thompson. A memorial will be held Sunday, April 6, at 1pm at the Columbia University Faculty House.

PALTROW--Dorothy W.,of Palm Beach, FL; formerly Great Neck, NY on March 31, 2014. She was preceded in death by her husband, Arnold "Buster" Paltrow. She is survived by her children, Robert and Fran and the memory of her late children Bruce and Randi, five grandchildren and the memory of her late grandson Keith, and ten great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held privately at a later date. Donations may be made to the Keith Adam Paltrow Memorial Scholarship Fund at Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.

WERTHEIM--Samuel, of New York City passed away at his home on March 31, 2014 at the age of 94 surrounded by his loving family. He was a Holocaust survivor and one of the Schindler Juden of Schindler's List. He was preceded in death by his first wife of 52 years Edith Wertheim, and is survived by his second wife, Ester Szechtman Wertheim. He is also survived by his son Elliot Wertheim (son of Edith) and daughter-in-law Ellen, their son and Samuel's beloved grandson Aaron, his wife Alina and their baby daughter Jordan. Through his marriage to Ester, he also leaves behind a devoted extended family, including two daughters, Helen Selzer and her daughter and Gloria Boritz, her husband Randy and their two sons. He will be deeply missed and remembered by his family and friends.

SCHULICH--Mitchell B.,88 years old, on March 29, 2014. A graduate of Abraham Lincoln High School, Mitch volunteered for the U.S. Army Air Force, became a radio operator in a B-29 assigned to the 330 Bomb Group, 20th Air Force. Based on North Field, Guam, he flew 22 missions over Japan for which he was awarded the Air Medal with Two Bronze Stars (Oak Leaf Clusters). Honorably discharged in 1946, Mitch returned to college, received his B.A. and M.A. degrees, became a pharmacist and in time, a teacher of chemistry and physics at Seward Park High School in lower Manhattan. He ended his teaching career as Principal of Curtis High School on Staten Island, which he retired from in 1991. A dedicated, innovative and hardworking teacher and administrator, a wonderful friend, he was a man of many interests and strong opinions who always believed that education was an indispensible part of the path that led to a more truthful, just, and caring society.

HAVE YOU SEEN MY DRAGON? Written and illustrated by Steve Light. 48 pp. Candlewick. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 6) 
 
East Side, West Side, all around the town, a little boy searches the streets of New York for his friendly fire-breathing dragon. Drawn in bold, caricature-style pen and ink, Light’s illustrations are dizzy with detail, architectural and otherwise, all the better to disguise the dragon, who lurks in every picture. Half the fun is in finding him, but there’s also some counting to be done, of water towers, subway cars and other city sights.

Dr. Ingster was born in Philadelphia and attended Central High School, LaSalle College and Temple University, receiving his doctorate from Rutgers University. He was an international consultant in human resources management, collective bargaining, compensation and labor-management relationships. He was a Past President, Philadelphia Chapter, Labor and Employment Relations Association (LERA) and held active membership in the International Labour and Employment Relations Association (ILERA). The warmest, funniest, consummate friend and godfather, connoisseur and lover of film, books, music, newspapers, conversation and food, and a man with the recipe for how to lead a wonderful, meaningful life, died March 31, 2014, leaving spectacular memories and an unfillable void behind. MORGAN--Priscilla. The Trustees and staff of The Noguchi Museum join with the many who mourn the passing of the indefatigable and ever charming Priscilla Morgan, a founding member of the board and our first Honorary Life Trustee. A force of nature she stood loyally and steadfastly for all she believed in. Precise and high standards defined her and she brought these to the relationships and organizations she so dedicated herself to. Key amongst these was her love for Isamu Noguchi and by extension his Museum which she not only assisted in founding, but continually affirmed, and in her inimitable way helped lead. Her sparkle, her great stories, her mercurial ways and underlying warmth touched all who knew her. She will remain a guiding light to the Noguchi Museum as we move forward. We shall miss her inexplicably. David D. Holbrook, Chairman Jenny Dixon, Director

NAIR--Sreedhar, MD, FACP, FCCP, of Norwalk, CT and Longboat Key, FL died on March 3, 2014. Dr. Nair received several awards from his peers, was the editor of five books and published over 70 articles in medical journals. A memorial service will be held in late April at the Norwalk Inn. www.palmsrobarts funeralhome.com

SARNOFF--Rena, of Hewlett, NY, passed away March 31, 2014. She was strong and full of life for 89 years. Rena loved her daily New York Times, knitting, and a good game of solitaire. MALTESE--Anthony Jay, aka AJ. Beloved son of Cynthia and Anthony Maltese, brother of Kristen Maltese Krusen, husband of Christine and father to Ashlyn passed away at the early age of 44 on April 3 in New York City. SCHLESINGER--James R. February 15, 1929 - March 27, 2014. James Rodney Schlesinger passed away on March 27, 2014. Starting in 1971, he was Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, then Director of the CIA, Secretary of Defense, and the nation's first Secretary of Energy until 1979. Over the next 35 years, Dr. Schlesinger would serve on numerous high level government commissions, task forces, and advisory panels. At the time of his death he was Chairman of the MITRE Corporation, a trustee of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a member of the Defense Policy Board, and a trustee of the Henry M. Jackson Foundation. He was born in New York City to Julius and Rhea Schlesinger, and was welcomed by his older brother Eugene Richard. He attended the Horace Mann School. His studies continued at Harvard where he received a bachelor's degree in Economics, summa cum laude, was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and selected for the Frederick Sheldon Prize Fellowship. After his fellowship year in Europe, he returned to Harvard where he earned his master's and doctoral degrees in Economics. It was there that he met Rachel Mellinger whom he married at her family farm in Springfield, Ohio, in 1954. He became a professor of economics at the University of Virginia for eight years, followed by six years at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, California. He then went to Washington. Dr. Schlesinger is the author of The Political Economy of National Security (1960), America At Century's End (1989), and a consistent flow of carefully considered articles and commentary. He valued education and personally endowed chairs at New York University and the University of Virginia. Friends and colleagues also endowed chairs in his name at Georgetown and Harvard Universities. He was instrumental in the building of a concert hall in memory of his late wife Rachel, who was an accomplished violinist. Throughout his life he supported hundreds of charities, including many birding organizations, as he was an avid birder. He is survived by eight children: Cora, Charles and his wife Francine Kelley, Ann and her husband Josef Lustig, William, Emily, Thomas, Clara and James; and eleven grandchildren: Emily and Andrew Schlesinger; Flenner, Lily, Martha and Ellen Hoagland; and Jacob, Tess, Rachel, Rebecca and Max Lustig. They will all miss his wry sense of humor, his twinkling eyes and sly winks, his songfests with guitar and harmonica, his readings of Winnie the Pooh, and his ever-present quiet support. A private funeral was held at 11:00am on April 5, 2014, at Grace Evangelical Lutheran Church, and he will be interred next to his beloved wife Rachel at Ferncliff Cemetery, in Springfield, Ohio. A memorial service will be held at 4:00pm, Saturday April 26, 2014, at the Rachel M. Schlesinger Concert Hall and Arts Center, 3001 North Beauregard Street, Alexandria, Virginia.

MacCORMICK--Alexander M.C.,of New York and Locust Valley, born April 16th, 1930 in Point Piper, Sydney, Australia passed away on April 1st after a long, fought battle with prostate cancer. He is survived by his six children, Fiona Austin of Sydney, Australia, Alexander MacCormick of Locust Valley, NY, Jill Kelsall of Avon, CO, Robert MacCormick of Norwich, VT, Catriona Burns of San Francisco, CA and Malcolm MacCormick of Fort Collins, CO, as well as thirteen grandchildren and his sister, Lee MacCormick Edwards of NYC and Sydney. He is predeceased by his wife Monica who passed away on March 2nd, 2006. An avid croquet, court (real) tennis player and sailor, he was member of many clubs including Piping Rock, The Creek, Racquet & Tennis, Royal Sydney Golf Club in Australia, and Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron, as well as a former member of Coral Beach and Hillsborough Clubs and in various clubs in the UK. While he considered himself more of a student in these disciplines, he proudly earned himself many titles, including a 3rd Place in 1965 in the Canadian Finn Championships. He attended Tudor House and The King's School in Australia. He graduated from Union College in Schenectady, NY in 1952, and earned his MBA at NYU in the early 70's. He spent many years as a Director of SI Group, Inc. (formerly known as Schenectady Chemicals, Inc), a multinational chemical conglomerate started by his grandfather Howard Wright in 1906. His paternal grandfather, Sir Alexander MacCormick, was a highly-regarded surgeon and yachtsman who served in the Boer and First World Wars. Many thanks to his doctors, his caregivers Augustine, Dextina, David and Ben, as well as the amazing Marina. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Amercian Cancer Society and/or Hospice NYC.

RASCOFF--Dr. Joel H.,passed away on March 31, 2014. He left this world as he lived in it: with integrity, courage, and gratitude for his many blessings. Born in Brooklyn in 1941, he was raised there and in Rockaway Beach, NY. He was educated at Columbia College, Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, where he studied mathematics, and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. After further medical training and work in the Public Health Service, he practiced nephrology for decades in the Bronx and Queens, bringing wisdom, respect, and compassion to the care of thousands of patients. A polymath whose interests ranged from cosmology to foreign policy, he was also a passionate botanist, woodworker, and photographer. His greatest devotions were to his family, his Jewish faith, and his community. Diagnosed with pancreatic cancer eight years ago, he defied the odds through a combination of excellent medical care and determination. He is survived by his sweetheart and wife of 46 years, Barbara; his devoted brother Joseph; the sons and daughters-in-law he adored, Henry and Carina, Samuel and Lauren, and Matthew and Emily; and the grandchildren he cherished, Raffaella, Gabriella, Jordana, Jonah, and Roselle. Donations in his memory can be made to Amit or to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

SCHLOSSBERG--Ronald, of Bedford, NY. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend passed away on Thursday, April 3, 2014. Funeral services on Sunday, April 6 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Ron's name to the Katonah Museum of Art.

LOAR--Brian F.,Philosopher of Mind and Language, died peacefully at his home surrounded by loved ones on March 31, 2014, after a prolonged battle with Parkinson's Disease. Born November 17, 1939 in Brooklyn, NY. After receiving his D.Phil. in Philosophy from Oxford University, he taught at the Universities of Michigan and Southern California, and, until 2007, at Rutgers University. A highly original, complex, and subtle thinker, he wrote about the nature of meaning and of consciousness. In addition to philosophy, Brian was passionate about art, music, architecture, and his beloved friendships. He is survived by his wife Stephanie Beardman of New York, NY, and his brother Terry W. Loar of Marina, CA. Donations may be made to the Mount Sinai Visiting Doctors Program. A memorial will be announced at a later date. He will be deeply missed by those who were lucky enough to have known him.

RANDALL--Frederick R.,MD. 91. Former Surgeon and Professor of Surgery at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He had compassion for his patients; and wisdom for his students. A devoted husband and loving father, he leaves Elizabeth, his wife of over 68 years and his sons, Derek and John. A bereaved family is consoled by cherished memories. What be it worth the life of a man, but that which he himself has given to it? This strong man gave much.

POKORNY--Maria (Marise) Angelucci, a strong willed and generous woman of practicality, logic, and vigor left the world to the rest of us on Friday, March 28th. MORGAN--Priscilla Miner. Born in Poughkeepsie, New York on October 10th, 1919, Priscilla died peacefully at home in Manhattan on March 30th, 2014. Great aunt and great friend. She studied at Vassar College and served as a WAVES officer during WWII. Priscilla began her ground-breaking career in show business as a producer of radio and early television. She became an agent, representing Julie Harris, Jerry Herman, Tad Mosel, Gian Carlo Menotti, Fred Coe and Arthur Penn at Liebling & Wood, the Priscilla Morgan Agency and the William Morris Agency. Priscilla then joined Menotti in Italy as associate director of the Spoleto Festival, which she brought to the United States. A founding board member of her friend Isamu Noguchi's Garden Museum in Long Island City, she devoted her last decades to furthering artistic causes and nurturing friendships across many generations. Memorial contributions, if desired, may be made to the Children's Aid Society. "To love with all one's soul and leave the rest to fate."

CLEMENT--Ida "Illa" Louise Larkin, died peacefully April 1, 2014 at her residence on King Ranch after a lengthy illness. Born January 19, 1919 in New York City, she resided at 119 E. 81st Street. It is easy to see why 19 was her lucky number, but her favorite numbers were her six children, 17 grandchildren and ten great-grandchildren. Her attention to her family earned her the affectionate nickname, "Mother Goose." Above all, Illa was devoted to her husband, Jim. Illa, the daughter of Henrietta Rosa Kleberg and John Adrian Larkin, graduated from the Ethel Walker School, of Simsbury, CT. She married James (Jim) H. Clement in 1943. In 1949, the family moved to South Texas. From recreating Raglands Department store into a premier shopping destination to designing beautiful tapestries, Illa's artistry and flair were only matched by her energy and work ethic. As indefatigable as she was, she also was very involved in philanthropy and volunteer work. She helped start and build the Epiphany Episcopal Day School in Kingsville, TX and she often privately came to the aid of many families in need. While actively engaged in a variety of community based efforts, she was most proud of her support of NAS- Kingsville, so it is possible the Blue Angels winged her away after their recent visit. In spite of not attending college she became a treasured member of the Trinity University board in San Antonio, TX. She also served on the boards of and was active with Celanese, the Kennedy Center for Performing Arts and the James Madison Council of the Library of Congress. A lifelong Republican, she worked tirelessly to bring a viable two party system to South Texas. Illa will be dearly missed and will be most fondly remembered for her contagious laugh and fun-loving spirit. She is survived by her children, daughter Leslie and husband, Pat Jackson; daughter, Pruyn Hildebrand; son, Martin and wife, Melinda; daughter, Ida Louise and husband John T. Steen Jr.; son Jamey and wife Judy; daughter Alice and husband Eric Foultz; 17 grandchildren: Henrietta and husband, Eric Armbruster; Perry C. Finger; Marshall Hildebrand; Irene Hildebrand and husband, Frank Torres; Martin W. Clement III; John T. Steen III and wife Mary; Illa Steen and husband Will Gaunt; Jamey Steen; Capera Clement and husband, Igor Norinsky; Lt. James Clement III, USMC; Capt. Gregory Clement, USMC; Lisa Carrington and husband Greg Bohn; Clay Carrington and wife Elizabeth; Clement Carrington; Rahm Carrington; Andye Foultz and Griffin Foultz, plus 10 great-grandchildren: Larkin Armbruster; Taylor, Samantha, Elizabeth and Loretta Torres; Larkin and Ivy Steen; Igby Norinsky; and Sloan and Walker Carrington. The family would like to thank Jane and Scott Dodds, who led a wonderful corps of caregivers for their untiring and loving care of our mother. They are: Meme Burden, Trina Cavazos and Pita and Cipriano Escobedo, plus Norma Adrian, Edna Alvarado, Rosalinda Durbin, Norma Figueroa Elda Garza, Rachel Henderson, Jennifer Macias, Elvia Del Moral, Anna Lisa Saldana and Robert Caldera. Services were held at Epiphany Episcopal Church, Kingsville, TX. In lieu of flowers, the family requests gifts be made to the charity of their choice or to the Epiphany Episcopal School, 206 N 3rd St., Kings-ville, TX 78363. Services are entrusted to Turcotte-Piper Mortuary, 205 General Cavazos Blvd., Kingsville, Texas.

DARDEN--George. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of former assistant conductor George Darden. A consummate musician whose knowledge of repertory and style made him an invaluable resource in preparing operas for performance, George was also a much beloved colleague to Met artists for more than 20 years. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family and numerous co-workers who sorely miss both his artistry and incomparable sense of humor. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

CAMING--H. W. William. An advocate for international tribunals to investigate and prosecute crimes against humanity and a prominent figure in the history of telecommunications law and privacy, died January 24, 2014, at his home in Summit, NJ, at the age of 94. A Memorial Service for Mr. Caming will take place at the Calvary Episcopal Church, 31 Woodland Ave., Summit, NJ on Friday, April 11th at 10am. As chief prosecutor and deputy director of the Political Ministries Division in the Office of the United States Chief Counsel for War Crimes from 1946 to 1949, Caming charged 21 German military and civilian leaders with crimes against peace, war crimes, crimes against humanity, and membership in criminal organizations in the largest, longest, and last phase of the Nuremberg trials. In November 2011 he accepted the Joshua Heintz Award for Humanitarian Achievement from the Robert H. Jackson Center for his work. After his military service in World War II and at Nuremberg, Caming joined the New York State Attorney General's office and then in 1953 the Bell System. He moved to AT&T's headquarters in 1965 as senior counsel and until 1984 oversaw all legal matters related to privacy, corporate security, information technology, criminal law, and related litigation for AT&T and its affiliates, testifying frequently before Congressional committees and regulatory bodies. Before and after retiring in 1984, Caming served as a consultant on privacy matters to the CIA, FBI, Congress, and the American Bar Association Section on Criminal Justice. Caming graduated summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from New York University in 1937. He also earned an L.L.M. in labor law from NYU and a J.D. from Harvard Law School. Born in New York City to a corporate and residential real estate developer and his wife, he was married for 54 years to Kathleen Marie (nee White) Caming, who died in 2005. He is survived by a daughter, Patricia Castillo of Elizabeth, NJ, and a brother, Lionel Caming of New York City and his dedicated caregiver, Ann McPherson. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may contribute in his memory to The H. W. William and Kathleen W. Caming Scholarship Fund at Drew University, c/o Drew University, 36 Madison Avenue, Madison, NJ, 07940. Services by Bradley, Brough & Dangler Funeral Home, Summit. For a complete obituary, additional information and to leave the family a message of condolence, please go to: bradleyfuneralhomes.com.

de BLIJ--Harm Jan, 1935-2014, of Sarasota, Florida and Chatham, Massachusetts died on March 25, 2014, at The Moffitt Cancer Center in Tampa, Florida. Born in the Netherlands, de Blij received his early schooling in Europe, his undergraduate education in Africa from the University of the Witwatersrand and his graduate degrees in the United States from Northwestern University. Dr. de Blij taught at Michigan State University as a Professor from 1960 to 1969 and then moved to the University of Miami where he served as Chairperson of the Department of Geography. He served on the National Geographic Society's Committee for Research and Exploration for more than 20 years, was founding editor of its journal National Geographic Research and was awarded National Geographic's Distinguished Geography Educator Award and lifetime membership for his advocacy of geography. He received the highest recognitions from the Association of American Geographers, the American Geographical Society and the National Council for Geographic Education. Dr. de Blij has also held the George Landegger Chair in Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service and the John Deaver Drinko Chair of Geography at Marshall University and was Presidential Scholar at the Colorado School of Mines. Dr. de Blij returned to MSU in 2000 as a Distinguished Professor and was subsequently named the John A. Hannah Professor of Geography. His scholarly work has been recognized through honorary degrees awarded by Marshall University, Rhode Island College, Grand Valley State University, North Carolina State University and Michigan State University. Dr. de Blij specialized in geopolitical and environmental issues and has published more than 30 books including scientific, educational, and trade titles, and over 100 articles. His textbook Geography: Realms, Regions and Concepts (Wiley) has exceeded 1.3 million copies in 15 editions since 1970. Another book, Wine: a Geographic Appreciation (Rowman & Allanheld) was awarded a medal by the French wine organization, OIV, in Paris. His books have been translated into several foreign languages. Over the past 40 years, de Blij was also one of the few academic geographers of his generation to make a major and lasting impact in the public arena. He was the popular Geography Editor on ABC's "Good Morning America" from 1989 to 1996. In 1996, he joined NBC News as Geography Analyst, appearing mostly on MSNBC. He was writer of and commentator for the original PBS Series "The Power of Place". Dr. de Blij was much in demand on the lecture circuit and his extraordinary communication skills were widely recognized. He gave over 400 presentations since 2001 with lecture titles such as; Confronting Militant Islam: the changing Geography of Terrorism, Why Geography Matters: the Cost of Geographic Illiteracy, and Climate Change Forever: Truth and Consequences. Harm de Blij's parents were both distinguished musicians and he remained a violinist and chamber-music participant through the end of his life. He was an avid wine collector, lifelong soccer (Holland) and baseball (Cubs) fan. His second love after geography was animals, all animals but a special place in his heart was always kept for his own. Harm is survived by his wife of 37 years, Bonnie of Chatham and his only son Hugh James of Maryland and beloved sister in law Patti McCulley of North Chatham. He was predeceased by his Mother Nelly and Father Hendrik and his daughter Tanya Powers de Blij. Memorial contributions may be made to The de Blij Geography Scholars, Department of Geography, Michigan State University, 673 Auditorium Road, Room 116, East Lansing, MI 48824 or to The Wildlife Center of Venice, Inc. 3252 Border Road, Venice, FL 34292.

DINHOFER--Dr. Norman. Diagnostic Radiologist Pioneer, Entrepreneur, Art Collector, and Humanitarian, died on October 23, 2013 at 91. http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/nytimes/obituary.aspx?n=norman-dinhofer&pid= 170048355&fhid=22036#

BENKARD--James W.B. The President, Trustees and entire community of Teachers College, Columbia University, mourn their colleague and friend Jim Benkard, a TC Trustee since 1980 and the College's current longest-tenured board member. Jim served on our board's Business & Finance Committee, Executive Committee and Compensation Committee, which he most recently chaired, and played a key role in each of TC's two previous major fundraising campaigns. He also participated in the searches for two presidents. Jim approached his role at TC like the brilliant litigator he was, and his wise counsel, coupled with a dry sense of humor, were a boon to all who worked with him. Even as he posed tough questions, he brought a fierce idealism to causes he embraced, from education to the environment to his pro bono legal work. We offer our condolences to Margaret, his wife of 49 years; their three children, Andrew Benkard, James Benkard and Margaret Benkard Chaves; their six grandchildren, Penelope, Dexter and Oscar Benkard; Evelyn Benkard Gaumnitz; and Margaret and Nathaniel Chaves; and Jim's sister, Joan Derby Benkard Jackson. Susan H. Fuhrman, President John W. Hyland William D. Rueckert, Board Co-Chairs

BENKARD--James W.B. James "Jimmy" Benkard, a brilliant litigator with Davis Polk & Wardwell who devoted himself to his professional craft as well as to leading and invariably improving an extraordinary number of civic and social organizations, died on April 1, 2014. He was born on April 10, 1937 in New York City, the son of the late Franklin Bartlett Benkard and Laura Derby Dupee Benkard. He attended St. Bernard's School in New York City, St. Mark's School in Southborough, Massachusetts and Harvard College, where he was sports editor of the Harvard Crimson. After college, he served in the U.S. Marine Corps and then attended Columbia Law School. In 1964, Jimmy married Margaret Walker Spofford, whom he cherished for the rest of his life. They raised three children, Andrew Benkard, James Benkard, and Margaret Benkard Chaves, and six grandchildren, Penelope, Dexter and Oscar Benkard, Evelyn Benkard Gaumnitz, and Maggie and Nathaniel Chaves. He is also survived by his sister, Joan Derby Benkard Jackson. Upon graduation from law school in 1963, Jimmy joined Davis Polk and spent his professional career with the firm, litigating a broad variety of commercial matters. He tried cases and argued appeals, including in the United States Supreme Court. Jimmy was beloved within his firm for his interest in guiding and teaching younger lawyers. After his retirement, he continued leading the firm's pro bono practice and mentoring the lawyers involved in the work. Last year, Jimmy was awarded the Norman Redlich Capital Defense Pro Bono Award by the New York City Bar Association, in recognition of decades of skilled advocacy on behalf of death row inmates. Jimmy was a Trustee of the Environmental Defense Fund and for years oversaw much of their litigation activity. He also served on the boards of Vassar College, St. Mark's School, Prisoners' Legal Services, and Teachers College, Columbia University. He took particular delight in serving as President of the Knickerbocker Club in New York City from 2003-2013 and as a Governor of that organization for four decades. Jimmy and his family kept a house on Fishers Island, New York where he similarly devoted himself to the community, serving for years as the Secretary and a board member of the Fishers Island Development Corporation, and as President of the Hay Harbor Club from 1981-1984. Jimmy was renowned for his skill at public speaking. As a colleague noted, Jimmy's comments always contained a rare combination of specificity, cogency, and humor. His speeches were unfailingly marked by wit and grace and were highly anticipated. Members of the organizations he led, as well as his colleagues at Davis Polk, flocked to events that under other circumstances would be tedious, simply to hear and laugh with Jimmy Benkard. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Wednesday, April 9 at The Brick Presbyterian Church, located at 91st Street and Park Avenue. The family would prefer memorial gifts in his memory be directed to either The Innocence Project or the Fishers Island Recreational Path Foundation, in lieu of flowers.

EBERSTADT--Vera. Died April 2, 2014 at home. Born May 5, 1928 in Vienna, Austria, the only child of Ignaz von Kuffner whose family owned the Ottakringer Brewery there and Helene von Kuffner, nee Dreyfus, whose family founded the Basel, Switzerland-based bank of that name. Vera's childhood came to an abrupt end in 1938 when, just two weeks after the death of her father, she and her mother fled Vienna to escape the Nazis, traveling via Switzerland and England to settle in New York City in 1940. She attended the Birch Wathen School and received her BA from Vassar College in 1948 and a Masters in European History from Columbia University in 1950, where she also worked as assistant to the historian Jacques Barzun. She was a talented sculptor and member of the Art Students League in New York City, creating modern forms inspired by Jean Arp, with whom she apprenticed in Paris. In 1964, she married the investment banker Walter Eberstadt. For almost 50 years, she joined in his business and civic activities, traveled the world and collected art with him, supported educational and cultural institutions with him through the Eberstadt-Kuffner foundation, and took loving care of him until his death, just one month before hers. She loved her sons Michael and George, adored her grandchildren Max, Zoe, Maya, and Esme, and was devoted to her daughters-in-law Nina Beattie and Cynthia Young. Their summer home in Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard and their community of friends there were her great joy. Vera had a deep capacity to understand people, which made her both a wonderful listener and an enthralling storyteller, which she did with a bracing lack of varnish. She was the steadiest, most caring of friends, and she loved to bring her friends together. Her family and many friends will miss her so. Donations may be made in Vera's memory to the Frick Collection and to Doctors Without Borders. A memorial service will be held soon please contact George or Michael for information.

COHEN--Ellen Eisenstadt. Giving, loving and selfless is how Ellen, who was lost to us far too soon on April 4, 2014, lived her life. Wife and life-partner of Herb, mother of Sharon and Bill Levin, Steven and Lisa Melmed Cohen and Rich Cohen and Jessica Medoff, grandmother of Matt, Madeline, David, Ethan, Emma, Elias, Hannah, Aaron, Nate and Micah, sister-in-law of Renee Blumenthal. Born on September 24, 1938, in the Midwood Section of Brooklyn, transplanted to Libertyville and Glencoe, Illinois, and most recently a resident of Delray Beach, Florida, Ellen was a graduate of NYU and spent her life as the business partner of Herb. But Ellen's true life work was being a support and inspiration to her family and all those who were lucky enough to know her. Her kindness and generosity were boundless. There was nothing that Ellen possessed that she would not willingly give away -- including her time, her compassion, her jewelry and her dinner if it would provide solace to another person. She enriched us all, and her absence will forever leave a hole in our hearts. Those wishing to honor Ellen's life are encouraged to contribute to the Bronfman Center of NYU, 7 East 10th Street, New York, NY. Funeral Services to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, 11:45am, on Sunday, April 6, 2014.

GOLD--Diane Apotheker. "Dina" Age 83. Just a few months ago, Dina was preceded in death by her husband of almost 60 years, Bernard Gold. Their marriage was what the poets write about, filled with love, respect and admiration. In their home, they raised Billy and Bobby into two fine, caring men. Dina was the very proud grandmother of Michael, Brian, John, David, Elizabeth, Tom and Danny. Dina was a Woman of Valor. Her many friends and family will remember her wit, easy laugh and warmth. Too many qualities to write about, but so many to cherish, including her intelligence, artistry and gourmet cooking. No holiday or family gathering will pass without memories of what she brought to the table. A wonderful wife, mother, grandmother, cousin, aunt and friend.
HOROWITZ--Isadore. Zed, a remarkable friend we will love forever. Merry and Richie Slone

FREDERICKS--Ruth, 93 years, of New York City, passed April 2nd. Ruth was an intelligent, fiercely independent woman with a passion for life that touched her many friends and family. She has left a void in the lives of those she left behind but remains a shinning example of a life lived with dignity and joy. Memorial Service: Friday, April 11th at Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker St., New York, NY from 10:30am12:30pm, 212-431-6712. Burial to follow immediately at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

HOOPER--Penny Lauren, died on the morning of Wednesday, March 26, 2014. She was surrounded by family and friends. Penny was born in San Francisco, California, on January 8, 1950. She was the first child of Nadine and V.M. Hanks, Jr. She grew up in San Francisco where she attended Lowell High School. She continued her studies at UC Berkeley. She began her career in advertising at Ogilvy and Mather in San Francisco. From there she moved to New York City where she became one of the first women ever to reach the position of Senior Vice President of a major advertising firm. While working at Young and Rubicam, Penny was asked to move to Switzerland to set up the "Save the Rhino" campaign for the World Wildlife Fund. It was there that she met the love of her life, David Hooper. They returned to New York City and settled in Cos Cob, Connecticut, where they made many life long friends. After their retirement, Penny and David began to split their time together between Cos Cob and their new home in Naples, Florida. After David's death in 2008, Penny began to spend the majority of her time in Naples, where she was surrounded by new and very dear friends. Her family will be forever grateful for the loving care that was given to her husband and to her by Virginia Sanders, and in her final months, by Showana Glasco. Penny's love and light will shine eternally. She touched everyone she knew, and will be deeply missed. Her passing will most deeply be felt by her surviving family members: her sisters, Lisa Hanks Baxter (John Baxter); Janet Sheldon (Gary Sheldon); her brother, Chuck Hanks (Patty O'Donnell Hanks); and her nephews and nieces: Michael Baxter; Erin Hughes (Kyle Hughes); Christopher Foehr; Brianna Foehr (Neil Rodenmeyer); Heidi Foehr (Rich Mangum); Caitlin Foehr; Alison Foehr; Ruby Sheldon; Jacob Sheldon; Amber Hanks; Justin Hanks; Megan Hanks; and her grandniece, Leona Hughes. She is also survived by her beloved cousin Laura Schuh, and her other cousins, David, Bob, and Tom Newman. Finally, she is survived by her adored grandchildren, William and Issy Bonebrake and their mother Caroline. A celebration of Penny's life will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, May 3, 2014, at St. John's Episcopal Church in Naples, Florida. There will be a private graveside service in Riverside where she will join with her husband in the memorial garden at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, The Reverend Lee Ann Tolzmann presiding.

GILROD--Stella, passed away April 4, 2014. Loving mother to David (Sandy) and Rose. Sister to Larry (Jane) and adoring Tick Tock to granddaughter Michelle. Predeceased by devoted husband Mike and brothers Ronald and Marvin. Loyal friend to many - we will miss you, love you and cherish you every day. You were a unique combination of brilliance and quick wit along with class and grace. It is the end of an era - your glamour is unequaled. Services private.
GOLDSMITH--Harris. It's with deep sadness that New York Concert Review mourns the passing of the inimitable musical polymath Harris Goldsmith.

GILROD--Stella. Stella, my Stella! How could you leave us? You were my sister, my surrogate Mom. You were everything to me. You had a wonderful life - brought joy to all. To say you did it your way is an understatement. Rest easy and promise to keep in touch - we love you so. Janie and Larry

GINSBERG--Toni. HADDA--Annemarie, nee Kohn. June 4, 1922 to March 30, 2014, after a prolonged decline. Born in Germany, she left there for England in 1939 in order to escape Nazi persecution. Despite losing her parents and her homeland, she always considered herself lucky, counted her blessings and embraced life in her new homes, England and the United States, where she arrived in 1948. Annemarie married her adolescent love, George Manfred Hadda, M.D., in 1942. He predeceased her in 1984. She is survived by cherished children Janet (Allan Tobin), Ceri (Lloyd Gelwan), and Kathy (Michael Andrews). For the last nine years she was cared for with affection and kindness by the wonderful Abby, Gloria, Jackie, Jennifer, Mavis, and Samantha, as well as by the excellent medical team at Lenox Hill Hospital and Drs. Sherri Sandel and Mitchell Chandler. Donations may be made to VNS Hospice. Always a lady, she will be missed.

GINSBERG--Toni Axler, New York, NY. A woman of substance. Beloved daughter, wife, mother, sister, aunt, cousin and friend. Funeral service at Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Sunday, 11:15am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to American Cancer Society or VNSNY Haven Hospice.

FISH--Richard Edward. March 18, 1953 - April 4, 2014. Beloved son of the late George Wagman Fish and Edith Davis Fish, brother of Robert Davis, Daniel Gene, Ruth Ellen Fishbein. "The song is ended, but the melody lingers on..." Gathering at Pelham Funeral Home, Sunday, April 6, 4pm-7pm, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham. 914-738-1060 for further information.

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Nathan, his wife Marcia and to grandsons, Isaac and Benjamin, and his wife Jamie and great-granddaughter, Natalie. SAWYER--Philip N.,of Brooklyn, NY died April 4, 2014. Loving husband to his wife Grace of 60 years, father to Peggy, Elizabeth, Susan, and Philip, and grandfather to Katharine, Hal, Emily, Lily, Victoria, Elliot, Max and Oliver. Dr. Sawyer graduated from Harvard College and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School as a Naval Officer, and served in the Second World and Korean Wars. An unusual and creative thinker, he was a surgical scientific pioneer, credited with over 100 patents and 500 manuscripts and books. Among his medical contributions were a biophysical theory of charge characteristics that helped explain blood vessel clotting, a bovine graft for repairing damaged vessels, the "gas endarterectomy" procedure for removing clots, and his role in developing the coronary artery bypass procedure. His innovative ideas led to his co-founding several medical technology companies. Dr. Sawyer was former chair of the Department of Vascular Surgery at Downstate Medical Center, President of the NY Surgical Society, founding editor of the Journal of Investigative Surgery and a Markle Scholar, among other awards and honors. A dedicated physician, he continued to treat patients until his death at age 88. Services will be held at 9:30am, April 10 at the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn, NY. Donations may be made to the American Heart Association and his church.

MALTESE--Anthony Jay, aka AJ. Beloved son of Cynthia and Anthony Maltese, brother of Kristen Maltese Krusen, husband of Christine and father to Ashlyn passed away at the early age of 44 on April 3 in New York City. Raised in Saddle River, Mantoloking New Jersey and resident of New York City. AJ graduated from Blair Academy and University of Colorado. Employed by JP Morgan Chase and Co-owner of Threshold recording studio. AJ was an avid athlete and had a passion for downhill skiing, surfing, mountain bike riding, motorbikes and more recently triathlons. He was a very talented base guitar player and in his honor we have established the AJ Maltese III fund for students of the base guitar to Fillimin Dagostino Greenburg, School of Music at Lifeshouse International for base players.

GREENBAUM--Beatrice Weiner, died April 5, 2014, born May 31, 1919 in Brooklyn, NY to Israel and Rose Weiner. A graduate of New York University, and holder of Masters' degrees in Health and Public Policy from the University of Michigan and Sarah Lawrence College. A life-long advocate for compassionate end of life care and the founder and supporter of numerous charitable organizations devoted to hospice care and informed decision-making. Pre-deceased in 2009 by her beloved husband of 67 years, the Hon. Maurice Coleman Greenbaum. Survived by her children Debra and Robert Fisher; her grandchildren Daniel (Ashley) Fisher and Elizabeth Fisher; and her great-grandchildren Cabot Coleman Fisher, Winston Clark Fisher and Burke Samuel Fisher. Services April 7, 9:30am at Temple Beth El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY. Shiva, 6:30-9pm, April 7, at Bea's home, 6:30-9pm, April 8 and 9, Debbie and Bob's home. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to to the Rabbis' Discretionary Fund at Temple Beth El, Great Neck. An example of dignity and rectitude to all who knew her; a living symbol of a time gone by. She will be missed.

SHULMAN--Florence K. Florence K. "Flossie" Shulman. Born December 31, 1924, Paterson, NJ to Samuel and Marian Katz. Sister of beloved late Muriel Goldman. Adored wife of Harvey L. Shulman for almost 68 years. Loving and beloved mother of Robert (Phyllis), John (Joan) and Thomas. Proud grandmother of Jamie (David Banker), Joshua, Adam and Alaina. Doting great-grandmother of Elyssa and Sydney. Her life revolved around her beloved family, dear friends, literature and world travel with her inseparable soul-mate husband. "She was my North, my South, my East and West, My working week and my Sunday rest, My noon, my midnight, my talk, my song; I thought that love would last forever: I was wrong." (excerpt/modified from W H Auden; Twelve Songs, IX) "The years have run like rabbits, For in my arms I held The Flower of the Ages, And the first love of the world." "O let not Time deceive you, You cannot conquer Time" (both excerpts/modified from W H Auden; "As I Walked Out One Evening") "Love either grows or it dies; ours still growing and deepening with the years until death intervened" (HLS). Died April 2, 2014. Cremated April 4 in accordance with her wishes. Contributions to Visiting Nurse Service of New York or to cancer research.
ASHFORTH--Elsie Little. April 8, 1914-October 30, 2010. Happy 100th Birthday today! "Elegance is the only beauty that never fades." All our love , Tina, Sandy and Elizabeth

DOYLE--Joseph Anthony. 93, beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, died peacefully at home on April 5, 2014 with his wife of nearly 70 years at his side. He was born on June 13, 1920 in The Bronx, NY to Joseph A. Doyle Sr. and Jane Donahue. The oldest of five children and the only boy, Joe and his family moved many times following their salesman father. Joe was unusually bright and made the family very proud by earning a BS from Georgetown University in 1941. He then served as a Navy pilot in the Pacific during WWII earning the Navy Cross, Distinguished Flying Cross with three gold stars and the Air Medal with seven gold stars. While at Georgetown he met a Marymount College student, Eugenie Fleri, and on August 19, 1944, while on leave from the war, they married, commencing the happy marriage that both partners credited for their long and healthy lives. Together they raised five children, traveled widely, and enjoyed going to the ballet. He always supported Genie's career as a doctor and benefited greatly from her tender, expert care at the end of his life. After the war, on the advice of his commanding officer, he entered Columbia Law School on the GI Bill, and after graduating in 1947 enjoyed a long career as partner at Shearman & Sterling in New York City. Continuing to value his Navy career Joe served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy from 1979-1981. During this time, Genie commuted from her job at NYU Medical Center to make a home for him in Washington DC. He always spoke of his gratitude to her for making his public service possible. He served on the Board of Directors of Fuji Bank & Trust and of the United Service Organizations of Metropolitan NY. He was also proud of his service on the Roxbury Land Trust Board in the Connecticut town where he maintained a weekend and summer home at which his large family could gather. He is survived by his wife, Genie, his sister, Mary, five children and their spouses, Christopher and wife, Laurie; Stephen and wife, Kathryn Fuller; Eugenie and husband Sam Burr; Jane Marie and husband John Day, Jr., Richard and wife Kate. His strong work ethic, loyalty to family, and devotion to duty has deeply affected his children. Joe was immensely proud of them. He was the loved and respected patriarch, "Pipa", to grandchildren, Sarah, Michael, Anne, Matthew, Peter, Margaret, Nora, Silas, Caleb, Nick, Addie, Helen, and Brendan. He lived to enjoy the news of his first great-grandchild, Noah. He also leaves many devoted nephews and nieces. He was predeceased by his parents, and three sisters, Jayne, Anne, and Sheila. When interviewed for a family history book in 2000, he said, "If someone asked, 'What is the most important step that you took in your whole life to be as well off as you are now,' I would say, 'Marrying a woman who saw things the way I do, without my having to persuade her or she having to persuade me'. We have a common understanding of what life means and what's important." He also said, "Always concentrating on where you are going is very important and you're the pilot. Remember, you're the pilot." Visiting hours at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, Tuesday, April 8, 6-8pm. There will be a Funeral Mass Wednesday at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 371 Sixth Ave.
