Mourned by sister Rosemary, nieces Bobby, Mary and Gaby; nephews Philip, Nick and Robin; great-nephews/nieces Joanna, Lucie, Christopher; Miles, Jake, Toby, Ben and Zoe.

SAWYER--Philip N.,of Brooklyn, NY died April 4, 2014. Loving husband to his wife Grace of 60 years, father to Peggy, Elizabeth, Susan, and Philip, and grandfather to Katharine, Hal, Emily, Lily, Victoria, Elliot, Max and Oliver. Dr. Sawyer graduated from Harvard College and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School as a Naval Officer, and served in the Second World and Korean Wars. An unusual and creative thinker, he was a surgical scientific pioneer, credited with over 100 patents and 500 manuscripts and books. Among his medical contributions were a biophysical theory of charge characteristics that helped explain blood vessel clotting, a bovine graft for repairing damaged vessels, the "gas endarterectomy" procedure for removing clots, and his role in developing the coronary artery bypass procedure. His innovative ideas led to his co-founding several medical technology companies. Dr. Sawyer was former chair of the Department of Vascular Surgery at Downstate Medical Center, President of the NY Surgical Society, founding editor of the Journal of Investigative Surgery and a Markle Scholar, among other awards and honors. A dedicated physician, he continued to treat patients until his death at age 88. Services will be held at 9:30am, April 10 at the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn, NY. Donations may be made to the American Heart Association and his church.

GUTNER--Ira J.,of Rhinebeck, NY, died on Friday, April 4, 2014. He was 57. He founded Samuel's, a coffee business. He was active in civic activities in Rhinebeck. Survived by husband John Schwartz, parents, sister, brother, nephews and nieces. A service will be held on April 9 in Rhinebeck, NY.

BERTLES--John F.,MD, of Bronxville, on April 6, 2014. Beloved husband of Lila. Loving father of Mark, Jacquelyn and John. Cherished Grandfather of Ian Bertles and Alex and North Vincent. He was Born in Spokane, Washington on June 8, 1925 and served in the U.S. Navy during WWII on a mine sweeper off the coast of California. He graduated from Yale University Class of 1945 and from Harvard Medical School Class of 1952. He specialized in hematology. At the time of his death, he was Professor of Medicine Emeritus For Life at Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons. He had served as Director of Transfusion Services (1981-1995) at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center and Chief of Hematology Oncology (1962-1995) of the Medical Service at St. Luke's. At the National Institute of Health, he was on the Hematology Study Section and the Blood Research Review Board (1972-1984). He received a Pioneer Award from the National Sickle Cell Disease Program of the NIH. He was an Attending Physician in the Medical Service from 1962 to 1995 at St. Luke's Roosevelt Center, Attending Physician 1995 to 1997 at Montefiore and Career Scientist from 1962 to 1975 at the Health Research Council of New York City. His research appears in multiple medical journals and text books. Jack loved his family, traveling and good food and wine. True to his Irish roots he always loved a good story and good company. His vibrant spirit will live in our hearts forever. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9pm Thursday and 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Friday. A funeral service will be held on Saturday April 12th at the funeral home at 12 noon.

HUNT--Calvin. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Ailey Board of Trustees, and staff mourn the passing of Calvin Hunt, our beloved Senior Director of Performance & Production. In 1982, at the invitation of Alvin Ailey, he joined the production staff and over the next three decades he became a pivotal leader within the organization, working closely with Artistic Directors Judith Jamison and Robert Battle. Calvin played an integral role managing Ailey's tours around the world, extending Ailey's role as a cultural ambassador. Calvin had an unparalleled love for Ailey and a passion for life. His sense of humor, wise counsel, and warm friendship will be deeply missed. He was an extraordinary man whose passing is a great loss to the Ailey family and the world of dance. Our hearts go out to his loving wife Margaret, their two children Eli and Brenna, and his entire family. A memorial celebration will be announced later in the spring. Joan H. Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Dir..; Masazumi Chaya, Associate Artistic Director; Bennett Rink, Executive Dir.; Judith Jamison, Artistic Director Emerita

BROPHY--Gerald Patrick. Passed away on April 2, 2014 following a short illness. Born in Kansas City, Missouri on September 11, 1926 Gerry's family moved to Westchester County, New York and settled in New Rochelle. He graduated from Iona Preparatory School in early 1944 and enlisted in the U.S. Maritime Service, serving in the North Atlantic region until the end of hostilities. Entering Columbia University, he completed his undergraduate and PhD studies in Geology in 1954 and accepted a faculty appointment at Amherst College where he served until 1998, retiring as Hitchcock Professor of Mineralogy and Geology. During his studies at Columbia (supported by the Atomic Energy Commission) he helped explore the uranium potential of central Utah and discovered a new uranium-bearing ore mineral. During his tenure at Amherst he also maintained consulting operations with several mining companies in the U.S., Canada and South Africa, in addition to conducting geological investigations in Pakistan, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Ethiopia, Kenya, Tanzania and Mexico. From 1978 to 1980, taking a leave from Amherst College, he managed the Department of Energy programs for potential geothermal resources in the lower 48 contiguous United States. For many years he was a member of the Yellowstone Bighorn Research Association serving as Counselor and President. Other professional memberships included the Geological Society of America, the Mineralogical Society of America and the Society of Economic Geologists. The Geological Society of America established at his urging and request: 1) the undergraduate membership program and 2) a section of the Society encouraging the Northeastern U.S. and adjacent Canada to concentrate on studies within that unique geological region. Gerry is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Joanne Young Brophy; son Thomas, daughter-in-law Laura and granddaughter Katherine of Brooklyn, NY; son James, daughter-in-law Evelyn and granddaughters Jennifer of Bloomington, IN and Sarah of Chicago, IL. His eldest son, William Michael, predeceased him. Private funeral services will be held soon and a public memorial service will be held at a later date.

FISHMAN--Robert B.,a man of principle, integrity, and quiet dignity passed away peacefully at his home on April 3, 2014 at age 88. He is survived and mourned by his wife, Elaine, of 62 years, sons Jack and David, daughters-in-law Paula and Stephanie, granddaughters Julia and Claire. After serving in the Navy during World War II, he graduated from CCNY and worked as a physicist for the US Army Laboratories for forty years in the development of acoustic, seismic, magnetic, optical and EMP sensors, receiving a patent for an optical dosimeter. A loyal husband, devoted father and caring grandfather, he will be in our hearts forever.

ALBER--Thomas C. Professor at University of California, Berkeley known for his elegant biochemical and structural studies of proteins, died peacefully on March 28, 2014 in Berkeley, CA. He celebrated his 60th birthday in January after a five-year battle with ALS, which sapped his strength but not his spirit. He will be remembered for the enthusiasm with which he lived his life and shared his passions with his beloved children Josh (19) Emily (17) Mackenzie (13). He is also survived by their mother Julie Nye and his brothers William, Chad, and Don Alber. For further details please go to: http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2014/04/04/berkeley-professor-thomas-alber-dies-at-60/

RECHTSCHAFFEN--Pamela. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Pamela Rechtschaffen, of blessed memory, the profoundly cherished, devoted and admired wife of Manfred Rechtschaffen, an alumnus of Yeshiva College '54 and the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) '56 who serves as a member of the Sy Syms School of Business Board of Overseers. Pamela was a dedicated Vice President of the Yeshiva University Women's Organization. Together they are YU Guardians. Pamela was admired and cherished as a friend and co-worker by all who came in contact with her for the faith she expressed as she did battle as a virtual Ayshet Chayil to overcome the health challenges to which she ultimately succumbed. Surely her memory will be a source of enduring blessings for all who knew her. Heartfelt condolences to Rabbi Rechtschaffen and their loving sons, Andrew and Eric. May the entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

SCHEINFELD--Solomon. The Board, staff, and volunteers of the Alzheimer's Association, New York City Chapter mourn the loss of Solomon "Al" Scheinfeld, beloved father of Linda Podolsky and father-in-law of esteemed Board member, Abe Podolsky. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his loving family. Benjamin Jenkins, Jeffrey Jones, Co-Chairs; Lou-Ellen Barkan, President and CEO

HUNT--Calvin. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Ailey Board of Trustees, and staff mourn the passing of Calvin Hunt, our beloved Senior Director of Performance & Production. In 1982, at the invitation of Alvin Ailey, he joined the production staff and over the next three decades he became a pivotal leader within the organization, working closely with Artistic Directors Judith Jamison and Robert Battle. Calvin played an integral role managing Ailey's tours around the world, extending Ailey's role as a cultural ambassador. Calvin had an unparalleled love for Ailey and a passion for life. His sense of humor, wise counsel, and warm friendship will be deeply missed. He was an extraordinary man whose passing is a great loss to the Ailey family and the world of dance. Our hearts go out to his loving wife Margaret, their two children Eli and Brenna, and his entire family. A memorial celebration will be announced later in the spring. Joan H. Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Dir..; Masazumi Chaya, Associate Artistic Director; Bennett Rink, Executive Dir.; Judith Jamison, Artistic Director Emerita

RECHTSCHAFFEN--Pamela. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Pamela Rechtschaffen, beloved wife of Rabbi Manfred Rechtschaffen. She leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Pamela's husband; her children, Andrew (Monique) and Eric (Kim); her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

PIEROT--Elsie "Bunny", (Elsie Pell Guion Pierot), the beloved matriarch of the Pierot family, died on April 3 at Greenwich Hospital with her four children, Robert Pierot, Catherine Zicherman, Ted Pierot and Felicia Brody, as well as daughter Julie in spirit, by her side. She was born in 1933, the only child of Elsie Pell and Floyd Guion. Her amazing, shining spirit transformed the lives of those she met. She had an unrelenting humour and passion for living. A jewelry artist, her work was displayed at museums in New York City and Connecticut. For over forty years she was founder and president of The Resale Company, an estate sales specialist. Bunny's extraordinary sensibilities never allowed the glue to dry in our love and support of one another as her family and extended family and also with her great eclectic circle of friends around her. Her loving, positive values will live on in all of us. Bunny's legacy will live on in her grandchildren Penelope and Melanie Brody, Olivia, Cecily and Spencer Choi, Dustin Ziegler, George and Isabel Pierot, Elizabeth Welch, Christopher, Phillip, Nicholas and Sophie-Charlotte Chen and her great-granddaughter Bella Grace D'Archangelo. She wanted to be everywhere all the time for everyone and now she is. Contributions may be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

MOORE--Marion C.,beloved mother and devoted wife peacefully passed on to a better life March 28th, 2014. She joins her husband William M. Moore and is survived by her son, Christopher. She had impeccable taste, class, charm and style. Contact: greenmarble@optonline.net

BLOOM--Florence (nee Kowalsky), died April 8, 2014. Born in Queens, NY on January 29, 1929 to Levy and Clara Kowalsky. Predeceased by her beloved husband Frank (Fritzie). She is survived by her devoted daughters Susan (Larry) Jones, Debbie (Jack) Arkin, Marcia (Ira) Pollack and was a loving grandmother to Leigh (Tina), Chloe (Glen), Geoffrey, Rachel and Jason. She will be greatly missed. Private graveside services on Wednesday at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Shiva at Susan and Larry's home on Thursday 2:00-4:00pm and 6:30-8:30pm.

BERTLES--John F.,MD, of Bronxville, on April 6, 2014. Beloved husband of Lila. Loving father of Mark, Jacquelyn and John. Cherished Grandfather of Ian Bertles and Alex and North Vincent. He was Born in Spokane, Washington on June 8, 1925 and served in the U.S. Navy during WWII on a mine sweeper off the coast of California. He graduated from Yale University Class of 1945 and from Harvard Medical School Class of 1952. He specialized in hematology. At the time of his death, he was Professor of Medicine Emeritus For Life at Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons. He had served as Director of Transfusion Services (1981-1995) at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center and Chief of Hematology Oncology (1962-1995) of the Medical Service at St. Luke's. At the National Institute of Health, he was on the Hematology Study Section and the Blood Research Review Board (1972-1984). He received a Pioneer Award from the National Sickle Cell Disease Program of the NIH. He was an Attending Physician in the Medical Service from 1962 to 1995 at St. Luke's Roosevelt Center, Attending Physician 1995 to 1997 at Montefiore and Career Scientist from 1962 to 1975 at the Health Research Council of New York City. His research appears in multiple medical journals and text books. Jack loved his family, traveling and good food and wine. True to his Irish roots he always loved a good story and good company. His vibrant spirit will live in our hearts forever. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 6 to 9pm Thursday and 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Friday. A funeral service will be held on Saturday April 12th at the funeral home at 12 noon.

DURRANI--Hassan. HM King Hassan Durrani I, son of King Amanulla Kahn of Afghanistan, died of natural causes on April 2, 2014 at his home in New York. H.R.H. died peacefully surrounded by close friends and his beloved dogs.

DOYLE--Joseph Anthony. 93, beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, died peacefully at home on April 5, 2014 with his wife of nearly 70 years at his side. He was born on June 13, 1920 in The Bronx, NY to Joseph A. Doyle Sr. and Jane Donahue. The oldest of five children and the only boy, Joe and his family moved many times following their salesman father. Joe was unusually bright and made the family very proud by earning a BS from Georgetown University in 1941. He then served as a Navy pilot in the Pacific during WWII earning the Navy Cross, Distinguished Flying Cross with three gold stars and the Air Medal with seven gold stars. While at Georgetown he met a Marymount College student, Eugenie Fleri, and on August 19, 1944, while on leave from the war, they married, commencing the happy marriage that both partners credited for their long and healthy lives. Together they raised five children, traveled widely, and enjoyed going to the ballet. He always supported Genie's career as a doctor and benefited greatly from her tender, expert care at the end of his life. After the war, on the advice of his commanding officer, he entered Columbia Law School on the GI Bill, and after graduating in 1947 enjoyed a long career as partner at Shearman & Sterling in New York City. Continuing to value his Navy career Joe served as Assistant Secretary of the Navy from 1979-1981. During this time, Genie commuted from her job at NYU Medical Center to make a home for him in Washington DC. He always spoke of his gratitude to her for making his public service possible. He served on the Board of Directors of Fuji Bank & Trust and of the United Service Organizations of Metropolitan NY. He was also proud of his service on the Roxbury Land Trust Board in the Connecticut town where he maintained a weekend and summer home at which his large family could gather. He is survived by his wife, Genie, his sister, Mary, five children and their spouses, Christopher and wife, Laurie; Stephen and wife, Kathryn Fuller; Eugenie and husband Sam Burr; Jane Marie and husband John Day, Jr., Richard and wife Kate. His strong work ethic, loyalty to family, and devotion to duty has deeply affected his children. Joe was immensely proud of them. He was the loved and respected patriarch, "Pipa", to grandchildren, Sarah, Michael, Anne, Matthew, Peter, Margaret, Nora, Silas, Caleb, Nick, Addie, Helen, and Brendan. He lived to enjoy the news of his first great-grandchild, Noah. He also leaves many devoted nephews and nieces. He was predeceased by his parents, and three sisters, Jayne, Anne, and Sheila. When interviewed for a family history book in 2000, he said, "If someone asked, 'What is the most important step that you took in your whole life to be as well off as you are now,' I would say, 'Marrying a woman who saw things the way I do, without my having to persuade her or she having to persuade me'. We have a common understanding of what life means and what's important." He also said, "Always concentrating on where you are going is very important and you're the pilot. Remember, you're the pilot." Visiting hours at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, Tuesday, April 8, 6-8pm. There will be a Funeral Mass Wednesday at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, 371 Sixth Ave.

HUNT--Calvin. Opus 3 Artists mourns the passing of Calvin Hunt, dear friend and colleague. His passion for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will continue to guide us, and his kindness and warm spirit will continue to inspire us.
AYDIN--Maria, beloved mother and friend, died peacefully on April 5. Visitation 5-9pm Friday, John Krtil, 1297 1st Ave. Services 10am Saturday, Our Lady of Peace, 237 E 62nd St. Interment private.

ELYACHAR--Ralph. (1927-2014). Loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, and friend passed away peacefully on April 7 in his home in Scarsdale. Ralph's career spanned many decades in real estate development and management of commercial and residential properties in the New York metro area and Sarasota, FL. A graduate of Purdue University who served in World War II, he cherished his 62-year marriage with his wife, Alice.

FRIED--Helen B. Passed away on April 6, 2014 at 94 years old. Predeceased by her husband, Harry A. Fried. Survived by her loving daughters, Benna (Robert Brown) Norman and Ruth (Joshua Herz) Fried; grandchildren, Alexandra, William, Beth and Naomi; brother, Norman (Lenore) Berkowitz; nieces and nephews and cousins. Helen lived her entire life in New York City except for the last 17 months, when she lived in Rochester, NY, near her daughter. She and her husband owned Carlyle Chemists on Madison. A brief service will be held in Mt. Ararat Cemetery Thursday at 11am. A Memorial Service will be held at the Beacon Hotel at 75th and Broadway on Thursday at 3pm followed by a gathering until 5:30pm. Donations may be made to the Guggenheim Museum in her memory. BrightonMemorialChapel.com

RUDOLF--Edith T. On April 8, 2014, peacefully at home. She is survived by her beloved husband, Bill, of over 60 years of marriage; her beloved children, Paul, Margaret and her husband Tom Coffey; her adored grandchildren Alexander, Eliot, Nathaniel, Max, Janna, Calvin, Halle and Matthew. She is also survived by her sister, Mae Feluren, brother, Jay Tanenbaum, and her extraordinary caregivers, Virginia Norwood and Marcenia Williams. Edith lived for her family and the world of art. She touched the lives of many and will be greatly missed by all. She was our star and source of love for everyone. Service Thursday, April 10, 2014, 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in her memory to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston or to The Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Maine.

HUNT--Calvin. The staff of New York City Center mourns the passing of Calvin Hunt. Calvin had become a beloved member of the New York City Center family during his many years with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and we will miss him deeply. He inspired us all with his brilliance, kindness, passion and commitment. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Margaret, and their two children, Eli and Brenna.

ELYACHAR--Ralph. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Ralph Elyachar, beloved husband of Alice. He was the son of the revered Colonel and Mrs. Jehiel R. Elyachar, son of his twin brother, Daniel. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Alice Elyachar, Daniel Elyachar and his sister Dr. Ruth Dvorkin, their children, grandchildren nephews and nieces and entire family. May they be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus

Service Thursday, April 10, 2014, 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76 St. at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made in her memory to the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston or to The Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Maine.

LAFFORD--Lindsay Arthur, Aged 101, died April 5, 2014, Tempe, AZ; born 1912, Gloucester, England. 1922 Hereford Cathedral: chorister, organ scholar. 1935 St. John's Cathedral, Hong Kong: organist, music director. 1939 Haverford, Swarthmore colleges: teacher. Princeton University: organist. 1943 U.S. Navy: Chaplain's Assistant. 1948 Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Geneva, NY: professor, department chair, conductor, organist. 1979 St. Philip's Episcopal Church, Coral Gables, FL: organist, music director. 1994 Tempe, AZ: composer, conductor, organist. 1998 became Lord of Ridley. Predeceased by wife, Anne, 1988; survived by daughter, Julia Welbon, and sons, Llewellyn and Peter, their spouses and a grandson, Christopher Welbon. Lafford's vocal and instrumental compositions are detailed on his website Lord-of-Ridley.com

BARKIN--Bernice W.,of Fairfield, CT. Age 91, passed away peacefully on April 7. Wife of the late Herbert. Mother of Joel and Samuel. Sister, sister-in-law, aunt, grandmother and great-grandmother. She departed this life as she lived it, with dignity.

BEEBER--Bernie. Colel Chabad - Lubavitch shares the grief of Randi and Arthur Luxenberg, Chairman of United Soup Kitchens, on the passing of your father and father-in-law Bernie Beeber obm. A man known for his modest ways, the love he had for his family, and the pride he took in the accomplishments of his children. May the A-mighty comfort you among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sholom Duchman, Director

BERNHARD--Ronald L.,64, of White Plains, NY lost his battle with cancer peacefully at Calvary Hospital on April 8, 2014. Ron retired after a 35 year career at TIAA CREF as an Investment Officer. Ron started his own consulting firm and began a new career as a volunteer. This included: Westchester Community College ESL Department, The Volunteer Center of United Way and Big Brothers Big Sisters as a board member. Ron, a native New Yorker, was born on January 26, 1950. He was educated at Hofstra University and New York University. Ron was a loving husband, adored father, most loyal friend and an avid sports fan. He is survived by his wife, Tess Cerra of 37 years and children Amanda and Adam Bernhard of Elmsford, NY. Ron will be missed by all whose professional and personal lives were touched by his goodness and generosity of spirit. Reposing, Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 West Stevens Avenue, Hawthorne, NY, (914-769-4404), on Friday, 4-8pm. Funeral Mass, Holy Name of Jesus Church, Valhalla, NY on Saturday, 10:30am. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Volunteer Center of United Way, Big Brothers Big Sisters and the Dickstein Cancer Center in White Plains, N.Y. would be appreciated.

BERKMAN--Joseph L.,died April 8th. Born January 5, 1927 in New York to Meyer and Fannie Berkman. He is survived by his loving wife of 65 years, Ann Posner Berkman. His children Bonnie and Doug Blum, Debra Goldfarb, and Michael Fischman. His grandchildren Micah and Michelle Blum, Julie and Frank Rendon, Andrew, Joshua and Benjamin Goldfarb and his five great-granddaughters. His sister-in-law Judy, Sara and Michael Corwin. He was a veteran of WWII and served in the Pacific. A life-long Westchester County resident where he ran a successful family business. He cherished time with his family. A lover of travel, golf, the beach, the New York Giants and his dog Daisy. Contributions may be made to the Bronx Zoo, Hadassah, or a charity of your choice. Graveside services at Sharon Gardens April 10th at 11:30am in Valhalla, NY. Shiva 1-4pm and 6-8pm Thursday, April 10th and 2-6pm Friday, April 11th, 20 Shawnee Rd., Scarsdale, NY 10803.

BLOOM--Florence (nee Kowalsky), died April 8, 2014. Born in Queens, NY on January 29, 1929 to Levy and Clara Kowalsky. Predeceased by her beloved husband Frank (Fritzie). She is survived by her devoted daughters Susan (Larry) Jones, Debbie (Jack) Arkin, Marcia (Ira) Pollack and was a loving grandmother to Leigh (Tina), Chloe (Glen), Geoffrey, Rachel and Jason. She will be greatly missed. Private graveside services on Wednesday at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Shiva at Susan and Larry's home on Thursday 2:00-4:00pm and 6:30-8:30pm.

BRUSTEIN--Lillian Heller, age 94, of Tinton Falls, NJ originally from Brooklyn, NY, where she met her late husband Abraham Brustein, and later moved to Woodhaven, Queens, NY. Predeceased in 2012 by her son Jeffrey, she is survived by her sons and daughters-in-law Fred, Marsha, Scott, Lenore, and Ina; her grandchildren and their wives Josh, Mariah, Adam, Jun, and Rebecca, and her great-grandchildren Lilly, Carly, and Milo. She will be greatly missed by all. Donations in her memory should be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America www.alzfdn.org.

HARAP--Frederick. 4/11/2013. Taken from his loving family before his time. You are dearly missed - and will be eternally cherished by your Wife, Son and two Granddaughters.
ERPF--Buddy. Gone for 30 years. We miss and love you. Come back and we can watch our great-grandchildren and the Dow Jones.

ROSENFELD--Norman, of New York, NY, died April 10. Born December 11, 1933, in New York City to Morris and Ray Rosenfeld. Predeceased in 2008 by his beloved wife of 49 years, Lee Green Rosenfeld. Survived by his sister, Phyllis Zuckman, of New Rochelle, NY; his son and daughter-in-law, Joshua Rosenfeld and Stephanie Parr of San Francisco, CA; his daughter and son-in-law, Marion Rosenfeld and Thomas H. Jones of New York City; and granddaughters Maxine, Sylvia, and Theadora. Norman was a proud graduate of the Bronx High School of Science (1951) and Pratt Institute (1956). He founded Norman Rosenfeld Architects in 1969 and was an innovator in the design of healthcare facilities, embracing a humanistic approach to creating hospital environments. He was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects and Founding Fellow of the American College of Healthcare Architects. In his semi-retirement, he spent time mentoring young architects at Pratt and establishing The Lee and Norman Rosenfeld Award in 2010 to provide financial assistance to deserving undergraduates at the School of Architecture at Pratt Institute. A memorial service will be held in the late spring. Donations in his memory can be made to P.S. 3, The Charrette School, a progressive public school in Greenwich Village where he was a founding parent: ps3nyc.org/news/donate/donations/ or HIAS, the organization that helped settle his immigrant parents: www.hias.org/

WHITE--Larry, Age 83, devoted lifelong Brooklynite, died peacefully, on April 8, after a long, courageous battle with Lou Gehrig's disease. Beloved husband of Alice for more than 50 years. Loving father of Josh (Carrie), David (Marlene) and Jessica (Scott). Brother of Martin (Marta). Cherished grandfather of Matt, Ariella, Talia, Ethan, Elana, Orli and Jake. He had a long career with the NYC Board of Education as an attendance teacher and guidance counselor. Larry lived his life fully through family, travel and athletics. In gratitude for his extraordinary care, donations may be made to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL, hbts.org. Funeral service will be held Sunday, April 13, 11:00am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

BLUM--Abbey. Loved, missed, and remembered, today and every day by family and friends. The memories we shared keep us close and you are always only a thought away. Three years have passed but the lessons you taught us continue to be our guide. Love always, Ward, Tripp, Ross, and Maritza.

WALKER--Jeffrey P.,of Salisbury, CT, passed away peacefully on April 8, 2014. He was a former teacher, coach, business manager and trustee of Salisbury School. He is survived by his beloved wife, Doris. He is also survived by a sister, a son, two daughters and two granddaughters. He is also survived by four step-children, eight step-grandchildren and eight step-great grandchildren. A memorial service will be scheduled for later in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Jeffrey P. Walker Memorial Scholarship Fund, Salisbury School, 251 Canaan Road, Salisbury, CT 06068 would be greatly appreciated. The Kenny Funeral Homes of Sharon, CT has care of services.

WEHBERG--Dirk, on March 17, 2014, Dirk Anton Wehberg passed away peacefully in Miami Beach with Richard de Pasquale, his life partner of fifteen years, by his side. He was sixty-six. Before retiring with Richard to Miami Beach, Dirk had a successful thirty-year career in international sales at Meadwestvaco, a global packaging company. His son, Koert Wehberg, former wife Carole Wehberg, sisters Carla Wehberg and Ine Klinkers of the Netherlands, along with many friends remember him with much fondness and love.

Schmidt--George, August 1, 1926, died April 9, 2014. Professor of Physics at the Stevens Institute of Technology for over 20 years, he was the author of one book and over 100 research papers mostly in an area of physics related to nuclear fusion. Some of his later papers were on chaos theory. He was born in Hungary near Budapest. During WWII he survived a forced labor camp in Yugoslavia and returned home to learn he had lost his entire family to the Holocaust. He sided with the rebellion during the Hungary 1956 uprising and became a refugee when the uprising failed. He then traveled with his wife Katalin to the new state of Israel where he taught at the Technion in Haifa for two years before emigrating to the United States.

BRADLEY--Rev. Dr. Paul W.,The Blanton-Peale Institute and Counseling Center and New York Theological Seminary announce with great sadness the death of The Rev. Dr. Paul W. Bradley, the President and CEO of the Blanton-Peale Institute and Counseling Center. He died on Friday, April 4, 2014, after a prolonged illness. Dr. Bradley began his tenure as President in June 2010, after serving as a fundraising consultant and as Vice President for Development beginning in the fall of 2009. Prior to his work at the Blanton-Peale Institute, Dr. Bradley was the Vice President for Development and Institutional Advancement at New York Theological Seminary, where he was also the Director of Supervised Ministry and an Adjunct Professor, teaching Supervised Ministry, Church Administration and Stewardship, and United Church of Christ Polity. For the past three years he served as a Trustee of New York Theological Seminary where he chaired the Development Committee. He previously served for five years in the Development Office of Union Theological Seminary, and worked for ten years at The New York Public Library in several increasingly responsible development positions, culminating in five years of service as Manager of the Campaign for the Library's successful $750 million "Second Century Campaign." Before joining the Library's staff, he was Director of Development for The League of Women Voters of New York State and Director of its capital campaign, and earlier served as a development officer for Yale University. In his thirty-plus-year career, he consulted on development, stewardship, and communications for many churches and other not-for-profit organizations. A sixth-generation Congregational/United Church of Christ minister, Dr. Bradley was born at Hartford Hospital in Hartford, Connecticut, on September 14, 1954. He moved to New York City in 1976. Dr. Bradley received his B.A. from Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, New York, his Masters of Divinity from Union Theological Seminary in the City of New York, and his Doctor of Ministry from New York Theological Seminary. He was ordained as a UCC minister at The Riverside Church in the City of New York in 2002 and had been a member of Riverside since 1993. He was active as a lay leader and as backup clergy at Riverside and was a member or chair of a number of committees and organizational bodies at the local, regional, and national levels of the United Church of Christ. Beginning in 2001, Dr. Bradley was the Senior Pastor and Co-Minister of Step By Step: A Ministry of Recovery and Healing, a project of the Center for Recovery Ministries at NYTS, which meets in nine locations in the New York metropolitan area, and uses the Twelve Steps of recovery in a spiritual worship program. He was also Assistant Pastor at Eldred Congregational Church in Eldred, New York. Dr. Bradley was married to Dr. Robert J. Abel, DNP, PMHNP-BC. Their love spanned more than 14 years. He is survived by Bob, his mother, Paula Bradley, his two brothers, James Choukas-Bradley and Dwight Bradley and their wives, Melanie Choukas-Bradley and Lauren Bradley, and nieces and nephews Sophia Choukas-Bradley, Jesse Choukas-Bradley, Alice Bradley, and Dan Bradley. A service of celebration for Dr. Bradley's life will take place at The Riverside Church in the City of New York, on Friday, May 30, 2014, at 2:00pm. Donations may be made to the New York Theological Seminary Rev. Dr. Paul Bradley Scholarship Fund for Lesbian, Gay Bisexual and Transgender Students.

CARLIN--Phyllis. Was born in Newark, NJ in 1929 to Gertrude and Walter Goldberg. She died peacefully on April 6th at home in Maplewood, NJ from the effects of lung cancer. She was a loving mother, sister, aunt, grandmother, daughter, relative, companion and friend. But above all she was an artist, a creative spirit who made paintings, sculpture and ceramics with great skill that delighted everyone who saw them. She grew up during the Depression at a time when there were few opportunities for women to be artists, much less find work in the field. But she became one of the first women admitted into the union of United Scenic Artists and painted sets for a variety of important productions in New York ranging from the Metropolitan Opera to the Ed Sullivan show. She continued to do so after her first son, John was born; but stopped and moved back to New Jersey after her second son, Tom, arrived. Phyllis spent most of the next two decades taking care of her family while remaining an active participant in the New York art world, visiting the Museum of Modern Art almost every week for over half a century as well as other museums, theater and gallery shows. At the same time she began an active career at home, painting a series of accomplished work that blended modernism with domestic portraits of familiar faces. A man could be standing in the center of a blank room with a gob of painted smeared across his body and a dog howling discretely in the background. Or a blur of beautiful stars could blend into a patterned landscape that made it seem as if Paul Klee was living in suburban New Jersey. The whimsical quality of the paintings, assemblages and objects came from Phyllis' unique spirit and joy in finding wonderful things in the world and in the people around her, combined with a focus on quality and craft. She worked at her art and her relationships in a way that never seemed labored and always ended up as good as possible. As she grew older she never grew old, always finding new things and new people to share her delight in the world. She spent much of the past twenty years with her companion Bob Collier and nurturing her three grandchildren, Magritte, Mallory and Dexter; helping them grow and find the same joy she was able to take and give from everything around her. She lives on in our hearts and imagination.

MATTHIESSEN--Peter. Peter received the Lifetime Achievement Award for Literature from the Guild Hall Academy of the Arts. He will be sorely missed. Ruth Appelhof, Executive Dir. Roy Furman, President of the Academy Martin Cohen, Chair

BRANCIFORTE--James T.,Born December 21, 1961 passed away April 7, 2014. He is survived by sister Joan Branciforte (Pat Viteri) and brother Robert Branciforte (Ronnit) and nephews Michael Branciforte and Stephen Branciforte. He will be missed by his many other relatives and friends who knew him as a very caring, loving and generous person. He made everyone he knew feel special and he leaves us wishing the world had more people like him. Services will be held on Friday, April 11, 2014 at 5pm at Moloney Funeral Home in Ronkonkoma, New York.

POLSKIN--Professor Ilse Dusoir Lind, passed away on April 5, 2014, at the age of 96, as an inevitable result of the passage of time. Professor of English at New York University, where she taught for some 61 years. She is survived by her devoted son Peter E. and his wife Judith Lind, her beloved grandson Michael Lind, thousands of former students and many dear friends. Funeral Services were private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to the English Dept. (Ilse Dusoir Lind Prize) at New York University. Contact information for donations is NYU Office of Gift Administration, PO Box 2251, NY, NY 10116, gift.administration@nyu.edu or 1-800-NYU-4144.

EZRATTY--Dorothy Danowitz, 75, died Wednesday. She was loved by her husband Bernie, her son Martin and his wife Bari, her daughter Michelle and her husband Richie. Cherished by her grandchildren Jennifer, Adam, Melinda and Carly. Dorothy will always be remembered for her smile, laughter and thoughtfulness towards others. She will always live and be loved forever and a day - and then some - through eternity. Dorothy's finally at peace and resting peacefully. Amen! Services by Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY.

MARDER--Ira. Of Englewood, NJ, passed away on April 8, 2014. He was 94 years old. He leaves behind his beloved wife of more than 52 years, Anne, sons William and John, their wives Dominique and Valerie, as well as five grandchildren and a niece. Ira served in the Army Air Corps during World War II, when he was stationed in China, Burma and India. Ira served as the President of the Matson Manufacturing Company of Long Island City, a company founded by his father, Leo Marder. Ira also served as the President of the Englewood Community Chest, raising money for local projects. In his spare time, Ira was an avid sailor, skier and traveler. Ira will be greatly missed by his family, friends and former coworkers. Memorial services will be held at Scanlan Funeral Home in Pompton Plains, NJ on Sunday, April 13th at 2:30pm.

DEMING--Donald L.,passed away on April 9, 2014 at his retirement home in Fort Myers, FL. He was 89 and succumbed to lung cancer. Don was born on July 30, 1924 in Ahmednager, India where his parents, Wilbur and Elsie had been missionaries for many years. Don, his siblings Mary and Bill, and his parents returned from India in 1934 and settled in Washington, CT where his father served as the Congregational minister. Don attended the Gunnery School, graduating in 1941. He entered Yale University that fall. World War II intervened and Don enlisted in the Army in 1942. He joined a tank unit, was sent to Europe and served in Alsace and Germany with the United States Seventh Army. He returned to Yale, graduated in 1947, and was awarded a Phi Beta Kappa key. Subsequently, Don went to Yale Law School. After graduation in 1950, he joined the firm of Chadbourne & Parke, New York City. He remained with the firm for over forty years as a corporate lawyer. He did work for a variety of clients and retired in 1992, after having been the senior partner of the firm for the last few years. Don is survived by Meleanor, his wife of 62 years; three sons, David, James and Robert; their spouses, Jamie, Sharon and Burnedette; five grandchildren, Peter, Julia, Meredith, Emily, and Logan; and their spouses, Jessica (Peter) and Eric Vaughn (Julia); and one great-grandchild, Kate Deming. A family graveside service will be held at a later date.

KURNOW--Ernest. The NYU Stern community mourns the loss of its beloved professor, Ernest Kurnow, who died April 7th. He celebrated his 101st birthday in October 2013. A recipient of NYU's Great Teacher Award, he taught statistics for more than 60 years, last as an adjunct in 2010. Former Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan was his student. Prof. Kurnow created the Statistics Department at NYU Stern and chaired it from 1963 until 1975, a period in which the School focused on building full-time, research-based MBA and PhD programs. He recruited many of the School's most prominent professors. His path-breaking book, "Statistics for Business Decisions," changed the way the subject was taught by introducing sampling procedures to basic statistics. Ernie was born in Brooklyn in 1912 and received his BA and MA in mathematics from New York City College in 1932 and 1933, respectively. Before joining NYU, he worked at the WPA; the Aberdeen Proving Ground, the military base in Maryland where important innovations in computing and the application of statistical quality control were developed; and the New York City Board of Education. Those who had the good fortune to know Ernie also know how much he will be missed. The family has asked that those interested in honoring his legacy donate to the Ernest Kurnow Fellowship c/o NYU Stern, 44 West 4th St., Suite 10-46, NY, NY 10012.

GIBBONS--Sir David. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of The Honorable Sir David Gibbons, who was a generous Benefactor of the Museum. He and his wife, Lully Lorentzen, Lady Gibbons, were loyal members of the Met's Chairman's Council from 1995 through 2011. Sir David also provided funding in 2004, in honor of his wife, for the conservation, reinstallation, and scholarly presentation of the Cubiculum, a bedroom originally from a Roman villa at Boscoreale that was buried by the eruption of Vesuvius in A.D. 79. The Cubiculum is a renowned highlight of the renovated Greek and Roman Galleries, which opened to the public in 2007. We extend condolences to his entire family. Daniel Brodsky, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director and CEO Emily K. Rafferty, President

LEFKOWITZ--Albert, The Board of Directors and Administration of United Hebrew of New Rochelle mourn the passing of Mr. Albert Lefkowitz, esteemed member of our Board of Directors and long-time supporter of United Hebrew. His dedication to those in need is a lasting tribute to his memory. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and prayers to his bereaved family. Michael R. Rozen, Chair Malcolm H. Lazarus, Senior Chair Rita C. Mabli, President and CEO

HUNT--Calvin. The Board of Trustees and Staff of New York Public Radio mourn the tragic loss of Calvin Hunt. He was a beloved father, husband and the soul of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Margaret and their children, Eli and Brenna. Cynthia King Vance, Chair; Laura Walker, President and CEO.
PERPER--Ellen. I will miss your beauty, intellect and many kindnesses. Rest in peace, dear friend. Ruth Weisgal

SMITH--Gregory White, The Juilliard School wishes to express our great sadness on the passing of Gregory White Smith, a wonderful friend to the school and a very special human being. He and his life partner, Steven Naifeh, created a unique environment to support Juilliard artists in Joye Cottage, their magnificent home in Aiken, South Carolina. Greg's deep understanding and love of music were manifested most recently in performances of the Bach St. Matthew Passion that were developed through his support. We express our deepest condolences to Steve, his and Greg's families, and their many friends. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

ROSENFELD--Norman, of New York, NY, died April 10. Born December 11, 1933, in New York City to Morris and Ray Rosenfeld. Predeceased in 2008 by his beloved wife of 49 years, Lee Green Rosenfeld. Survived by his sister, Phyllis Zuckman, of New Rochelle, NY; his son and daughter-in-law, Joshua Rosenfeld and Stephanie Parr of San Francisco, CA; his daughter and son-in-law, Marion Rosenfeld and Thomas H. Jones of New York City; and granddaughters Maxine, Sylvia, and Theadora. Norman was a proud graduate of the Bronx High School of Science (1951) and Pratt Institute (1956). He founded Norman Rosenfeld Architects in 1969 and was an innovator in the design of healthcare facilities, embracing a humanistic approach to creating hospital environments. He was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects and Founding Fellow of the American College of Healthcare Architects. In his semi-retirement, he spent time mentoring young architects at Pratt and establishing The Lee and Norman Rosenfeld Award in 2010 to provide financial assistance to deserving undergraduates at the School of Architecture at Pratt Institute. A memorial service will be held in the late spring. Donations in his memory can be made to P.S. 3, The Charrette School, a progressive public school in Greenwich Village where he was a founding parent: ps3nyc.org/news/donate/donations/ or HIAS, the organization that helped settle his immigrant parents: www.hias.org/

Schmidt--George, August 1, 1926, died April 9, 2014. Professor of Physics at the Stevens Institute of Technology for over 20 years, he was the author of one book and over 100 research papers mostly in an area of physics related to nuclear fusion. Some of his later papers were on chaos theory. He was born in Hungary near Budapest. During WWII he survived a forced labor camp in Yugoslavia and returned home to learn he had lost his entire family to the Holocaust. He sided with the rebellion during the Hungary 1956 uprising and became a refugee when the uprising failed. He then traveled with his wife Katalin to the new state of Israel where he taught at the Technion in Haifa for two years before emigrating to the United States.

SHAWE--Irvin Burl "Big Irv," 83, passed away peacefully on April 7, 2014 in New York City after bravely fighting leukemia for the past year. He was born in Norfolk, VA on August 8, 1930, to the late Philip and Pearl Shawe. Irv was a longtime resident of Virginia and Washington, DC, he also lived in Los Angeles, CA, Palm Beach, FL, Las Vegas, NV, and finally New York City. Irv was a true entrepreneur and built many businesses including art galleries, the first of which was in the New York World's Fair. He was also a renowned real estate broker. Irv loved sports, especially football, and he shared his passion with his sons. Most recently, the family attended Super Bowl XLVIII together. Irv is survived by and will be dearly missed by his sons, Eric Shawe and his wife Dolores of West Palm Beach, FL, Larry Shawe, his wife Renee and their daughter Ava Capri of New York City and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and Phil Shawe and his wife Joanna of New York City, his siblings, Earle K. Shawe of Baltimore, MD, Norman Schikevitz of Boynton Beach, FL, Rosalie Kolker of Bethesda, MD, Katie Klein of Chevy Chase, MD and Bette Belle Becker of Chevy Chase, MD, and his love Shirley Shawe. Irv will also be missed by his extended family and friends. Funeral services for Irv will be held on Sunday, April 13, 2014 at 12pm at the Star of David Cemetery, located at 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, the Shawe family kindly asks that modest donations are made to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in Irv's honor via the following website: http://www.crowdrise.com/ InMemoryofBigIrv/ fundraiser/shawefamily
OPPENHEIM--Aron Solomon. Happy 100th Birthday, Dad. We love and miss you. Love, Irma, Karin and Robert

BILLET--Eda G.,April 11, 2014 Beloved wife of Daniel Billet. Mother of Dan Billet, Tom Billet, Marian Norman and Jane Morgan. Sister of Elvira Rice. Born in New York City on September 19, 1930. Hastings Funeral Home. Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm.

POKORNY--Maria (Marise) Angelucci. A strong willed and generous woman of practicality, logic, and vigor left the world to the rest of us on Friday, March 28th. She passed away quietly at home as she wished, surrounded by her close Italian family. Her character and example shall be carried on by her only son, Stefan Pokorny who already misses her dearly. She joins her beloved husband of 54 years, Jan Hird Pokorny, esteemed Architect and Teacher in another place, of which we do not know but which we imagine must be a place of beauty and happiness surrounded by dear friends in the company of angels...A service and recollections of a beautiful and fully lived life shall be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY 10017 (at 81st St) on Sunday, April 13th at 4:00pm. It would be her wishes that we do not mourn her passing, but that we celebrate a life lived fully and without regrets.

CORRIGAN--Edward Joseph (E.J.). Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Ailey Board of Trustees, and staff mourn the passing of E.J. Corrigan, our much-loved Technical Director. E.J. made many valued contributions to Ailey's performances since joining the production team in 1988, but he most cherished his self-appointed position as "head of morale," for which he was revered. His tradition of joyous barbecues in tour cities with Ailey dancers and crew and their local counterparts, along with his adventurous spirit, will be greatly missed. Generous of heart, he once biked coast to coast to support those dealing with catastrophic illness. E.J. loved the Ailey company and enjoyed each day to the fullest. Our hearts go out to his loving daughter Ana Luisa Corrigan, and all his family and friends. For information on a memorial celebration later in the spring, or to send a note of condolence to his family, please email to: EJMemorial@alvinailey.org. Joan H. Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Dir.; Masazumi Chaya, Assoc. Artistic Dir.; Bennett Rink, Exec. Dir; Judith Jamison, Artistic Director Emerita

Klass--Sheila Solomon, died on March 26 at 86. She was professor emerita of English at Borough of Manhattan Community College, where she taught for 47 years, and a prolific writer who published 19 books. Born 1927 in Williamsburg, she attended Brooklyn College, where she worked on the college newspaper, the Vanguard. She received an MFA from the Iowa Writers' Workshop. In 1953 she married Morton Klass, who became professor of anthropology at Barnard College, Columbia University. Together they lived in Trinidad and India, as well as Bennington, VT; Leonia, NJ; and Manhattan. Her books include Come Back on Monday (1960), the memoir Everyone in this House Makes Babies (1964), Bahadur Means Hero (1969), A Perpetual Surprise (1981), In a Cold Open Field (1997); her young adult fiction includes historical novels about Louisa May Alcott, Annie Oakley, and Deborah Sampson (her very last book, Soldier's Secret, 2009). She published a joint memoir, Every Mother is a Daughter, written with her daughter, Perri, in 2006. In her eighties she began a blog (blogginggrandma.com) and attracted thousands of page views as she wrote about being a legally blind New Yorker who rode the subways by counting the stops. She continued to teach writing at BMCC through last December, and corrected student papers with a magnifying glass. She loved living and working and teaching in New York City. She will be remembered as an inspirational teacher, writer, and New Yorker by her family members, her many students, and the friends she made and kept at every stage of her long and productive life. Her brother, Arnold Solomon, died in 1950 in the Korean War; her sister, Marilyn Koster, died in 2004. Her husband, Morton Klass, died in 2001. Her determination to make writers of everyone around her is reflected in her children, all three of whom are published writers. She is survived by her children, Perri, David, and Judy, and by her grandchildren, Orlando, Josephine, Anatol, Gabriel, and Madeleine. Donations in her memory may be sent to the BMCC Foundation (199 Chambers St. FH 1330A, NY, NY 10007) with a notation directed to the English Department's Writing and Literature Program for annual awards.

MATTHIESSEN--Peter. Riverkeeper and Waterkeeper Alliance mourn the passing of Peter Matthiessen, whose eloquent writings inspired generations of environmentalists. We send heartfelt condolences to his family, especially his son Alex, our friend who has worked tirelessly in support of the Waterkeeper movement. The Board and Staff of Riverkeeper The Board and Staff of Waterkeeper Alliance

MARDER--Ira. Of Englewood, NJ, passed away on April 8, 2014. He was 94 years old. He leaves behind his beloved wife of more than 52 years, Anne, sons William and John, their wives Dominique and Valerie, as well as five grandchildren and a niece. Ira served in the Army Air Corps during World War II, when he was stationed in China, Burma and India. Ira served as the President of the Matson Manufacturing Company of Long Island City, a company founded by his father, Leo Marder. Ira also served as the President of the Englewood Community Chest, raising money for local projects. In his spare time, Ira was an avid sailor, skier and traveler. Ira will be greatly missed by his family, friends and former coworkers. Memorial services will be held at Scanlan Funeral Home in Pompton Plains, NJ on Sunday, April 13th at 2:30pm.

OBERHAUS--A. Edward Jr.,of Bronxville, NY, died April 5, at his home. Born in Hartford, CT, lived in Farmington and attended St. Thomas Seminary School. Graduated Norwich University, VT, and served two years as 1st Lt in the U.S. Armored Div. during the Korean War. In 1955, graduated Harvard Business School and worked in advertising until 1972, when he joined Kaneka America Corp..Traveled throughout the world during his 33 years at KAC and retired as Senior Vice President in 2005. After retirement, studied at the National Academy of Fine Arts. Preceded in death by his wife of 56 years, Dorothy Huff Oberhaus. Survived by his daughter Ann (Tim) Mackin, and grandchildren Kate and Sean, all of Chagrin Falls, OH. Private funeral, and a memorial at a later date.

POSNER--Marty "Saul" passed away on April 11, 2014 after a long fight with cancer. He was loved by his wife Debbie, his sons Leo, Christopher and Jonathan, their wives and his five grandchildren. He was also deeply loved by his step- children Bernard and Amy, their spouses and his four grandchildren. After many years in the men's clothing industry, he devoted himself to his lifelong love for photography. Services will be held at 1pm on Sunday, April 13, 2014 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., (at 91st St.) New York City.

MULLER--Lawrence, age 95 and one day. Beloved father, father-in-law, grandpa and great-grandpa. Giver of flang rides and "what for." A WWII vet and true Mad Man, Larry graced us with intelligence and quiet humor. He was preceded in death by his wife of 55 years, Marion. Services April 13, 12:30, Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY.

STERLING--Helen C.,92, died peacefully April 10, 2014 in Manhattan where she lived with her son, David B. Sterling, grandchildren, Liana Sterling and Alexander O. Sterling and former daughter-in-law, Nora Lavori. She also leaves her son Eric E. Sterling, daughter-in-law June Beittel, and granddaughter Maya Sterling, of Chevy Chase, MD, her brother Frederick Champnella of Florida, and devoted nieces, nephews and friends. Her husband, Bowen Sterling, companion, Jack Fox, Sr. and her sister Hazel Malone predeceased her. A coal miner's daughter, born in Kingwood, WV, Helen was a graduate of West Virginia University School of Journalism and served as editor-in-chief of the The Daily Atheneum. For nearly twenty years, she worked as a technical editor at IBM and rose to become one of its first female managers. Sound of mind and body, Helen was the exemplar of graceful aging.

WALLACE--Lois Kahn, age 73, noted literary agent, died peacefully in New York City April 4th, after a long illness. She leaves her son, George Baer Wallace, two nieces, Alexandra Wallace Creed and Sarah Wallace Deckey, and a nephew, Benjamin Wallace. A memorial service will take place later this spring.

SMITH--Gregory White, The Juilliard School wishes to express our great sadness on the passing of Gregory White Smith, a wonderful friend to the school and a very special human being. He and his life partner, Steven Naifeh, created a unique environment to support Juilliard artists in Joye Cottage, their magnificent home in Aiken, South Carolina. Greg's deep understanding and love of music were manifested most recently in performances of the Bach St. Matthew Passion that were developed through his support. We express our deepest condolences to Steve, his and Greg's families, and their many friends. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

SILVERMAN--Arthur (Arty), 96, died on Tuesday, April 8th, 2014 in Boca Raton, Florida. Services will be held on Sunday, April 13th 2014 at 10:00am at Bernheim-Apter-Kneitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston, New Jersey. Interment will be at Beth Israel Cemetery in Edison, NJ. Born and raised in Newark, New Jersey, Arty lived for many years in Warren, New Jersey before moving to Boca Raton, Florida. He was a graduate of Central High School in Newark. Coming from humble beginnings, Arty received a Boy Scout Scholarship that enabled him to fulfill his dream of going to college. He attended Newark College Of Engineering (now NJIT) where he received a degree in Mechanical Engineering. For more than 25 years, Arthur's participation in the NJIT Alumni Association, including his service as president, helped him to keep up with the latest technological developments. During his active years with the Alumni Association, he established the Silverman Scholarships, which were awarded to five NJIT students in honor NCE Dean Allen R. Cullimore, who helped him to obtain the scholarship he desperately needed to begin his undergraduate studies in 1935. In 1997 Arthur was honored with NJIT's Distinguished Alumni Medal for Outstanding Achievement. Arthur founded The Union Machine Company in 1947 which ultimately became Silver Line Building Products Corporation in 1960, a manufacturer of aluminum windows and doors. Recognizing a change in the industry, Arty and his son Ken became one of the first innovators to transition from aluminum to vinyl windows and doors. The risky move paid off as Silver Line became the largest vinyl window and door manufacturer in North America. Arty's innovative designs and engineering ability enabled him to create numerous patents which are still recognized today in the vinyl window industry. His great passion for art is demonstrated by his many accomplished sculptures. He also loved golfing, boating and travel. He leaves his wife Georgia, three children, Laurie and husband Peter Friedman, Kenneth and wife Claudia Silverman, Joan and husband Stanley Baer along with his six grandchildren, Michael, Jaclyn, Britany, Blake, Ashley, Alana and seven great-grandchildren. He also leaves behind step-daughters Wendy Chivian, Karen and her husband Michael Toback and their two children, Ella and Cara. Donations may be made in Arty's name to a charity of your choice.

SELDES--Aileen Patterson. Aileen "Lee" Patterson Seldes, died peacefully in her New York City on April 7th from complications of pneumonia. She was 85. A resident of Manhattan and Water Mill, Long Island, Lee was the eldest daughter of Margaret W. and Robert P. Patterson, the former Under Secretary of War during World War II, and Secretary of War (1945-1947) under President Harry S. Truman. Lee graduated from Radcliffe College, class of 1950. She was a reporter for Newsweek, and also wrote for Collier's, Barron's, The Village Voice and Esquire. She is the author of "The Legacy of Mark Rothko," the definitive account of the trial of the artist's heirs against Marlborough Gallery. A marriage to Timothy Seldes of New York ended in divorce. She is survived by a son, Gilbert Seldes, a daughter, Elisabeth Seldes Annacone, and a grandson, Emmett Carnahan. Also surviving are two sisters, Susan H. Patterson and Virginia P. Montgomery and a brother, Robert P. Patterson, Jr. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, April 26th, at 2pm, at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

PYN--Norma Perry, passed away peacefully on April 2, 2014. She is preceded in death by husband Wilbur W. H. Pyn, Jr. and daughter-in-law Angela Puse Pyn. Norma Perry was born in Malone, NY to Edward and Louvah Perry. A graduate of St Vincent's School of Nursing NYC, she entered the US Navy as Lt JG to care for WWII soldiers. Norma worked at the Bronx VA, and graduated from Fordham University. She married Wilbur, had five children and resided in Greenwich Village, Bay Ridge and Belle Harbor, NY. Norma was renowned for her beauty, her exceptional dancing and her outstanding patient care at the Brooklyn VA. Norma belonged to St. Francis De Sales Church in Belle Harbor where a memorial will be held later this summer. She is survived by three sisters, five children, seven grandchildren, numerous nieces and nephews, and an anticipated great-grandchild. Recently, she attended Nativity Church, Lake Mary FL where her funeral service will be held on April 26. Donations in her name to: Sisters of Charity Center 6301 Riverdale Ave Bronx NY 10471. www.scny.org

ROTH--Daniel M.D.,on April 9, 2014 in Bridgeport, CT., medical researcher, teacher, artist. Beloved husband of Roslyn, devoted father of David Roth (wife Annette), Sally Roth Zemke (husband Phillip), and adoring grandfather of Melanie, Matthew and Abigail. Interment April 10, 2014, Sharon Gardens Valhalla, NY.

RASCOFF--Dr. Joel H. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear uncle, Dr. Joel H. Rascoff. He was an extraordinary man who loved us dearly. We share the depth of this loss with our father, Joseph Rascoff, who lost his only sibling, and with our mother, Jane Rascoff, who lost a dear friend and confidante. Spencer, Brooke and Jake Rascoff

ROSENFELD--Norman, of New York, NY, died April 10. Born December 11, 1933, in New York City to Morris and Ray Rosenfeld. Predeceased in 2008 by his beloved wife of 49 years, Lee Green Rosenfeld. Survived by his sister, Phyllis Zuckman, of New Rochelle, NY; his son and daughter-in-law, Joshua Rosenfeld and Stephanie Parr of San Francisco, CA; his daughter and son-in-law, Marion Rosenfeld and Thomas H. Jones of New York City; and granddaughters Maxine, Sylvia, and Theadora. Norman was a proud graduate of the Bronx High School of Science (1951) and Pratt Institute (1956). He founded Norman Rosenfeld Architects in 1969 and was an innovator in the design of healthcare facilities, embracing a humanistic approach to creating hospital environments. He was a Fellow of the American Institute of Architects and Founding Fellow of the American College of Healthcare Architects. In his semi-retirement, he spent time mentoring young architects at Pratt and establishing The Lee and Norman Rosenfeld Award in 2010 to provide financial assistance to deserving undergraduates at the School of Architecture at Pratt Institute. A memorial service will be held in the late spring. Donations in his memory can be made to P.S. 3, The Charrette School, a progressive public school in Greenwich Village where he was a founding parent: ps3nyc.org/news/donate/donations/ or HIAS, the organization that helped settle his immigrant parents: www.hias.org/

WEBER--Judith Ruth, 76, retired librarian, died April 9. She is survived by her sister, Deborah Heller, her nephews, Jules Heller Roazen and Daniel Heller-Roazen, a grandniece and two grandnephews. We will miss her.

ROTH--Elaine, passed away on April 10, 2014. The beloved wife of Stanton F. Roth, loving mother of Glenn Roth, and Laurie and Roddy Austin, proud grandmother of Evan. She was a charitable and devoted director for the Mental llIness Foundation. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 13, 12pm, at The Riverside Chapel, NYC.

SHAWE--Irvin Burl "Big Irv," 83, passed away peacefully on April 7, 2014 in New York City after bravely fighting leukemia for the past year. He was born in Norfolk, VA on August 8, 1930, to the late Philip and Pearl Shawe. Irv was a longtime resident of Virginia and Washington, DC, he also lived in Los Angeles, CA, Palm Beach, FL, Las Vegas, NV, and finally New York City. Irv was a true entrepreneur and built many businesses including art galleries, the first of which was in the New York World's Fair. He was also a renowned real estate broker. Irv loved sports, especially football, and he shared his passion with his sons. Most recently, the family attended Super Bowl XLVIII together. Irv is survived by and will be dearly missed by his sons, Eric Shawe and his wife Dolores of West Palm Beach, FL, Larry Shawe, his wife Renee and their daughter Ava Capri of New York City and Palm Beach Gardens, FL, and Phil Shawe and his wife Joanna of New York City, his siblings, Earle K. Shawe of Baltimore, MD, Norman Schikevitz of Boynton Beach, FL, Rosalie Kolker of Bethesda, MD, Katie Klein of Chevy Chase, MD and Bette Belle Becker of Chevy Chase, MD, and his love Shirley Shawe. Irv will also be missed by his extended family and friends. Funeral services for Irv will be held on Sunday, April 13, 2014 at 12pm at the Star of David Cemetery, located at 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, the Shawe family kindly asks that modest donations are made to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society in Irv's honor via the following website: http://www.crowdrise.com/ InMemoryofBigIrv/ fundraiser/shawefamily

WELTMAN--Edward S.,64, left this world peacefully on April 4, 2014 in Sarasota, FL in the loving care of his daughter, Alexandra, and the staff of Neuro International, following a battle with dementia and Alzheimer's. A retired lawyer formerly of New York and California, Ed lived his life fully and displayed great passion both in the courtroom and in the pursuit of his many personal interests. Predeceased by his parents, Paul and Jean, he is survived by his three daughters, brother, two nieces, and many others whose lives he touched in a variety of ways. Private memorial service to be held in East Hampton, NY at a later date. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or charity of your choice.

KROLL--Douglas 7/67 4/8/02 Forever and always a blessing in all our lives. We miss and love you-- Mom, Pamela, family and friends.
SMITH--David Shiverick, April 13, 2012. Two years have passed. My heart and mind are comforted by memories of your love and courage. Forever Your Mary

GOLDHAMMER--Robert Frederick, died peacefully at home on March 31, 2014. Funeral service will take place at 3:00pm on Wednesday April 30th in the Grosvenor Chapel, 24 South Audley Street, London.
HOROWITZ--Isadore, We could not have asked for a more dedicated and compassionate doctor. He is forever in our hearts. Pearl and Maurice Goetz

LEE--Sally White, 81, of Spring Island, South Carolina and Prouts Neck, Maine died peacefully at home in Maine on April 9, 2014. She was born to the late Sally Sprague Kirkland and Ogden White in New York City on July 3, 1932. Sally graduated from the Foxcroft School in 1950 and from Briarcliff College in 1952. She married Charles C. Lee Jr., who survives her, on June 27, 1953 and had celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary last year. Sally is lovingly remembered by her four children and their spouses: Sally L. Swift and her husband Edward of Carlisle, MA; Diana L. Hammond and her husband Peter of Perth, Australia; Lucy L. LaCasse and her husband William of Scarborough, ME; and Charles C. Lee III and his wife Eliza of Philadelphia, PA. She is also survived by 11 grandchildren and one great-grandchild; her two sisters, Patsy W. Timpson and Alexandra W. Smith; her brother Ogden White; and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Sally and Charlie lived in Far Hills, New Jersey for 43 years until moving to Spring Island, SC in 1998. Sally spent every summer of her life in Prouts Neck, Maine, a place she loved dearly. Sally was an avid birder who loved nature, travel, and spending time with her family. She had served on various boards, including Far Hills Country Day School, New Jersey Audubon, Prouts Neck Audubon Society, and the Prouts Neck Sanctuary. She and Charlie took over 50 trips to all seven continents, all of which were documented in Sally's colorful travel journals. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Sally's memory to Prouts Neck Audubon Society, 499 Black Point Road, Scarborough, ME 04074 or the Spring Island Trust Foundation, 40 Mobley Oaks Lane, Okatie, SC 29909. A memorial service is planned for early summer in Prouts Neck, Maine.

FARTHING--Charles F.,M.D. age 60, died suddenly on April 5, 2014 in Hong Kong of an acute myocardial infarction. Born April 22, 1953, Charles was raised and educated in Christchurch, New Zealand. From there, he embarked on a world-wide journey of work and travel. Always the gentleman, scholar, diplomat and healer, Charles made many places his home including London, New York, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and Hong Kong. Charles received many honors and accolades for his patient care, teaching and academic accomplishments. He was predeceased by his loving parents, and is survived by his devoted partner Dougie Lui, his adoring brother Bruce and sister-in-law Kay and nieces Kathryn, Lizzy, Sonja, and Helaina, as well as many devoted friends, colleagues, and patients that span the continents. Burial will occur April 22, 2014 in Christchurch. Memorial services for Charles are being planned in his home cities of New York, Los Angeles, Hong Kong and London. All who knew him will sorely miss his kind and gentle presence.

GOLDSTEIN--Rebecca, died peacefully April 12, 2014, age 96. Predeceased by her beloved husband William (Bill), dear sisters Mary Brenner and Lillian Edelberg. KASEN--Leonard, M.D.,82, passed away peacefully on April 10. Dearly loved husband of Vivian, father of Raphael, future father-in-law of Rebecca and brother of Anita, he was a highly regarded pediatrician who practiced in Riverdale, NY. He was devoted to his patients and loved by his community. He will be greatly missed. Service: Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, Sunday, April 13, 9:30am, 475 W. 250 St, Riverdale, NY.

MOSKOWITZ--Mildred R.,Age 91, on April 6, 2014 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Sydney M. Moskowitz for 42 wonderful years. Loving and devoted mother to Michael and Naomi. Loving daughter of Nathan and Gertrude Reback and loving sister of Maurice. She was a caring Psychotherapist with a successful practice of over 40 years dedicated to the well being of her patients. During her tenure as an Adjunct Professor in the doctoral program at Smith College School for Social Work and NYU School of Social Work she was fiercely committed to her students. She was passionate in support of a just cause and the advancement of our better nature. She loved dancing, writing about her life experiences, swimming in the ocean which she considered to be her personal lap pool, the performing arts, playing her piano and spending time with her children. Her family, friends, colleagues and students will remember Millie for her humor, directness, compassion, insight, wisdom and most importantly her love of life. A private memorial celebration of her life will be held on Saturday, April 19, 2014.

DJURIC--Radovan Lale, extraordinary man, father and friend has passed after a valiant battle. He remains a force of nature. His creativity expressed through his art is only surpassed by his commitment to the youth and culture of his native Serbia, where he will be laid to rest. He leaves behind his son, William "Vuk" Djuric, his former wife Marlene Baragano, and a world of friends. A service will be held Sunday from 5 to 7pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan.

He was also deeply loved by his step- children Bernard and Amy, their spouses and his four grandchildren.
