Services will be held at 1pm on Sunday, April 13, 2014 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., (at 91st St.) New York City.

PLUM--Carol Houston, Died April 9, 2014. Born Seattle November 16, 1954. Graduate of Chapin School and Smith College. Predeceased by her parents Dr. Fred Plum and Jean Houston Plum, she is survived by her stepmother Susan Plum and brothers Michael Frederick Plum and Christopher Plum. Travel and bird life were her passions. Family to receive friends, Sunday, April 13, 2014, 5-7pm at Frank Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, NY, NY 10028.

PIEROT--Elsie "Bunny", (Elsie Pell Guion Pierot), the beloved matriarch of the Pierot family, died on April 3 at Greenwich Hospital with her four children, Robert Pierot, Catherine Zicherman, Ted Pierot and Felicia Brody, as well as daughter Julie in spirit, by her side. She was born in 1933, the only child of Elsie Pell and Floyd Guion. Her amazing, shining spirit transformed the lives of those she met. She had an unrelenting humour and passion for living. A jewelry artist, her work was displayed at museums in New York City and Connecticut. For over forty years she was founder and president of The Resale Company, an estate sales specialist. Bunny's extraordinary sensibilities never allowed the glue to dry in our love and support of one another as her family and extended family and also with her great eclectic circle of friends around her. Her loving, positive values will live on in all of us. Bunny's legacy will live on in her grandchildren Penelope and Melanie Brody, Olivia, Cecily and Spencer Choi, Dustin Ziegler, George and Isabel Pierot, Elizabeth Welch, Christopher, Phillip, Nicholas and Sophie-Charlotte Chen and her great-granddaughter Bella Grace D'Archangelo. She wanted to be everywhere all the time for everyone and now she is. Contributions may be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.
PERPER--Ellen. I will miss your beauty, intellect and many kindnesses. Rest in peace, dear friend. Ruth Weisgal
GREENGRASS--Ken. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Ken Greengrass. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

JACOBS--Howard. Howard Jacobs passed away on April 2, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife Ruth, their two sons, Kenneth and David, and six grandchildren. Howard held a lifetime commitment to education, community service and the arts. He was born in the Bronx on May 31, 1928, to Doris and Max Jacobs. A graduate of DeWitt Clinton High School, he earned a BA from the State University of New York at Brockport and a Master's in Education from Columbia University. After serving in the U.S. Army in the Korean War, Howard began his 30-year career in education as a teacher. He was involved with the planning of Woodlands High School in Hartsdale, NY, where he became the assistant principal. He later was the principal of Highland Falls (NY) High School, and for 15 years was the principal of Ramapo High School in Spring Valley, NY. He also served on the Board of Education for the Greenburgh, NY School District. He retired from education in 1985 to dedicate himself fully to serving his community and to enjoying the arts and travel. A passionate believer in the importance of reading and libraries, Howard led the expansion, construction and enhancement of the new Greenburgh Public Library, as Chair of the Board of Trustees. He discovered the art of photography late in life, and co-founded the Westchester Amateur Photography Contest. One of his greatest joys was music. He was an accomplished trombonist, a big band leader in college and a lifelong jazz lover. At the age of 80, he picked up a new instrument, the banjo, and proudly participated in the Dixieland Express Jazz Band of Westchester County.

NEWALL--Loraine P. 1915-2014. Wife of Arthur, mother of Leslie, William, Holly. Longtime Unitarian, fearless world traveler, and independent thinker, she is remembered for her wit, spirit of adventure, and unshakable belief in the goodness of humankind. We loved her.

GROSSMAN--Mordecai William, of Westport, CT, better known as Bill, passed on March 25, 2014 at the age of 87. Born in Boston, MA, to Helen (nee Kaplan) and Rabbi Benjamin Grossman, Mr. Grossman was an active graduate of the Boston Latin School, Harvard (Class of 1949 Phi Beta Kappa) and Hebrew Teachers College. Following a successful career in the entertainment industry as a principal owner of Lynne Broadcasting, Bill became a major syndicator of real estate founding Nutmeg Real Estate & Nutmeg Financial Services. Mr. Grossman also served on the Board of Directors of Goodwill Industries as well as serving as President and Chairman of the building campaign for Temple Beth-El and remained a fixture of its daily minyan. Bill was laid to rest next to his beloved daughter, Danielle who predeceased him in 1983. He is survived by his wife Adrienne of 27 years, their children and grandchildren, and the children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren of his brothers, the late Rabbi Herman and Joseph Grossman

KURNOW--Ernest. The NYU Stern community mourns the loss of its beloved professor, Ernest Kurnow, who died April 7th. He celebrated his 101st birthday in October 2013. A recipient of NYU's Great Teacher Award, he taught statistics for more than 60 years, last as an adjunct in 2010. Former Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan was his student. Prof. Kurnow created the Statistics Department at NYU Stern and chaired it from 1963 until 1975, a period in which the School focused on building full-time, research-based MBA and PhD programs. He recruited many of the School's most prominent professors. His path-breaking book, "Statistics for Business Decisions," changed the way the subject was taught by introducing sampling procedures to basic statistics. Ernie was born in Brooklyn in 1912 and received his BA and MA in mathematics from New York City College in 1932 and 1933, respectively. Before joining NYU, he worked at the WPA; the Aberdeen Proving Ground, the military base in Maryland where important innovations in computing and the application of statistical quality control were developed; and the New York City Board of Education. Those who had the good fortune to know Ernie also know how much he will be missed. The family has asked that those interested in honoring his legacy donate to the Ernest Kurnow Fellowship c/o NYU Stern, 44 West 4th St., Suite 10-46, NY, NY 10012.

MILLER--Edwin B.,("Big Ed" or "Eddie" to many), passed away on Wednesday, April 9, 2014 at the age of 82 at his home in Boca Raton, Florida. Ed was born on June 18, 1931 to Herman and Ruth Miller, and was raised in New Rochelle, NY with his sister Elaine. Following two years in the NBA with the Baltimore Bullets, Ed had a successful career in the toy business for over 40 years, culminating in the establishment of his own partnership, Miller-Sperber, Inc. Ed is survived by his loving wife of 44 years, Helaine Miller along with their son Richard and his sister Elaine Newman. Friends and family will best remember Ed for his sharp wit, sense of humor, and charmingly gregarious nature.

DEMING--Donald L.,passed away on April 9, 2014 at his retirement home in Fort Myers, FL. He was 89 and succumbed to lung cancer. Don was born on July 30, 1924 in Ahmednager, India where his parents, Wilbur and Elsie had been missionaries for many years. Don, his siblings Mary and Bill, and his parents returned from India in 1934 and settled in Washington, CT where his father served as the Congregational minister. Don attended the Gunnery School, graduating in 1941. He entered Yale University that fall. World War II intervened and Don enlisted in the Army in 1942. He joined a tank unit, was sent to Europe and served in Alsace and Germany with the United States Seventh Army. He returned to Yale, graduated in 1947, and was awarded a Phi Beta Kappa key. Subsequently, Don went to Yale Law School. After graduation in 1950, he joined the firm of Chadbourne & Parke, New York City. He remained with the firm for over forty years as a corporate lawyer. He did work for a variety of clients and retired in 1992, after having been the senior partner of the firm for the last few years. Don is survived by Meleanor, his wife of 62 years; three sons, David, James and Robert; their spouses, Jamie, Sharon and Burnedette; five grandchildren, Peter, Julia, Meredith, Emily, and Logan; and their spouses, Jessica (Peter) and Eric Vaughn (Julia); and one great-grandchild, Kate Deming. A family graveside service will be held at a later date.

HOLLANDER--Zander (Alexander), died peacefully on April 11th at the Jewish Home Life Care NH from Alzheimer's Disease. Always a sports writer, editor, and book packager starting with covering High School Sports, then skiing, boating, and tennis for the New York World Telegram and Sun. He was a WWII veteran writing for Brief Magazine. More a loving husband, father and family man. He cherished his time at his Indian Lake home where he would chop wood, shoot hoops, go out on the lake, grill and care for his property. Survived by his dedicated wife Phyllis of 62 years, daughter Susan (Neil), grandchildren Tobye and Emma, sister-in-law Davee Israel, nieces and nephews and Charlestown, SC family. Predeceased by his companion and loving son Peter. Donations to the Dementia Unit 5th floor Friedman-Jewish Home Life Care, Manhattan Division. Memorial Service April 27, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 180 West 76th St., NY, NY.

MORGAN--Ellen Jane (Byrne), born May 16, 1940 in Brooklyn, NY. Died April 7, 2014 at her home New York City. Daughter of the late Joseph and Millicent (Kyle) Byrne, she is survived by her beloved son, Peter, his wife Beth, and her cherished grandson Samuel Francis, of Franklin, MA. She is also survived by her cousins Jack Byrne and Susan Strauss and their families, along with countless friends, neighbors and colleagues. She was a graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute and Hood College, and just recently retired after more than 40 years as a Real Estate Broker. She was an avid reader, loved cooking, quoting poetry and her ever evolving menagerie of animals. She loved traveling and spent time between Mexico, Manhattan and Shelter Island. A memorial service will be held at a later date to honor her and her amazing life. Donations in her memory may be made to her favorite animal charity: Frankie's Friends, 2950 Busch Lake Blvd, Tampa FL 33614.

ESTESS--Gene. June 1, 1935-April 9, 2014. Gene lived life to the fullest. He was an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. While he was a broker on Wall Street for many years, his real passion was the work he did as Executive Director for 20 years at the Jericho Project, a nonprofit organization that provided permanent housing and wraparound services for formerly homeless substance abusers. He leaves behind the love of his life, his wife, Pat Schiff Estess, and children who he inspired and who will treasure his memory forever, Noah Estess (Patrice), Andrea Wohl (Eric Silverman), Peter Wohl (Kate Breslin) and Jen Wohl. His grandchildren, who adored him and his sense of humor, Jonah and Paloma Estess, Sam and Zoe Silverman, Elias and Jordan Wohl and Aidan Wohl. He also leaves his sister Barbara Leber of Potomic, Maryland. In memory of Gene, contributions can be made to the Jericho Project or the Visiting Nurses Association of New York.

HERTZ--Theodore, of White Plains, New York, passed away on April 11, 2014, at the age of 105. Born in Czechoslovakia, he was the son of Sally and Jacob Hertz. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Selma and 11 brothers and sisters. He is survived by his children, Rosalind Hertzog, Sharon Spotnitz and Jeffrey Hertz and by his sons-in-law, David Hertzog and Henry Spotnitz, and his daughter in law, Brenda Koblick. Cherished grandfather of Adam (Hope), Lauren (James), Michelle (Joe), Matthew, Shana (Daniel), and Ari and of three great-granddaughters, Chloe, Emily, and Lily. We will all miss him. Donations may be made to Hadassah.

MACLAIRE--Arthur Scott, died April 10, 2014. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Survived by wife Caroline, daughters Andrea Falgoust, Debra Kaufman/Goldstein (Steven), Stephanie Garten (Steven) and grandchildren Brittney Segal, Taylor Falgoust, Jared Garten, Gabrielle Garten, Jessie Garten and Jacob Goldstein. Resident of Boca Raton, FL. A former resident of Merrick, LI and Manhattan. Graduated from Stuyvesant High School and North Carolina State University. Funeral today 1pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. He will be missed by all.

EZRATTY--Dorothy Danowitz, 75, died Wednesday. She was loved by her husband Bernie, her son Martin and his wife Bari, her daughter Michelle and her husband Richie. Cherished by her grandchildren Jennifer, Adam, Melinda and Carly. Dorothy will always be remembered for her smile, laughter and thoughtfulness towards others. She will always live and be loved forever and a day - and then some - through eternity. Dorothy's finally at peace and resting peacefully. Amen! Services by Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY.

HOFFMAN--Geraldine Dorothy Paradise, died Sunday, March 16, 2014 after a long and extraordinary life. Her beloved brother Mel preceded her in 2006. Geri leaves behind her younger brother, Harvey. Love and kisses go with her. Sweet good-byes Geraldine.

MARONEY--Louise S.,on April 9, 2014. Beloved wife of the late John, cherished mother of Susan, sister of the late Robert Sides and aunt to many nieces and nephews. She will be remembered for her incredible spirit, sharp intellect, fierce loyalty and her completely unique sense of humor. Services will be private. As per her wishes, donations can be made in her memory to Marymount School of New York, 1026 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10028; Attention Samantha Hanley.

COLLINS--William 89, predeceased by Doris, loving wife of 65 years. Loved by children Michael (Elise), Paul (Beth), Susan (Tom). Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Proud graduate of the US Naval Academy and RPI. An accomplished Civil Engineer whose devotion and humor will be greatly missed.

BLANK--Curtis E.,of New York, NY and Bal Harbour, FL, an accomplished businessman, sportsman, local politician and restaurateur passed away in Long Beach, CA on April 10, 2014. Curtis attended DeWitt Clinton High School and Penn's Wharton School, Philadelphia. At Penn, Curtis once pitched a no-hitter versus arch rival Princeton. His college career was interrupted by WWII, and he joined the Army Air Corp as a Navigation Instructor. That year, he met his future wife, Marcia Rosen of Baltimore. In 1946, he completed his degree at Penn. Curtis and Marcia settled in NYC, where their son and daughter were born. Curtis held executive positions with Fortune 500 Companies and NBC before entering the restaurant business. As co-owner of the world renowned Cafe Chauveron in Manhattan, Curtis oversaw its rise to prominence as one of only eight 5-Star Mobil Guide Restaurants in the US, eventually relocating with Chefs A. Heinz and M. Challamel to Bay Harbour Island, FL, again attaining the highest Mobil Guide Ranking. Later, Curtis became a food and dining consultant, was interviewed by Larry King and kept his interest in sport via golf and rooting for his beloved NY Yankees. He is survived by his son, Michael (Deidre), daughter Karen (Tim), and four grandchildren. Services are planned for Arlington National Cemetery. Donations welcome: Penn Fund of the University of Pennsylvania.

COLLINS--Doris, 84, loved by husband Bill, children Michael (Elise), Paul (Beth), Susan (Tom). Adored by eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A special lady loved by all lucky to have known her.

BIRNBAUM--Jacob. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Jacob Birnbaum, a Jewish activist and founder of the Student Struggle for Soviet Jewry, a grassroots group built around a core of teachers and students at Yeshiva University which worked vigorously to persuade the US government to become the protector and rescuer of Soviet Jewry. His group's efforts together with leaders of the Jewish community eventually inspired the late Senator Harry Jackson and Representative Charles Vanik to introduce the famous Jackson-Vanik Amendment to the 1974 Trade Act which denied most Favored Nation trading status to Communist Regimes which restricted emigration. His accomplishments in 60 years of selfless service to the Jewish people were recognized when he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters (DHL) degree from Yeshiva University at the 76th Commencement Exercises on May 17, 2007. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Frida B. Birnbaum and his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus

COTLER--Jerome M.,M.D. Dr. Jerome M. Cotler, 85, formerly of Haddon Heights and Bridgeton, NJ, passed away peacefully at his home in Voorhees, NJ on April 10, 2014 surrounded by his loving family. Dr. Cotler was Director of Orthopaedic Surgery and Orthopaedic Residency Program at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital (TJUH). He served as President of the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery and Vice President of the American Orthopaedic Association. He was also the Dr. Everett J. and Marian Gordon Professor of Orthopaedic Surgery at TJUH. Not only was Dr. Cotler a renowned surgeon, he was also a researcher and an academic, co-authoring numerous clinical research papers and orthopaedic textbooks. His numerous honors and awards included the J. Aiken Meigs Medical Society and the American Spinal Injury Association's Lifetime Achievement Award. Above all, his warmth and gentle demeanor will be missed by patients, students, family and friends alike. He will be remembered for his hard work, positive attitude, soft-spoken manner, sense of humor, love of family, and above all, his passion for making a difference. Dr. Cotler is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Florence Dion Cotler; his children Dr. Howard Cotler (Susan), Michele Bronkesh (Noah); grandchildren Mitchell and Amanda Cotler, Laura Bronkesh Weinberg (Jeremy), Elizabeth Bronkesh; and great-grandson Jacob Weinberg. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting donations in memory of Dr. Jerome M. Cotler to the Parkinson's and Movement Disorders Program at Thomas Jefferson University and Hospitals to further MSA Research. Please make checks payable to Jefferson Foundation, 125 S. 9th St., Suite 700, Philadelphia, PA 19107 or donate online at: http://connect.jefferson.edu/ makeagift. Platt Memorial Chapels, Cherry Hill, NJ

BENKARD--James W.B. The Board and staff of Environmental Defense Fund mourn the passing of our long-time trustee. His contributions to our organization were enormous and we will be forever grateful for his over 30 years of service and support. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Peggy and his family. Carl Ferenbach, Chairman Fred Krupp, President

CORRIGAN--Edward Joseph (E.J.). Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, the Ailey Board of Trustees, and staff mourn the passing of E.J. Corrigan, our much-loved Technical Director. E.J. made many valued contributions to Ailey's performances since joining the production team in 1988, but he most cherished his self-appointed position as "head of morale," for which he was revered. His tradition of joyous barbecues in tour cities with Ailey dancers and crew and their local counterparts, along with his adventurous spirit, will be greatly missed. Generous of heart, he once biked coast to coast to support those dealing with catastrophic illness. E.J. loved the Ailey company and enjoyed each day to the fullest. Our hearts go out to his loving daughter Ana Luisa Corrigan, and all his family and friends. For information on a memorial celebration later in the spring, or to send a note of condolence to his family, please email to: EJMemorial@alvinailey.org. Joan H. Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Dir.; Masazumi Chaya, Assoc. Artistic Dir.; Bennett Rink, Exec. Dir; Judith Jamison, Artistic Director Emerita

BIDDLE--Virginia, M.D.,of Blue Hill, ME, formerly of Woods Hole, MA, died peacefully on March 28th, after a long illness. She was born in Milton, MA on July 4th, 1929, daughter of Virginia Morris Biddle and Nicholas Biddle. Virginia became a medical technician and went to Nagasaki as medical director of a research lab for the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission. At age 31, she was accepted by Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. In 1967, she opened her own practice in Woods Hole, MA and became medical director of the Falmouth Nursing Home and Director of Continuing Medical Education at Falmouth Hospital. In 1991, Virginia moved to Blue Hill, ME; she practiced in Ellsworth and retired in 2006. Virginia ("Ginny") had numerous, widely varying interests. She was an expert equestrian, skier, sailor and a lifelong devotee of wooden boats. An avid reader, Ginny also loved gardening, lobster fishing, photography, creative writing, birds and animals . . . a true Renaissance woman. She was an extremely competent physician, and her priority was always her patients. Virginia is survived by sisters Katharine More of Sharon, VT; Elizabeth Barrett of Dover, MA; brother Nicholas Biddle, Jr, of Temecula, CA and eight nieces and nephews. For years, family flocked to Blue Hill to share the adventures of this beloved sister/aunt/cousin for whom we grieve. A service will be held at the First Congregational Church of Blue Hill on May 9, at 3pm. Donations may be made to The Peninsula Ambulance Corp of Blue Hill or The Bagaduce Music Lending Library, PO Box 829, Blue Hill, ME 04614.

ADLER--Jacqueline. February 12, 1926-April 6, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Harold. We will forever miss the love our devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother bestowed upon us always. Stacee, Jeff, Ryan & Ben Bernstein; Iane, Steven & Jennifer Deutsch; Allie, Matt, Rylan & Bryce Ammerman

BARKIN--Bernice W.,of Fairfield, CT. Age 91, passed away peacefully on April 7. Wife of the late Herbert. Mother of Joel and Samuel. Sister, sister-in-law, aunt, grandmother and great-grandmother. She departed this life as she lived it, with dignity.

WOLF--Edith W.,"Edie" age 93 Died April 11, 2014. Born in New York, NY February 5th 1921. She graduated from Mt. Holyoke College in 1943. Following graduation she married Richard B. Wolf in October 1943 before he left for service in the Pacific as a 2nd Lt. in the Army Air Force. Upon his return in 1945 they moved to Worcester, MA where he went into the textile business. Edie worked in retail advertising as a copywriter for a department store before joining the League of Women Voters of Worcester, MA where she served as its president for four years. In 1952 she organized volunteers for Stevenson and campaigned actively for Adlai Stevenson. As a result of her civic activities she was awarded a Public Achievement award from the University of MA, Amherst, in 1960. In 1962, Edie and her husband moved to Coral Gables, FL where he went into business. She worked as a volunteer social worker for the American Red Cross for over 15 years and received an Emergency Survival award for assisting military personnel and their families in times of crisis. Edie was a lover of the outdoors and sports; she was an avid golfer and tennis player. She will be remembered by her family and friends for her generosity, kindness and warmth. Predeceased by her brother, John F. Wilson of NYC, she leaves her devoted husband Richard B. Wolf, brother-in-law Dr. Charles Wolf (Theresa) of Brentwood, CA, nephews Timothy Wolf (Mary) of Boulder, CO, Ted Wolf (Frank) of NYC and grandnephews. Funeral services are private. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, April 16th, 2014 at The Coral Gables Country Club from 6pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The American Red Cross of Greater Miami and the Keys, 335 SW 27th Ave., Miami, FL 33135 or the charity of your choice.

ROVIT--Barbara,The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi David E. Levy, Assistant Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

MATTHEISSEN--Peter. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Peter Matthiessen, an explorer and great literary champion for wildlife, vast wild places and for the peoples whose livelihoods are reliant on the natural world. Peter brought critical and keen insights into conservation and environmentalism, catalyzing action and wonder for wildlife in America and across the globe. We will always be honored that Peter served on the WCS Board of Trustees and supported our work for decades. Peter's literary works will continue to inspire and guide us for many generations to come. We extend our sympathies to Peter's family.

KRIPKE--Myer S.,Retired Rabbi Emeritus Beth El Synagogue, Omaha, Nebraska. Survived by son, Saul A. Kripke, daughter, Madeline F. Kripke, son-in-law Yossi Stern, grandson and wife Gil and Brandi Stern, granddaughter Tamar Stern, and great-grandsons Benjamin and Ari Stern. Wife Dorothy deceased in September 2000, daughter Netta Stern, deceased in March 2011. And many nieces and nephews.

KRIPKE--Myer S.,"My rabbi" is the greatest compliment a rabbi can earn. My Rabbi, Myer S. Kripke, Bible scholar, philanthropist, and beloved friend of our family, will forever live in our hearts. May his memory always be a blessing and a comfort to Linnie, Saul, Yossi and the Kripke family. Ron Wolfson President Kripke Institute

APPEL--Valentine, of Big Canoe in Jasper, Georgia, and former long time resident of New York, died Saturday morning, April 12, 2014. Val died in his home, at the age of 88, after a lengthy struggle with heart disease. Val was born on February 13, 1926 in the Bronx, New York. He was the only child of Valentine Appel, Sr. and Adolfine Pelzl-Appel. His parents were of German descent, which allowed Valentine to become fluent in the German language as a child. Valentine grew up in the Bronx and he learned alpine skiing in Van Cortland Park. His ability to ski and his command of the German language served him well while fighting the Germans as an infantryman in Northern Italy during World War II with the US Army 10th Mountain Division. Valentine was wounded twice during World War II and was awarded the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Cluster for gallantry during combat action in the North Apennines Po Valley in Italy. He took part in the liberation of Florence, Italy from the Germans. Following his honorable discharge from the US Army after World War II, Valentine went onto college and graduate school under the GI Bill, earning a PhD in Industrial Psychology from New York University. Val had a long and distinguished career in the media and market research industry, working for Benton & Bowles, Ford Motor Company and Ted Bates. Valentine was involved in advertising from the very infancy of television and media research. He conducted extensive research studies on viewer ad recognition recall of TV commercials. Those standards of effective advertising frequency are used by the media industry today. During the course of his career, Valentine formed his own company, AHF Marketing Research, which he later sold to Columbia Pictures. The media research company that he founded is still in business. For a number of years, Val served as President of the Advertising Research Foundation. He also worked for Simmons Market Research Bureau, conducting syndicated and proprietary media and market research studies for the magazine industry. At the end of his career, Valentine started Appel Advertising Research whose primary clients included the Wall Street Journal and National Enquirer. Just days before his death, Valentine celebrated the birth of his first great-grandchild, Ian Valentine Wilson and his 63rd wedding anniversary with his wife Patricia. Valentine is survived by his wife Patricia Fisher Appel, daughters, Suzanne Appel Wilson, Jasper, Georgia, Marguerite Appel Gardner, Weaverville, North Carolina, sons Gregory V. Appel, Port Jervis, New York and William Appel, Woodstock, Georgia, plus four grandsons and one great-grandson. Funeral with Military Honors will take place on Tuesday, April 15, 2014 at 10am at the Roper Funeral Home and Crematory, Jasper, GA.

KOVAR--Lester J.,died on April 9, 2014 at age 98. Dear brother of Philip, husband of the late Mariann, father of Rabbi Shelley Kovar Becker (Marty), and Lance (Galina), grandfather of Sophia. A graduate of CCNY, he was a WWII veteran trained by the Navy at Notre Dame, Northwestern University, and at the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis. Commissioned an Ensign, he rose to Lieutenant Commander, serving on several aircraft carriers in the South Pacific. During that time he took part in 19 battle engagements (two Unit Citations) and he was also awarded the Pacific Theatre Ribbon with Seven Stars. Les was a highly successful advertising executive in the "Mad Men" era with Goodren Products, specialists in print media and point-of-purchase design and was listed in Sales Executives of New York Who's Who. He was a past President of Riverdale Temple (Bronx, NY) and its Men's Club as well as active in Israel Bonds, B'nai B'rith, UJA and other Jewish organizations. He was also a past president of a fraternal organization, Lipsonian Kinsmen, Inc. Also survived by beloved wife Sylvia Klein Paff Kovar, he will be missed by the Paff and Konigsberg families: Bonnie and Bob, Jonathan, Ami, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, who gave him years of abundant comfort and support. The funeral service is at Riverdale Temple on Thursday April 17 at 11:30am. Observing Jewish tradition, no flowers. Donations may be made to RAC.org or GSJC.org.

CHASKEL--Kim, of New York passed away on Friday, March 28, 2014. She was the wife of William Dalasio and the daughter of Walter and Jacqueline (Kirk) Chaskel of Huntington, NY. Born January 6, 1963, she received a bachelor's degree in Theater from Sarah Lawrence College. Kim also held a master-level certification in neuro-linguistic programming and was a level II reiki practitioner. Her work on stage included acting in several significant roles in various regional and off-Broadway. Kim was a published poet and playwright. A memorial service will be held for Kim at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship of Huntington on April 26, 2014 at 1pm.

FRANKEL--Leon, 86, passed away on April 11, 2014. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Beryl Bynoe Frankel, his son Adam, as well as his granddaughters, Eastlyn and Ava, his two nephews, his niece, as well as his three great-nephews. Leon was born in 1927 in Scranton, PA but spent most of his life in Manhattan, and he graduated from The Bronx High School of Science and Hunter College. He spent the bulk of his career at what is now Verizon, retiring after 23 years as a Systems Analyst. He was a true New Yorker, with an unquenchable love of learning, travel and family, which allowed him to enrich all who knew him. He happily lived his life on his own terms. A celebration of his life will be held on Thursday, April 17, 11am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 2nd Avenue, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to The New York Public Library.

FISCHER--Rev. James J.,S.J., on April 11,2014. Former President of St. Peter's Prep in Jersey City, Regis High School in Manhattan and McQuaid Jesuit in Rochester, Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Tuesday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass in Fordham University Church on Wednesday 10:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the NY Province, Society of Jesus, 39 East 83rd St., NY, NY 10028. For information contact Farenga Brothers, Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500.

KELSON--Irma, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by loved ones on Thursday April 10, 2014 at the age of 83. Born in New York City in 1930, she was a Long Branch resident since 1998 and previously lived in Monmouth Beach, NJ, and Deal Park, NJ. She was the youngest of two siblings, and was married for 57 years to Max Kelson, who predeceased her in 2009. A beautiful woman with a love for life, Irma Kelson had numerous interests including her active contributions to the community. She previously served on Boards of organization including the Arthritis Foundation of Monmouth County, Temple Beth El Sisterhood, Deal Hadassah, and Deborah Hospital - Deal/Long Branch Chapter. She was a licensed real estate agent for more than 30 years and was affiliated with G&G Realtors, Deal, NJ. Her avid hobbies included real estate and playing bridge, as well as enjoying the many restaurants in the area for a meal with friends and family. She is survived by two daughters, Laura Kelson of Monmouth Beach, NJ, and Diane Rosen (Lou) of Chevy Chase, Maryland, and her three grandchildren, Adam, Justin, and Nina. She will be missed eternally by all who knew and loved her.

KAPLAN--Lillian, nee Jaffe, of Harrison, NY, 92 years young, died April 12th, 2014. Devoted wife of Saul, who predeceased her, sister of Miriam Shein, beloved mother of Susan and Howard Essner; Arlene and Ira Lewis; Diane and Peter Lampack; adoring grandmother (Nana) of Gary, Missy, Jeffrey and Lisa, Marc, Debra and Steve, and Andrew; great-grandmother extraordinaire of Ariela, Jacob, Dean, Candace, Mollie, Danny, Belvina, John, Miranda, Eden, Riley and Daisy. We thank you for your priceless legacy of Love! You are forever in our hearts.

MORGANSTEIN--Helen, nee Greenberger, born 1917, left the party April 12, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Alex Morganstein. Survived by children Joan Morganstein (Cooper) and Sanford Morganstein, son-in-law Sheldon Cooper and daughter in law Monica Sabo, grandchildren Douglas, Eric, Mara and Laura Mlyn, Jace and Tyler Morganstein, five great-grandchildren. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to charity of choice.

MORGAN--Ellen Jane (Byrne), born May 16, 1940 in Brooklyn, NY. Died April 7, 2014 at her home New York City. Daughter of the late Joseph and Millicent (Kyle) Byrne, she is survived by her beloved son, Peter, his wife Beth, and her cherished grandson Samuel Francis, of Franklin, MA. She is also survived by her cousins Jack Byrne and Susan Strauss and their families, along with countless friends, neighbors and colleagues. She was a graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute and Hood College, and just recently retired after more than 40 years as a Real Estate Broker. She was an avid reader, loved cooking, quoting poetry and her ever evolving menagerie of animals. She loved traveling and spent time between Mexico, Manhattan and Shelter Island. A memorial service will be held at a later date to honor her and her amazing life. Donations in her memory may be made to her favorite animal charity: Frankie's Friends, 2950 Busch Lake Blvd, Tampa FL 33614.

KIRSCH--Robert "Bobby", Larger than life. Adored patriarch who placed Abby and his family above all else. Loyal and loving friend. Embraced life to the fullest, with boundless enthusiasm and unshakeable optimism. Commander in Chief. World traveled. Son of Dartmouth. An eclectic gourmand whose taste ranged from caviar and truffles to peanut butter and jelly. Will be joyfully remembered, and loved. Paula and Mel, and family

MARCUS--Howard W. The board and staff of American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev are profoundly saddened by the passing of Dr. Howard Marcus, a mensch and visionary philanthropist. Together with his wife, Lottie Marcus, Howard made a significant impact on Israel's Negev region through his magnanimous support of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev (BGU). In 2004, he and Lottie were awarded honorary doctoral degrees by BGU in recognition of their pioneering spirit, exceptional generosity and dedication to higher education. The Marcus Family Campus in Beer-Sheva reflects the commitment of Howard's family to the University and to the fulfillment of David Ben-Gurion's vision to build a world-class institution of education and research in the Negev desert. Their pledged legacy gift will make a dramatic impact on the development and growth of the University for generations to come. Howard will be sorely missed. We extend our profound condolences to Lottie, his beloved wife of almost 72 years; to his daughter, Ellen Marcus; his son-in-law, Harvey Malyn; his granddaughter Jennifer Kaplan; and to all those who have been touched by Howard's benevolent and enriching life. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lloyd Goldman, President Ruth Flinkman-Marandy, Regional Campaign Chair Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President Philip Gomperts, Regional Director

PYN--Norma Perry, passed away peacefully on April 2, 2014. She is preceded in death by husband Wilbur W. H. Pyn, Jr. and daughter-in-law Angela Puse Pyn. Norma Perry was born in Malone, NY to Edward and Louvah Perry. A graduate of St Vincent's School of Nursing NYC, she entered the US Navy as Lt JG to care for WWII soldiers. Norma worked at the Bronx VA, and graduated from Fordham University. She married Wilbur, had five children and resided in Greenwich Village, Bay Ridge and Belle Harbor, NY. Norma was renowned for her beauty, her exceptional dancing and her outstanding patient care at the Brooklyn VA. Norma belonged to St. Francis De Sales Church in Belle Harbor where a memorial will be held later this summer. She is survived by three sisters, five children, seven grandchildren, numerous nieces and nephews, and an anticipated great-grandchild. Recently, she attended Nativity Church, Lake Mary FL where her funeral service will be held on April 26. Donations in her name to: Sisters of Charity Center 6301 Riverdale Ave Bronx NY 10471. www.scny.org

RUBIN--Peter C.,on April 12, 2014. Devoted father of Marcie and granddaughter Anna. Will be sorely missed and fondly remembered by all who knew and loved him. Graveside service on Thursday, April 17, 10:45am at Maimonides Cemetery, 90 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY.

RUSSANO--Robert. "Dr. Bob" was our lifeblood. As member, mentor, treasurer and fierce competitor he epitomized the gentleman golfer. The Stationer's Golf Association Board of Directors extends our sympathy and love to Marion, RXR, his children and grandchildren.

SOLOMON--Florence, age 92: Loved by her children William, Robert, and Judith, her daughters-in-law Terry and Marge, and her five grandchildren, Philip, Sophie, David, Daniel, and Stephen, whom she held dear. Born to Isidor Schneider and Reyzl Lenofsky as the eldest of five, she was forever devoted to Yiddishkeit, Judaism, and Israel. She put herself through NYU to become a special ed teacher and saw her late husband of 41 years, Nathan A Solomon, through his PhD, MD. A superb Jewish joke teller, folk dancer, and Loehmann's lover, she turned her dreams into realities, doing so in her own inimitable way until her very last day: released, at her insistence, from a two-month rehab stay, she died later that night in her own bed, a longstanding wish. Her final, spoken words were "To thine own self be true." Donations in her memory may be made to the Park Avenue Synagogue Library, 50 E. 87th Street, New York, NY 10128.

ROCHE--M. William, of Stamford, CT died peacefully at home with his family by his side on April 12, 2014. Bill was born in New London, CT on April 1, 1928. After high school at Bulkeley School, he graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Bill's dedication to serving his country led him to memorize the eye chart to get in the Navy in World War II. He later served as a Second Lieutenant in the Army in Korea earning a Bronze Star. Bill married his college sweetheart, Dolores Robert, in Cohoes in 1953. Bill launched a brilliant 39 year career with Pfizer. He paved an adventurous trail abroad with 20 years of international leadership in Canada, United Kingdom, and in Belgium. Bill served as Chairman Pfizer UK, President Pfizer Europe, and President Animal Health Group. RPI continued to receive support and leadership from Bill as an Alumni Association Fellow. His beloved Dolores died in 1982. Bill found love again and has been married to Mary Elizabeth Paul for the last 24 years. In retirement Bill enjoyed his time at both Winged Foot Golf Club and Harbour Ridge Yacht and Country Club. He will be dearly missed by his wife Mary Elizabeth and his children: Marie (Chris), Lori (Royce), Ellen (Brian), Bill ( Lisa), Bob (Judiann), and Mark. He was also blessed with twelve grandchildren and a brand new great grandchild. Visitation will be held Tuesday, April 15, 2014 from 4-8pm at Shippan's Thomas M. Gallagher Funeral Home (same building as Bosak) 453 Shippan Ave Stamford, CT (203)359-9999. A Mass of Christian burial will be held at 10am on Wednesday, April 16, 2014 at St Michael the Archangel Parish 469 North Street Greenwich, CT. The burial will follow at St John Cemetery, Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Rensselaer at www.rpi.edu/giving/ways.html in honor of M.W.Roche ('51) Words of comfort may be sent to the family at: gallagherfuneralhome.com
KORNREICH--Matthew R. 12/4/1924-4/15/2009 Five years since you left us to join Mom. The wonderful memories we have of you will never fade. We love you forever, Kathy, Sam, Lisa, Andrew

KIRSCH--Bob. The Patriarch of our family and beloved cousin and best friend. Our heartfelt condolences to Abbie, Richard, Jo, Billy and Jim. Bob was special in so many ways. He along with his darling Abbie, through guts, entrepreneurial skills and management talent, created Abigail Kirsch, one of the most outstanding catering organizations in America. He loved life as everybody loved him. He adored his children, grandchildren and was excited that he, just recently, became a great-grandfather. He shall be sorely missed by all and we wish that he rest in peace. The Koenig Family

KATZ--Esther, Died peacefully on April 13, 2014 at the age of 62 years surrounded by her family and pets. You taught me to believe...in the joy and sharing that was our marriage in the union that was ours for 44 years in our years of loving, understanding, patience, humor and lots of laughter in our past, present and ours families future you have made your children and I very happy. With much love forever. Your husband and family David, John, Daniel, Hanna, Otis, Basil and Reggie Sign online guest book at www.jewishfuneralcare.com Dressler's Jewish Funeral Care, Atlanta.

PERLMAN--Evelyn (born Shechter), passed away peacefully in her sleep on April 14 at the age of 91. Evelyn lived a full and challenging life with dignity and resiliency. She left home as a teen to become one of the first woman marines, serving in a support role during World War II. She was profiled in the book "Ours to Fight For: American Jews in the Second World War". Evelyn then fearlessly went to Los Angeles with no resources and became a professional legal secretary in the entertainment industry. After returning to New York, she married Sydney Perlman and raised two sons, Lee and Douglas, while continuing to work and serving as a role model to her children and grandchildren. In addition to her children, she leaves her beloved daughter-in-law Linda Riefberg, son-in-law Dan Brooks, siblings Jack Shechter and Harriet Levy, and scores of nieces and cousins who adored and admired her. Funeral services will be private. The family wishes to pay special tribute to the extraordinary staff of Hebrew Home at Riverdale for making Evelyn's last years so fulfilling and comfortable. In lieu of flowers, please feel free to make a contribution in her honor to the Home, c/o Development Office, 5901 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, NY 10471.

MARCUS--Howard W. The board and staff of American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev are profoundly saddened by the passing of Dr. Howard Marcus, a mensch and visionary philanthropist. Together with his wife, Lottie Marcus, Howard made a significant impact on Israel's Negev region through his magnanimous support of Ben-Gurion University of the Negev (BGU). In 2004, he and Lottie were awarded honorary doctoral degrees by BGU in recognition of their pioneering spirit, exceptional generosity and dedication to higher education. The Marcus Family Campus in Beer-Sheva reflects the commitment of Howard's family to the University and to the fulfillment of David Ben-Gurion's vision to build a world-class institution of education and research in the Negev desert. Their pledged legacy gift will make a dramatic impact on the development and growth of the University for generations to come. Howard will be sorely missed. We extend our profound condolences to Lottie, his beloved wife of almost 72 years; to his daughter, Ellen Marcus; his son-in-law, Harvey Malyn; his granddaughter Jennifer Kaplan; and to all those who have been touched by Howard's benevolent and enriching life. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Lloyd Goldman, President Ruth Flinkman-Marandy, Regional Campaign Chair Doron Krakow, Executive Vice President Philip Gomperts, Regional Director

PERLMAN--Evelyn. The entire Hebrew Home at Riverdale family deeply mourns the loss of Evelyn Perlman, who was an integral part of our community for many years. Evelyn was beloved by our staff and especially the young students who she befriended and taught. We will miss her warmth and elegance. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Perlman family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

GOTTLIEB--Albert. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Albert Gottlieb, and extend sincere condolences to his family. James Dreyfus, President

PERLMAN--Evelyn. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of Evelyn Perlman, beloved mother of our dear friend and gifted GNYHA colleague Lee H. Perlman. We extend our sincere condolences to Lee, his wife Linda, their children Shauna and Jake, the entire Perlman family, and their many friends. Louis A. Shapiro, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA

EMORY--Eric Steuer, age 88, of Katonah, NY, son of the late Henry and Ethel (Steuer) Epstein died April 12th. Mr. Emory is survived by his wife of 30 years: Linda (nee Rodgers); his children: David, Victoria, and Ellen (Michael) Hoffman and his granddaughter, Elizabeth Hoffman. Mr. Emory was a graduate of Amherst College and Columbia University School of Business and the author of "When To Sell Stocks". Funeral Services will be Thursday, April 17th at 12 Noon at Scarsdale Synagogue Temples Tremont and Emanu-El, 2 Odgen Road, Scarsdale, NY. Private interment to follow.

MATTHIESSEN--Peter. The Wildlife Conservation Society mourns the death of Peter Matthiessen, an explorer and great literary champion for wildlife, vast wild places and for the peoples whose livelihoods are reliant on the natural world. Peter brought critical and keen insights into conservation and environmentalism, catalyzing action and wonder for wildlife in America and across the globe. We will always be honored that Peter served on the WCS Board of Trustees and supported our work for decades. Peter's literary works will continue to inspire and guide us for many generations to come. We extend our sympathies to Peter's family.

GOTTLIEB--Albert J.,age 82, passed away on April 14 in White Plains, NY. Cherished husband of Anne for 37 years, loving father of David, Jeffrey and Adam Gottlieb, Carey Ramos and Amy Mesirow, and loving stepfather of Jenni Ryan, Sue Tsokris, and Greg Nathan. Awesome grandpa of Seth, Lev, Shira, Natalie, David, Ben, Robin, Alex, Rebecca, Kelsey, Samantha, Jack and Bailey. Well known for his mischievous sense of humor, he will be greatly missed by all. He was a graduate of Yale and Harvard Business School. As a commercial real estate broker, he created The Bank Services Group at Newmark Knight Frank where he was a senior vice president until his retirement. His passion for family extended to children everywhere and he supported Save the Children and Teach for America. His funeral will be held on Thursday, April 17th at 10am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, a donation in his memory may be made to The Alzheimer's Assn., 2900 Westchester Ave, Purchase, NY 10577 or Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 311 North St #

ANDREW--Penelope T.,beloved daughter, sister, aunt, and cherished friend, passed away peacefully on Monday, April 14, 2014. Ms. Andrew was a Magna Cum Laude graduate of Brandeis University, and received her MSW from New York University. At NYU, she was awarded an NIMH clinical traineeship and Dean's Merit Awards. She worked at St. Luke's- Roosevelt Hospital for 16 years and was an Adjunct Lecturer/Field Instructor for Columbia University graduate students and for NYU interns. She volunteered with the American Red Cross during 9/11, worked in-patient and community psychiatry and with combat veterans. Ms. Andrew was certified in Psychoanalytic Psychotherapy from the Psychoanalytic Training Institute/NYCC. She was also a writer/editor, film critic, and member of the Women Film Critics Circle. Her work appeared on Huffington Post, Bright Lights Film Journal, Arts Express, Critical Women on Film and The American Association for Psychoanalysis. Ms. Andrew worked as a writer and editor for The New Manhattan Review, H Proini, Universal Press Syndicate and Hellenic Voice. She was a consultant with non-profit organizations and individuals on PR, resume and biography development, website copywriting and other creative projects. Her interests and involvement included Amnesty International and Save Darfur Coalition. Born in Hopewell, Virginia on July 30, 1956, Ms. Andrew was the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Andrew. She is survived by her mother, Mrs. Freda P. Andrew, her brother, Dr. Constantine T. Andrew, his wife Susan, niece and nephew, Leia and Ted, and her devoted loving friends. She will be deeply missed by all whose lives she touched. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Amnesty International, amnestyusa.org, Amnesty International USA, 5 Penn Plaza, 16th Floor, New York, NY 10001 or Save Darfur Coalition/United to End Genocide, endgenocide.org, 1000 Vermont Avenue NW, Suite 200, Washington, DC 20005 or a charity of choice.

FRANKEL--Leon, 86, passed away on April 11, 2014. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Beryl Bynoe Frankel, his son Adam, as well as his granddaughters, Eastlyn and Ava, his two nephews, his niece, as well as his three great-nephews. Leon was born in 1927 in Scranton, PA but spent most of his life in Manhattan, and he graduated from The Bronx High School of Science and Hunter College. He spent the bulk of his career at what is now Verizon, retiring after 23 years as a Systems Analyst. He was a true New Yorker, with an unquenchable love of learning, travel and family, which allowed him to enrich all who knew him. He happily lived his life on his own terms. A celebration of his life will be held on Thursday, April 17, 11am at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 2nd Avenue, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to The New York Public Library.

ROCHE--M. William, of Stamford, CT died peacefully at home with his family by his side on April 12, 2014. Bill was born in New London, CT on April 1, 1928. After high school at Bulkeley School, he graduated from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Bill's dedication to serving his country led him to memorize the eye chart to get in the Navy in World War II. He later served as a Second Lieutenant in the Army in Korea earning a Bronze Star. Bill married his college sweetheart, Dolores Robert, in Cohoes in 1953. Bill launched a brilliant 39 year career with Pfizer. He paved an adventurous trail abroad with 20 years of international leadership in Canada, United Kingdom, and in Belgium. Bill served as Chairman Pfizer UK, President Pfizer Europe, and President Animal Health Group. RPI continued to receive support and leadership from Bill as an Alumni Association Fellow. His beloved Dolores died in 1982. Bill found love again and has been married to Mary Elizabeth Paul for the last 24 years. In retirement Bill enjoyed his time at both Winged Foot Golf Club and Harbour Ridge Yacht and Country Club. He will be dearly missed by his wife Mary Elizabeth and his children: Marie (Chris), Lori (Royce), Ellen (Brian), Bill ( Lisa), Bob (Judiann), and Mark. He was also blessed with twelve grandchildren and a brand new great grandchild. Visitation will be held Tuesday, April 15, 2014 from 4-8pm at Shippan's Thomas M. Gallagher Funeral Home (same building as Bosak) 453 Shippan Ave Stamford, CT (203)359-9999. A Mass of Christian burial will be held at 10am on Wednesday, April 16, 2014 at St Michael the Archangel Parish 469 North Street Greenwich, CT. The burial will follow at St John Cemetery, Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Rensselaer at www.rpi.edu/giving/ways.html in honor of M.W.Roche ('51) Words of comfort may be sent to the family at: gallagherfuneralhome.com
REFF--Elaine Helena. 1/19/1935 -4/16/2011. You are always with me. Love, Everett

KIRSCH--Bob. The Patriarch of our family and beloved cousin and best friend. Our heartfelt condolences to Abbie, Richard, Jo, Billy and Jim. Bob was special in so many ways. He loved life as everybody loved him. He adored his children, grandchildren and was excited that he, just recently, became a great-grandfather. He shall be sorely missed by all and we wish that he rest in peace. The Koenig Family

KELVIN--Norman, on April 14, 2014. CCNY and GC, CUNY, Distinguished Professor Emeritus. Beloved husband of Phyllis, devoted father of Elizabeth and Jane. Service Thursday, April 17, 2014, 12:45pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

PERLMAN--Evelyn (born Schecter), passed away peacefully in her sleep on April 14 at the age of 91. Evelyn lived a full and challenging life with dignity and resiliency. She left home as a teen to become one of the first woman marines, serving in a support role during World War II. She was profiled in the book "Ours to Fight For: American Jews in the Second World War". Evelyn then fearlessly went to Los Angeles with no resources and became a professional legal secretary in the entertainment industry. After returning to New York, she married Sydney Perlman and raised two sons, Lee and Douglas, while continuing to work and serving as a role model to her children and grandchildren Shauna and Jake. In addition to her children, she leaves her beloved daughter-in-law Linda Riefberg, son-in-law Dan Brooks, siblings Jack Shechter and Harriet Levy, and scores of nieces and cousins who adored and admired her. Funeral services will be private. The family wishes to pay special tribute to the extraordinary staff of Hebrew Home at Riverdale for making Evelyn's last years so fulfilling and comfortable. In lieu of flowers, please feel free to make a contribution in her honor to the Home, c/o Development Office, 5901 Palisade Avenue, Riverdale, NY 10471.

WILLIS--Charles Julius, Sr.,was born on March 20, 1931 in Mathews County, Virginia and passed away on April 10, 2014 in Brooklyn, NY. Charles was an active church member and minister, a real estate investor, musician, community volunteer and always a proud father. Charles spent his last 20 years as an inspiration to everyone who crossed his path.

GOTTLIEB--Albert J.,age 82, passed away on April 14 in White Plains, NY. Cherished husband of Anne for 37 years, loving father of David, Jeffrey and Adam Gottlieb, Carey Ramos and Amy Mesirow, and loving stepfather of Jenni Ryan, Sue Tsokris, and Greg Nathan. Awesome grandpa of Seth, Lev, Shira, Natalie, David, Ben, Robin, Alex, Rebecca, Kelsey, Samantha, Jack and Bailey. Well known for his mischievous sense of humor, he will be greatly missed by all. He was a graduate of Yale and Harvard Business School. As a commercial real estate broker, he created The Bank Services Group at Newmark Knight Frank where he was a senior vice president until his retirement. His passion for family extended to children everywhere and he supported Save the Children and Teach for America. His funeral will be held on Thursday, April 17th at 10am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave East, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, a donation in his memory may be made to The Alzheimer's Assn., 2900 Westchester Ave, Purchase, NY 10577 or Hospice and Palliative Care of Westchester, 311 North St #

OBERHAUS--A. Edward Jr.,of Bronxville, NY, died April 5, at his home. Born in Hartford, CT, lived in Farmington and attended St. Thomas Seminary School. Graduated Norwich University, VT, and served two years as 1st Lt in the U.S. Armored Div. during the Korean War. In 1955, graduated Harvard Business School and worked in advertising until 1972, when he joined Kaneka America Corp..Traveled throughout the world during his 33 years at KAC and retired as Senior Vice President in 2005. After retirement, studied at the National Academy of Fine Arts, and displayed his art in numerous shows. Preceded in death by his wife of 56 years, Dorothy Huff Oberhaus. Survived by his daughter Ann (Tim) Mackin, and grandchildren Kate and Sean, all of Chagrin Falls, OH. Private funeral, and a memorial at a later date.

SORKIN--Ellen, 85, died April 14, 2014 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Saul for 51 years. Mother of David, Richard (Susie), and John (Jessica). Grandmother of Leah, Daniel, Abby, Sam, Emma and Lilly. Sister of the late Frances Friedman. A brilliant, engaged, and loving woman. Ellen was a graduate of New York University and the Columbia University School of Social Work and served for many years as a psychiatric social worker for the Veterans Administration prior to the birth of her children. She shaped our lives and we will remember her with love always. Service Friday, April 18, 2014, 10:30 am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th Street in New York City. Memorial donations may be sent in Ellen's memory to the Philanthropic Fund of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York, 1 East 65th St. NYC, NY 10065 or NYU Alz- heimer's Disease Center, 145 East 32nd St., NYC, NY 10016.

GREEN--Lindsay Waggener. March 13, 1926 - April 11, 2014 of Dallas, Texas and New York, NY. Airborne when she danced. Steadfast when she landed. Child of Texas, citizen of New York. Radiant, with a charm that set rooms aglow. Descendent of pioneers, soldiers and scholars. Inheritor of all that energy and spirit of inquiry, that gift for innovation, that vein of genius. An engine of creativity, a reservoir of humor and wit possessed of enviable literary and theatrical skills. Astonishing beauty and incandescent intellect, all brought to bear on her career of choice as delightful wife, devoted mother, adoring grandmother, caring friend. Bill, Ross, Nancy, Ellie will never forget her, nor will anyone who ever met her.

PELL--Nuala, on Sunday, April 13 at the age of 89, Nuala O'Donnell Pell passed away peacefully in Newport, RI. Mrs. Pell was born in New York City on June 30, 1924 to Charles Oliver and Josephine Hartford O'Donnell. She attended Brearley School and Bennington College. Mrs. Pell was the beloved wife of the late United States Senator Claiborne Pell whom she married in 1944. She is survived by her brother Columbus O'Donnell of England, her son Christopher Pell and his wife, Janet of Newport, RI and her daughter, Dallas Pell Yates of New York City, NY. She was the mother of the late, Herbert Pell and Julia Pell. She is also survived by her five grandchildren, Tripler Pell, Nicholas Pell, Clay Pell, Christina Neal, and Eames Yates and her nine great-grandchildren; Elias, Marina and Atlas Hammoud, Oliver, Bertie and Nuala Randall, Zara Neal, Georgina and Henry Pell. Mrs. Pell was an extraordinary woman who dedicated her life to her husband, her children, and the citizens of Rhode Island. Her wit and generosity were obvious to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations to the Potter League for Animals, PO Box 412, Newport, RI 02840. A funeral service will be held at 11:00am on Monday, April 21st, 2014 at Trinity Church in Newport, Rhode Island. Additional information available at: memorialfuneralhome.com

SEARS--Diane. April 17, 2004. Sorely missed, loved and cherished. Mary and Nancy

ELLNER--Martin, passed away in the company of his family on April 14, 2014. Beloved husband of Rhoda, loving father of Andrew and Jill, Kenneth, James and Stefanie, and Robert, and proud grandfather of Samantha, Greg, Ben, Jack and Cole. He was an exceptional man who survived the Holocaust to live a long, happy and full life. He will be greatly missed but never forgotten. Funeral will be held April 17th at 10am at Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, NY 11375.

LEV--Jane Abby, died peacefully in her home in San Francisco on Tuesday, March 25th with her husband, Stefano Hillman, by her side. Jane, the only child of Leon and Adelaide Lev, was born in 1950 in Brooklyn, and raised in Manhattan. She moved to the San Francisco area in 1967. There she studied film, made documentary films, and met two of her lifelong friends, Marilyn J. Curry and Pam Heaton. The three lived together for several years forming a deep bond that sustained them for life. In 1985 Jane met her partner, Stefano. The two independent New Yorkers fell in love, married, and made a loving home with their cats in Bernal Heights. In 1989 she received a Masters in Public Health at University of California Berkeley, and began her career as a health educator. She worked in public health for over 20 years, being extremely effective in advocating for vulnerable populations most in need of services. Jane's beauty went beyond her bright blue eyes, dark curly hair, and dazzling smile. It was her mind and spirit that captivated people. Her passions were palpable and they were many, including being an avid reader and gardener. Her greatest joy was strolling through the streets of cities that she knew and loved and of those that she had just discovered. We all will miss her and never, ever forget her. Donations can be made to S.F.'s Friends of the Urban Forest.

SORKIN--Ellen, 85, died April 14, 2014 in New York City. Beloved wife of the late Saul for 51 years. Mother of David, Richard (Susie), and John (Jessica). Grandmother of Leah, Daniel, Abby, Sam, Emma and Lilly. Sister of the late Frances Friedman. A brilliant, engaged, and loving woman. Ellen was a graduate of New York University and the Columbia University School of Social Work and served for many years as a psychiatric social worker for the Veterans Administration prior to the birth of her children. She shaped our lives and we will remember her with love always. Service Friday, April 18, 2014, 10:30 am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th Street in New York City. Memorial donations may be sent in Ellen's memory to the Philanthropic Fund of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York, 1 East 65th St. NYC, NY 10065 or NYU Alz- heimer's Disease Center, 145 East 32nd St., NYC, NY 10016.

WOLF--Melvin (Mel), pioneer of the commercial wallcovering industry and founding partner of leading American design company, Wolf-Gordon, died peacefully at his home in Boynton Beach, FL on March 22nd. He was 90 years old. Mel was born in York, PA in 1924 to Dorothy and Albert Wolf. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School and attended City College. He started working at age 14 for Gilford Fabrics, and remained for 25 years, returning after serving on the front lines in France, 1942-1945. In 1967 Mel founded Wolf-Gordon with Bernard Gordon, Frank Carr and Tony Prota, and served as the wallcovering company's CEO until retiring in 1995. Today, Wolf-Gordon continues its founders' legacy, offering interior surfacing materials under the leadership of the second-generation: Rick Wolf, David Gordon and Rob Wolf. Mel was married to Libby Wernick in 1949, mother of his four surviving sons: Richard, Robert, Gregory and Lawrence. After Libby's death in 1965, Mel married Dorothy Davis and was stepfather to Cathy (deceased), and Gurujot Kaur Khalsa (formerly Jill Davis). Dorothy died in 2000. In 2002, Mel married Marilyn Prigozen, who survives him along with his sister, Harriet, 16 grandchildren and two great grandchildren. A service was held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel in Boynton Beach on March 24th, and an interment was held at Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, where Mel was honored by the US military for his service during WWII.

ROSEN--Leonard M. The Rosen family mourns the passing of Leonard M. Rosen, beloved husband of Phyllis for 56 years. He is also survived by his children Adam, Steven, David and Carol, as well as his nine grandchildren Alex, Emma, Benjamin, Hannah, Jack, Sophie, Owen, Ella and Naree. Leonard will be greatly missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Those wishing to recognize Leonard's passing may donate to two charitable organizations with which he was deeply involved: The Lymphoma Research Foundation and The Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy.
HOLLANDER--Zander. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of Zander Hollander, a loyal member.

WEBSTER--Jenneth. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Preforming Arts deeply mourn the passing of Jenneth Webster, former Associate Director, Programming, the flaming spirit who ignited the free annual Lincoln Center Out of Doors Festival with passion and imagination for nearly 30 years. From an early age she became aware of the importance of community arts groups and in her own words, "the impact of living arts on people." Over the decades, through Jenneth's efforts, thousands of people and countless performers came together on Lincoln Center's outdoor spaces to celebrate music, dance, spoken word, and community. We join the arts community in extending our sympathies to her partner Charles Allcroft, her family and friends, and to all who have been touched by her work. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

KELVIN--Norman, on April 14, 2014. CCNY and GC, CUNY, Distinguished Professor Emeritus. Beloved husband of Phyllis, devoted father of Elizabeth and Jane. Service Thursday, April 17, 2014, 12:45pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.
SHANLEY--Joan. February 2, 1934 to April 12, 2014. Public school educator and social worker for 50 years. Known for her big heart and love of life.

KIRSCH--Robert "Bobby", Larger than life. Adored patriarch who placed Abby and his family above all else. Loyal and loving friend. Embraced life to the fullest, with boundless enthusiasm and unshakeable optimism. Commander in Chief. World traveled. Son of Dartmouth. An eclectic gourmand whose taste ranged from caviar and truffles to peanut butter and jelly. Will be joyfully remembered, and loved. Paula and Mel, and family

ROSEN--Leonard M.,All of us at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are deeply saddened by the death of our dear colleague and friend, Leonard M. Rosen, at age 83. We will miss him greatly. We will be inspired by him always. Leonard was a founder of our Firm, and was instrumental in making it what it is today. He was a partner from 1965, when, intrepidly, together with Martin Lipton, Herbert Wachtell and George Katz, all graduates of NYU Law School, he launched our practice, until 1997, when he retired. In his retirement, he served as Of Counsel to our Firm until his passing on April 16, 2014. Leonard created, and led, the Firm's creditors' rights group. He transformed it into one of the nation's leading bankruptcy practices, representing banks, insurance companies, bondholders, and other institutional creditors. He counseled, advised, and advocated and negotiated for his clients on all manner of bankruptcy matters. He was a student of the law -- author of numerous articles on bankruptcy law, and a draftsman of sections of the leading treatise in the field. He was also a teacher of the law, serving for many years as an adjunct professor at the New York University School of Law, where he introduced aspiring lawyers to the subject he so loved. He was a leader of the bar, and a shaper of the law. He contributed to the drafting of the Bankruptcy Code and, as Chairman of the National Bankruptcy Conference from 1984 to 1992, played a leading role in the Code's development. He received the American College of Bankruptcy's Distinguished Service Award in 2003, along with many other accolades for his accomplishments during his decades of distinguished practice. As the leader of the Firm's bankruptcy and restructuring practice, Leonard was the attorney to whom our major institutional creditor clients so often turned first when credit problems arose with a major corporate borrower. To him they looked for judgment and leadership. And to him we looked for wisdom and guidance. By the time he retired, he had built a practice group so eminent that it was called upon by the United States Department of the Treasury to design and implement the immense government rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac -- the largest ever. Throughout his career, the matters Leonard handled were enormously consequential. In 1975, his client was the City of New York. It was on the verge of bankruptcy. The federal government had refused to help, and the Daily News headline famously screamed, "Ford to City: Drop Dead." After President Ford relented, Leonard stayed up round the clock with virtually the entire Firm, in the effort to prepare the complex and myriad agreements, securities, legislation and tax rulings needed so the City could obtain critical financing before year-end. At almost the same time, Leonard led the Firm's team that represented W. T. Grant during its historic bankruptcy -- the first billion-dollar Chapter 11 case, and the last in which the Firm was the lead counsel for a bankruptcy debtor. The list of historic matters goes on: Leonard represented the bank lenders to Chrysler during its government bailout in the early 1980s. He masterfully forged an agreement among Chrysler and each of its more than 400 bank lenders, an agreement that enabled Chrysler to survive and prosper during a period in which its failure appeared imminent. Leonard was also the lead attorney for the principal lenders in the debt restructurings and bankruptcies of many other major corporations in the real estate, financial, energy, agricultural equipment, steel and aircraft industries. But above all, Leonard was a good man. A generous man. A kind man. A man you could trust with your most difficult problems and deepest concerns, a superb partner who represented, and will always represent, all we strive to be as lawyers, citizens, and human beings. He was much sought after for his judgment, as well as for his marvelous ability to resolve disputes and reconcile disparate views. He shaped the culture of our Firm. He was the glue that cemented a group of hard-working and talented attorneys into a leading law firm that has served as a model for other firms. He was not only admired and respected by his colleagues; he was beloved. Leonard was deeply involved in the work of the Lymphoma Research Foundation and the Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy. The entire Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz family sends its deepest condolences to Leonard's wife Phyllis, his sons Adam, Steven and David, his daughter Carol, and his nine grandchildren. We share your loss, and your love for our dear friend Leonard.

KIRSCH--Robert. The FSH Society is saddened by the passing of Robert Kirsch. With his wife Abigail, Bob made a significant impact on finding solutions for FSH muscular dystrophy. We extend our condolences to his family. He will be greatly missed.

RICE--Peggy S.,died peacefully at home on April 16th, 2014. She was extraordinary and lived an extraordinary life. She is survived by her children: Edwin and Sallie Stern, Mary Stern Grossman, Suzie and Peter Kunhardt, Maggie and Dan Terris, Eve Rice and Tim Madison; her grandchildren, Kara, Eddie, Amanda, Nick, Rebecca, Jessie, Peter, Abby, Teddy, Ben, George, Nate, Eli, Theo, Julie, Beth, Sam, Rachel and Danny; and her great children, Maisie, Lili, Mia, Adam, and Nathan. The family will be receiving on Thursday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, from 5-7pm. A celebration of her life will take on June 19th, 2014.

de Fazio--Dr. Laurence, on April 13, 2014: Beloved husband of Giovanna; Loving father of Dr. Mark, Dr. Gregory and Dr. Andrew; Dear father-in-law of Susan, Isabella and Domenica; Devoted grandfather of Matthew, Gabriella, Simona, Marcello, Isabella Gianluca and Avellina. Reposing at the Torregrossa Funeral Home, 1305 79 Street, Brooklyn. Visiting Thursday and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Monday, April 21 at St. Bernadette RC Church at 9:45am. PLUM--Carol Houston. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of Carol Houston Plum, a loyal member.

DICKSON--Edythe, a native New Yorker, died on April 15th at the age of 87, after a life well lived. Extraordinary in every way, she drove at age 12, volunteered as a plane spotter for the Mayor's office during WWII, was a fervent bobby soxer, skilled artist and craftswoman, women's advocate and the most amazing mother, wife, daughter, sister, aunt, cousin and friend you could wish for. She treasured her years on Wall Street in the Corporate Communications Department at JP Morgan, where she worked happily into her 70's. There are almost no words to describe her smarts, incandescence and wit with which she dazzled until the very end. We wish her eternal peace and will miss her every day. Deede, Wheeler and her loving family

LOWENFELD--Elena M.,beloved wife of Andreas, mother of Julian and Marianna, grandmother of Mark, Diana, and Ana, died on April 15, just short of her 86th birthday. She was born and raised in Cuba and came to America after the Castro revolution. Always elegant, Elena threw herself with enthusiasm into whatever she did. She received her Master's degree in Music from City College and taught there for five years. Her Master's thesis on a little-known Spanish composer was published by the University of Michigan. Subsequently, she taught in the New York City public schools for 12 years in both English and Spanish. After retiring from the Board of Education, Elena became a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She also sang for 43 years with The Collegiate Chorale. Contributions may be made in her honor to The Collegiate Chorale, 115 E. 57 St., #

LEVI--Walter, 87, of Stamford, Ct.,died peacefully at home on April 14, 2014. He grew up in New Rochelle, NY, graduated from Brown University and later settled in Connecticut. His life work was imported food and finance. He was an avid reader and enjoyed gardening in his earlier years. During his first marriage to Joan Levi, he had three children. Their marriage ended in divorce. He then married Janet Siegel who had three children of her own. She predeceased him. He had a long-time partnership with Ruth Lowy who died in October, 2013. He is survived by three children, three grandchildren, three stepchildren and three step-grandchildren. At Mr. Levi's request there will be no service. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Cancer Care of Westchester, NY or to the charity of your choice. The tribute to the life of Walter Levi will go forward in memories of family and friends. He was loved. He will be missed. He will be remembered. Services entrusted to Shippan's Thomas M. Gallagher Funeral Home 453 Shippan Ave. Stamford,Ct. Tributes to Mr. Levi may be sent to: gallagherfuneralhome.com

PERLMAN--Evelyn. We at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital extend our deepest condolences to Lee Perlman on the passing of his mother, Evelyn Perlman. Our sympathies are with the entire Perlman family at this sad time. Steven J. Corwin, MD, CEO Robert E. Kelly, MD, President NY-Presbyterian Hospital

FARBER--Marilyn. The entire Hebrew Home at Riverdale family mourns the loss of Marilyn Farber. Marilyn was a remarkable woman with a joyful spirit. Her artistic expression was beautifully captured in her sculptures. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Farber and Raiff families. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

PERLMAN--Evelyn. The Board of Directors, Volunteers and Staff of Ronald McDonald House New York wish to express our sincere sympathy on the passing of Evelyn Perlman, mother of our devoted board member Lee H. Perlman. We send our sympathy to the entire Perlman family on their significant loss. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman of the Board and William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

FUHRMAN--Nathan, 88 years old, died April 14, 2014. Brilliant polymath Prince, kind and tender patriarch, possessing both scientific rigor and a romantic soul, wickedly witty, caring protector, scholar and mensch, distinguished nuclear chemist, gentle and principled provider, combat Veteran, cautious adventurer and intrepid traveler, always evolving, ever young, but deserving a better chin next time. Service on Thursday, April 17, 2014 11am at Gutterman and Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.
MARKS--Stuart. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its longtime member and honorary trustee and extends sympathy to his family. Louis M. Solomon, Parnas

JAFFE--Fredrick, M.D. The members of the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the untimely passing of our valued friend and colleague, Dr. Fredrick F. Jaffe. Dr. Jaffe was an honored member of our department for 44 years, as a resident, faculty member, and Director of the Division of Adult Reconstructive Surgery. He was an outstanding clinician, gifted surgeon and dedicated educator. Thousands of patients have benefited from the hip and knee replacement surgery he performed, restoring productive and pain free lives. He contributed to the education of scores of orthopaedic residents, who now practice the principles he taught. He leaves a saddened hospital community with a profound void. His many years of dedicated work at the Hospital for Joint Diseases touched the lives of an infinite number of people. We grieve his passing as we celebrate his exemplary life and extend our heart-felt sympathy to his wife, Dr. Deborah Moody; his sons, David and Harry; his daughters-in-law, Leslie and Andrea and his grandchildren Zachary, Aria and Lila. Joseph D. Zuckerman M.D., Chair William L. Jaffe, M.D. Joseph A. Bosco, M.D. Kenneth A Egol, Vice Chairs, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, NYU Langone Medical Center

After retiring from the Board of Education, Elena became a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She also sang for 43 years with The Collegiate Chorale.
