EMERSON--Ann McCollester (Niki) died April 7. Survived by husband, John Bradford, children, Ann deForest, Parker McCollester, Eleanor Baldwin and six grandchildren. Predeceased by son Alexander Esty. Raised in Gramercy Park, avid viola player, full of character.

LEE--Robert J.,at home on April 16, 2014. Bob was a founder of Lee-Hecht-Harrison, Inc., past president of The Center for Creative Leadership in Greensboro, NC and active executive coach and co-founder of ICoach. He was a dedicated teacher. Beloved husband of Mary, devoted father of David and Carola Schambach, Andrea and Jerry Carlson, and Mark. Loving grandfather of Rebecca, Orin and Benjamin. He will be dearly missed. Service Sunday, April 20, 2014, 1:15pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory would be appreciated to The American Diabetes Association or the American Heart Association.

JAFFE--Fredrick. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member and Past Commodore, Fredrick Jaffe, and extend sincere condolences to his family. James Dreyfus, President

DICKSON--Edythe, a native New Yorker, died on April 15th at the age of 87, after a life well lived. Extraordinary in every way, she drove at age 12, volunteered as a plane spotter for the Mayor's office during WWII, was a fervent bobby soxer, skilled artist and craftswoman, women's advocate and the most amazing mother, wife, daughter, sister, aunt, cousin and friend you could wish for. She treasured her years on Wall Street in the Corporate Communications Department at JP Morgan, where she worked happily into her 70's. There are almost no words to describe her smarts, incandescence and wit with which she dazzled until the very end. We wish her eternal peace and will miss her every day. Deede, Wheeler and her loving family

CASSIAN--Nina, of New York City, died at age 89 on April 14, 2014. A central figure in Romanian arts and literature, Nina was a poet, translator, critic, children's book author, visual artist, and composer. She published more than 50 books in Romania; several collections of her poems, translated from Romanian or written originally in English, have appeared here including "Life Sentence" and her last "Continuum." A refugee from the Ceausescu regime, Nina took up residence in New York in the 1980s and later became an American citizen. Her poems have been published in The New Yorker, The Atlantic, and many other magazines. A compelling reader of her own work, she appeared at numerous poetry venues across Europe and the United States. She continued to be celebrated in her homeland, where her multi-volume autobiography was published in the early 2000s. Nina's brilliant mind, razor wit, and great personal charm will be missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her husband, Maurice Edwards. A funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., on Tuesday, April 22 at 4pm.

NEWFIELD--Joseph "Joey", passed away unexpectedly on April 9, 2014 in Mesa, Arizona. Son of Janie Eisenberg and the late Jack Newfield, and brother of Rebecca Newfield, Joey's sweet shy presence will be forever in our hearts. Memorial contributions may be made in Joey's memory to the Theodore Atlas Foundation (for at-risk youth). 543 Cary Avenue, Staten Island, New York 10310. 718-980-7037.

OLIVA--L. Jay. The NYU community grieves deeply the loss of its cherished 14th president, L. Jay Oliva. No one served NYU better or more faithfully than he, or did more to shape the NYU we know today. Starting as a member of the history faculty in 1960, he went on to be the last dean of the Heights campus, helping to guide NYU through some of its most challenging moments. From that point forward, through his tenure as chancellor and then president, he had a key hand in engineering what has been described as the greatest success story in contemporary American higher education. Understanding the diversity of student success at NYU, he cheered on NYU's top students, our athletes, our performing artists, and our community service volunteers. Educator, mentor, leader, and great colleague and friend -- he loved NYU through-and-through, believed in its promise, and led the way in making NYU a respected national research university and jump-starting its global efforts. All those who wear violet mourn today, and we send our deepest sympathies to his wife of 54 years, Mary Ellen, his son Eddie and wife Christine, and his son Jay, wife Tina, and their children Caelinn and Declan. His absence from our community will be keenly felt, but his memory will live on in the great institution he did so much to build. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU

ROSEN--Leonard M. The Lymphoma Research Foundation notes with sadness the passing of Leonard M. Rosen, a 15-year member of the Foundation Board of Directors. During his tenure as a board member, Leonard contributed to the growth and expansion of the Foundation and its mission. The long-time Chair of the Foundation's public policy committee, he was a loyal champion of those facing a lymphoma diagnosis. Numerous patients and survivors have benefited from Leonard's dedication and the voice he helped to give to so many. His intelligence, candor and sincerity will be greatly missed. Our thoughts are with his family. Board of Directors, Lymphoma Research Foundation
ROSEN--Leonard M. We deeply mourn the loss of Leonard M. Rosen, long-time devoted board member, committed to improving the lives of children with cancer. Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy

WOLFSON--Nathan L. JBI International (the Jewish Braille Institute) mourns the passing of longtime Trustee and Honorary Officer, Nathan L. Wolfson. Together with his beloved wife, Suzanne, he was instrumental in supporting many JBI programs: The Suzanne K. Wolfson Fund for the Blind of Israel and Eastern Europe, Suzanne K. and Nathan L. Wolfson Recording Studio for the Blind of Israel and the Wolfson Special Needs Fund. These programs today help 35,000 blind and visually impaired children and adults in the US, Israel and around the world. Our thoughts are with his son, Myles, and his sister and brother-in-law, Elaine and Mervin Jacobs. We will mourn him but we will forever be blessed by his memory. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President & CEO Israel A. Taub, Vice President & CFO The Board of Trustees and Staff of JBI

PELL--Nuala, on Sunday, April 13 at the age of 89, Nuala O'Donnell Pell passed away peacefully in Newport, RI. Mrs. Pell was born in New York City on June 30, 1924 to Charles Oliver and Josephine Hartford O'Donnell. She attended Brearley School and Bennington College. Mrs. Pell was the beloved wife of the late United States Senator Claiborne Pell whom she married in 1944. She is survived by her brother Columbus O'Donnell of England, her son Christopher Pell and his wife, Janet of Newport, RI and her daughter, Dallas Pell Yates of New York City, NY. She was the mother of the late, Herbert Pell and Julia Pell. She is also survived by her five grandchildren, Tripler Pell, Nicholas Pell, Clay Pell, Christina Neal, and Eames Yates and her nine great-grandchildren; Elias, Marina and Atlas Hammoud, Oliver, Bertie and Nuala Randall, Zara Neal, Georgina and Henry Pell. Mrs. Pell was an extraordinary woman who dedicated her life to her husband, her children, and the citizens of Rhode Island. Her wit and generosity were obvious to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations to the Potter League for Animals, PO Box 412, Newport, RI 02840. A funeral service will be held at 11:00am on Monday, April 21st, 2014 at Trinity Church in Newport, Rhode Island. Additional information available at: memorialfuneralhome.com

ROSEN--Leonard M.,All of us at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are deeply saddened by the death of our dear colleague and friend, Leonard M. Rosen, at age 83. We will miss him greatly. We will be inspired by him always. Leonard was a founder of our Firm, and was instrumental in making it what it is today. He was a partner from 1965, when, intrepidly, together with Martin Lipton, Herbert Wachtell and George Katz, all graduates of NYU Law School, he launched our practice, until 1997, when he retired. In his retirement, he served as Of Counsel to our Firm until his passing on April 16, 2014. Leonard created, and led, the Firm's creditors' rights group. He transformed it into one of the nation's leading bankruptcy practices, representing banks, insurance companies, bondholders, and other institutional creditors. He counseled, advised, and advocated and negotiated for his clients on all manner of bankruptcy matters. He was a student of the law -- author of numerous articles on bankruptcy law, and a draftsman of sections of the leading treatise in the field. He was also a teacher of the law, serving for many years as an adjunct professor at the New York University School of Law, where he introduced aspiring lawyers to the subject he so loved. He was a leader of the bar, and a shaper of the law. He contributed to the drafting of the Bankruptcy Code and, as Chairman of the National Bankruptcy Conference from 1984 to 1992, played a leading role in the Code's development. He received the American College of Bankruptcy's Distinguished Service Award in 2003, along with many other accolades for his accomplishments during his decades of distinguished practice. As the leader of the Firm's bankruptcy and restructuring practice, Leonard was the attorney to whom our major institutional creditor clients so often turned first when credit problems arose with a major corporate borrower. To him they looked for judgment and leadership. And to him we looked for wisdom and guidance. By the time he retired, he had built a practice group so eminent that it was called upon by the United States Department of the Treasury to design and implement the immense government rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac -- the largest ever. Throughout his career, the matters Leonard handled were enormously consequential. In 1975, his client was the City of New York. It was on the verge of bankruptcy. The federal government had refused to help, and the Daily News headline famously screamed, "Ford to City: Drop Dead." After President Ford relented, Leonard stayed up round the clock with virtually the entire Firm, in the effort to prepare the complex and myriad agreements, securities, legislation and tax rulings needed so the City could obtain critical financing before year-end. At almost the same time, Leonard led the Firm's team that represented W. T. Grant during its historic bankruptcy -- the first billion-dollar Chapter 11 case, and the last in which the Firm was the lead counsel for a bankruptcy debtor. The list of historic matters goes on: Leonard represented the bank lenders to Chrysler during its government bailout in the early 1980s. He masterfully forged an agreement among Chrysler and each of its more than 400 bank lenders, an agreement that enabled Chrysler to survive and prosper during a period in which its failure appeared imminent. Leonard was also the lead attorney for the principal lenders in the debt restructurings and bankruptcies of many other major corporations in the real estate, financial, energy, agricultural equipment, steel and aircraft industries. But above all, Leonard was a good man. A generous man. A kind man. A man you could trust with your most difficult problems and deepest concerns, a superb partner who represented, and will always represent, all we strive to be as lawyers, citizens, and human beings. He was much sought after for his judgment, as well as for his marvelous ability to resolve disputes and reconcile disparate views. He shaped the culture of our Firm. He was the glue that cemented a group of hard-working and talented attorneys into a leading law firm that has served as a model for other firms. He was not only admired and respected by his colleagues; he was beloved. Leonard was deeply involved in the work of the Lymphoma Research Foundation and the Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy. The entire Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz family sends its deepest condolences to Leonard's wife Phyllis, his sons Adam, Steven and David, his daughter Carol, and his nine grandchildren. We share your loss, and your love for our dear friend Leonard.

SHERMAN--Doris C.,born December 30, 1916, lived until April 15, 2014. Daughter of Morris and Sarah Slavin. Survived by her children Thomas (Silma), Susan (William) and Stuart (Susan). Predeceased by her husband of many decades, Jack, and remembered lovingly by her grandchildren Richard (Kim), Lauren (Bobby), Glenn (Suzi), Elizabeth (Chris), Michael (Maggie) and Anthony (Ashley) and adoring great-grandchildren Lily, Nicholas, Isabella, Sam, Marly, Casey and Fiona. Also survived by dear friend, Edith Feldman.

HARLOW--Arthur Brooks Jr.,79, passed away peacefully on April 15, 2014. He is the former Headmaster of Fay School and a graduate of Groton School and Trinity College. Memorial service May 3, 2014 at Glenmoor, St., Augustine, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the A. Brooks Harlow, Jr. Scholarship Fund at Fay School, 48 Main Street, Southboro, MA 01772. www.craigfuneralhome.com

RICE--Peggy (Schwarz). The faculty, students and staff of the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at NYU mourn the death of Peggy (Schwarz) Rice. As president of the Rice Family Foundation, Peg established the Henry Hart Rice Professorship of Urban Policy and Planning, and the Henry Hart Rice Fellowship, awarded to outstanding students in the urban planning program. Peg and her late husband Henry Hart Rice deeply believed in New York City, a commitment carried on by her family. We extend our condolences to the entire Rice family.

RUBIN--Hyacinth, 97 years old, died April 15, 2014. Brilliant scientist and teacher, always ahead of her time, generous and loving, impeccably dressed with a hilarious, dry wit. She is survived by daughter Lois, grandchildren Heather and Dustin. Service Friday, April 18, 2014, 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel.
BORTOLUZZI--Shirley, nee Gollonder, 96, beloved wife of Dominick, died peacefully April 14, 2014. Survived by children Maria, Larry and Maribel and grandchildren Alana and Daniel.

BELLOWS--Howard Arthur. Howard Arthur Bellows, Jr., 76, died on March 20, 2014, at the Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Home in Greenwich, CT, following an extended illness. A longtime resident of Greenwich, he was the beloved husband of Mary Josephine "Jody" Boyd Bellows. In addition to his wife, Arthur is survived by his children: daughter, Maffitt Vodrey Bellows; son, Alexander Scott Bellows and his wife, Erin; daughter, Hillary Bellows Picardi and her husband, Preston; daughter, Jennifer Pacheteau Bellows, and two grandsons, Logan Bellows Picardi and Malcolm Arthur Bellows. He is also survived by a daughter, Heather Harvey Kremer, her husband, Jurgen, and granddaughter, Frejya Kremer. A sister, Judith Bellows Allen, predeceased him. Born March 10, 1938, in New York City, Arthur was the son of the late Howard Arthur and Rita Maffitt Bellows. His early years were spent in South Orange, NJ, before moving to Ohio with his family. He attended Western Reserve Academy in Hudson, OH, graduating in 1956; Princeton University, graduating in 1960. He earned an MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1964. He served as a Lieutenant, JG, in the U.S. Navy aboard the U.S.S. Midway aircraft carrier from 1960 to 1962. In 1967 Arthur became a founder, CEO and Chairman of The Triangle Corporation, maker of hand tools. In 1995 he joined Audits and Surveys Worldwide, Inc. as President, COO and Director. In 1999 he founded Braeburn Associates. Arthur also served on the Board of Directors of Hexcel Corp., Beacon Roofing Supply, Inc., First Communications, Inc., United Video Cablevision, Inc. and was a founder and Chairman of United Media, Inc. Arthur was active in many educational institutions, having served from 1979 to 2006 on the Board of Western Reserve Academy as Trustee and as Chairman from 2000 to 2006. He was Chairman of the Board of Governors of the University Cottage Club of Princeton University and was the Harvard Business School Class of 1964 Historian. Arthur was a Trustee of the Greenwich Hospital, the Greenwich Country Day School, the Round Hill Community Church, as well as a Director of the Boys and Girls Club, the Arch Street Teen Center and a Chairman of the Republican Round Table. An avid sportsman, Arthur enjoyed many sports at many clubs over the years. He loved skiing the black diamond trails on Vail Mountain, and entertaining the guys on his annual "Male Vail" trip. He played squash, tennis, golf, and enjoyed swimming in the summer. In Greenwich, he was a member of the Round Hill Club, the Blind Brook Club, the Field Club and the Stanwich Golf Club. He was also a member of the McArthur Golf Club in Hobe Sound, FL, the Eagle Springs and Game Creek Club in Vail, CO, as well as the Racquet and Tennis Club, the River Club and the Links Club in New York City. In Southampton, NY, he belonged to the Bathing Corporation, Meadow Club and the Shinnecock Golf Club. He was member of YPO and CEO. But, best about Arthur was his love of life. He could truly light up a room with his sense of fun, his sharp wit and engaging humor. He was always eager for a new trip, new friends, a new adventure, a new dance stepand his old favorite, the "chicken hop". He was especially supportive of his family and his old friends. He was a gentleman, with a twinkle in his eye and mischief always there for all to enjoy. He will be missed greatly. A Family Service was held in Greenwich on Saturday, April 5, 2014. The Interment Service was held in East Liverpool, Ohio. A Memorial Service will be held at Christ Church in Greenwich at 2:30pm on Saturday, May 17, 2014, with a Reception to follow at the Round Hill Club. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Arthur's memory to the LIFE Supportive Living Program in Hyannis, MA, or to Western Reserve Academy in Hudson, OH.

KELLER--Norma. December 27, 1921-April 17, 2014. Teacher, mother, wife. Born in Brooklyn, Norma went to CCNY at night for her B.A. and worked for Eimco for many years. She married Peter Keller, WWII veteran and Bronze Star recipient, in 1945, and was with him for 59 years until his 2005 death. They moved from Joralemon Street in Brooklyn to Stuyvesant Town, where their daughters Lisa (Saky Yakas) and Nina (Rich Adago) were born. In 1960 they settled in New Rochelle. In the early 1960s an elementary school principal plucked her from the secretary's chair and put her in a classroom, where she had a crash course in how to teach. For 25 years she was a dedicated and beloved first grade teacher, first in the South Bronx and then in Greenburgh. She returned to college nights and weekends to earn a Master's in Education. In retirement, she became a tutor for home-bound students with both mental and physical disabilities. Children adored her, and she was enormously kind to anyone she met. She is survived by her daughters, sons-in-law, sister Renee, nephew Mark and Jeff, niece Lynette, and beloved grandchildren Benjamin, Perry, and Naomi. Services will take place at Temple Israel of New Rochelle Tuesday, April 22, 1 pm, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. The family will host shiva at Norma's home afterwards. Gifts in memory can be made to the Norma Keller Fund, New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Development Office (Attn. Tamiko Collier), 654 West 170th Street, New York, NY 10032.

ROSEN--Leonard M.,All of us at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are deeply saddened by the death of our dear colleague and friend, Leonard M. Rosen, at age 83. We will miss him greatly. We will be inspired by him always. Leonard was a founder of our Firm, and was instrumental in making it what it is today. He was a partner from 1965, when, intrepidly, together with Martin Lipton, Herbert Wachtell and George Katz, all graduates of NYU Law School, he launched our practice, until 1997, when he retired. In his retirement, he served as Of Counsel to our Firm until his passing on April 16, 2014. Leonard created, and led, the Firm's creditors' rights group. He transformed it into one of the nation's leading bankruptcy practices, representing banks, insurance companies, bondholders, and other institutional creditors. He counseled, advised, and advocated and negotiated for his clients on all manner of bankruptcy matters. He was a student of the law -- author of numerous articles on bankruptcy law, and a draftsman of sections of the leading treatise in the field. He was also a teacher of the law, serving for many years as an adjunct professor at the New York University School of Law, where he introduced aspiring lawyers to the subject he so loved. He was a leader of the bar, and a shaper of the law. He contributed to the drafting of the Bankruptcy Code and, as Chairman of the National Bankruptcy Conference from 1984 to 1992, played a leading role in the Code's development. He received the American College of Bankruptcy's Distinguished Service Award in 2003, along with many other accolades for his accomplishments during his decades of distinguished practice. As the leader of the Firm's bankruptcy and restructuring practice, Leonard was the attorney to whom our major institutional creditor clients so often turned first when credit problems arose with a major corporate borrower. To him they looked for judgment and leadership. And to him we looked for wisdom and guidance. By the time he retired, he had built a practice group so eminent that it was called upon by the United States Department of the Treasury to design and implement the immense government rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac -- the largest ever. Throughout his career, the matters Leonard handled were enormously consequential. In 1975, his client was the City of New York. It was on the verge of bankruptcy. The federal government had refused to help, and the Daily News headline famously screamed, "Ford to City: Drop Dead." After President Ford relented, Leonard stayed up round the clock with virtually the entire Firm, in the effort to prepare the complex and myriad agreements, securities, legislation and tax rulings needed so the City could obtain critical financing before year-end. At almost the same time, Leonard led the Firm's team that represented W. T. Grant during its historic bankruptcy -- the first billion-dollar Chapter 11 case, and the last in which the Firm was the lead counsel for a bankruptcy debtor. The list of historic matters goes on: Leonard represented the bank lenders to Chrysler during its government bailout in the early 1980s. He masterfully forged an agreement among Chrysler and each of its more than 400 bank lenders, an agreement that enabled Chrysler to survive and prosper during a period in which its failure appeared imminent. Leonard was also the lead attorney for the principal lenders in the debt restructurings and bankruptcies of many other major corporations in the real estate, financial, energy, agricultural equipment, steel and aircraft industries. But above all, Leonard was a good man. A generous man. A kind man. A man you could trust with your most difficult problems and deepest concerns, a superb partner who represented, and will always represent, all we strive to be as lawyers, citizens, and human beings. He was much sought after for his judgment, as well as for his marvelous ability to resolve disputes and reconcile disparate views. He shaped the culture of our Firm. He was the glue that cemented a group of hard-working and talented attorneys into a leading law firm that has served as a model for other firms. He was not only admired and respected by his colleagues; he was beloved. Leonard was deeply involved in the work of the Lymphoma Research Foundation and the Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy. The entire Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz family sends its deepest condolences to Leonard's wife Phyllis, his sons Adam, Steven and David, his daughter Carol, and his nine grandchildren. We share your loss, and your love for our dear friend Leonard.

ROSEN--Leonard M. The Rosen family mourns the passing of Leonard M. Rosen, beloved husband of Phyllis for 56 years. He is also survived by his children Adam, Steven, David and Carol, as well as his nine grandchildren Alex, Emma, Benjamin, Hannah, Jack, Sophie, Owen, Ella and Naree. Leonard will be greatly missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Those wishing to recognize Leonard's passing may donate to two charitable organizations with which he was deeply involved: The Lymphoma Research Foundation and The Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy.

PLATNICK--Audrey, died April 13, 2014, just shy of her 93rd birthday, from respiratory problems. She lived on the Upper West Side for over 70 years. Until January, Audrey remained active at church and worked in architecture. She graduated from Columbia University in 1947, was active in NOW and a leader of the Society of Design Administration. She is survived by her husband Joe, her son Joe, his wife, her grandchildren and a sister. A memorial service will be held on May 18, 2014 at Park Avenue Christian Church in Manhattan.

ROTHSTEIN--Patricia J.,passed away on April 18, 2014. Devoted wife of Ira Rothstein. Beloved mother of Michael, Brett and Trish. Loving sister and brother-in-law of Pamela and Allen Dreyfuss. Cherished aunt of Jason, Jonathan, Jessica and Joanna. Services Sunday, April 20, 2014 at 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Leukemia Fighters, C/O Dr. Gail J. Roboz- 520 E. 70th Street, Box 403, NY, NY 10021.

ROSEN--Leonard M. The Rosen family mourns the passing of Leonard M. Rosen, beloved husband of Phyllis for 56 years. He is also survived by his children Adam, Steven, David and Carol, as well as his nine grandchildren Alex, Emma, Benjamin, Hannah, Jack, Sophie, Owen, Ella and Naree. Leonard will be greatly missed by his family, friends and colleagues. Those wishing to recognize Leonard's passing may donate to two charitable organizations with which he was deeply involved: The Lymphoma Research Foundation and The Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy.

SUDARSKY--R. David. Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital (MEETH) and the North Shore-LIJ Health System wish to offer our condolences on the loss of our esteemed former Chairman of the Board of Surgeon Directors, Dr. R. David Sudarsky. Born in Hartford, CT, Dr. Sudarsky was a renowned Retinal expert who was instrumental in developing the retinal/cataract cryoprobe in 1964 with Alcon Corp. A graduate from Yale University School of Medicine in 1949, he completed both his Residency in Ophthalmology (1954-1956) and Fellowship in Retinal/Vitreous Surgery with Dr. Charles Schepens (1957-1959) at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary. He was appointed Chief of Retinal Services at MEETH in 1985 and also appointed an Associate Clinical Professor at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons-Harkness Eye Institute. Amongst his numerous accolades, he served as President of the Manhattan Ophthalmological Society, New York Society for Clinical Ophthalmology and Chairman of the Board of Surgeon Directors at MEETH 1985-1995. Dr. Sudarsky mentored generations of Retinal Surgeons in training and guided MEETH to the forefront of Ophthalmological training and care in the United States. We extend our feeling of loss to his family and friends as he will be greatly missed.

TOLLIS--Barbara Dana. The Officers and The Board of Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home note with great sadness the passing of our friend, Barbara Dana Tollis. A kindhearted supporter of our mission, Barbara made many important contributions to the Home. She always went the extra mile in all that she did for our children, who she loved very dearly. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family and friends. The Officers and Directors of the Southampton Fresh Air Home

TOLLIS--Barbara Dana, passed April 7 surrounded by family and friends. Barbara was a trailblazer for women in the financial world, but her heart belonged to children in the MSKCC Pediatrics Dept. The family wish to thank her many friends, and the medical staff of Lenox Hill Hospital and MSKCC. The funeral is on April 28 at 4:30pm, St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St. Reception to follow at the Colony Club, 6pm, Park at 62nd St. Donations may be made in Barbara's memory to fund the MSKCC Pediatrics Dept. Immune Cell Therapy Lab through: www.maxcurefoundation.org.

WILSON--William B.,of Menlo Park, CA, formerly of New York City and Bryn Mawr, PA, passed away peacefully on April 11, 2014 at age 92. Born and raised in Rochester, NY, Bill was attending Williams College when he enlisted as a Lieutenant in the Navy on December 8, 1941. As a pilot in the Navy, he taught aerial photography and was later based on the carrier, Intrepid. After WWII, he graduated from Williams ('43), and with his first wife, Penelope, moved to Pennsylvania to work in R & D at Smith-Kline. His real love was aviation though, and in the 1950's, Bill bought and developed a field in West Chester, PA, which he eventually named Brandywine Airport. He loved the countryside there, and took pride in developing the land around the airport in an environmentally friendly manner. Throughout his life, his adventurous spirit never left him---flying his small plane, sailing his "Winddance", and skiing all over the world. He was known for the wonderful tales he told about his exploits. For over 65 years Bill was a member of the Adirondack League Club in Old Forge, NY, and even after moving to CA in 2003, he and his wife, Joan, whom he married in 1985, would drive across the country with their dog to this favorite place. The natural beauty of the Bay Area brought great enjoyment to him in his retirement. In addition to his wife, Bill is survived by his daughters, Linn Krieg of McAllister, MT, Suzanne Wilson of Big Timber, MT, Wendy O'Brien of Aiken, SC, Elizabeth Gonzalez of Oley, PA, and Victoria Wilson-Charles of Veneta, OR; his step-son, Steedman Hinckley of Chevy Chase, MD, 14 grandchildren, 17 great-grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Memorial services will take place in Palo Alto, CA on May 17th and at the Adirondack League Club around August 23rd. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made online to the Peninsula Open Space Trust or to the Adirondack Council.

ROVIT--Barbara M.,passed away peacefully on April 13, 2014. She was born on August 26, 1928, in Boston, Massachusetts, graduated from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and lived in Boston, MA, Wynnewood, PA and Scarsdale, NY. She was the daughter of Joseph and Ruth Margolis. She is survived by her husband of 61 years, Dr. Richard L. Rovit. She is also survived by her three children, Hugh (Alice), Adam and Sandra (Peter) Golze, six grandchildren--Elizabeth, Sarah and Andrew Rovit, Julina Coupland and Benjamin and Michael Golze, and two great-grandchildren (Sasha and Miri Coupland). She is also survived by her sister Ellyn (James Stewart) Polshek. Services were private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Barbara M. Rovit Memorial Fund, Sarah Neuman Center, 845 Palmer Avenue, Mamaroneck, NY 10543. May her memory be a blessing.

LOVENTHAL--Lawrence. August 1, 1925 - April 17, 2014. Husband, Father, Grandfather, Businessman, Commissioner. Born in New York and lived there for over 83 years before settling in Santa Monica. Lawrence was active in supporting our Policeman and Fireman for many years. He founded and served as President of The Centurion Foundation supporting New York Policeman for almost 20 years. He was appointed an Honorary Police Commissioner in New York City for his dedicated services. Devoted, caring and loving husband for over 58 years to Renee. Devoted father of Charles and Leonard (Laura). Cherished grandfather of Minna (Aaron), Hannah, Emma and Lily. Loving brother of Gloria Silver. Services Wednesday, 10:45am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to Tufts University, Lawrence Loventhal Scholarship Fund.

She left behind her adored brother-in-law, my husband James Stewart Polshek, and our loving children, Peter Max Polshek, his wife, Nina Hofer, and Jennifer Hyde Polshek. Martha Vietor Glass, President The Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center

PARDO--Gary "Garo", 12/14/1957 - 4/20/2013 You will forever dance in our hearts and minds. You gave us many gifts: beloved soul mate and father, devoted friend and teacher, courageous and loving man. We love and miss you Squeeze. Estelle, Dustin & Noah

ROSEN--Leonard M.,All of us at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are deeply saddened by the death of our dear colleague and friend, Leonard M. Rosen, at age 83. We will miss him greatly. We will be inspired by him always. Leonard was a founder of our Firm, and was instrumental in making it what it is today. He was a partner from 1965, when, intrepidly, together with Martin Lipton, Herbert Wachtell and George Katz, all graduates of NYU Law School, he launched our practice, until 1997, when he retired. In his retirement, he served as Of Counsel to our Firm until his passing on April 16, 2014. Leonard created, and led, the Firm's creditors' rights group. He transformed it into one of the nation's leading bankruptcy practices, representing banks, insurance companies, bondholders, and other institutional creditors. He counseled, advised, and advocated and negotiated for his clients on all manner of bankruptcy matters. He was a student of the law -- author of numerous articles on bankruptcy law, and a draftsman of sections of the leading treatise in the field. He was also a teacher of the law, serving for many years as an adjunct professor at the New York University School of Law, where he introduced aspiring lawyers to the subject he so loved. He was a leader of the bar, and a shaper of the law. He contributed to the drafting of the Bankruptcy Code and, as Chairman of the National Bankruptcy Conference from 1984 to 1992, played a leading role in the Code's development. He received the American College of Bankruptcy's Distinguished Service Award in 2003, along with many other accolades for his accomplishments during his decades of distinguished practice. As the leader of the Firm's bankruptcy and restructuring practice, Leonard was the attorney to whom our major institutional creditor clients so often turned first when credit problems arose with a major corporate borrower. To him they looked for judgment and leadership. And to him we looked for wisdom and guidance. By the time he retired, he had built a practice group so eminent that it was called upon by the United States Department of the Treasury to design and implement the immense government rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac -- the largest ever. Throughout his career, the matters Leonard handled were enormously consequential. In 1975, his client was the City of New York. It was on the verge of bankruptcy. The federal government had refused to help, and the Daily News headline famously screamed, "Ford to City: Drop Dead." After President Ford relented, Leonard stayed up round the clock with virtually the entire Firm, in the effort to prepare the complex and myriad agreements, securities, legislation and tax rulings needed so the City could obtain critical financing before year-end. At almost the same time, Leonard led the Firm's team that represented W. T. Grant during its historic bankruptcy -- the first billion-dollar Chapter 11 case, and the last in which the Firm was the lead counsel for a bankruptcy debtor. The list of historic matters goes on: Leonard represented the bank lenders to Chrysler during its government bailout in the early 1980s. He masterfully forged an agreement among Chrysler and each of its more than 400 bank lenders, an agreement that enabled Chrysler to survive and prosper during a period in which its failure appeared imminent. Leonard was also the lead attorney for the principal lenders in the debt restructurings and bankruptcies of many other major corporations in the real estate, financial, energy, agricultural equipment, steel and aircraft industries. But above all, Leonard was a good man. A generous man. A kind man. A man you could trust with your most difficult problems and deepest concerns, a superb partner who represented, and will always represent, all we strive to be as lawyers, citizens, and human beings. He was much sought after for his judgment, as well as for his marvelous ability to resolve disputes and reconcile disparate views. He shaped the culture of our Firm. He was the glue that cemented a group of hard-working and talented attorneys into a leading law firm that has served as a model for other firms. He was not only admired and respected by his colleagues; he was beloved. Leonard was deeply involved in the work of the Lymphoma Research Foundation and the Children's Cause for Cancer Advocacy. The entire Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz family sends its deepest condolences to Leonard's wife Phyllis, his sons Adam, Steven and David, his daughter Carol, and his nine grandchildren. We share your loss, and your love for our dear friend Leonard.

SCHMIDT--Marsha A.,passed away quietly on April 14, 2014 surrounded by family and friends after a brief illness caused by acute pulmonary distress following surgery recovery. Born on October 4, 1943 in Hackensack, NJ, Marsha graduated from Tenafly High School in 1961 and from Hood College in Frederick, Maryland in 1965 after making lifelong friends at both schools. She excelled at languages and earned several graduate level teaching certificates which enabled her to teach Spanish and coach non-English speaking visiting diplomats from the United Nations who were new to New York City. She also had a successful career in Marketing and held several executive positions at book publisher Doubleday and Company. It was at Doubleday where Marsha met John O'Donnell, whom she married and spent ten happy years before his death in 1993. Since his death Marsha split her time between New York City and Oakdale, Long Island and enjoyed the loyal companionship of college and career friends. She loved to travel to Europe and especially to Mexico where she had enjoyed many happy vacations with John. Marsha is survived by her father, Werner Schmidt, of Yarmouth Port, Massachusetts and her brother Paul and his wife Mary of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, and three nephews who live in Chicago and Seattle. She will be sorely missed by them and by all her friends around the country. A memorial celebration of her life is being planned for later this spring. Marsha, as did John, had a passion for domestic animals and their welfare as well as for medical research to combat cancer. Donations in Marsha's memory may be made to the ASPCA or the New York Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell Medical Center.
LESTER--Dorothy Bindelglass April 1, 1931 - April 18, 1989 25 years. I miss you everyday. I love being your daughter. Susan

ROTHSTEIN--Patricia J.,passed away on April 18, 2014. Devoted wife of Ira Rothstein. Beloved mother of Michael, Brett and Trish. Loving sister and brother-in-law of Pamela and Allen Dreyfuss. Cherished aunt of Jason, Jonathan, Jessica and Joanna. Services Sunday, April 20, 2014 at 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Leukemia Fighters, C/O Dr. Gail J. Roboz- 520 E. 70th Street, Box 403, NY, NY 10021.

SOLOMON--Florence, age 92: Loved by her children William, Robert, and Judith, her daughters-in-law Terry and Marge, and her five grandchildren, Philip, Sophie, David, Daniel, and Stephen, whom she held dear. Born to Isidor Schneider and Reyzl Lenofsky as the eldest of five, she put herself through NYU to become a special ed teacher and saw her late husband of 41 years, Nathan A Solomon, through his PhD, MD. Forever devoted to Yiddishkeit, Judaism, and Israel, she was a superb Jewish joke teller, folk dancer, and Loehmann's lover. She turned her dreams into realities, and did so in her own inimitable way until her very last day: released, at her insistence, from a two-month rehab stay, she died later that night in her own bed, a longstanding wish. Her final, spoken words were "To thine own self be true." Donations in her memory may be made to the Park Avenue Synagogue Library, 50 E. 87th Street, New York, NY 10128.
KAZLOW--Sol E. 1st year without you (Can Do, You Did!) Love You Forever, Pauline and Family

CASSIAN--Nina, of New York City, died at age 89 on April 14, 2014. A central figure in Romanian arts and literature, Nina was a poet, translator, critic, children's book author, visual artist, and composer. She published more than 50 books in Romania; several collections of her poems, translated from Romanian or written originally in English, have appeared here including "Life Sentence" and her last "Continuum." A refugee from the Ceausescu regime, Nina took up residence in New York in the 1980s and later became an American citizen. Her poems have been published in The New Yorker, The Atlantic, and many other magazines. A compelling reader of her own work, she appeared at numerous poetry venues across Europe and the United States. She continued to be celebrated in her homeland, where her multi-volume autobiography was published in the early 2000s. Nina's brilliant mind, razor wit, and great personal charm will be missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her husband, Maurice Edwards. A funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., on Tuesday, April 22 at 4pm.

GORDON--Saul, died peacefully on Sunday, April 6th, surrounded by his family. A long-time resident of New York City, Paris, France, and Nairobi, Kenya, Saul was born in Williamsburg, Brooklyn on April 18, 1932 and graduated from City College at the age of 18. He traveled widely through Europe, Africa, and the Middle East, collecting further degrees in France and London. He lived in a Moshav in Israel his 20s. In 1966 Saul and his brother, Harold Gordon, founded Park East Tours, one of the largest safari companies, opening the US tourist market to East Africa. He married Marcia Corbett in 1971 and lived in Kenya where their three daughters were born. Saul and Marcia moved to Paris in 1981 where their children were educated. Park East Tours was sold in the late 1990s. Saul Gordon is survived by his wife, Marcia, of New York City and Albuquerque, New Mexico and his three daughters: Eleana and her husband Avi Jorisch of Washington, DC, Joanna of Paris, France; and Elizabeth and her fiance, David Halliday of Brooklyn, New York, as well as two grandchildren, Eiden and Oren Jorisch of Washington, DC. Saul is also survived by his brother Harold Gordon. Saul will always be remembered as a great wit and a raconteur of the first order and above all for his belief in the power of education and devotion to his family.

JAFFE--Fredrick, M.D. The members of the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the untimely passing of our valued friend and colleague, Dr. Fredrick F. Jaffe. Dr. Jaffe was an honored member of our department for 44 years, as a resident, faculty member, and Director of the Division of Adult Reconstructive Surgery. He was an outstanding clinician, gifted surgeon and dedicated educator. Thousands of patients have benefited from the hip and knee replacement surgery he performed, restoring productive and pain free lives. He contributed to the education of scores of orthopaedic residents, who now practice the principles he taught. He leaves a saddened hospital community with a profound void. His many years of dedicated work at the Hospital for Joint Diseases touched the lives of an infinite number of people. We grieve his passing as we celebrate his exemplary life and extend our heart-felt sympathy to his wife, Dr. Deborah Moody; his sons, David and Harry; his daughters-in-law, Leslie and Andrea and his grandchildren Zachary, Aria and Lila. Joseph D. Zuckerman M.D., Chair William L. Jaffe, M.D. Joseph A. Bosco, M.D. Kenneth A Egol, Vice Chairs, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, NYU Langone Medical Center

EDELSON--Beatrice, age 99, passed away peacefully on April 17th at her home in Roswell, GA. She was a devoted wife of 65 years to late husband Robert, proud, loving mother to sons Drs. Kenneth and Stephen, doting grandmother to Dana, Richie, Alex, Bradley, Joshua and great-grandmother to Olivia, Gibson, Nico and Calliope. Bea was always upbeat and full of positive fun energy. Her legacy is that she campaigned for social justice, equality and human rights all her life. She will be missed beyond words. Funeral in Atlanta.

KANOF--George, of White Plains, NY passed away April 14, 2014. He was 82. George was born on February 2, 1932 in New York, NY to Isidore and Esther Kanof. He was predeceased by his sister Libby Stein and later, by his dear sister Manya Gussack. George is survived by his loving wife of 53 years, Beverly Coombs Kanof; his son, Steven Ian Kanof and his wife Lisa; his daughter, Laura Brette Coyle and her husband Timothy. He had two grandchildren whom he adored, Sydney Marie and Grady James Coyle. He was Uncle George to Amy and Kermit, Lisa, Faith, Nina and Allan, David and Snow and all of their children: Adam, Sophie, Jonathan, Rebecca, Benjamin, Daniel, Natasha, Linda and Jessica. Aunt Belle was like a sister to him. George served in the Army during the Korean War under his birth name, Joseph Kanof. He was stationed in Poitier, France and was the Communications Specialist. He enjoyed sharing his good humor and talent as he participated in entertaining the troops. His work in the ball bearing industry as Vice President of International Relations and Director of the Micro Ball Bearing Division at General Bearing Corporation sent him traveling around the world. On August 8, 1988, George fulfilled his lifelong dream of starting his own business and lived the rest of his years as the President of Prime Bearing, Inc., where he worked diligently and happily. George was a well-respected, honest man and a person everyone could trust. George enjoyed tennis, golf, and boating. He was an avid photographer, who marveled at Cape Cod's landscapes, its waters, and its extraordinary sunsets for nearly sixty years. He appreciated history, theater, movies, college sports, music of all kinds, and reading. He was happy to go to the track, especially with his nephew, David Gussack. George was an extremely loyal friend to many. He treasured his friendships with Billy Fischgrund and Herbie Michaelis and missed them deeply after they passed. He will forever be one of the boys from Weeks Avenue and with their wives, they were The Group. George was committed to keeping in touch and shared love, support, and humor with all of his friends and family. He made us all laugh again and again. The memorial service was held at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home. George was laid to rest in the Garden of the Maples at Kensico Cemetery.

ROSENBERG--George, passed away on April 18, 2014. Devoted husband of Pearl. Beloved father of Joseph (Randi Gordon) and Fred (Lana). Cherished grandfather of Alexa, Louis, Scott and Lauren. Services Sunday, April 20, 2014 at 1:30pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza (Opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to The Parkinson's Foundation.

GOODYEAR--Toby, died April 6. Born in Buffalo, NY in 1934, to Louise and Lawrence Grady. Survived by her daughter, Lauren Goodyear Schramm of Washington, DC, son Jake Goodyear of New Canaan, CT, sister Joy Simpkins of Pound Ridge, NY, and six grandchildren. Donations may be sent in her memory to the Princeton Symphony Orchestra, the Princeton Singers, or the Park School of Buffalo.

JAFFE--Dr. Fredrick F. The family of Dr. Fredrick F. Jaffe, M.D. mourns his passing on April 16, after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of Dr. Deborah Moody, loving father to David and Harry, proud grandfather to Zachary, Lila and Aria. He enjoyed a long and distinguished career as orthopedic surgeon, teacher and researcher in New York City, mostly at the HJD division of the NYU-Langone Medical Center. Respected, admired and loved by extended family, medical colleagues and the thousands of patients whose lives he restored. He will live in our hearts forever.

ROBERTS--George H.,III, 85, died at The Cypress, Hilton Head Island, SC on Friday, April 11th. George was born in Brooklyn, NY to Dr. George H. Roberts, Jr. and Alma Gordon Roberts. A graduate of The Hotchkiss School and Rutgers University, George served in the U.S. Army as an officer in the First Guided Missile Corps, Artillery. He graduated from NYU Law School and passed the New York State Bar in 1956. It was at NYU that he and Estelle Scrobogna met, and they were married in NYC in 1955. Following graduation, George embarked on his 34 year-long career with Citibank where he ran the Corporate Banking Group's Chemical Department and served as a senior banker. He became Region Head in the World Corporation Group, retiring in 1991. George and Estelle raised their family on Long Island, living in Lloyd Harbor for 32 years. George was a quintessential Long Island commuter. He was an active community leader, serving as Chairman of the Huntington American Red Cross, Chairman of the Huntington Parks Committee, Treasurer of the Cold Spring Harbor Library and a member of Huntington Hospital Board of Governors and its Finance Committee. For many years, he was also an active Trustee of the Huntington Country Club. Upon retiring to Hilton Head, George led the restructuring of Moss Creek Plantation serving, among other things, as Treasurer and President. He mentored many, frequently advising on personal and professional matters. George was a loving partner and father, known for his positive wit and moral compass. He and Estelle traveled extensively, cherishing the opportunity to experience new places and cultures together. George was an avid sailor and life-long golfer who enjoyed time spent at The Creek in Locust Valley; National Golf Links of America and Shinnecock in Southampton; and the Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club. George is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Estelle S. Roberts, their two daughters, Catherine Roberts Casalicchio (Piero) of Huntington, NY; Patricia Roberts Winton (Nick) of Boston, MA; grandchildren George, Brando, Cristina Casalicchio; Hank, Fuller, Lucia, Charlotte Winton; son-in-law Carlos Madrid; his sister, Dr. Ann Stewart, and brother-in-law, Dr. William Durant. George was predeceased by his adored daughter, Elizabeth Stacey Roberts, and his sister, Barbara Gavigan Hershberger. A celebration of George's life will be held at Moss Creek Plantation, Hilton Head, South Carolina on June 14, 2014. Memorials may be made to the Liz Roberts Fund, c/o Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Bungtown Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, 11724. www.theislandfuneral home.com.

FRANCE--Harold Stanley, 88, passed away April 3, 2014 at his home in Tappan, NY. Born on May 25, 1925 to Alex and Mary (Bruno) France in Garfield, NJ, Harold is survived by his cousin Caroline Paparozzi and predeceased by sister Elaine Schomberg and cousin Marguerite Brown. His wife Elinor Levey France and their beloved dog, Bella, survive him; Also Harold, Paula (Pierre), Leslie (Frank) and Caren (Kevin) children of Florence DeRosa; his stepchildren, Jonathan (Monique) and Theodore (Mei) and grandchildren, Oscar, Lyric and Samuel. Hal's kindness, warmth, intelligence and sense of humor will be missed by those fortunate to know him. Memorial donations may be made in Harold's name to the Ridgewood Symphony Orchestra, Box 176, Ridgewood, NJ.

KELLER--Norma. December 27, 1921-April 17, 2014. Teacher, mother, wife. Born in Brooklyn, Norma went to CCNY at night for her B.A. and worked for Eimco for many years. She married Peter Keller, WWII veteran and Bronze Star recipient, in 1945, and was with him for 59 years until his 2005 death. They moved from Joralemon Street in Brooklyn to Stuyvesant Town, where their daughters Lisa (Saky Yakas) and Nina (Rich Adago) were born. In 1960 they settled in New Rochelle. In the early 1960s an elementary school principal plucked her from the secretary's chair and put her in a classroom, where she had a crash course in how to teach. For 25 years she was a dedicated and beloved first grade teacher, first in the South Bronx and then in Greenburgh. She returned to college nights and weekends to earn a Master's in Education. In retirement, she became a tutor for home-bound students with both mental and physical disabilities. Children adored her, and she was enormously kind to anyone she met. She is survived by her daughters, sons-in-law, sister Renee, nephew Mark and Jeff, niece Lynette, and beloved grandchildren Benjamin, Perry, and Naomi. Services will take place at Temple Israel of New Rochelle Tuesday, April 22, 1 pm, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. The family will host shiva at Norma's home afterwards. Gifts in memory can be made to the Norma Keller Fund, New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Development Office (Attn. Tamiko Collier), 654 West 170th Street, New York, NY 10032.

JOACHIM--Ira Lewis. July 2, 1925, passed away March 14, 2014 at his home in Northern California. He was predeceased by his wife Paula. He is survived by his son Lindsay and daughter Robin. See the full obituary at Legacy.com.

OLIVA--L. Jay. The NYU community grieves deeply the loss of its cherished 14th president, L. Jay Oliva. No one served NYU better or more faithfully than he, or did more to shape the NYU we know today. Starting as a member of the history faculty in 1960, he went on to be the last dean of the Heights campus, helping to guide NYU through some of its most challenging moments. From that point forward, through his tenure as chancellor and then president, he had a key hand in engineering what has been described as the greatest success story in contemporary American higher education. Understanding the diversity of student success at NYU, he cheered on NYU's top students, our athletes, our performing artists, and our community service volunteers. Educator, mentor, leader, and great colleague and friend -- he loved NYU through-and-through, believed in its promise, and led the way in making NYU a respected national research university and jump-starting its global efforts. All those who wear violet mourn today, and we send our deepest sympathies to his wife of 54 years, Mary Ellen, his son Eddie and wife Christine, and his son Jay, wife Tina, and their children Caelinn and Declan. His absence from our community will be keenly felt, but his memory will live on in the great institution he did so much to build. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU

OLIVA--L. Jay. Dr. Oliva was a joy to work with for nearly three decades. This brilliant and talented man will be missed by me. Heartfelt condolences to Mary Ellen, their sons and their families. Patrice A. Fealy

ERLE--Joan Barbara, M.D. 84, died at home on April 18 after a long struggle with Parkinson's Disease. Remarkable mother, grandmother, wife, physician, psychoanalyst, teacher, researcher, cook, baker, gardener, reader, traveler and friend. We miss you. Henry, David, Renee, Steven, Kim, Matt, Erica, Eliza, Eric, Oliver. A Memorial Service will be held at Plaza Memorial Chapel on Sunday, April 27 at 2:30pm, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.
KUHL--Dr. Frank P.,78, of the Bronx and Wharton, NJ, on April 12, 2014. Respected scientist and beloved patriarch.

PELL--Nuala, on Sunday, April 13 at the age of 89, Nuala O'Donnell Pell passed away peacefully in Newport, RI. Mrs. Pell was born in New York City on June 30, 1924 to Charles Oliver and Josephine Hartford O'Donnell. She attended Brearley School and Bennington College. Mrs. Pell was the beloved wife of the late United States Senator Claiborne Pell whom she married in 1944. She is survived by her brother Columbus O'Donnell of England, her son Christopher Pell and his wife, Janet of Newport, RI and her daughter, Dallas Pell Yates of New York City, NY. She was the mother of the late, Herbert Pell and Julia Pell. She is also survived by her five grandchildren, Tripler Pell, Nicholas Pell, Clay Pell, Christina Neal, and Eames Yates and her nine great-grandchildren; Elias, Marina and Atlas Hammoud, Oliver, Bertie and Nuala Randall, Zara Neal, Georgina and Henry Pell. Mrs. Pell was an extraordinary woman who dedicated her life to her husband, her children, and the citizens of Rhode Island. Her wit and generosity were obvious to all who knew her. In lieu of flowers, kindly send donations to the Potter League for Animals, PO Box 412, Newport, RI 02840. A funeral service will be held at 11:00am on Monday, April 21st, 2014 at Trinity Church in Newport, Rhode Island. Additional information available at: memorialfuneralhome.com

LEE--Robert J.,at home on April 16, 2014. Bob was a founder of Lee-Hecht-Harrison, Inc., past president of The Center for Creative Leadership in Greensboro, NC and active executive coach and co-founder of ICoach. He was a dedicated teacher. Beloved husband of Mary, devoted father of David and Carola Schambach, Andrea and Jerry Carlson, and Mark. Loving grandfather of Rebecca, Orin and Benjamin. He will be dearly missed. Service Sunday, April 20, 2014, 1:15pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory would be appreciated to The American Diabetes Association or the American Heart Association.

PLATNICK--Audrey, died April 13, 2014, just shy of her 93rd birthday, from respiratory problems. She lived on the Upper West Side for over 70 years. Until January, Audrey remained active at church and worked in architecture. She graduated from Columbia University in 1947, was active in NOW and a leader of the Society of Design Administration. She is survived by her husband Joe, her son Joe, his wife, her grandchildren and a sister. A memorial service will be held on May 18, 2014 at Park Avenue Christian Church in Manhattan.

NEWHOUSE--Patricia G.,passed away on April 17 after a brief illness. She was at her home in John's Island in Florida and surrounded by her family. Born in Orange, New Jersey, she was 87 years old. She graduated from Columbia High School in South Orange and attended Wellesley College. She studied nursing and received her certification as a Licensed Practical Nurse. She was formerly of Short Hills, NJ and spent summers in Nantucket, MA. She is survived by her beloved husband of 69 years Robert J. Newhouse, Jr., her loving sons and daughters-in-law Robert J. Newhouse III and Laurie, Stephan F. Newhouse and Judy, and Paul B. Newhouse and Diane, six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. She was loved by all who knew her and was as beautiful on the inside as she was on the outside. A private service will be held in Nantucket, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

GREEN--Lindsay Waggener. March 13, 1926 - April 11, 2014 of Wichita Falls, Texas and New York, NY. Airborne when she danced. Steadfast when she landed. Child of Texas, citizen of New York. Radiant, with a charm that set rooms aglow. Descendent of pioneers, soldiers and scholars. Inheritor of all that energy and spirit of inquiry, that gift for innovation, that vein of genius. An engine of creativity, a reservoir of humor and wit possessed of enviable literary and theatrical skills. Astonishing beauty and incandescent intellect, all brought to bear on her career of choice as delightful wife, devoted mother, adoring grandmother, caring friend. Bill, Ross, Nancy, Ellie will never forget her, nor will anyone who ever met her.

OLIVA--Dr. L. Jay. We who worked with Dr. L. Jay Oliva for more than 30 years were first-hand witnesses to the role he played in moving a near-bankrupt university in the 1970's to the leading national and international research university it is today. His vision, talent and devotion to academic values defined his tenure as professor, provost, chancellor and president. One key to his success was his love and devotion to the institution and his commitment to its communities of faculty, staff and students. He led a singular institutional transformation with no one left behind. He was a rare blend of dreamer and realist, pushing us all to try harder, reach farther and pursue ideas which often seemed out of reach, but have come to define the essence of NYU today. A man with a big heart, he sustained and nurtured New York University. We miss his leadership and his friendship. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Sylvia Baruch Naomi Levine Ann Marcus C. Duncan Rice Harvey Stedman

CAPRETZ--Pierre, creator of French in Action, the innovative French language instruction program, died on April 2 in Aix-en-Provence, France. He was 89 years old. French in Action, introduced in 1985, is a total immersion course, modeled on language acquisition in young children: you hear, you mimic, you repeat, and gradually you acquire understanding and a natural grammar. Not a word of English is used. It's estimated that the course has created over a million new French speakers throughout North America and overseas. Each video lecon is led by a jovial mentor in grasping the fundamentals of French, and becoming imbued with a soupcon of Frenchness, known as "Le Professeur": Pierre Capretz, naturally. He was born in Mazamet, France, and earned a law degree and doctorate from the Sorbonne in Paris. His career in language instruction began at the University of Florida, Gainesville, and went on to Yale University in 1956, until he retired. The revised 3rd edition of French in Action, 2014, brings the narrative into the age of Twitter and "les bobos", the French counterparts to brownstone bohemians. He is survived by his companion of many years, Sylvie Mathe and their son Pierre Olivier Mathe, both of Aix-en-Provence, three sons from a former marriage, Michel Yan of Mill River, MA, Yves of New Haven, CT, and Alain of Manhattan, and one grandson.

GRIMALDI--Carol. The family along with the staff of Juliana's mourns the loss of our mother, sister, grandmother, wife, mentor and friend, Carol Grimaldi, who succumbed to cancer on April 10. Carol leaves behind her husband Patsy of 43 years, her beloved children, Rhonda Sobel of Rego Park, NY; Jayne and husband Arthur Bail of Denver, CO; Michael and wife Shelly Sobel of Douglassville, PA and Pat Grimaldi of Forest Hills, NY as well as her grandchildren, Sarah Cozzini; Aaron Sobel; Jacob Bail and Abigail Sobel. In addition she is survived by her brother Marty Abbe; sister-in-law Heather; nephew David and niece Melissa of New York. Born in the Bronx on May 20, 1938, the only daughter of the late Irving and Fannie Abbe, Carol attended PS 77, earned entry to the prestigious High School of Music and Art and graduated from Forest Hills High School. Together with her husband, Patsy Grimaldi, they emerged from retirement in late 2012 to open Juliana's in the same Brooklyn location where they launched legendary Grimaldi's Pizzeria in 1990, which they sold a decade later. Only recently did her illness force her to forsake her seat as President of the Board of Directors of Independence Residences, Inc. (IRI), a not-for-profit human service agency providing quality of life support to individuals with developmental and other disabilities. She will be deeply missed and remembered forever. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to IRI. http://www.in-res.org/

AUERBACH--Marjorie A. (Hoffberg), 83, of North Andover passed away Thursday, April 17, at the Meadows in North Andover. She was born in Queens, NY on December 10, 1930, daughter of the late Irving and Martha (Baer) Hoffberg. Marjorie graduated from the University of Wisconsin-Madison and later The Copper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in Manhattan. She wrote and illustrated children's books and was a gifted artist both in her paintings and graphic design. She is survived by her husband of 60 years Leon Auerbach, her daughter Andrea P. and her husband Nicholas T. Papapetros, DMD, four grandchildren Theo, Isabella, Olivia and Zachary all of North Andover, nieces Paula Tessler and Gail Goldberg. She was also the sister of the late Henry Hoffberg. Her graveside service was held Friday, April 18 at Temple Emanuel Cemetery, Lawrence. There was no memorial observance. Services handled by the H.L. Farmer & Sons Funeral Homes, Haverhill and Bradford. Contributions in her memory may be made to Temple Emanuel, 7 Haggetts Pond Rd., Andover, MA 01810. Condolences to her family may be made at farmerfuneralhomes.com

BARD--Martin, 79, basso and psychotherapist, died April 5 of complications from a kidney transplant. He was the loving father of Rachael and David and devoted grandfather to Emerson, Aaron, Elian and Estella. Also survived by his friend Martha and nephew Jared, he was predeceased by his brother Robert. Both mental health counselor and singer/ playwright, countering war and oppression through musical theater, Martin will be missed by many. Memorial Service next Sunday, April 27, 2pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th St., NYC.

BESHAR--Robert Peter, 86, died peacefully at home in Somers, New York on April 16. The son of Herbert and Ella Beshar, Bob grew up in New Rochelle with his two brothers and sister. During his senior year at Yale University, Bob was appointed Scholar of the House and graduated summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa. While at Yale Law School, Bob met the love of his life, Christine von Wedemeyer. Christine was attending Smith College on a Fulbright. Bob and Christine were married in Germany in 1953. Late last year, they celebrated their 60th anniversary together with their four children -- Cornelia (Rob Spring), Jacky (Scot Jones), Fritz (Peter Lehner) and Peter (Sarah Beshar) -- and their fourteen grandchildren. Bob enjoyed a distinguished career in private practice. He also served in a number of government positions: Assistant General Counsel of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, law clerk for the Honorable Charles Breitel on the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court, and Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Director of the Bureau of International Commerce in Washington. After leaving the Commerce Department in 1972, Bob returned to New York to set up his own practice. Bob served as special counsel, then Corporate Secretary and, for almost thirty years, on the board of directors of National Semiconductor Corporation in Santa Clara, California. He was a member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, the Foundation Board of Westchester Community College and the Planning Board of the Town of Somers. In 1993, Bob became President of his family's rug and antiques business, Beshar's, in New York City. Bob's interests were varied and intense. A love of decorative arts -- bronzes, china, jewelry, clocks. He liked to say: "the hand shapes the mind." Reading novels late into the night -- convinced there was more truth in fiction than in non-fiction. Telling a great story over dinner and challenging children, grandchildren and startled guests to "sing for their supper." Driving, and carefully polishing, his convertible Mercedes with the license plate "Besh" -- his nickname at New Rochelle High School. Playing backgammon and eating Armenian food -- dolma, olives, cheoreg and lahmajoon. Trapshooting at Gipsy Trail with friends -- usually top gun and always wearing his trademark Stetson. Most of all, though, Bob adored his wife, his children and his grandchildren: Huyette, Peter, Alexander, Melissa, Vanessa, Lizi, Maddie, Scout, Nadine, Eliza, Marina, Isabel, Henry and Sophie. A service will be held at St. Luke's Church in Somers, New York on Saturday, April 26 at 11:00am, followed by a reception at the Stone House. The family has asked that those interested in honoring Bob's legacy consider a donation to Westchester Community College Foundation Hartford Hall, 75 Grasslands Road, Valhalla, New York 10595.
BRICKNER--Philip W.,MD. Memorial on Saturday, April 26 at 3pm at The Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, NYC.
BORTOLUZZI--Shirley, nee Gollonder, 96, beloved wife of Dominick, died peacefully April 14, 2014. Survived by children Maria, Larry and Maribel and grandchildren Alana and Daniel.

ROVIT--Barbara M. August 26, 1928 - April 13, 2014. After a very long illness, my dear and only sister Barbara (nee Margolis) passed away last weekend. She left behind her adored brother-in-law, my husband James Stewart Polshek, and our loving children, Peter Max Polshek, his wife, Nina Hofer, and Jennifer Hyde Polshek. Barbara is also survived by our beloved grandchildren, Lucien Polshek and Solomon Polshek as well as her devoted children, Sandy and Peter Golze, Hugh and Dr. Alice Rovit, Dr. Adam Rovit and her husband Dr. Richard Rovit. We loved Barbara's vibrant personality, her quick laugh, her well-recognized teaching accomplishments and her generous spirit. I will always miss those many lost years we could have shared together. If you wish, you may make donations in Barbara's memory to University Hospitals c/o Judy Polshek Goodman Alzheimer's Disease Clinical Research and Prevention Fund, P.O. Box 715658, Columbus, Ohio 43271-5658. Ellyn M. Polshek

MEYER--Harvey Joel, born March 5, 1946, passed away suddenly on Saturday, April 19, 2014 leaving family and friends devastated. Harvey was one of a kind, a divergent thinker, a true free spirit and a gentle soul. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather. He leaved behind his cherished wife Shelley Greenberg Meyer, adored son Mark and daughter-in-law Grace, beloved granddaughter Jade, his pal Marilyn, and his lifelong friends. We are all diminished by his passing.

KELLER--Norma. December 27, 1921-April 17, 2014. Teacher, mother, wife. Born in Brooklyn, Norma went to CCNY at night for her B.A. and worked for Eimco for many years. She married Peter Keller, WWII veteran and Bronze Star recipient, in 1945, and was with him for 59 years until his 2005 death. They moved from Joralemon Street in Brooklyn to Stuyvesant Town, where their daughters Lisa (Saky Yakas) and Nina (Rich Adago) were born. In 1960 they settled in New Rochelle. In the early 1960s an elementary school principal plucked her from the secretary's chair and put her in a classroom, where she had a crash course in how to teach. For 25 years she was a dedicated and beloved first grade teacher, first in the South Bronx and then in Greenburgh. She returned to college nights and weekends to earn a Master's in Education. In retirement, she became a tutor for home-bound students with both mental and physical disabilities. Children adored her, and she was enormously kind to anyone she met. She is survived by her daughters, sons-in-law, sister Renee, nephew Mark and Jeff, niece Lynette, and beloved grandchildren Benjamin, Perry, and Naomi. Services will take place at Temple Israel of New Rochelle Tuesday, April 22, 1 pm, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla. The family will host shiva at Norma's home afterwards. Gifts in memory can be made to the Norma Keller Fund, New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Development Office (Attn. Tamiko Collier), 654 West 170th Street, New York, NY 10032.

MAXWELL--Hamish, 87, of Brooklyn Heights, Quogue and Palm Beach, died peacefully at home on Saturday, April 19, a year and six days after the death of Gee Gee, his wife of 58 years. Hamish is survived by his daughters Graham Russell (Ira Briskman) and Robin Maxwell (Jim Wilentz), his grandchildren Alexander and Hamish Russell and Ben and Sarah Wilentz, and his sister Hilary Harding. Hamish will always be remembered by his daughters as a loving, engaged, and supportive father, by his many friends as wonderfully good company, by his grandchildren as the funniest adult they knew, and by everyone who knew him in and out of the workplace as someone whose enormous accomplishments and generosity were matched only by his modesty. His family is grateful to the many doctors, nurses, and other care-givers who gave us so many years with one of the world's last great gentlemen. The memorial service will take place at 11:00am on Saturday, April 26, at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11217, or the Norton Museum of Art, 1451 S. Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33401.

OLIVA--Jay, The Town Hall mourns the passing of a passionate patron of the arts who we recognized as such in 1999 with our Friend of the Arts Award. Our deepest sympathy to his legion of friends and his family. The Trustees and Staff of The Town Hall Foundation

SCRANTON--Suzanne Somersall Roberts, 89, the widow of Donald H. Roberts and S.Samuel Scranton, Jr., died of natural causes on April 14, 2014 at her residence at Clare Bridge of Vero Beach, FL. Born Suzanne Somersall Outerbridge on October 23, 1924 on the island of Bermuda, she was the daughter of Ira Stuart Outerbridge and Mary Trott Outerbridge. Through her parents, Mrs. Scranton was a direct descendant of two of the island's oldest families which had settled in Bermuda in the 17th Century. In 1939, Mrs. Scranton enrolled as a boarder at Dwight School for Girls (Englewood, NJ). There Mrs. Scranton made a number of life-long friends and developed a great love for America and New York City. After graduation from Dwight in June, 1943 as President of Dwight's Boarding Department, Mrs. Scranton returned to Bermuda. Shortly thereafter, she met and became engaged to her first husband and the father of her three children, Donald Roberts. Mr. Roberts, a First Lieutenant in the US Navy, was stationed in Bermuda with the USS Hamul prior to its departure in late 1944 to the Pacific. After their marriage ceremony in 1946, the couple moved to America. For 30 years, the couple lived in Summit, NJ where they raised their children. After Mr. Roberts' retirement in 1992, the couple moved to Vero Beach, FL. In 1996, Mr. Roberts died shortly after they had celebrated 50 years of marriage. In 2001, Mrs. Scranton married her second husband, Samuel Scranton who died in 2011. Mrs. Scranton was a member of Trinity Episcopal Church (Vero Beach). Mrs. Scranton was also a member of the Riomar Country Club (Vero Beach) and Coral Beach & Tennis Club (Bermuda). Mrs. Scranton is survived by her three children: Margaret Roberts Murphy, Charlottesville, VA.; Stuart O. Roberts, Steamboat Springs, CO; Donald H. Roberts, Jr., Philadelphia, PA; and by eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be sent to the Dwight-Englewood School 315 East Palisade Avenue Englewood, NJ 07631. Private funeral service at a later date. Services are by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book is available at: www.strunkfuneralhome.com.

SCHMIDT--Marsha A.,passed away quietly on April 14, 2014 surrounded by family and friends after a brief illness caused by acute pulmonary distress following surgery recovery. Born on October 4, 1943 in Hackensack, NJ, Marsha graduated from Tenafly High School in 1961 and from Hood College in Frederick, Maryland in 1965 after making lifelong friends at both schools. She excelled at languages and earned several graduate level teaching certificates which enabled her to teach Spanish and coach non-English speaking visiting diplomats from the United Nations who were new to New York City. She also had a successful career in Marketing and held several executive positions at book publisher Doubleday and Company. It was at Doubleday where Marsha met John O'Donnell, whom she married and spent ten happy years before his death in 1993. Since his death Marsha split her time between New York City and Oakdale, Long Island and enjoyed the loyal companionship of college and career friends. She loved to travel to Europe and especially to Mexico where she had enjoyed many happy vacations with John. Marsha is survived by her father, Werner Schmidt, of Yarmouth Port, Massachusetts and her brother Paul and his wife Mary of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, and three nephews who live in Chicago and Seattle. She will be sorely missed by them and by all her friends around the country. A memorial celebration of her life is being planned for later this spring. Marsha, as did John, had a passion for domestic animals and their welfare as well as for medical research to combat cancer. Donations in Marsha's memory may be made to the ASPCA or the New York Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell Medical Center.
