SCHLESINGER--James R. February 15, 1929 - March 27, 2014. A memorial service for former Secretary Of Defense, Secretary Of Energy, Director Of The CIA and Chairman Of the Atomic Energy Commission James R. Schlesinger will be held at 4:00pm, Saturday April 26, 2014, at the Rachel M. Schlesinger Concert Hall and Arts Center, 3001 North Beauregard Street, Alexandria, Virginia. The Hall can be accessed by taking Seminary Road West from Interstate 395 in Alexandria Virginia, and in several blocks taking a right heading downhill on Beauregard Street. The second light at the bottom of the hill is West Braddock, where a left turn takes you into the Northern Virginia Community College Alexandria Campus. The Schlesinger Center is a very large building immediately to the right headed back up the hill. There is a circle for drop offs, and monitors will guide drivers to close-in parking. Attendees are advised to arrive by 3:30pm, and there will be a reception to meet with family and friends in the main atrium following the Service.

STAFFORD--John Rogers, 76, of Essex Fells, NJ, and Captiva Island, FL died peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family on Friday, April 18, 2014. A funeral service will be held on Tuesday, April 22 at 11am at The First Presbyterian Church at Caldwell, Bloomfield Avenue, with a reception to follow at Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, NJ. Interment will be private. Services by Paul Ippolito-Dancy Memorial, Caldwell, NJ. To send the family condolences, please visit: www. Ippolitofuneralhomes.com. Born in Harrisburg, PA., Mr. Stafford was a long-time resident of Essex Fells and Captiva Island since 1976. John R. Stafford served as Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Office of Wyeth (formerly American Home Products Corporation) from 1986 to 2001 and continued as Chairman of the Board until his retirement in December, 2002. Mr. Stafford joined Wyeth in 1970 as General Counsel. He was elected a Vice President in 1972, a Senior Vice President in 1977, Executive Vice President and a Director in 1980, and President in 1981. During his tenure as CEO, Mr. Stafford led the company in growth from $4.9 billion annual net revenue to $14.6 billion. He streamlined the company to focus on its pharmaceutical business, dramatically increasing its investment in pharmaceutical research and development and transforming it into one of the leading innovation-based companies in the industry. Mr. Stafford is a 1959 graduate of Dickinson College, Carlisle, PA, where he played football and lacrosse. He received his LL.B. with distinction at The George Washington University Law School where he served as Editor-in-Chief of The Law Review and was elected to the Order of the Coif. From 1962 through 1966, Mr. Staf- ford practiced with the Washington, DC law firm of Steptoe & Johnson. From 1966 through 1970, he was a member of the legal staff of Hoffmann-La Roche, Nutley, NJ. In 1991, Mr. Stafford received an honorary doctorate of law from The George Washington University. Mr. Stafford served on the Board of Directors of Verizon Communications, Inc., Honeywell International Inc., J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., Deere & Co., and Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and was an active supporter of charitable and civic organizations including the Central Park Conservancy, the Metropolitan Opera, and Dickinson College. An avid golfer and boater, Mr. Stafford also greatly enjoyed travel and spending time with his close extended family and many dear friends. Mr. Staf- ford was deeply devoted to his wife of 52 years, the late Dr. Inge Paul Stafford. Surviving are his loving daughters Carolyn Stein and her husband, Dr. Eric, Jennifer Farrow and her husband, John, Christina Chapin and her husband, Jason, and Charlotte Stafford; his 13 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren; his brother P. Gordon Staf-ford, brother-in-law George Paul, and sisters-in-law Nancy Stafford, Barbara Stafford, and Susan Paul. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the First Presbyterian Church, Bloomfield Avenue, Caldwell, NJ 07006.

WITTMANN--Joseph vanBeuren, Jr. of Somers, NY died April 13, 2014. He was 80. Joseph is survived by his wife of 50 years, Barbara S. Wittmann of Somers, NY, and two children, a son, Joseph vanBeuren Wittmann III of Carmel, NY and his wife Jennifer and granddaughter Elizabeth Margaret Schuyler Wittmann; a daughter, Rachel DeWitt Wittmann-Maher of Somers and her husband, Charles Maher and grandson Connor Kiliaen Maher. Friends are invited to Clark Associates Funeral Home in Katonah, NY on Friday, April 25th for a closed casket viewing from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Lupus Foundation of America, 2000 L Street, NW, Suite 410, Washington, DC 20036 or www.Lupus.org.

STRAUSS--Robert S. Ambassador Robert S. Strauss, died peacefully on March 19 at the age of 95. Amb. Strauss was born on October 19, 1918, in Lockhart, TX, to Charles Strauss, a German immigrant with a love of music, and Edith Schwarz Strauss, a Texas native. He graduated from the University of Texas at Austin and then from the University of Texas School of Law in 1941 and thereupon joined the Federal Bureau of Investigation, where he worked for four years. Upon leaving the FBI in 1945, Amb. Strauss and fellow FBI special agent Richard Gump founded a two-man law office, Gump and Strauss, in Dallas which would become Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, with 20 offices and over 900 attorneys worldwide. Mr. Strauss served as Chairman of the Democratic National Committee from 1973 to 1976. In 1977 Mr. Strauss entered the Cabinet of President Carter, serving as Special Trade Representative. President Carter next turned to him as his Personal Representative to the Middle East to follow up on the successes and challenges engendered by the 1978 Camp David Accords. At the end of his term, President Carter awarded Amb. Strauss the nation's highest civilian award, the Presidential Medal of Freedom. In August 1991, he was sworn in as the United States ambassador to the Soviet Union. Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ambassador Strauss became the U.S. ambassador to the Russian Federation. After the 1992 presidential elections, he returned to Washington and Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld. Amb. Strauss was the widower of Helen Jacobs Strauss and is survived by his son Robert A. Strauss, wife Olga Glick Strauss, grandchild Robert Strauss and wife Whitney Williams Strauss and their two children, Bobby and Timmy; grandchild Lisa Strauss Mastin and her two children, John and Jordan; grandchild Laurie Strauss; son Richard C. Strauss, wife Diana King Strauss, grandchild Tania Strauss Agran her two children, Ricky and Alex, grandchild Staci Strauss McCord and husband Craig McCord, and grandchild Jenifer Strauss; daughter Susan Strauss Breen, husband George Breen and grandchild Natalie Breen; nephew Leslie L. Jacobs, III and by brother Theodore H. Strauss, wife Sue Wayne Strauss his daughter Janie Strauss McGarr and her husband Cappy McGarr and grandchildren Elizabeth McGarr and Kathryn McGarr, author of the biography "The Whole Damn Deal: Robert Strauss and the Art of Politics," and his daughter Nancy Strauss Halbreich and husband Jeremy Halbreich. His legacy will live on at the Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law at the University of Texas at Austin and at Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld LLP. A Memorial for Mr. Strauss will be held on April 23, 2014 at 11am at the National Cathedral in Washington, DC. The memorial service is open to the public.

SOHIGIAN--Arsen F. A resident of Delray Beach, Florida passed away on April 21, 2014 after a courageous battle with cancer. His beloved wife Amy was beside him through every step of the fight. Arsen's immediate surviving family include his sister Anjel Yessanyan; daughters Laura Anderson, Dawn Sohigian, Kimberly Huntoon, and Stephanie Wineman; and grandchildren Charlotte Huntoon, Nicholas Palley, Alexandra Wineman, Caroline Wineman and Gwyneth Wineman. Arsen earned a Bachelor's degree in business administration and a Master's degree in marketing. He followed his passion for advertising starting his career as a scriptwriter at NY Ayer. His hard work earned him an executive vice president position at Maxon, Inc. After 15 years, Arsen co-founded Sohigian & LaChuisa in Detroit, Michigan with offices in Los Angeles, Chicago, New York and Toronto. Arsen sold his shares in the company after 20 years and moved to New York City as president of Wundies Enterprises. Arsen entered the healthcare arena in 2000 as co-founder of Jacksonville Open MRI. In 2002, the company was sold and Arsen moved from Michigan to Florida where he co-founded The Imaging Center of West Palm Beach as Chief Operating Officer. The first MRI-only facility was opened in December 2003 in West Palm Beach, Florida. His marketing strategy led the expansion into Lake Worth, Boynton Beach, and Hollywood. Arsen pursued his dreams with a passion not to be denied. His word was his bond. His charm and charismatic personality built an incredible network of friends. Arsen possessed a unique ability to make you feel better about yourself with each encounter. While he lives in our hearts, his presence will be missed deeply. Services will be held at Temple Beth El, 333 SW 4th Avenue, Boca Raton on Wednesday, April 23rd.

SINDELL--Stuart. Died at age 85 on April 21, 2014 in Boynton Beach, FL. Born in 1928 to Beatrice (Stoopak) and William Sindell in New York City. Resident of New York City, Glen Rock, NJ, Somerset, NJ, and Boynton Beach. Beloved husband of 55 years to Zoe Shuman Sindell. Devoted to his three daughters and their husbands: Marci Sindell and Gary Goffin of Canton, MA, Dale Sindell and Charles Tejera of Madrid, Spain, and Nancy and James Wolf of Short Hills, NJ, and grandchildren Daniel, Isabel, Rachel, Sophie, Andrew, James and Emily. A lifelong Freemason and former board member of the New Jersey YMHA-YWHA Camps, Stuart was very outgoing, with a great sense of humor. He enjoyed watching sports, playing cards, collecting coins, and studying genealogy. A private funeral service will be held at Weiss Memorial Chapel in Boynton Beach. Donations in his memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

PERNICK--David, passed away peacefully on April 21, 2014. He was born August 27, 1919 in Queens New York. He was a graduate of Lowell Tech College in Massachusetts. He lived in Kings Point, New York and moved to Boca Raton Florida. David was awarded an honorary doctorate from University of Massachusetts at Lowell, was Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Governors of Shenkar College in Israel. He was a member of the board of the Morikami Museum and a former trustee of North Shore hospital. Loving husband of the late Frances. Devoted father of Jill (Mitchell) Friedman and Bruce (Susan) Pernick. Adored grandfather of Pamela (Scott) Ollendorff, Jocelyn (Elliot) Steelman, Jeffrey (Jessica) Friedman, Jessica DiPalma and Craig Pernick. Cherished great-grandfather of Andrew, Olivia, Benjamin, Trent, Jacob and Felix. Beloved brother of Betty Haft. He is loved and will be missed by all. Services Wednesday, April 23, 2014, 10am at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR) Great Neck, NY www.riversidenassaunorth chapel.com

PATERSON--Basil. The City University of New York mourns the passing of the Honorable Basil Alexander Paterson, a longstanding supporter of CUNY and the enhancement of its educational mission. A former Vice Chairperson of The Friends of CUNY, he was an early supporter of the Percy Ellis Sutton Search for Education and Knowledge (SEEK) program and vigorously advocated for the well-being of the University during his tenure as a Secretary of State of New York, state senator, deputy mayor, and private citizen. He worked especially closely with CUNY on opportunities for health care workers to pursue higher education and always brought warmth, insight, and humor to deliberations on how best to extend the ladder of education. We extend deepest condolences to his beloved family. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson Board of Trustees William P. Kelly, Interim Chancellor

PERNICK--David. It is with deep sadness that the American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel notes the passing of our dear friend, generous patron and a true mensch, David Pernick, Life Chancellor of Shenkar College of Engineering, Design & Art, former Chairman of the International Board of Governors of Shenkar College and former President of our Board of Directors. A graduate of the University of Massachusetts-Lowell, David went on to found, in 1961, the Monarch Knitting Machinery Company, which under his leadership would gain a reputation as the finest supplier of circular knitting machinery in the world. David's support and passion for Shenkar College was unsurpassed and unconditional. For over thirty years, David gave generously of his resources, time, energy and wisdom to further the mission of the College which he loved so much. Some 60 years after graduating Lowell, David and his late wife Frances would establish the International Program of Graduate Studies in Plastic Engineering which brings to the Lowell campus doctoral students from Shenkar and sends faculty to Shenkar for research and collaboration. Recognizing the effect Engineering has on excellence in Design, David supported the development of the Engineering Faculty which became a platform for expanding the college, helping to create job opportunities in Israel. In 1990 the main facility on the Shenkar campus was renamed The Pernick Building, in honor of Frances and David. The Pernick family's generosity was most recently recognized with the naming of the Pernick Faculty of Engineering. We are forever grateful for David's unstinting support and wise counsel. He will be sorely missed, and never forgotten. With every Shenkar graduate, Frances and David leave a legacy that will prosper and flourish. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Pernick family and David's many, many friends throughout the world. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, April 23, 10:00am at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Bruce Pernick - President, Board of Directors, American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel Ivan Helfand Executive Director Charlotte Fainblatt - Executive Director Emeritus

PORTER--A. Alex, died at his farm in Davidson, NC on Good Friday. He was 75. The cause was cancer. Porter was born in Charlotte, NC and moved to New York in the 1960s subsequently becoming a member of the Wall Street generation that popularized the hedge fund. He became a successful practitioner of that now-familiar investing craft, managing a firm he founded in 1976 as Porter Management and now known as Amici Capital. Porter was a longtime trustee of his beloved Davidson College and of Queens University of Charlotte. Among others, he served on the boards of Rollcast Energy, Distribution Technology, SLM Corp., the Library of America, and the John Simon Guggenheim Foundation. In addition to his sister, Sarah Porter Boehmler, he is survived by his nieces Elizabeth Anne Boehmler and Alexis Porter Boehmler of New York City, and Jean Boehmler Reynolds and her children Sarah Hollingsworth Reynolds and Margaret Grier Reynolds of Haverford, Pennsylvania. A service to celebrate his life will be held at Davidson College Presbyterian Church on Saturday, April 26 at 1:00 pm.

GOLDSMITH--Jack Preston, 85, of Osterville, passed away suddenly on Wednesday, April 16, 2014. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Iris Goldsmith; sons, Karl Goldsmith, John Goldsmith and daughters, Leslie Goldsmith and Susan Conway. Born in Buffalo, New York, Jack graduated from Rochester Institute of Technology School of Art and Design in 1948, and began a 35 year career in advertising that took him to New York City. He was Creative Director and Vice President working at BBDO, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, and McCann Erickson while living in Larchmont, New York. After his retirement he moved to Osterville and began a second career as a painter, exhibiting at the Granary Gallery in West Tisbury, MA and The Northwater Gallery in Edgartown, MA.

MARKS--Stuart, 94, died April 13, 2014. Kaye Scholer remembers our friend and colleague Stuart Marks, a partner at the firm from 1959 until his retirement in 1991. A consummate international corporate lawyer, accomplished scholar of linguistics and man of true compassion, Stuart handled a variety of high-profile deals around the globe throughout his career, and always made sure that his colleagues and his clients knew how important they and the firm were to him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children Deborah, Elizabeth and David, and their families.

JONES--Anne. Citizens' Committee for Children of New York (CCC) mourns the passing of Anne K. Jones. We send our condolences to her family and friends and those who share our deep respect for Anne's tireless commitment to child advocacy. Anne took CCC's Community Leadership Course 50 years ago and ran the course from 1990-1996. She became an official member of CCC 30 years ago, was elected to CCC's Board 28 years ago and became an Honorary Director in 2007. Anne's intelligence and determination to make NYC a better place for children made her an inspiration to all of us. Chris Stern Hyman, Chairman Jessica Aaron, President Jennifer March, Exec. Director

LAWRENCE--Hulda. Born Hulda Janos Goetz, in East Liverpool, Ohio on July 23, 1920, the daughter of Albert and Clara Cohn Goetz. After growing up and attending schools in Atlantic City, New Jersey, the family moved to New York City, where Hulda enrolled in a special program at New York University where she received both her B.A. and M.A. degrees. She was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and captain of the female debating team, joining Tau Kappa Alpha. She was an officer of University organizations, including the International Relations Club, throughout her university career. She also organized war efforts from 1938 to 1942 for students by collecting funds and arranging meetings, including one where Eleanor Roosevelt spoke. Hulda joined the national staff of the Girl Scouts of America and was sent all over the country to train scout leaders. She was also a member of the Women's City Club for over 50 years. She married Morton Brown Lawrence in 1954 and they were married for 52 years. Morton passed away August 26, 2006 at the age of 85. In 1960, she and her husband founded a newspaper specifically for the Upper East Side, called "Manhattan East". Two years later, they founded "Park East", which was published until 1993. During that time, Hulda's particular field of writing was "Shopping with Hulda" and reviews of wines and restaurants. She traveled the world in her capacity as a writer and reviewer for Park East. Hulda passed away on April 18, 2014, surrounded by friends. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 1, 2014 at 1pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.
KRESCH--Doris. Died April 19th, age 93, devoted wife to late husband Arthur, loving mother to Ron, Rob and Melissa, proud grandmother of Rebecca, Liana, Tyler, Preston, Jake and Max. Buon viaggo Mom.

PERLMAN--Evelyn. The Board of Directors and Staff of Care for the Homeless mourns the passing of Evelyn Perlman, beloved mother of Board Member Emeritus Lee Perlman and mother-in-law of Board member Linda Riefberg. We extend our sincere condolences and sympathies to the entire Perlman Family.

KLEINMAN--Elaine J.,91, cherished wife of more than half a century of the late Kenneth R. Kleinman, died April 20, 2014, in New York City where she was born on August 16, 1922, to Jesse and Jennie Jacobs. She is survived by devoted daughters Jill and Joan and son David, sons-in-law Judd and Rich, grandchildren Jennifer, Jon, Alexandra, Emily and Eyal, her great grandchildren Eliot and Gabriel and the admiration and love she sparked in friends, families and strangers alike with her knack for amusing anyone within earshot. Her strength, courage and enduring spirit despite decades of debilitating pain from a back injury inspired us all. With her irrepressible comedic sense, she entertained us from childhood on with stories pulled out of thin air and her uncanny gift for creating colorful characters in ways that kept us coming back for more. She could have been anything but wanted nothing more than to be a mother, wife, daughter and sister (to Gloria and Muriel, predeceased) and she lived up to her dream as her entire being was dedicated to living for and loving us all. She will be laid to rest at New Montefiore Cemetery on Tuesday, April 22, next to the love of her life and darling husband. She will be forever missed and forever in our hearts. We love you, Mom, heart and soul.

Gotto Jr., Co-Chairman, Board of Overseers Sanford I. Weill, Chairman, Board of Overseers

Laura was born May 8, 1927 in Queens, New York, the daughter of the late Walter and Victoria Gritz, she is preceded in death by her brothers Bernard and Lawrence and her beloved husband of 61 years, Edward and survived by eight children and their spouses: as well as 21 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. EDWARDS--Dr. Lee MacCormick, Passed away on April 19 of ovarian cancer. She died in Edgecliff, Australia, an eastern suburb of Sydney, as she looked out to Point Piper where she was born on October 20, 1937. Lee lived in Locust Valley, NY; in addition to Edgecliff she also had homes in New York City and Vail. Lee was the granddaughter of the renowned Sydney surgeon and international yachtsman, Sir Alexander MacCormick, who after studying medicine under Joseph Lister at Edinburgh University in the 1880s, introduced antiseptic surgery to Australia. Lee's maternal grandfather, the chemist W. Howard Wright, founded Schenectady Varnish Company in 1906; the company grew to become the multinational SI Group, Inc., and Lee served on its Board of Directors up until the time of her death. Lee was an accomplished art historian and consultant and artist with a M.A. (1978), M. Phil. (1981), and Ph.D. (1984) from Columbia University. She lectured and taught widely in the United States, Europe and Australia and specialized in the arts and social history of the nineteenth century. She was on the art history faculty of her alma mater (class of 1976) Sarah Lawrence College from 2000 2008. Her book, "Herkomer: A Victorian Artist," was awarded the Henry-Russell Hitchcock prize by the Victorian Society of America for the best book of the year in 2001. Lee was the President of the International Festival Society (IFS) from 2002 until 2013. The IFS makes grants to promising young American classical musicians on the cusp of their professional careers. She served on the boards of many other charitable organizations including the International Foundation for Art Research, The American Friends of the National Gallery of Australia and The American Australia Foundation. A keen photographer, Lee exhibited her work annually; she considered it as an extension of her interest in the arts of the nineteenth century. Her last show in the United States, "My World," photographs of her native Australia, was held at Heimbold Visual Arts Center at Sarah Lawrence College in November 2012. All proceeds from her final exhibition, "Capturing the Moment" at Maunsell Wickes in Sydney in October 2013, were donated to support ovarian cancer research at the Garvan Institute for Medical Research and the St. Vincent's Curran Foundation in Sydney. She was active in tennis, golf, kayaking, ocean swimming and golf croquet. She was a member of The Century Association, Colony Club, Metropolitan Opera Club, Piping Rock Club, The Creek, Sonnenalp Golf Club, Game Creek Club, Royal Sydney Golf Club as well as the club co-founded by her paternal grandfather, the Royal Prince Edward Yacht Club in Sydney. With her husband, the artist Michael Crane, Lee attended the Salzburg Festival for thirty years. She was awarded the Goldene Kreuz of the State of Salzburg in 2005 for her work as head of the American Friends of the Salzburg Festival. In addition to her husband she is survived by her loving daughter Alison Edwards Curwen, son-in-law Austin Curwen and grandchildren Darcy, Tag and Stapley Curwen. A memorial service in New York will be scheduled for a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations in Lee's honor can be made to the Dr. Lee MacCormick Edwards Charitable Foundation, c/o Tina Albright, Secretary, Curtis Mallet, 101 Park Ave., New York, NY 10178.

MOSKOVITZ--Clara, 100, died peacefully at home on April 20. She was a devoted daughter and loving sister, aunt and great-aunt. She enjoyed opera and travel, and was an enthusiastic link to cousins scattered around the world. She is dearly remembered by many, including Anne, Peter, Carol, Susan, Ariel, David, Zoe, Stephanie, Deborah, Sarai, Virginia, Mary Jane, Juliet and Mary. The family will receive visitors today, April 22, 4-8pm, at the home of Anne Davis.
FITZGIBBON--Eugene. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Eugene Fitzgibbon, associated with The New York Times from October 1, 1966 until retiring on February 1, 1993.

MEYER--Harvey Joel, born March 5, 1946, passed away suddenly on Saturday, April 19, 2014 leaving family and friends devastated. Harvey was one of a kind, a divergent thinker, a true free spirit and a gentle soul. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather. He leaves behind his cherished wife Shelley Greenberg Meyer, adored son Mark and daughter-in-law Grace, beloved granddaughter Jade, his pal Marilyn, and his lifelong friends. We are all diminished by his passing.

MAXWELL--Hamish, 87, of Brooklyn Heights, Quogue and Palm Beach, died peacefully at home on Saturday, April 19, a year and six days after the death of Gee Gee, his wife of 58 years. Hamish is survived by his daughters Graham Russell (Ira Briskman) and Robin Maxwell (Jim Wilentz), his grandchildren Alexander and Hamish Russell and Ben and Sarah Wilentz, and his sister Hilary Harding. Hamish will always be remembered by his daughters as a loving, engaged, and supportive father, by his many friends as wonderfully good company, by his grandchildren as the funniest adult they knew, and by everyone who knew him in and out of the workplace as someone whose enormous accomplishments and generosity were matched only by his modesty. His family is grateful to the many doctors, nurses, and other care-givers who gave us so many years with one of the world's last great gentlemen. The memorial service will take place at 11:00am on Saturday, April 26, at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11217, or the Norton Museum of Art, 1451 S. Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33401.

MAXWELL--Hamish. The Board of Directors and staff of The Rogosin Institute are deeply saddened by the death of Hamish Maxwell. His extraordinary accomplishments, generosity of spirit, and steadfastness are legendary. We greatly valued his vision and wise counsel, which will continue to guide us. Hamish and his late wife, Georgene, were dedicated friends and benefactors of the research and treatment programs at The Rogosin Institute. Their committed support helped make life better for others and we were honored to have them as part of the Rogosin "family". He will always be remembered as a perspicacious, kind and compassionate man, who was appreciated by all those around him for his optimism and sense of humor. Our hearts go out to his devoted daughters, Graham and Robin, and their families. Richard D. Hall Chairman, Board of Directors The Rogosin Institute Barry H. Smith, MD, PhD President & CEO The Rogosin Institute

PORTER--A. Alex. The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation notes with special sadness the death of A. Alex Porter, who was one of a kind. Alex served on our Board of Trustees for eighteen years, enlightening us with his wide-ranging reading, his financial acumen, and his wise counsel. We adored him, and grieve his loss with his family, to whom we send the deepest condolences. William Kelly, Chairman Edward Hirsch, President

BOODISH--Dr. Wesley, died Saturday, April 19 at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, NJ. Services will be 11:30am, Wednesday, April 23 at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills. Survived by his adoring and devoted wife of 46 years, Lynn.

BORRI--Cecil Ane Schrader, of Metuchen, NJ, died peacefully on April 18, 2014. Born in Huron, SD in 1929, she is survived by her husband of 61 years, Tullio J. Borri, her children Gregg Borri of NYC, Catherine Lyness of Summit, NJ, Claire Hallock of Irvington, NY, and six grandchildren. Cecil received a B.A. from Augustana College in Sioux Falls, SD, and a Masters in Education from Rutgers University, and worked as a Learning Consultant in the New Jersey public school system for 25 years. She loved travel, bridge, books, tennis, theater and opera. Cecil was beautiful, smart, funny, and courageous: she will be lovingly remembered and greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on May 6 at 11am at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Metuchen, NJ.

HERO--Angela Constantinides, Ph.D. Born in Athens, Greece, in 1926, died peacefully at her home in New York City on April 22, 2014. Predeceased by her husband, Dr. Byron A. Hero; survived by her sons Byron (wife Camille) and Basil, her adoring grandchildren, Alexander, Gabrielle, Alexandra, and Ariane; and her brother George and wife Maguy. Historian, author and professor emerita at the Center for Byzantine and Modern Greek Studies at Queens College of the City University of New York. Her memory will be treasured by family, colleagues, former students and friends. The family will receive friends and relatives on Thursday, April 24th from 6-8 p.m. at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St.). At her request, funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to: Center for Byzantine and Modern Greek Studies at Queens College, 65-30 Kissena Boulevard, NY 11367.

MARKOWITZ--Randi, on April 14th, passed away at her home in Los Angeles after a long battle against Leiomyosarcoma. Randi was a loving wife, mother, friend and a woman of compassion. She was also a dedicated and passionate Psychonanalyst. She had tremendous support from and will be greatly missed by her friends and her family - husband, Robert Israel; son, Alexander Israel, his wife Anna Lewis; her brother, Mark Markowitz and his wife Terry.

RAFFEL--Charles Michael, born August 28th, 1950 passed away suddenly on the evening of April 19th. He was a remarkable husband to his surviving wife Rivka, a devoted father, loving friend and wise counselor to his two children Aliza and Joshua and an inspiring voice to his countless students over his long career as a teacher of Jewish philosophy at Yeshiva University Stern College for Women. The funeral will be held on Wednesday, April 23rd at 11:30am at Beth El Synagogue on 1324 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10804. For Shiva information, please contact Beth El at 914-235-2700. The family asks that donations be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation (MJFF) for Parkinson's Research.

WEILL--Morton D.,"Pop," of Manhattan, 104. Beloved husband of the late Adele Oelbaum Weill, died at home on April 22, 2014. Proud graduate of Cornell University 1930. For 52 years Morty worked at United Merchants and Manufacturers, and in the last years of his distinguished career in the textile industry he was President of UM&M. He was the first President and long-time board member of the Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts. Devoted father of Joan Levin (Stu) and Jim Weill (Judy Waxman); adoring grandfather of Anne Marsh, Tom Levin (Stephanie), Steve Levin (Jessica Shaw), Andy Levin (Francine), Jennie Weill and Andy Waxman (Pam Yosca); adoring great-grandfather of his 10 great-grandchildren; and beloved by a legion of family and friends, including his wonderful long-time caretakers Dolly Persaud, Errol Robinson and Mark Brown. In lieu of flowers, please contribute in his memory to the charity of your choice or the Morton and Adele Weill Fund at the Usdan Center, www.usdan.com.

GORE--Jacob (Gorowitz), on April 21, 2014, age 104, in Lauderhill, Florida. Former Shallow Junior High School Principal-Brooklyn, Assistant Principal PS 39-Manhattan, Inspiring Teacher of Social Studies at Taft High School-Bronx and Benjamin Franklin High School-Manhattan. Director, Daylight Day Camp, known as Uncle Jack. Author of Regents Outlines in World History and American History. He is survived by his loving wife of 78 years, Tinnie, and sons Arnold and Michael, a sister Lillian Hughes, daughter-in-law Susan Epstein, grandson Lazar Treschan, and great-granddaughter Celia, and nieces Sondra Palenbaum and Susan Hillman. Service Thursday, April 24, 2014, 12:45pm, "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

MAXWELL--Hamish, 87, of Brooklyn Heights, Quogue and Palm Beach, died peacefully at home on Saturday, April 19, a year and six days after the death of Gee Gee, his wife of 58 years. Hamish is survived by his daughters Graham Russell (Ira Briskman) and Robin Maxwell (Jim Wilentz), his grandchildren Alexander and Hamish Russell and Ben and Sarah Wilentz, and his sister Hilary Harding. Hamish will always be remembered by his daughters as a loving, engaged, and supportive father, by his many friends as wonderfully good company, by his grandchildren as the funniest adult they knew, and by everyone who knew him in and out of the workplace as someone whose enormous accomplishments and generosity were matched only by his modesty. His family is grateful to the many doctors, nurses, and other care-givers who gave us so many years with one of the world's last great gentlemen. The memorial service will take place at 11:00am on Saturday, April 26, at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11217, or the Norton Museum of Art, 1451 S. Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33401.

PORTER--A. Alex, died at his farm in Davidson, NC on Good Friday. He was 75. The cause was cancer. Porter was born in Charlotte, NC and moved to New York in the 1960s subsequently becoming a member of the Wall Street generation that popularized the hedge fund. He became a successful practitioner of that now-familiar investing craft, managing a firm he founded in 1976 as Porter Management and now known as Amici Capital. Porter was a longtime trustee of his beloved Davidson College and of Queens University of Charlotte. Among others, he served on the boards of Rollcast Energy, Distribution Technology, SLM Corp., the Library of America, and the John Simon Guggenheim Foundation. In addition to his sister, Sarah Porter Boehmler, he is survived by his nieces Elizabeth Anne Boehmler and Alexis Porter Boehmler of New York City, and Jean Boehmler Reynolds and her children Sarah Hollingsworth Reynolds and Margaret Grier Reynolds of Haverford, Pennsylvania. A service to celebrate his life will be held at Davidson College Presbyterian Church on Saturday, April 26 at 1:00 pm.

WEISS--Neil, (July 21, 1933 - April 21, 2014) Beloved Husband, Father, Brother, Grandfather, Uncle and Dear Friend. Passed away peacefully while surrounded by family after an extended, purposefully private battle with cancer, one fought with strength, humility, courage, and conviction, dedication to family and dignity for himself, never allowing the ravages of his illness to prevent him from maintaining normalcy and hope in his life, being the unwavering family patriarch and consummate business person he always was. In true Neil Weiss fashion, tirelessly driven and steadfast, from the moment he learned of his fate, he chose not to go gently into that good night. Neil went about his life, going to his office everyday, challenging our family and inner-circle of advisors with ideas and expectations, attending meetings, shooting off emails and text messages, analyzing new deals and investment opportunities, taking calls, making calls, enjoying lunches, dinners and movies with family and friends, as he loved to do, and traveling the world. He continued to do it all, until he could no longer do it all. With a knack for seamlessly combining his personal and business lives onto one playing field, Neil applied a drive and passion for business in everything he did. He had a sensibility for knowing how to make things happen, albeit with great success and tenacity. An extraordinary role model to his children and grandchildren, his nieces and nephew, he enjoyed "keeping score" in his business dealings and investments as much as he did in his squash games, or the number of flights he would climb in his apartment building as part of his morning exercise routine. He stayed busy doing what he enjoyed doing... working hard, enjoying family, having fun, negotiating deals and playing with a certain degree of managed risk, always with a strong moral compass. Born and raised in the Bronx, he worked a short time early in his illustrious career for an established apparel manufacturer before deciding with unflappable confidence that he had the ability and ambition to do it better. The business grew, as did his business relationships and lasting personal friendships within the industry. Ever the pioneer, he was amongst the first in the industry to open offices in Hong Kong and the Dominican Republic, and manufacture private label for global luxury brands and retailers. It was also the pioneer in him that led to real estate investments in China and Hong Kong, in the late 70's after relations between the United States and China thawed. It was that same adventurous, enterprising, pioneering spirit that had him returning from trips in the early days to Asia with novel gifts, technologically-advanced gadgetry for family and friends, all precursors to today's cell phone. As his manufacturing business flourished, he continued to parlay his international business experience into a multitude of opportunistic ventures and partnerships, investing globally early in his career in commercial real estate in New York City and Asia, and more recently in New Orleans, as well as in Brazil with his dear friend and partner. He also had a penchant for complex alternative investments, all the while developing his own disciplined, self-taught investment skills that would often lead to returns that had many investment advisors in awe. In this regard, Neil viewed life as a game and business as a sport. He always made sure to have fun doing both. With an insatiable appetite for reading newspapers and sharing his knowledge with those he loved, he pushed us to do better, think with greater clarity and to experiment. He had a profound impact on all we did. A man of impeccable integrity and style, Neil took pleasure in every aspect of life, great and small. He was bold with his business deals. He had a huge heart and exceedingly generous spirit when it came to his family and friends. Decisive, direct, feisty, he was always his own man. Neil embraced life, family and business with an indomitable spirit, gusto, and boundless energy. He conducted his life with an abundance of love, wisdom, and wit. His legacy will live on in the many lives he touched throughout his industrious life, and he will be sorely and profoundly missed. Neil is pre-deceased by his eldest son Steven and survived by his faithful partner, the woman he adored and married more than 42 years ago, Virginia, his devoted children, Ken, Douglas and Elizabeth, his daughter-in-law, Jennifer (Ken), the grandchildren he so cherished, Roy, Gil, Stefan, Leila, Steven and Ava, and his sister who he so adored, Mal. He also leaves behind brother-in-law Murray, nieces Sandi and Lisa, and nephew Douglas, Noreen (fiancee to Douglas), Anthony (fiancee to Elizabeth), his COO and faithful friend Anna, Gus and Laling, as loyal and faithful as they come. A patron of the many arts in New York City, Neil was active in a wide range of philanthropic endeavors and worthy causes. A celebration of his life will be held on April 24th, 2014 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel on Madison and 81st street. Donations can be made to Susan G. Komen (ww5.komen.org) and the Friars Foundation Wounded Warriors Program (friarsclub.com).

MCCLURE--Rhyder. Born February 27, 1943, died April 17, 2014. Beloved husband of Susan McClure and father of Alexandra McClure. Service 4:00pm Wednesday, April 23, First Presbyterian Church, 12 West 12th Street, New York City.

SCHLESINGER--James R. February 15, 1929 - March 27, 2014. A memorial service for former Secretary Of Defense, Secretary Of Energy, Director Of The CIA and Chairman Of the Atomic Energy Commission James R. Schlesinger will be held at 4:00pm, Saturday April 26, 2014, at the Rachel M. Schlesinger Concert Hall and Arts Center, 3001 North Beauregard Street, Alexandria, Virginia. The Hall can be accessed by taking Seminary Road West from Interstate 395 in Alexandria Virginia, and in several blocks taking a right heading downhill on Beauregard Street. The second light at the bottom of the hill is West Braddock, where a left turn takes you into the Northern Virginia Community College Alexandria Campus. The Schlesinger Center is a very large building immediately to the right headed back up the hill. There is a circle for drop offs, and monitors will guide drivers to close-in parking. Attendees are advised to arrive by 3:30pm, and there will be a reception to meet with family and friends in the main atrium following the Service.

ERLE--Joan. The members of the NY Psychoanalytic Society & Institute mourn the loss of Dr. Joan Erle. A longtime and devoted member, she served as President of the Institute as well as Chair of the Education Committee. We extend our condolences to her family. Ian D. Buckingham, MD, President

STEINBROCK--Sylvia (nee Holzman). It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Sylvia Steinbrock on Friday, April 18, 2014. Daughter of Lee (nee Arnest) and Barnet Holzman, she was born in 1929 and raised in the Bronx. She graduated from City College and spent most of her life on her beloved Manhattan Island. She spent many happy years working for Graniteville Fabrics and even after retirement remained in touch with her former co-workers. She was a person with many loves - the theater, movies, music, museums and the world. In 1988, she married her beloved husband Jack, and together they explored the world and all that their city had to offer. She felt very strongly for the suffering of people and thus contributed generously to many charities and organizations. Sylvia is survived by her dear niece Natalie (Holzman-Bernardoni), Natalie's husband Gene and son Joseph, her close friend and confident Norma Meidberg, cousins (some newly found), and valued friends. She will be missed.

KOLTUN--Daniel S.,80, a longtime resident of Rochester, NY and professor of physics at the University of Rochester, died April 9, 2014 at the Quadrangle in Haverford, PA. Daniel was devoted to his family, his students, and his community, and was beloved by them. He is fondly remembered for his infectious curiosity, his wide-ranging and incisive intellect, and his gentle kindness. Full Obituary Online at www.legacy.com/Link.asp?I=LS000170748084X .
SAPERSTEIN--Bella. Magen David Adom in Israel mourns the passing of Bella Saperstein, z"l. Mother of our friend Arnold Gerson, CEO of American Friends of MDA

STRAUSS--Robert S. Ambassador Robert S. Strauss, died peacefully on March 19 at the age of 95. Amb. Strauss was born on October 19, 1918, in Lockhart, TX, to Charles Strauss, a German immigrant with a love of music, and Edith Schwarz Strauss, a Texas native. He graduated from the University of Texas at Austin and then from the University of Texas School of Law in 1941 and thereupon joined the Federal Bureau of Investigation, where he worked for four years. Upon leaving the FBI in 1945, Amb. Strauss and fellow FBI special agent Richard Gump founded a two-man law office, Gump and Strauss, in Dallas which would become Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, with 20 offices and over 900 attorneys worldwide. Mr. Strauss served as Chairman of the Democratic National Committee from 1973 to 1976. In 1977 Mr. Strauss entered the Cabinet of President Carter, serving as Special Trade Representative. President Carter next turned to him as his Personal Representative to the Middle East to follow up on the successes and challenges engendered by the 1978 Camp David Accords. At the end of his term, President Carter awarded Amb. Strauss the nation's highest civilian award, the Presidential Medal of Freedom. In August 1991, he was sworn in as the United States ambassador to the Soviet Union. Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ambassador Strauss became the U.S. ambassador to the Russian Federation. After the 1992 presidential elections, he returned to Washington and Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld. Amb. Strauss was the widower of Helen Jacobs Strauss and is survived by his son Robert A. Strauss, wife Olga Glick Strauss, grandchild Robert Strauss and wife Whitney Williams Strauss and their two children, Bobby and Timmy; grandchild Lisa Strauss Mastin and her two children, John and Jordan; grandchild Laurie Strauss; son Richard C. Strauss, wife Diana King Strauss, grandchild Tania Strauss Agran her two children, Ricky and Alex, grandchild Staci Strauss McCord and husband Craig McCord, and grandchild Jenifer Strauss; daughter Susan Strauss Breen, husband George Breen and grandchild Natalie Breen; nephew Leslie L. Jacobs, III and by brother Theodore H. Strauss, wife Sue Wayne Strauss his daughter Janie Strauss McGarr and her husband Cappy McGarr and grandchildren Elizabeth McGarr and Kathryn McGarr, author of the biography "The Whole Damn Deal: Robert Strauss and the Art of Politics," and his daughter Nancy Strauss Halbreich and husband Jeremy Halbreich. His legacy will live on at the Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law at the University of Texas at Austin and at Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld LLP. A Memorial for Mr. Strauss will be held on April 23, 2014 at 11am at the National Cathedral in Washington, DC. The memorial service is open to the public.

Michael Lamoretti, President David Finkelstein, Secretary

PERNICK--David, passed away peacefully on April 21, 2014. He was born August 27, 1919 in Queens New York. He was a graduate of Lowell Tech College in Massachusetts. He lived in Kings Point, New York and moved to Boca Raton Florida. David was awarded an honorary doctorate from University of Massachusetts at Lowell, was Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Governors of Shenkar College in Israel. He was a member of the board of the Morikami Museum and a former trustee of North Shore hospital. Loving husband of the late Frances. Devoted father of Jill (Mitchell) Friedman and Bruce (Susan) Pernick. Adored grandfather of Pamela (Scott) Ollendorff, Jocelyn (Elliot) Steelman, Jeffrey (Jessica) Friedman, Jessica DiPalma and Craig Pernick. Cherished great-grandfather of Andrew, Olivia, Benjamin, Trent, Jacob and Felix. Beloved brother of Betty Haft. He is loved and will be missed by all. Services Wednesday, April 23, 2014, 10am at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR) Great Neck, NY www.riversidenassaunorth chapel.com

MAXWELL--Hamish, The Norton Museum mourns the death of Hamish Maxwell, generous, longtime Museum trustee, inspiring colleague, and leader. His humor, wisdom, and vision added immensely to the growth and strength of the Museum. Hamish, with his late wife Gee Gee, were valued members of the Norton family who will be greatly missed. Our thoughts go out to his daughter, Graham, long time Norton employee; her sister Robin; and their families. Henry W. Howell, Jr. and Janine Mayville, Co-Chairmen of the Board of Trustees Hope Alswang, Director and CEO.

PAPPAS--Bernice. Died peacefully at her home in Valhalla, NY on Saturday, April 19th. The eldest daughter of Nina Lein and Samuel Levine of Bronx Park East, she was a graduate of Brooklyn College and Ohio State University. A lover of opera, literature, travel, and fine art, Bernice was a committed feminist throughout the 60's and 70's, and a perpetually outspoken cultural critic, who applied her advanced training in science and medicine to a successful career as a medical copywriter. She disdained chauvinism or bigotry of any kind and was provocatively outraged by selfishness and injustice. Bernice is survived by her husband, Dr. George D. Pappas; her daughters, Zoe and Clio; her grandchildren, Celeste and Ion; and three great-grandchildren. Her legacy is one of profound fortitude, integrity, and kindness.

LEHMANN--John E. John Edward Lehmann, former President and CEO of The Butterick Company, Inc., 82, died in Ocoee, FL on April 18, 2014 surrounded by his family. Mr. Lehmann was born on December 23, 1931 on Staten Island, NY to John A. Lehmann and Catherine (DeYoung) Lehmann. Upon graduation from Port Richmond High School in 1949, he enlisted in the Air Force and served during the Korean War. After the service, Mr. Lehmann became a mail carrier for the United States Postal Service while attending college at night. He married Suzanne Grover in 1957, and graduated from Wagner College in 1962. Hired by The Butterick Company, Inc., Mr. Lehmann began in their accounting department, becoming President and CEO in the late 1980s. In 1993, he received an Honorary Doctorate from Wagner College. Upon retirement from Butterick, Mr. Lehmann devoted his life to traveling around the world with his family. Mr. Lehmann found no greater joy than being with his children and their families. He was a big man with an even bigger heart. He loved animals, traveling, playing Jeopardy and Trivial Pursuit, taking walks, horseback riding, playing with his dogs, going out to dinner, and telling jokes. Mr. Lehmann is survived by his five children, Krista Rekos and her husband Rich of Newtown, CT; Karla Lafferty and her husband Jack of Clermont, FL; Karyn Lehmann of Groveland, FL; Craig Lehmann and his wife Maureen of Weeki Wachee, FL; and Kurt Lehmann and his wife Marion of Belle Mead, NJ; his seven grandchildren, Travis Rekos, Shane Rekos, Samantha Lafferty, Erin Lafferty, Kaitlin Lehmann, Connor Lehmann, and Kelly Lehmann; and his wife and mother of his children, Suzanne Lehmann. Mr. Lehmann was predeceased by his daughter, Kim Adrienne Lehmann, his granddaughter, Jessica Adrienne Rekos, and his sisters, Barbara Aultman and Evelyn Granacher. Visitation will be from 2:00 to 4:00pm on Friday, April 25, 2014 at Harmon Funeral Home, Staten Island, NY. The funeral service will be held on Saturday, April 26, 2014 at 9:30am at Christ Church New Brighton, Staten Island, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Jessica Rekos Foundation, PO Box 713, Newtown, CT 06470 (jessicarekos.org), or the Alzheimer's Association, P.O. Box 96011, Washington, DC 20090-6011 (alz.org).

Kindly make checks payable to Cornell University. For further information www.shermanschapel.com

LUCAS--William Homer, of Ridgefield, CT on April 18, 2014. Former Senior partner of Lucas, Berger, McGuire and O'Brien. Husband of Alice Kenny. Father of Richard, Robert and James. Beloved grandfather of seven. Funeral Services Saturday, April 26, 2014 at 11am at Ridgebury Congregational Church, Ridgefield, CT. Visitation Friday from 5-7pm at Green Funeral Home, 57 Main St., Danbury, CT. RUBINSTEIN--Tina, High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Tina Rubinstein. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Frank, and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

BESHAR--Robert Peter, 86, died peacefully at home in Somers, New York on April 16. The son of Herbert and Ella Beshar, Bob grew up in New Rochelle with his two brothers and sister. During his senior year at Yale University, Bob was appointed Scholar of the House and graduated summa cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa. While at Yale Law School, Bob met the love of his life, Christine von Wedemeyer. Christine was attending Smith College on a Fulbright. Bob and Christine were married in Germany in 1953. Late last year, they celebrated their 60th anniversary together with their four children -- Cornelia (Rob Spring), Jacky (Scot Jones), Fritz (Peter Lehner) and Peter (Sarah Beshar) -- and their fourteen grandchildren. Bob enjoyed a distinguished career in private practice. He also served in a number of government positions: Assistant General Counsel of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, law clerk for the Honorable Charles Breitel on the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court, and Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Director of the Bureau of International Commerce in Washington. After leaving the Commerce Department in 1972, Bob returned to New York to set up his own practice. Bob served as special counsel, then Corporate Secretary and, for almost thirty years, on the board of directors of National Semiconductor Corporation in Santa Clara, California. He was a member of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board, the Foundation Board of Westchester Community College and the Planning Board of the Town of Somers. In 1993, Bob became President of his family's rug and antiques business, Beshar's, in New York City. Bob's interests were varied and intense. A love of decorative arts -- bronzes, china, jewelry, clocks. He liked to say: "the hand shapes the mind." Reading novels late into the night -- convinced there was more truth in fiction than in non-fiction. Telling a great story over dinner and challenging children, grandchildren and startled guests to "sing for their supper." Driving, and carefully polishing, his convertible Mercedes with the license plate "Besh" -- his nickname at New Rochelle High School. Playing backgammon and eating Armenian food -- dolma, olives, cheoreg and lahmajoon. Trapshooting at Gipsy Trail with friends -- usually top gun and always wearing his trademark Stetson. Most of all, though, Bob adored his wife, his children and his grandchildren: Huyette, Peter, Alexander, Melissa, Vanessa, Lizi, Maddie, Scout, Nadine, Eliza, Marina, Isabel, Henry and Sophie. A service will be held at St. Luke's Church in Somers, New York on Saturday, April 26 at 11:00am, followed by a reception at the Stone House. The family has asked that those interested in honoring Bob's legacy consider a donation to Westchester Community College Foundation Hartford Hall, 75 Grasslands Road, Valhalla, New York 10595.

De LOTTO--Yvonne Frieda (nee Epprecht), 63, of Crassier, Switzerland passed away peacefully on April 19, 2014. Yvonne is survived by her beloved husband, Dr. Robert De Lotto, Ph. D. and by her dear mother, Johanna Maria (nee Schipflinger) Epprecht and by many friends and colleagues. She was predeceased by her father, Andre Epprecht. Visitation will be Thursday and Friday from 5:00-9:00pm both days at Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, 1313 Van Houten Avenue, Clifton, NJ. Private cremation to follow. Please visit www.bizub.com for driving directions and online condolences.

DEMOSS--Bill, age 83, died on December 8, 2013 in Manhattan. He is survived by his loving wife Janet Brof, three children from a prior marriage, David, Anitra, and Aine, by a sister, Harriet Bigelow of El Cerrito, CA and by several nieces and nephews. A celebration of Bill's life that will include recordings of his singing will be held on Sunday, April 27, 2014 at 2pm at Riverside Church, Rm 411, 490 Riverside Dr., New York.

BECKER--Stephen Warner, of Vero Beach, FL and Hendersonville, NC passed away on April 16, 2014 of complications during heart surgery. He is survived by Grace Marie Becker, his wife of 56 years, and by his son, Stephen Nelson Becker, his daughter-in-law Sara Granley Becker and his three grandchildren, John Sidbury Becker, Sarah Grace Becker and Evan Granley Becker, all of McLean VA. He was predeceased by his brother, Philip D Becker. Becker was born June 12, 1926 in Bayside, Queens. He was a World War Two veteran, having served as a first mate in the Navy in the Pacific theater. He subsequently graduated with a bachelor's degree from American University and an MBA from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. He worked as director of research for several Wall Street investment firms before starting a mutual fund, the Becker Fund, in 1969. After selling the fund, he was an investment manager for Goldman Sachs and subsequently retired as a Principal from McCowan Associates. He was very fond of his weekends in East Hampton, NY where his hobbies including gardening, fishing and golf. Following his retirement, he moved to Stuart, FL and subsequently to Vero Beach, FL, and also maintained a summer home in Hendersonville, NC. He was a devoted husband, a terrific father and a loving grandfather. Despite many health challenges over the years, he was always upbeat. He was sharp, witty and fully engaged with everyone he met. There will be a private celebration of his life. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Spondylitis Association of America (www.spondylitis.org). Services are being handled by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book is available at www.strunkfuneralhome.com.

WALLIS--Victor - born November 10th, 1922 in London, England. Died peacefully on April 24th, 2012 in San Mateo, CA. Predeceased by his wife of 62 years, Kathleen, and survived by his sister, Lorna Howard, daughter, Amanda, granddaughter, Katie, and spouse Edith Schein Wallis. A man larger than life who brought laughter, compassion, and joy to friends and family alike. We miss him every day and always will. Amanda Wallis

HERO--Angela Constantinides, Ph.D. Born in Athens, Greece, in 1926, died peacefully at her home in New York City on April 22, 2014. Predeceased by her husband, Dr. Byron A. Hero; survived by her sons Byron (wife Camille) and Basil, her adoring grandchildren, Alexander, Gabrielle, Alexandra, and Ariane; and her brother George and wife Maguy. Historian, author and professor emerita at the Center for Byzantine and Modern Greek Studies at Queens College of the City University of New York. Her memory will be treasured by family, colleagues, former students and friends. The family will receive friends and relatives on Thursday, April 24th from 6-8 p.m. at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st St.). At her request, funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to: Center for Byzantine and Modern Greek Studies at Queens College, 65-30 Kissena Boulevard, NY 11367.

HILL--Margaret G. (Peggy)- January 3, 1925 - March 9, 2014, left us to be in heaven with her beloved husband, Bob, her parents Luke and Margaret, her sister Patricia and her brother Bill. Including many cousins, Peggy is survived by 10 nieces and nephews. A longtime Manhattan resident, Peggy was the first woman to be promoted to VP in NY Bell Telephone. She spent the latter part of her career successfully negotiating labor agreements with the labor unions. Peggy and Bob traveled the world extensively during their vacations, and always sent postcards from exotic locales. They moved to Rochester, MN so that Bob could get the benefit of Mayo Clinic medical care. After Bob left us in 1998, Peggy stayed in Rochester for the remainder of her years, active in Catholic based services. Despite her many accomplishments, Peggy remained modest. Peggy's love of family was a constant. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. John The Evangelist Church in Rochester, MN, at 9:00am Saturday, April 26, 2014. On Friday, April 25 2014, from 4:00pm to 7:00pm with a prayer service at 4:30pm, family members will receive friends at River Park Chapel, Macken Funeral Home, 1105 12th St SE, Rochester, MN 55904. Online condolences are welcome at mackenfuneralhome.com

PERNICK--David. Thanks to the generosity of David and his late wife Frances, NSUH has been able to upgrade its facilities to provide the highest level of quality care to patients. His friendship, philanthropic support and dedication to the health system helped North Shore-LIJ become a regional and national leader in healthcare. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his son Bruce and daughter-in-law Susan, daughter Jill Friedman and son-in-law Mitchell, sister Betty Haft, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Richard D. Goldstein, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System

Our lives have grown smaller for her absence. A memorial service and reception will be held Friday, April 25, at 5:30 pm at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts or to Horizons for Homeless Children, also in Massachusetts.

WEILL--Morton D.,The Trustees of Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts mourn the passing of Morton D. Weill, our beloved colleague and Usdan's first President. Morty was instrumental in guiding the planning process that lead to the opening of Usdan in 1968. He remained a trusted advisor, cherished by our Board and Administration, one who attended meetings and engaged in policy beyond his 100th year. We send condolences to Morty's children, Joan, Stuart, Judy and Jim, and to his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. John Usdan, President Dale Lewis, Executive Director

WEISS--Neil, (July 21, 1933 - April 21, 2014) Beloved Husband, Father, Brother, Grandfather, Uncle and Dear Friend. Passed away peacefully while surrounded by family after an extended, purposefully private battle with cancer, one fought with strength, humility, courage, and conviction, dedication to family and dignity for himself, never allowing the ravages of his illness to prevent him from maintaining normalcy and hope in his life, being the unwavering family patriarch and consummate business person he always was. In true Neil Weiss fashion, tirelessly driven and steadfast, from the moment he learned of his fate, he chose not to go gently into that good night. Neil went about his life, going to his office everyday, challenging our family and inner-circle of advisors with ideas and expectations, attending meetings, shooting off emails and text messages, analyzing new deals and investment opportunities, taking calls, making calls, enjoying lunches, dinners and movies with family and friends, as he loved to do, and traveling the world. He continued to do it all, until he could no longer do it all. With a knack for seamlessly combining his personal and business lives onto one playing field, Neil applied a drive and passion for business in everything he did. He had a sensibility for knowing how to make things happen, albeit with great success and tenacity. An extraordinary role model to his children and grandchildren, his nieces and nephew, he enjoyed "keeping score" in his business dealings and investments as much as he did in his squash games, or the number of flights he would climb in his apartment building as part of his morning exercise routine. He stayed busy doing what he enjoyed doing... working hard, enjoying family, having fun, negotiating deals and playing with a certain degree of managed risk, always with a strong moral compass. Born and raised in the Bronx, he worked a short time early in his illustrious career for an established apparel manufacturer before deciding with unflappable confidence that he had the ability and ambition to do it better. The business grew, as did his business relationships and lasting personal friendships within the industry. Ever the pioneer, he was amongst the first in the industry to open offices in Hong Kong and the Dominican Republic, and manufacture private label for global luxury brands and retailers. It was also the pioneer in him that led to real estate investments in China and Hong Kong, in the late 70's after relations between the United States and China thawed. It was that same adventurous, enterprising, pioneering spirit that had him returning from trips in the early days to Asia with novel gifts, technologically-advanced gadgetry for family and friends, all precursors to today's cell phone. As his manufacturing business flourished, he continued to parlay his international business experience into a multitude of opportunistic ventures and partnerships, investing globally early in his career in commercial real estate in New York City and Asia, and more recently in New Orleans, as well as in Brazil with his dear friend and partner. He also had a penchant for complex alternative investments, all the while developing his own disciplined, self-taught investment skills that would often lead to returns that had many investment advisors in awe. In this regard, Neil viewed life as a game and business as a sport. He always made sure to have fun doing both. With an insatiable appetite for reading newspapers and sharing his knowledge with those he loved, he pushed us to do better, think with greater clarity and to experiment. He had a profound impact on all we did. A man of impeccable integrity and style, Neil took pleasure in every aspect of life, great and small. He was bold with his business deals. He had a huge heart and exceedingly generous spirit when it came to his family and friends. Decisive, direct, feisty, he was always his own man. Neil embraced life, family and business with an indomitable spirit, gusto, and boundless energy. He conducted his life with an abundance of love, wisdom, and wit. His legacy will live on in the many lives he touched throughout his industrious life, and he will be sorely and profoundly missed. Neil is pre-deceased by his eldest son Steven and survived by his faithful partner, the woman he adored and married more than 42 years ago, Virginia, his devoted children, Ken, Douglas and Elizabeth, his daughter-in-law, Jennifer (Ken), the grandchildren he so cherished, Roy, Gil, Stefan, Leila, Steven and Ava, and his sister who he so adored, Mal. He also leaves behind brother-in-law Murray, nieces Sandi and Lisa, and nephew Douglas, Noreen (fiancee to Douglas), Anthony (fiancee to Elizabeth), his COO and faithful friend Anna, Gus and Laling, as loyal and faithful as they come. A patron of the many arts in New York City, Neil was active in a wide range of philanthropic endeavors and worthy causes. A celebration of his life will be held on April 24th, 2014 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel on Madison and 81st street. Donations can be made to Susan G. Komen (ww5.komen.org) and the Friars Foundation Wounded Warriors Program (friarsclub.com).
