WHEELER--Wesley D. Wesley D. Wheeler, MSE, 1933 - 2014, passed away on Friday, April 18th in Stamford, Connecticut. He was 80 years old. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Dolores Janes Wheeler, his three children: Wesley P. Wheeler, Jonathan H. Wheeler and Debbie W. Fagerstrom, his sister Rosalie W. Maiden and seven grandchildren. He was laid to rest in Cypress Hills Cemetery in Brooklyn, NY. Mr. Wheeler was a long time and well respected member of the international marine community. In his 60 year professional life, he worked for many well known marine consultants, shipbuilders and naval architects including: JJ. Henry & Co., J. J. McMullen Associates, H.M. Tiedemann & Co, American Bulk Carriers, Sparkman & Stephens Inc., Astilleros Espanoles and M. Rosenblatt & Son. He founded his own firm, Wheeler Associates Ltd. and for over 30 years worked as a technical director, naval consultant, shipyard representative, marine engineer, marine forensic expert and maritime arbiter for some of the largest and best known shipyards and ship owners in the world, most recently Blohm & Voss. He lived and worked in over 13 countries and was a long standing member of the Society of Naval Architects & Marine Engineers, the Royal Institute of Naval Architects, the Connecticut Maritime Association and others. Wes was the grandson of Howard E. Wheeler, who founded the Wheeler Yacht Company in 1910 in Brooklyn, NY. For 50 years, the Wheeler family produced more than 3,000 pleasure yachts and 800 ships for the US military, including the Coast Guard "matchbox fleet" which were deployed during the Allied invasion of Normandy. Hemingway's "Pilar" was also built by the Wheelers. Wes was born into this family and designed several of the last pleasure boats as a young architect. Mr. Wheeler graduated from the University of Michigan in 1958 with a master's degree in Naval Architecture & Marine Engineering, and from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in 1954 with a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering. He was a licensed engineer in Europe and the United Kingdom. Mr. Wheeler was a devoted professional and flag bearer for his industry and his family's legacy. He will be sorely missed by the many people he touched during his lifetime. A service to remember his life and career will be held at the 5th Ave. Presbyterian Church in New York City on May 3rd at 2pm. A reception will be held immediately after the service.

SHAFER--Alan (Felix) passed away on Tuesday, April 15th, after an 11-month struggle with lung cancer. He leaves his long-time partner, Miranda Bergman, his children, Ona, Gemma, Max and Jack, his sisters Uma, Stephanie and Jessica, and his extended family and friends. Felix was a revolutionary activist, internationalist, writer, poet, musician and psychotherapist. He was an avid reader, a lover of film, art and every aspect of culture and counterculture. He was forever curious about the cosmos. He valued making good food in good company. Felix was born in Brooklyn and, even after decades in the San Francisco Bay Area, always considered himself a New Yorker. His life of activism was fuelled by a passion for peace and justice for all people. He was part of the anti-Vietnam War movement and an ally of Black Liberation and Puerto Rican independence. Felix maintained a decades-long commitment to supporting and freeing political prisoners like Marilyn Buck, Geronimo Pratt, Bashir Hameed, and the SF 8. They were among his closest friends and comrades. Felix fervently believed in the transformative power of people, both politically and personally. He brought this spirit into his work as a therapist, and continued his practice until the last days of his life. Felix never lost his dignity, his intellect or his sharp sense of humor. The last months of his life were marked by great tenderness and love. We will always remember his strength, his humanity and his capacity to think of others, even while facing his own death. We love you Felix. Memorial details: felixmemorial@gmail.com.

SOMMERS--Edmond, 90 of Tenafly, New Jersey, peacefully on April 24, 2014. Survivors include his beloved wife Sylvia, daughter Joan, son Daniel, daughter-in-law Lillian and grandson Benjamin. Services Sunday, 11am at "Eden Memorial Chapel", 327 Main Street, Fort Lee, New Jersey. 201-947-3336.

REYNOLDS--Gibson Jr.,A mountaineer who explored the frontiers of Alaska and an aerospace engineer who helped pioneer exploration of space, died April 20. He was 89. He was born in Montgomery, AL, the son of Gibson Reynolds Sr., a physician, and the former Ethel Douglas Stewart of New York. He attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology before enlisting in the Army during World War II, where he was trained as an engineer and assigned to the Army Signal Corps. In 1945, he set up microwave relay towers to carry communications between commanders occupying Germany including one on the summit of the Zugspitze, Germany's highest mountain. While stationed at an abandoned observation post on the top of the mountain, he taught himself to ski and rock climb, launching a lifelong interest in mountaineering and exploring. When he returned home, he completed his engineering studies and obtained degrees from MIT and the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. He also joined expeditions in Alaska, Canada and the Pacific Northwest, making first ascents of Mt. Augusta (14,070 ft., 1952), University Peak (15,030 ft., 1955), and the second ascent of Canada's King Peak (16,971 ft., 1952) among other climbs. He also summited every peak in New York's Adirondack mountains, and New Hampshire's White Mountains. He remained an active member of the American Alpine Club and the Alpine Club of Canada throughout his life. As an aerospace engineer, Reynolds helped pioneer the exploration of a second frontier, outer space. Working at Bendix Corp. in Teterboro, NJ, he helped design flight systems for military aircraft, including the B-58 and B-52 bombers, and was part of the team that designed control systems for Apollo space missions, including the manual throttle used by astronaut Neil Armstrong to land on the moon. He later worked on the design of the Space Shuttle and the collision avoidance system for civilian aircraft. He retired in 1991. In 1962, he married Monica M. Monahan of Dublin, Ireland, an Irish climber who served as secretary of the American Alpine Club at its Manhattan headquarters, and settled in Tuxedo, NY. Reynolds is survived by his wife and five children, Maura Reynolds Kelley of Washington, DC, Ciara Reynolds Hayden of Manhattan, Gibson Reynolds III of Collingswood, NJ, Aidan Reynolds of Lynbrook, NY, Ronan Reynolds of Phoenix, AZ, and five grandchildren. Donations to the American Alpine Club, 710 10th St., Golden, CO 80401.

SCHWARTZ--Robert. September 17, 1941 April 17, 2014. A man who led his own path with humanity and love. Surgeon, sailor, leader amongst his peers, but most of all an amazing dad and beloved husband. Dr. Bob practiced Obstetrics and Gynecology and Gynecologic Oncology with his daughter, Sarah, on the South Shore of Long Island. He served as President of the Medical Staff and Chairman of the Department of Ob-Gyn at Good Samaritan Medical Center and was Director of Gynecologic Oncology at Nassau University Medical Center. He trained residents and medical students in advanced pelvic surgery at Southside Hospital, North Shore-LIJ Health System. An avid sailor and member of the New York Yacht Club, he competed in many of the world's most prestigious regattas. He touched everyone that ever met him with his compassion, contagious smile, and his enthusiasm to live life to the fullest. He will be dearly missed by his wife Diane, son Benjamin, daughters Anna and Sarah, grandchildren Abigail, Michael and Andrew.

SORENSEN--Marjorie M.,died in New York City on Sunday, April 13, age 92. Born Marjorie Joyce Mattson on a farm outside of Holdrege, Nebraska, she met her husband, Robert C. Sorensen, at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln. They lived in Chicago, where she completed her studies at Northwestern University while active in liberal A.D.A. Democratic Party politics, and Washington, D.C., before moving to Munich, where Dr. Robert Sorensen worked for Radio Free Europe for five years. Marjorie ran the household, learned fluent German, took courses at the Art Academy, and was an active volunteer in efforts to support handicapped children through the German-American Women's Club. Returning to the U.S. and to New York City in 1958, Marjorie created the family home in an Upper East Side brownstone. She was an early behind-the-scenes actor in a variety of nascent causes including public television, international education, environmentalism, and the rights of women and the elderly. Marjorie and Robert were parents of three children: Chris, Katherine, and David. Marjorie is mourned by her surviving sons, Chris (Robert C.A. of New City, N.Y.) and David (of Copenhagen, Denmark), and grandchildren, Hannah and Stephen Simpson and Nicholas and Axel Sorensen.
SAPERSTEIN--Bella. Magen David Adom in Israel mourns the passing of Bella Saperstein, z"l. Mother of our friend Arnold Gerson, CEO of American Friends of MDA

SIDERIS--George John, 87, of Fort Lee, NJ passed away at his home with his family by his side on April 24th, 2014. George is survived by Mary (nee Skouras), his beloved wife of 60 years, and two children Diane and John. George was born in Athens Greece and raised in New York's Hell's Kitchen where he attended High School of Commerce. After serving in World War II as a US Army Staff Sergeant, George came home to earn a Bachelor of Science in Economics from NYU. George had an illustrious career in Finance till he retired as Chief Financial Officer for Long Island Lighting Company in 1992. Loving husband, devoted father, fiercely loyal friend, indomitable spirit and honest as day is long. George will be missed more than words can say but will be remembered for the love he had in his heart for everyone he met, his ever present smile and his determined optimism best captured in his favorite phrase "I'm in good shape for the shape that I'm in". A viewing will be held on Sunday, April 27th from 4pm-9pm at AK Macagnas Funeral home, 495 Anderson Avenue in Cliffside Park, NJ. The funeral will take place on Monday, April 28th at 11:30am at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, NY. Burial, immediately following, at Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

STOLLER--Martin I. Born in New York City, October 5, 1922. Served in WWII 4th Armoured. Career began as chief economist NYC. Continued in Washington, D.C. Specializing in Latin American economic development with US AID, World Bank and investment banking. Loving husband and father survived by wife of 51 yrs, Marjory, 3 children and 6 grandchildren.

WEHLE--Anne Franklin, of Lloyd Harbor, NY, died peacefully on April 8th at the age of 93. Born in Warsaw, IN the only child of George and Mary Franklin. Valedictorian of her class at Warsaw High School, attended DePauw University and graduated with the Class of 1943 from Vassar College with a degree in Early Childhood Development. She went on to join the staff of the childcare department of Grumman Aircraft where she met aeronautical engineer L. Brandeis Wehle who became her beloved husband of 60 years. Brand predeceased her in 2007. Anne was a devoted mother and grandmother and an active member of her community. She served on the board of directors of Planned Parenthood of Suffolk County and volunteered for other local organizations including Huntington Hospital, Family Service League, North Shore Holiday House and Old First Church. She became a nurse later in life and thoroughly enjoyed her second career caring for patients at Huntington Hospital. An avid golfer, Anne twice hit a hole-in-one in 1976 and was an active tennis and platform tennis player as well as an inveterate sun-worshipper. At the time of her death she was the senior member of the Huntington Country Club and the Lloyd Neck Bath Club. She is survived by her daughter Nancy Aboff (Michael), Susan Wehle, Jonathan Wehle and grandchildren Matthew, Susannah (Brad) and Gareth. Her son Robert predeceased her in 2011. Anne believed that hers had been a very lucky life. Throughout the arc of that life, she was a sunny and optimistic person whose kindness, warmth and generosity were felt by all those around her. Anne will deeply missed by her family and her many friends. A memorial service will be held on May 3rd at 11am at Old First Church in Huntington, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Huntington Hospital or Planned Parenthood of Hudson Peconic.

SCOTT--Lael French, died at home in Greenwich Village on April 24. Journalist, lawyer, restless adventurer, beloved mother, wife, grandmother, aunt, friend. Born in Seattle in 1936, she studied at Goucher, the University of Washington, Heidelberg and London before graduating from Columbia in the city she made home. A reporter for Dolly Schiff's liberal New York Post in the '60s, she covered crime, politics (RFK's Senate race), society (Capote's B&W Ball). In '68, a new mother, she joined then-husband Arthur Herzog in helping run the McCarthy campaign. She divorced, wrote for magazines, became a business columnist, studied law at Cardozo - graduating at 46 - and started her own practice. In 2002 she met her second husband and great love, Lloyd Kaye, in a New School class; he died in 2011. She is survived by her son Matthew Herzog, daughter-in-law Linda, grandchildren Alex, Josephine and James, nieces Lenore Madeleine and Lael Alspach, nephews Tom de Kay, Phil Roosevelt, Lennox and John Scott.

WEILL--Morton D.,"Pop," of Manhattan, 104. Beloved husband of the late Adele Oelbaum Weill, died at home on April 22, 2014. Proud graduate of Cornell University 1930. For 52 years Morty worked at United Merchants and Manufacturers, and in the last years of his distinguished career in the textile industry he was President of UM&M. He was the first President and long-time board member of the Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts. Devoted father of Joan Levin (Stu) and Jim Weill (Judy Waxman); adoring grandfather of Anne Marsh, Tom Levin (Stephanie), Steve Levin (Jessica Shaw), Andy Levin (Francine), Jennie Weill and Andy Waxman (Pam Yosca); adoring great-grandfather of his 10 great-grandchildren; and beloved by a legion of family and friends, including his wonderful long-time caretakers Dolly Persaud, Errol Robinson and Mark Brown. In lieu of flowers, please contribute in his memory to the charity of your choice or the Morton and Adele Weill Fund at the Usdan Center, www.usdan.com.

WEINSTOCK--S. Alexander, PhD. 83, clinical psychologist, died April 14. Survived by companion Dorothy Stearn, sister Teri Ben-Eli (Shmuel), nephews David and Danny. Holocaust survivor, scholar/researcher will be remembered for his wit, intelligence and compassion by many patients, colleagues and friends.
WEISS--Neil. A funny, warm, generous and vibrant guy. We will sorely miss him. We send our love to Virginia and the entire family. Hedy and Arthur Goldberg

RATH--Elisabeth. Elisabeth Rath, who arrived in New York City in 1948 and lived there for nearly sixty years, died after a long illness on Friday, April 18th, 2014, at her home in Reston, Virginia. She was 91 years old. Born Elisabeth Chorin in Budapest Hungary, her father Francis Chorin, was one of the most important political and economic figures in pre-war Hungary. Her mother, Daisy, was the daughter of Manfred Weiss, Hungary's most important industrialist. She was the oldest of three children and lived a life of privilege in Budapest that ended with the German invasion of Hungary. As the result of an extraordinary deal that was brokered by her father, the family was saved and spent the war in Portugal. After they received their American visas, the entire family emigrated to New York where she became active in Hungarian causes. With energy and intellect, she helped to establish the Hungarian House, on the Upper East Side, an institution committed to sustaining the rich cultural life of the Hungarian emigre community. She also played an important role in helping families emigrate from Hungary, particularly after the Hungarian revolution of 1956, coordinating efforts to help them with jobs and resettlement in the United States. As the secretary to her father, she was deeply involved in all aspects of his financial career including investments in New York real estate and providing venture capital for Gulf and Western, before it became a public company. Her first marriage to Steven Rath ended in her husband's death in 1984. She then married Laszlo de Mandy, who was her childhood sweetheart when she was growing up in Hungary. He passed away in 1999. She is survived by her son from her first marriage, Francis Rath of Great Falls, Virginia and her sister Daisy Strasser of Vienna, Austria. A memorial service will be held on May 3 at 12 Noon at the St. Joseph Catholic Church in Herndon, VA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be sent to the "American Hungarian Library" at Hungarian House, 215 East 82 St., New York, NY 10028.
LIFTON--Richard Zane . A year has passed and we think of you every day. You are forever in our hearts.

PERNICK--David. It is with deep sadness that the American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel notes the passing of our dear friend, generous patron and a true mensch, David Pernick, Life Chancellor of Shenkar College of Engineering, Design & Art, former Chairman of the International Board of Governors of Shenkar College and former President of our Board of Directors. A graduate of the University of Massachusetts-Lowell, David went on to found, in 1961, the Monarch Knitting Machinery Company, which under his leadership would gain a reputation as the finest supplier of circular knitting machinery in the world. David's support and passion for Shenkar College was unsurpassed and unconditional. For over thirty years, David gave generously of his resources, time, energy and wisdom to further the mission of the College which he loved so much. Some 60 years after graduating Lowell, David and his late wife Frances would establish the International Program of Graduate Studies in Plastic Engineering which brings to the Lowell campus doctoral students from Shenkar and sends faculty to Shenkar for research and collaboration. Recognizing the effect Engineering has on excellence in Design, David supported the development of the Engineering Faculty which became a platform for expanding the college, helping to create job opportunities in Israel. In 1990 the main facility on the Shenkar campus was renamed The Pernick Building, in honor of Frances and David. The Pernick family's generosity was most recently recognized with the naming of the Pernick Faculty of Engineering. We are forever grateful for David's unstinting support and wise counsel. He will be sorely missed, and never forgotten. With every Shenkar graduate, Frances and David leave a legacy that will prosper and flourish. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Pernick family and David's many, many friends throughout the world. Donations in David's memory can be made at Shenkar.org or sent to The American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel, 307 7th Ave Suite 1805 New York, NY 10001. Bruce Pernick - President, Board of Directors, American Committee for Shenkar College in Israel Ivan Helfand Executive Director Charlotte Fainblatt - Executive Director Emeritus
LERNER--Jack Newton. Always in our hearts, we all send our love and appreciation to you and Mom.

RABINOWITZ--Bert. Sunrise May 18, 1925 - Sunset April 15, 2014. Bert (Bud) Rabinowitz died peacefully at home in Antigua of brain cancer. An entrepreneur and philanthropist, Bud spent 23 years at Colonial Provision Company, which he sold in 1970. He spent the next 15 years successfully fundraising as a volunteer. He served as Campaign Chairman for the Combined Jewish Philanthropies from 1968 to 1971. He was elected as a National Chairman of the United Jewish Appeal in 1970. Bud chaired the JDC/Brookdale Institute for Applied Research that has made positive contributions to the health and welfare of the Jewish population internationally. As a United States Marine, he attended Dartmouth College. He received his MBA with a specialization in meatpacking from the University of Chicago. He was the beloved husband of Constance (Connie) for 66 years. He will also be greatly missed by his children Craig Rabinowitz of California, Gail Grimes and her husband, William, of Lexington, Massachusetts and Sara Birnham and her husband, Rabbi Shmuel, of West Vancouver, Canada, as well as his grandchildren Timothy and his wife, Kate Daly, Cory, and Stuart Grimes and David Birnham.
HAZAN--Leslie Beth. To my daughter on her 51st Birthday. You are in my heart today and always.

PARKER--Kenneth Lewis, 89, of Greenwich, CT, died on April, 16, 2014, ending a life-long love affair with his wife Mary Jule "Judy". He died with his wife holding his hand, telling him it was an honor to be his wife. Born on November 18, 1924, as a third generation Houston, Texan, Ken met his wife-to-be in 1946 at the University of Houston upon his return from four years of WWII Naval service on the USS Detroit. Beginning their life journey after meeting over a friendly game of bridge on campus, they went on to create a formidable ACBL partnership that spanned several decades. Ken's boundless zest for life included his love for wine, food, international adventure travel, tennis and running. His goal of visiting all seven continents was realized in 2008 when he celebrated New Year's Day with his wife and daughters in Antarctica. Acting on his humanistic compassion, Ken donated his body to medical science. Survivors include Mary Jule, his wife of 67 years, his daughters Kathlyn (son-in-law Kenneth Davis), Kristin and Laurel (son-in-law Kenneth Ross), his grandchildren, Kalan and Parker, and devoted friends. Our brilliant flame extinguished, we rejoice that this wonderful man lived life to its fullest. Ken memorized his much-loved Rubaiyat and often quoted this. "Come, fill the Cup, and in the fire of Spring Your Winter-garment of Repentance fling: The Bird of Time has but a little way to flutter--and the Bird is on the Wing." His family will have a private memorial. Mary Jule Parker Kristin Parker

SILVERMAN--Louis R.,is survived by his wife of 54 years, Diane Silverman; three children, S Jonathan Silverman (Anne), Joshua Silverman (Kimberly), and Rachel Silverman Darlow (David); and six grandchildren, Baila, Naomi, Meira, Isaac, Tamar, and Jacob. Funeral services: Mon. April 28 at 11:30 a.m., Congregation Rodfei Zedek, 5200 S. Hyde Park Blvd, Chicago.
BRAYSHAW--Cissy Taggert.April 23, 2010. How we miss our beautiful Cissy. The Balaban Family The Grossman Family

PATURICK--Sarah. The family of Sarah Paturick mourns her passing on April 24, 2014. Wife of the late Arthur Paturick, mother of Charles Paturick and wife Bobbie, Barbara Tramonte, Roz Ayotte, Joanne (Priya) Zander Fox and the late Miriam Paturick. Beloved grandmother of Rachel and husband Dr. Ken Rosenfeld, David Tramonte and fiance Amanda Wilson, Kaylin Jones, Kristen Ayotte, and Anna Fox. Beloved great-grandmother of Hannah and Lily Rosenfeld. She was the ultimate New Yorker; a kind and generous woman who will be missed by many. Donations can be made to The Fresh Air Fund or The Henry Street Settlement.

SMALL--Abe, died peacefully in his sleep on January 31st, 2013 in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn where he lived most of his 97 years. Born Abraham Smolowitz on December 9th, 1915 in a LES tenement apartment to Jewish immigrants Ida and Sam Smolowitz. Mother Ida was a seamstress at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory, but as fate would have it she stayed home to care for her ill sister the day the factory burned down. Ida went on to marry Sam Smolowitz. They had three children David, Abe and Dorothy. Abe spent his formative years in Bensonhurst. Intelligent and curious, Abe graduated from New Utrecht High School and went on to Brooklyn College. As a devoted son, Abe left university to help his father run the family store on Orchard Street. At 26, Abe enlisted in the army. He was a proud member and decorated officer of the 3158th Signal Core, 45th infantry division. Before going overseas, Abe married his girlfriend Jean Shankman on April 14th, 1943. Three years later Abe returned home to his wife and the family store, but eventually made his career as a traveling salesman and garment expert in the tri-state area. If you needed directions from Brighton Beach to Sleepy Hollow, Abe was your guy. Three children later, he and Jean were settled in Sheepshead Bay, where they happily remained until his death. A devoted man to family and friends, Abe was greatly engaged in his faith and his community. His extensive work with the Shore Park Jewish Center, B'Nai Brith, Brooklyn College Hillel, UJA and his 20 years of service with the Brooklyn Veterans Hospital will long outlive him. Keeping up with the weather, the news, and his responsibilities as a US citizen, Abe read the New York Times front to back every day, and always exercised his right to vote. He cast his last vote (November 2012) at 96 years old. He loved baseball, black cherry ice cream, going to shul, the beach, the state of Israel, a good bargain, a good movie, a good debate, and his grandchildren. His sharp mind and memory never left him. He is survived by his wife Jean, 93, his sister Dorothy, 94, nieces and nephews, cousins, his three children, Barbara Callaghan, Paul Small, Gay Abrams, five grandchildren, and four great- grandchildren. He adored his granddaughter Robin, who sadly predeceased him. Abe leaves a legacy of a strong moral compass and a life well-lived. The unveiling of his monument will take place this Sunday, April 27th at 11am at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York.
EIREF--Zvi, on April 17, 2014 Beloved husband of Catherine (Lindy), father of Daniel, Benjamin and Simon and grandfather to six grandchildren in Princeton, New Jersey, USA.

GORT--Robert "Bob", 87, of Boynton Beach, FL. Formerly of Great Neck, NY, passed April 19, 2014. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother. Survived by wife Lucille Kellner Gort, children Jeffrey Gort (Michele), Laurie Arner (deceased), Lisa Leventhal (Mark), grandchildren Keith (Lindsay), Samantha, Brandon and brother of Seymour. Owner of Gort Industries, Naval Reservist and Shriner. So loved and so missed by all. Donations to the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation of America.

HERNDON--John Joyce Carter, died peacefully April 15, 2014 in Picton, Ontario. Leaving behind his much loved wife Tidi, his stepson sons Andrea and Silvio Pinto and their families. He is predeceased son John Hearst Herndon. John, had a very full life; graduated with high honors from Yale, a vet of the war of Korea, worked for City Bank, Rheen International which became City Investing. Later he became commissioner of Agriculture of Connecticut under governor Lowell Weicker and was a very successful Breeder of Angus. He retired in Ontario Canada to enjoy a rural life and bred more Angus. He will be remembered by numerous friends in all parts of the world and will never be forgotten by his beloved wife and all their pets. Donations if desired, go ASPCA and the Humane Society.

LANDES--Rabbi Aaron. Yeshiva University is saddened by the passing of Rabbi Aaron Landes, a cherished alumnus of Yeshiva College '51, who served with distinction as a navy chaplain in the United States Armed Forces and as the longtime Senior Rabbi of Beth Sholom Congregation in Elkins Park, PA and other important leadership roles in the Jewish community. The Rabbi Aaron Landes, YC '51, Rear Admiral CHC USNR RET Scholarship at Yeshiva College was established by his son Joshua H. Landes (and his wife Bryna Shuchat), a member of the Yeshiva University Museum Board of Overseers. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Sora E. Landes, his children: Rena (and Elliot) Rank, Rebecca (and Timothy) Kolman, Joshua H. (and wife Bryna Shuchat) Landes, Tamar (and Dr. Steven) Rapaport, his sister Marilyn and twelve grandchildren. May the entire family find comfort among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus

GOLDHAMMER--Robert Frederick, died peacefully at home on March 31, 2014. Much loved and best beloved husband; father, grandfather and innovator, a builder of companies and men, he trusted in the Lord. Funeral service will take place at 3:00pm on Wednesday April 30th in the Grosvenor Chapel, 24 South Audley Street, London.

GOLDSTEIN--Martin of New York City, born 1919 in Bronx, NY, died April 23, at home with his family. Goldstein taught chemistry at Yeshiva University and the Belfer Graduate School of Science, and authored many scientific articles, and essays about Dostoevsky, Shakespeare, and Trollope. With Inge F. Goldstein, his wife of 60 years, he wrote four books, How We Know, The Experience of Science, The Refrigerator and the Universe, and How Much Risk? He is survived by Inge, children, Eric, Michael and Aviva, and grandchildren, Teddy, Ari, Avital, and Eyal. Info on Marty's service at www.riversidememorialchapel.com. In lieu of flowers, support Bloomingdale Aging in Place, www.bloominplace.org.

HICKEY--Raymond F.,81, of Bedford, NY died Wednesday, April 23, 2014. Mr. Hickey was born August 1, 1932 in Brooklyn, NY. Raymond worked and started his own Insurance Business, Hickey & Hickey, in NYC in 1957, relocating to Bedford in 1968. He retired after 50 years in 2001, leaving his two sons continuing the business today. Raymond is survived by his wife of 60 years: Elizabeth (Kilcourse) Hickey; five children: Raymond F. Jr., Mary H. Palmerton, Brian J., Michael D., and Peter J. Hickey; and 16 grandchildren. Family will receive friends on Sunday, April 27 from 2-5pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, NY. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Monday, April 28 at 11am at St. Patrick's Church, Route 22, Bedford Village, NY. Interment will follow in Oakwood Cemetery, Mt. Kisco, NY.

GOLD--Hattie, eldest daughter of "Russ and Daughters" died April 17, at 101 years. Survived by son Paul, five grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Devoted husband of 57 years, Murray Gold, died in 1992. Beloved daughter Nina Silverman died in 2009. Sister Ida died in 1999. Youngest sister Ann lives in Florida.

HOFFMANN--Peter. Peter Paul Hoffmann, 78, of Rhinecliff, NY, beloved husband of Sarah (Briggs) Hoffmann passed away on April 18, 2014. Peter was an award-winning author, journalist, and photographer. As the editor and publisher of the "Hydrogen & Fuel Cell Letter", launched in 1986, he championed the cause of hydrogen and fuel cells as the clean energy carrier of the future. He is the author of two books on the subject; "Tomorrow's Energy: Hydrogen, Fuel Cells, and the Prospects for a Cleaner Planet" and "The Forever Fuel: The Story of Hydrogen". Born December 28, 1935 in Berlin, Germany the son of Rudolph and Kaethe (Floeter) Hoffmann, he first came to the United States in 1952 as an AFS exchange student in Tucson. He returned to the United States to graduate from the University of South Dakota and went on to receive an MA from Yale as well as a masters from the Columbia School of Journalism. Early in his career he worked as a journalist for the AP, The Washington Post and Time Magazine and then went on to spend the next 20 years as a correspondent and bureau chief for McGraw-Hill World News in Bonn, Germany; Milan, Italy and Washington, DC. His passions included photography, jazz, and bad puns. Peter loved his family; sons Peter, Rem, and Ben; daughters-in-law Jill and Carla; grandson Liam and his constant companion Giotto. As an only child he treasured his turbulent new family of Briggs in-laws. Memorial donations may be made in Peter's memory to the Rhinebeck Science Foundation, PO Box 508, Rhinebeck NY 12572.

JENNINGS--Samuel P.,81, died of prostate cancer on April 24, 2014. Mr. Jennings held several executive financial management positions at IBM. He was Vice-President, Finance and Planning for three different Groups, and was Assistant Group Executive for the Asia Pacific Group, headquartered in Tokyo, Japan, where the Jennings lived for over four years. In his last year in Japan, Mr. Jennings was a Senior Managing Director for IBM Japan. Sam loved his job and all the wonderful people he worked with during his 30 years with IBM. Above all else, Sam was a family man, and nothing was more important to him than Carlotta (de Sylva), his loving wife of 47 years; their four children, Peter (Ericka), Christopher (Priscilla), Bridget and Robert (Maria); and his five grandchildren. A Mass to celebrate his life will be held on May 2, 2014 at Our Lady Star of the Sea Catholic Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Sam's memory can be made to the General Scholarship Fund of Villanova University, Re: Samuel P Jennings, Development Office, 800 Lancaster Avenue, Villanova, PA, 19085. Please visit our online Tribute at www.quinn-shalz.com. Services under the care and direction of Quinn-shalz, A Family Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL.

HELLER--Annette A. (nee Abraham) Born February 17, 1937 passed away at her home in East Hampton from breast cancer peacefully on April 20, 2014 surrounded by her family. She was an entrepreneur in Focus Group Research and the Snack Industry with Harry's Premium Snacks and an artist in East Hampton known for her color field abstracts. She leaves her husband, Harry Heller, sister Vivian Freed (Steve Freed,) two children Lisa Heller MD (Harry Roth) and David Heller (Melissa Smith) and 5 grandchildren Andrew, Eric and Michael Roth, Alexa and Jessica Heller who all lovingly referred to her as Nettie. Her family and friends salute her courage, humor, determination and grace in her 22 year battle against breast cancer.

HAVEMEYER--Horace, III. Founder of Bellerophon Publications, publisher of Metropolis magazine and Metropolis Books, merging his lifelong interest in the breadth of architecture and design and in publishing and process. He was also a lifelong sailor, a natural teacher, and a talented, prolific watercolorist. Horace died March 19, 2014, at age 72, at home in New York from CIDP, a chronic neurological condition; he became quadriplegic in mid-2011. He is survived by his beloved and loving wife Eugenie Cowan Havemeyer; his mother Rosalind E. Havemeyer; his siblings Rosalind H. Roosevelt, William E. Havemeyer and Christian Havemeyer, and his uncle Harry W. Havemeyer. A 1964 graduate of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, in Geneva, New York, Horace served on the Board of Trustees from 1980-85 and 1991-97. He joined the family-owned National Sugar Refining Company in the Philadelphia factory, learning chemical processes, until the company was sold in 1969. He then began his publishing career in New York City as Production Planning Supervisor at Doubleday book publishers. There he learned editorial and business operations and nurtured his thirst for learning. Horace's intellectual and practical curiosity framed his vision for Metropolis: to ask and answer what, why and how, and to focus on collaborations and challenges in any project. Metropolis reaches beyond print: Its 1981 interactive conference "Midtown: Testing the Zoning Proposal" led to others; it was the initial sponsor of the International Contemporary Furniture Fair and sponsors competitions and educational tours. In 2009 the American Institute of Architects awarded Horace for Metropolis its Honor for Collaborative Achievement. "Reaching a broad cross-section of design disciplines, touching all elements of design excellence," the citation read, "it speaks to elemental and contextual innovation, including, but not limited to ecological insight, livability, and community development; in short, the spectrum of all goals of the architectural profession." He was a co-founder and board member of Exploring the Metropolis, Inc., nonprofit organization led by his wife, Eugenie Cowan, that solves workspace issues facing New York's performing arts and cultural communities. A celebration of Horace's life and influences will be held May 2, 2014, 11:00am, at St. James' Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street in Manhattan, reception following the service. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Horace's memory may be made to Exploring the Metropolis, Inc., 61 West 23rd Street, New York 10010, or to Hospital for Special Surgery: ALS Research, c/o Dr. Dale J. Lange, 525 East 71st Street, 5th floor, New York, 10021.
HELLER--Annette (nee Abraham). April 20, 2014. Beautiful, elegant, creative, warm, loving, gracious. She will be missed and remembered by many.
HELLER--Annette (nee Abraham), April 20, 2014 at home in East Hampton after a long illness. Beloved wife, mother, sister, grandmother, aunt, and friend.

LLOYD--Derek. The Board and Staff of The New 42nd Street and The New Victory Theater are deeply saddened by the untimely death of our dear Mary Rose Lloyd's beloved husband, Derek Lloyd. Derek was adored by all who were lucky enough to know him, as he was irresistibly warm and charming, gentle and oh so spirited. We embrace Mary with all our hearts. Fiona Rudin, Chairman Cora Cahan, President

MARGULIS--Irwin, formerly of Great Neck, NY, passed away in Boynton Beach, FL on April 17th at the age of 81. He was married for 59 years to his loving wife Sharon and raised two amazing daughters, Robin Smith of Baltimore, MD, and Joy Moss of Huntington, NY. Sons-in-law Dr. Sam Smith and Brian Moss, along with grandchildren Brandon and Jared Kilberg and Samantha and Zachary Moss will forever hold him in their hearts. Irwin was a legend in the deli food business, as well as a past treasurer of both the Great Neck and Boynton Beach Rotary Clubs.

FAGAN--Leo James,of Milford CT, died peacefully at home in the afternoon of a sunny day, April 17, 2014, in the arms of Alanna, his wife of 49 years, and best pal. He had Alzheimer's Disease for many years. He was 91. A man of grace, charm and wit, with a passion for flying and adventure, he was an instrument-rated pilot. He and Alanna often flew their airplane south through The Bahamas Islands to the Caribbean, visiting many along the way, to St. Bart's where they had built a small island-style house. Together they flew thousands of miles over the years. A veteran of WWII, Leo served four years in the USMC, attended flight school and earned his Aviation Navigator's wings. While stationed in Hawaii, he was Navigator in a B-25/PBJ on many flights in the Pacific to Midway, Johnston, Kwajelein, Guam, Wake, Okinawa; and to Shanghai, Tsing Tao, and Tientsin in China. In 1954 he opened Fagan's Restaurant on the banks of the Housatonic River in Stratford, CT, just upstream from the American Shakespeare Festival Theater. The restaurant became a great success, known for its fine dining and views over the water, and was frequented by actors, theater-goers, locals and food lovers from far and wide. After thirty-three years, the restaurant was sold in 1987 allowing Leo more time to fly, write and travel. He also loved to cook and to entertain friends at home for lunches and dinners. Leo is survived by his wife, Alanna, an artist; a daughter, Lynne, and a son, John, from his first marriage; Alanna's two sons, Charles D. and Daniel M. Lay; and two grandchildren. A party celebrating Leo's life will be held later this summer for family and friends. Semper Fi, Leo.

HAUGE--Helen Resor, died peacefully at her home in New York City on April 21, 2014 at 94. Born on December 8, 1919, she was the daughter of Stanley B. Resor, who ran the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency for 45 years, and legendary copywriter Helen Lansdowne Resor. A graduate of Ethel Walker School and Bryn Mawr College, Helen earned an M.A. at Teachers College. In 1948, she married Gabriel Hauge, who worked for President Dwight D. Eisenhower as Special Assistant for Economic Affairs, before moving to New York City where he became president and chairman of the board of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. She was passionate about education, population control, women's and community issues, and served on the boards of The Brearley School, Concord Academy, Henry Street Settlement House and the New York Urban League. She is survived by her children Ann Hauge, Stephen Hauge, John Hauge, Barbara Hauge, Susan Hauge, Elizabeth Hauge Sword and Caroline Hauge Crenshaw and nine grandchildren. A Celebration of Life will take place at the Colony Club, 564 Park Avenue, at 2:30pm on Friday, May 16. In lieu of flowers, please consider a gift to Channel Thirteen or De La Salle Academy.

MASSIMI--Gabriel, passed away peacefully in Tucson, AZ on the 22nd of April. Gabriel was born in 1927 in Yonkers, New York. He left high school to join the US Navy in World War II, serving aboard the USS Baltimore. After graduating from Syracuse University in 1951, he married fellow graduate Kathryn Mather and began a career in advertising in New York. His career as a copywriter and creative director of advertising agencies took him from New York to London, where he founded the successful Boase Massimi Pollitt advertising agency, and to Milan and Rome, Italy to write for film and TV. In 1975 he moved to Atlanta, Georgia where he became creative director of McDonald & Little then creative director and co-owner of Burton-Campbell. In his long career Gabe won numerous awards for advertising creativity and was honored by the Wall Street Journal as one of the industry's creative leaders. He is survived by his son Michael Massimi and Michael's wife Christine of Tucson, Arizona, his daughter Andrea Burroughs, her husband Steve and her son Andrew of Powder Springs, Georgia, and his sister, Bernice Rohdes of New Jersey. Memorial Mass will be offered Friday May 2, 2014 at 9:30am at St. Francis de Sales Catholic Church, 1375 South Camino Seco in Tucson, Arizona.

EDWARDS--Dr. Lee MacCormick, Passed away on April 19 of ovarian cancer. She died in Edgecliff, Australia, an eastern suburb of Sydney, as she looked out to Point Piper where she was born on October 20, 1937. Lee lived in Locust Valley, NY; in addition to Edgecliff she also had homes in New York City and Vail. Lee was the granddaughter of the renowned Sydney surgeon and international yachtsman, Sir Alexander MacCormick, who after studying medicine under Joseph Lister at Edinburgh University in the 1880s, introduced antiseptic surgery to Australia. Lee's maternal grandfather, the chemist W. Howard Wright, founded Schenectady Varnish Company in 1906; the company grew to become the multinational SI Group, Inc., and Lee served on its Board of Directors up until the time of her death. Lee was an accomplished art historian and consultant and artist with a M.A. (1978), M. Phil. (1981), and Ph.D. (1984) from Columbia University. She lectured and taught widely in the United States, Europe and Australia and specialized in the arts and social history of the nineteenth century. She was on the art history faculty of her alma mater (class of 1976) Sarah Lawrence College from 2000 2008. Her book, "Herkomer: A Victorian Artist," was awarded the Henry-Russell Hitchcock prize by the Victorian Society of America for the best book of the year in 2001. Lee was the President of the International Festival Society (IFS) from 2002 until 2013. The IFS makes grants to promising young American classical musicians on the cusp of their professional careers. She served on the boards of many other charitable organizations including the International Foundation for Art Research, The American Friends of the National Gallery of Australia and The American Australia Foundation. A keen photographer, Lee exhibited her work annually; she considered it as an extension of her interest in the arts of the nineteenth century. Her last show in the United States, "My World," photographs of her native Australia, was held at Heimbold Visual Arts Center at Sarah Lawrence College in November 2012. All proceeds from her final exhibition, "Capturing the Moment" at Maunsell Wickes in Sydney in October 2013, were donated to support ovarian cancer research at the Garvan Institute for Medical Research and the St. Vincent's Curran Foundation in Sydney. She was active in tennis, golf, kayaking, ocean swimming and golf croquet. She was a member of The Century Association, Colony Club, Metropolitan Opera Club, Piping Rock Club, The Creek, Sonnenalp Golf Club, Game Creek Club, Royal Sydney Golf Club as well as the club co-founded by her paternal grandfather, the Royal Prince Edward Yacht Club in Sydney. With her husband, the artist Michael Crane, Lee attended the Salzburg Festival for thirty years. She was awarded the Goldene Kreuz of the State of Salzburg in 2005 for her work as head of the American Friends of the Salzburg Festival. In addition to her husband she is survived by her loving daughter Alison Edwards Curwen, son-in-law Austin Curwen and grandchildren Darcy, Tag and Stapley Curwen. A memorial service in New York will be scheduled for a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations in Lee's honor can be made to the Dr. Lee MacCormick Edwards Charitable Foundation, c/o Tina Albright, Secretary, Curtis Mallet, 101 Park Ave., New York, NY 10178.

HARTENSTEIN--Florence Sherman, on April 21, age 90. Beloved wife of the late Chet. Loving mother of Steve (Jane) and Bob (Deb) and the late Rick. Adoring grandmother of Sarah (Chris) and Leah (Greg). Dear sister and sister-in-law. She was a special and cherished "Aunt Florrie" to so many. Graveside services 1pm, Wednesday, April 23 at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY. In lieu of f1owers, donations should go to the Chester Hartenstein DVM '45 Memorial Lecture Series at Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, Box 39, Ithaca, NY 14853. Kindly make checks payable to Cornell University. For further information www.shermanschapel.com

NALABOFF--Albert, Beloved husband of Irene, devoted father of Susan (Marc), Steven (Ellen), and Gary. Cherished grandfather of Lauren (Justin), Natalie (Conrad), Sean, Brielle, Eliza, and Hannah. Great-grandfather of Aiden. Services Tuesday 11:30am. "Sinai Chapels" 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

GELMAN--Bernard, on April 24, 2014 at 91 years of age. Loving husband of Terry Gelman. Devoted father of Debra Hurley (Mike) and Susan Sussman (Barry). Grandfather to Rachel Maeroff (Mike) and great-grandfather to Fern Maeroff. Financial Analyst of the New York Port Authority. Veteran of WWII. Any donations may be made to the American Heart Association. Funeral will be held on Sunday, April 27, 10am, graveside at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

GUTENSTEIN--Ellen (nee Salomon), on April 26, 2014. Ellen, who always celebrated life, regretfully says goodbye to her many friends and family who supported her in life, during her illness. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Michael and his wife Elaine, Lisa Silvershein and her husband Jeffrey and Howard and his wife Amy. Cherished and adored grandmother of Bess Samuel and her husband Charles, Jenna, Emily and Laura Gutenstein, Sam and Emma Silvershein and Hannah and Ella Gutenstein. Loving sister of Charles S. Salomon and his wife Joan. Dear sister-in-law of Gerry and Diana Gutenstein. Aunt of Michelle Hinz, her husband Timothy and Lauren Gutenstein. Great-aunt of Gabriella and Seamus Hinz. Services Monday, April 28, 12:00 noon at the Barnert Temple, 747 New Jersey Route 208, Franklin Lakes, NJ 07417. For directions and additional information call 212-288-3500. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Valley Hospice and Doula Program, Attn: Kris MacMillian, 15 Essex Road, Suite #

KOLKER--Dr. Joseph, passed away peacefully at home on April 25, 2014. Born in Washington, D.C., 1921 (to Sara and Sam Kolker); married 70 years to Frances (Kressin), whom he had known and loved since kindergarten. Graduated George Washington University and George Washington Medical School (B.A., M.D.). Internship and residency at Mt. Sinai, 1943-1945. Served in the Navy aboard USS Repose (hospital ship) in Tsingtao, China, 1945-1947. Entered psychoanalytic training after the war. Joined staff of Downstate University and Mt. Sinai Hospital, New York. Became liaison psychiatrist under Dr. Henry Dolger to the Diabetic Medical Service for 30 years until 2005. In private practice from 1950 until 2010. On the staff of Bellevue's Psychiatric Clinic until his death. President of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York (PANY) 1985 and 1986. Loved, cherished, and will missed deeply by his wife, Frances, his sister and brothers, his children Susan Finkel, Jeanne Stern, in-laws Derek Stern, Suzan Kolker, eight grandchildren, three great-grandchildren. Predeceased by his son, William Kolker in 2012 and son-in-law Donald Finkel in 1999. In lieu of flowers, please send memorials to Mt. Sinai Department of Psychiatry, George Washington University, or UJA. Services will be held at Sunday, April 27th, 12:45pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th.
McDONALD--George E.,President Emeritus, New York Mailers Union #

BLAKESLEE--David W. of Manhattan, died April 9, 2014. Born 1920 in North Haven, CT. Served in WWII with the 10th Army Air Force. He received a B.S. from Central Connecticut State University, a M.S. from New York University and a Doctorate of Business Administration from Harvard University. David made a career in higher education starting as associate professor at Simmons College in Boston and at Michigan State University. From 1957 to 1962 he lived in Sao Paulo, Brazil where he was technical advisor to the Getulio Vargas Foundation School of Business Administration and product director for Johnson & Johnson of Brazil. Returning to New York City in 1963 he became an associate professor at Rutgers University, made professor in 1974, served as Associate Dean of the business school from 1969 to 1983. In addition to his teaching he served on the boards of a number of prominent business associations. He retired in 1985, traveling the world with his life partner Hans Thrap-Olsen. David was a great patron of the arts and long-time subscriber to the New York Metropolitan Opera. Beloved by family and friends for his style and joie de vivre, he will be missed. Services to be held on May 10, 2:00pm at St. John's Church, 3 Trumbull Place, North Haven, CT.

BARTOS--Rena. Died at 96 on April 22, 2014. Devoted wife of the late Harold Bartos and loving mother of their son James. Named Senior Vice President of J. Walter Thompson Company and director of communication development in 1977, she was recognized as a pioneering qualitative market researcher. Her groundbreaking insights into the changing role of women were widely circulated in her influential books and numerous articles in such publications as the Harvard Business Review where her first, in 1978, titled "What Every Marketer Should Know About Woman" was a finalist in the 1979 National Magazine Award competition. Her profile in Ms. magazine in 1978 featured her views on women as "The Moving Target" and her skills at spotting and describing the profoundly changing social trends of the period. Important books included The Moving Target: What Every Marketer Should Know About Women and The New Demographics. In recognition of these pioneering accomplishments, she served as president of the Advertising Women of New York, was the first woman elected chair of the Advertising Research Foundation Board of Directors and was the first woman invited to be a member of the Copy Research Council. Two years ago, at the age of 94, she was honored with the Lifetime Achievement Great Mind Award of the Advertising Research Foundation.

AHERN--Geary E.,MD, beloved husband of Mary and father of Christopher, died unexpectedly on April 23. Wake: 3-6pm, Sunday, April 27 at Hannemann Funeral Home, 88 South Broadway, Nyack, NY. Funeral: 11am, Monday, April 28 at St. Ann's Catholic Church, 16 Jefferson St., Nyack, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

BOHN--Leon, died peacefully at home in New York City April 16, 2014. Born in 1917, Mr. Bohn graduated from the University of Cincinnati in 1935. He is survived by his wife Elinor Steinhardt Bohn and sister Laura Bohn Supman. A businessman, entrepreneur and inventor of miniaturized simplified office machines, his Bohn Contex adding machine designed in the 1950s is part of the permanent MoMA collection. In 1969 he introduced the Bohn Benton Institor, the first portable cartridge loading motion picture projector that predated the Sony Betamax by six years.

DUNPHY--Richard J.,on April 25, founder of Dick Dunphy Advertising Specialties. Beloved husband of Cecelia and the late Kathleen. Cherished father of Irene Goldberg, Richard, Thomas and Paul Dunphy, David and Wayne Mowry. Survived by 11 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

DWYER--Philip, of New York City and Sneem, Ireland, age 87, on April 23, 2014. Husband of the late Mary (nee Molloy). Survived by his sons and their wives, Pat and Kathy, Jim and Cathy, Phil and Denise, John and Marilyn; his brother Frank; and his grandchildren, Maura, Catherine, Kevin, Brendan, Clare, Joseph, Aidan, Maeve, Liam and Patrick. He regarded "broken" as a temporary condition. For memorials please consider the Michael J. Fox Foundation or Doctors Without Borders. The wake will be in the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Saturday, 7-9pm, and Sunday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass on Monday, 11:30am at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave.

COURTENAY--Elaine K.,86, passed away April, 17th, 2014 in New York City. She was born in Rochester, NY on February 4th, 1928. She was raised in Barrington, Il where she graduated from high school. She attended Knox College in Illinois and Northwestern University before heading to New York City. She worked for General Cable of New York and AT&T. Elaine was an avid patron of the arts and founded Courtenay Artists, Inc., a talent agency, and she placed many famous singers and opera stars. She was preceded in death by her loving husband James Clark Courtenay, Jr., formerly of Louisville, KY, and her parents Mabel Barron and Charles Kerry. She is survived by her sister Linda Truxell of Livonia, MI; brothers Warren Kerry of Daytona Beach, FL, John Kerry of Treasure Island, FL, and several close nieces and nephews, and her beloved Papillon dog, Coquine Posy. The family wishes to express special thanks to her wonderful caregiver and friend, Candice Hutcherson. Services were held yesterday at the Embry-Bosse Funeral Home, 2723 Preston Highway, Louisville, KY followed by burial at Cave Hill Cemetery next to her beloved husband Jim. Memorial gifts may be made to Papillon Haven Rescue, c/o Jan Jordan, P.O. Box 20306, Hot Springs, AR 71903.

CARBERRY--Dr. David Michael. of Pelham, NY died of natural causes at the age of 91 on April 17, 2014. Born in Brooklyn in 1923, he served in Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army and was awarded two Bronze Star Medals for acts of heroism during the Battle of the Bulge. He graduated from Providence College in 1947 and from Jefferson Medical School in 1951, going on to specialize in thoracic surgery. After a general residency at Buffalo General Hospital, Dr. Carberry completed a surgical residency at Roosevelt Hospital and began his practice there in 1961. He held the position of Chief of Thoracic Surgery at Harlem Hospital from 1976-1994. As an Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery, College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, he practiced at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center from 1979-1994. During the Carter Administration, Dr. Carberry received designation as thoracic surgeon-on-call during Presidential visits to New York City. An American College of Surgeons Fellow, he served as in-house physician for Rockefeller Center during his career. He was issued a Police Surgeon's shield by the New York City Police Department and, upon his retirement in 1994, was presented with a Certificate of Meritorious Service in recognition of 25 years of dedication and outstanding service from Police Commissioner William J. Bratton. A dedicated Providence College alumnus, Dr. Carberry proudly held numerous terms as President of the New York Alumni Club. His passing was preceded by his beloved wife, Joan, to whom he was married for 55 years. A devoted father and grandfather, he is survived by his children, Marcella, Jeanne, David Michael Jr. and Maggie, and by his grandchildren David Michael III, Ryan and Reilly.

An agreement will keep filming of the series in the state.

ROBINSON--Frank William, 87, of Westfield, NJ, White Plains, NY and Mt. Kisco, NY passed away peacefully on April 25, 2014. Frank was born October 22, 1926 to James P. and Margaret Carey. He was the fourth of seven children. He graduated from Queens College in 1951 with a BA degree. He served in the US Army, post war Berlin, from 1946 to 1949 with the Allied Control Authority in the 310th Infantry Company "H" and was elevated to an officer in the army as Staff Sergeant receiving notable commendations throughout his journey. While in the Army he developed a reputation as an amateur boxer and was known as "Kid Chocolate." After college, he joined Equifax Services Inc. (formerly Retail Credit Company) in 1951 starting as a Field Representative in their New York office and over the next two decades, he was the District Sales Manager for three increasingly large offices in Buffalo, Baltimore and Newark. In 1991, he retired as a Senior Vice President for National Life & Health/Claims Sales for NYC. Frank was an avid collector of music, especially Frank Sinatra. His love of sports from youth coaching to playing golf and watching football and baseball carried over throughout his life. He is predeceased by his wife, Grace M. Robinson. He is survived by his former wife, Kathryn L. Robinson with whom he had four children: Gerard Robinson, Atlanta, Ga, Jimmy & Karen Robinson, Atlanta, Ga, Kevin & Cindy Robinson, Shelton, Ct and Laura & Tom Travers, Westfield, NJ, his seven grandchildren, Jamie, Jessica, Jim Jr. and Kathryn (Katie) Robinson, Kevin Robinson Jr., and Kelly and Sarah Travers along with five great-grandchildren; Avery, Luke, and Connor Podraza, and Sydney and John (Jack) Brouillard. The family will receive friends at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY on Wednesday, April 30, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be held at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church in Elmsford, NY on Thursday, May 1 at 10am with burial following the service at Gate of Heaven in Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Frank's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, act.alz.org or 1-800-272-3900.

RABINOWITZ--Bert. Sunrise May 18, 1925 - Sunset April 15, 2014. Bert (Bud) Rabinowitz died peacefully at home in Antigua of brain cancer. An entrepreneur and philanthropist, Bud spent 23 years at Colonial Provision Company, which he sold in 1970. He spent the next 15 years successfully fundraising as a volunteer. He served as Campaign Chairman for the Combined Jewish Philanthropies from 1968 to 1971. He was elected as a National Chairman of the United Jewish Appeal in 1970. Bud chaired the JDC/Brookdale Institute for Applied Research that has made positive contributions to the health and welfare of the Jewish population internationally. As a United States Marine, he attended Dartmouth College. He received his MBA with a specialization in meatpacking from the University of Chicago. He was the beloved husband of Constance (Connie) for 66 years. He will also be greatly missed by his children Craig Rabinowitz of California, Gail Grimes and her husband, William, of Lexington, Massachusetts and Sara Birnham and her husband, Rabbi Shmuel, of West Vancouver, Canada, as well as his grandchildren Timothy and his wife, Kate Daly, Cory, and Stuart Grimes and David Birnham.

BERENDT--Lee Lipman. Lee Lipman Berendt would have been 91 years old today had he not left us recently, taking his last breath on March 30, 2014. Born in Sompolno, Poland, the youngest of 10 children, and an orthodox Jew, he was the only member of that family to survive the Holocaust. After enduring years of forced labor and the inhumanities of Auschwitz, Lee was liberated by the Americans in April 1945 at the Dachau concentration camp. He sought refuge in the United States and used his skills as a carpenter par excellence to help him build a full life in Queens, New York. Lee was the loving husband of his late wife, Rose, nee Hubscher, the inspiring father of Deborah (wife of Robert) and Charles, the proud grandfather of Eve (wife of Nicolas) and Simon, and hero of Phoebe Kornfeld, beloved for his indomitable spirit, astonishing intelligence and memory, and awe-inspiring humanity. We will never forget him.

HARTRIDGE--Walter Charlton, died on April 23rd. He was born to Julian and Emma Hopkins Hartridge in Savannah. He attended the University of Virginia, where he was Phi Beta Kappa, in the Raven Society, and lived on the lawn. He became a Captain in the Army, and then attended Harvard Law School. He practiced at Bouhan, Williams, and Levy, where he was a distinguished litigator and maritime lawyer. His roots in the South were deep. He was past President of the Society of the Cincinnati in Georgia, Chairman of Historic Savannah, and Trustee of the Georgia Conservancy. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Cornelia McIntire Hartridge; brother Julian Hartridge; three children: Elizabeth Phillips of Rye, NY; Emma Svoboda of West Point, NY; and Thomas Hartridge of Savannah; and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Independent Presbyterian Church on April 29.

VOUTSINAS--Spiros J.,President, Atlantic Bank, died at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Born June 14, 1933, Kefalonia, Greece, to Eugenia and George Voutsinas, Mr. Voutsinas lived a diverse and productive life. In a career spanning more than five decades, he followed his American dream through the competitive New York City banking world from teller at The Harlem Bank for Savings to President of Atlantic Bank, with various stops along the way. Forced to leave his ancestral home after it was leveled by the 1953 earthquake, Mr. Voutsinas made his way to America where his warmth won him friends, adoration and loyalty from Athens to New York. His pride in hisGreek heritage, children and grandchildren was only exceeded by his loyalty to his career and wife, Aristea. Mr. Voutsinas often returned to his beloved Kefalonia with his daughters, Jean and Christina (Kafes); their husbands Nicholas Kafes and Peter Klose. He leaves his adoring grandchildren, Owen, Celeste, Oliver and Lexington with memories of pristine beaches, joyous family gatherings, and a grandfather who doted on their every whim, desire, complaint and joy. Respected family man, epitome of American life. Reposing at Massapequa Funeral Home, Inc., South Chapel, 4980 Merrick Rd., Massapequa Park (corner of Whitewood Dr.), Monday 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass Wednesday 10am St. Pauls Greek Orthodox Church, Hempstead. Interment Greenfield Cemetery, Uniondale. Visit our website at www.massapequafuneralhome.com for further information. In lieu of flowers, donations are appreciated in memory of Spiros to the Fire Relief Fund at St. Demetrious Greek Orthodox Church, Merrick. http://saintdemetriosrelief.com/campaigns/fire-relief-fund/.

SCOTT--Lael French, died at home in Greenwich Village on April 24. Journalist, lawyer, restless adventurer, beloved mother, wife, grandmother, aunt, friend. Born in Seattle in 1936, she studied at Goucher, the University of Washington, Heidelberg and London before graduating from Columbia in the city she made home. A reporter for Dolly Schiff's liberal New York Post in the '60s, she covered crime, politics (RFK's Senate race), society (Capote's B&W Ball). In '68, a new mother, she joined then-husband Arthur Herzog in helping run the McCarthy campaign. She divorced, wrote for magazines, became a business columnist, studied law at Cardozo - graduating at 46 - and started her own practice. In 2002 she met her second husband and great love, Lloyd Kaye, in a New School class; he died in 2011. She is survived by her son Matthew Herzog, daughter-in-law Linda, grandchildren Alex, Josephine and James, nieces Lenore Madeleine and Lael Alspach, nephews Tom de Kay, Phil Roosevelt, Lennox and John Scott.

RATH--Elisabeth. Elisabeth Rath, who arrived in New York City in 1948 and lived there for nearly sixty years, died after a long illness on Friday, April 18th, 2014, at her home in Reston, Virginia. She was 91 years old. Born Elisabeth Chorin in Budapest Hungary, her father Francis Chorin, was one of the most important political and economic figures in pre-war Hungary. Her mother, Daisy, was the daughter of Manfred Weiss, Hungary's most important industrialist. She was the oldest of three children and lived a life of privilege in Budapest that ended with the German invasion of Hungary. As the result of an extraordinary deal that was brokered by her father, the family was saved and spent the war in Portugal. After they received their American visas, the entire family emigrated to New York where she became active in Hungarian causes. With energy and intellect, she helped to establish the Hungarian House, on the Upper East Side, an institution committed to sustaining the rich cultural life of the Hungarian emigre community. She also played an important role in helping families emigrate from Hungary, particularly after the Hungarian revolution of 1956, coordinating efforts to help them with jobs and resettlement in the United States. As the secretary to her father, she was deeply involved in all aspects of his financial career including investments in New York real estate and providing venture capital for Gulf and Western, before it became a public company. Her first marriage to Steven Rath ended in her husband's death in 1984. She then married Laszlo de Mandy, who was her childhood sweetheart when she was growing up in Hungary. He passed away in 1999. She is survived by her son from her first marriage, Francis Rath of Great Falls, Virginia and her sister Daisy Strasser of Vienna, Austria. A memorial service will be held on May 3 at 12 Noon at the St. Joseph Catholic Church in Herndon, VA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be sent to the "American Hungarian Library" at Hungarian House, 215 East 82 St., New York, NY 10028.

HITCHCOCK--Frederick A.,69, piano technician nonpareil for the New York City Ballet at Lincoln Center and countless admiring New Yorkers for over three decades, passed away April 26, 2014 after a short illness. Survived by sisters Janice McCloskey, Barbara Rinebold, Lila Maughan, colleagues Felipe and David Avendano and friend Richard Moredock.

BARASCH--Frances K.,April 25, 2014. Professor Emerita, Baruch College. A childhood of poverty, family problems and despair was overcome by brains, hard work and fearlessness. Scholar, union activist and fighter for due process. Beloved wife for 61 years of Seymour, mother of Jerry (whom we lost in 2006), Elihu (Cathy), Daniel (Gail). Grandmother of Jeremy (Karen), Erin, Noah, Adrienne, and Gregory. Great-grandma of Mayo. Sister of Dr. Irving Karten. Burial private. Please make donations in lieu of flowers, to the Perlmutter Cancer Center- (212) 404-3638.

BARTOS--Rena. Died at 96 on April 22, 2014. Devoted wife of the late Harold Bartos and loving mother of their son James. Named Senior Vice President of J. Walter Thompson Company and director of communication development in 1977, she was recognized as a pioneering qualitative market researcher. Her groundbreaking insights into the changing role of women were widely circulated in her influential books and numerous articles in such publications as the Harvard Business Review where her first, in 1978, titled "What Every Marketer Should Know About Woman" was a finalist in the 1979 National Magazine Award competition. Her profile in Ms. magazine in 1978 featured her views on women as "The Moving Target" and her skills at spotting and describing the profoundly changing social trends of the period. Important books included The Moving Target: What Every Marketer Should Know About Women and The New Demographics. In recognition of these pioneering accomplishments, she served as president of the Advertising Women of New York, was the first woman elected chair of the Advertising Research Foundation Board of Directors and was the first woman invited to be a member of the Copy Research Council. Two years ago, at the age of 94, she was honored with the Lifetime Achievement Great Mind Award of the Advertising Research Foundation.

BRISCOE--Anne, founding member and former president of AWIS died April 16. Equal salary and tenure for women was her cause. She was on the faculty of Columbia, an advisor to INPO, vice chairman of the New Y ork Committee on the Status of Women. She received the Yale and Wilbur Cross medals. Graveside services will be held on Friday, May 2nd at 11am at Old Rock Landing Cemetery, 326 Rock Landing Rd., E. FEUERSTADT--Rita, of Lake Worth, FL, passed away at the age of 91 on Tuesday, April 22, 2014. Rita was born in 1923 and grew up in Brooklyn. She had a great sense of humor and a huge heart that embraced her family and many beyond. She loved to bake and was renowned for her Peanut Butter Balls, much to everyone's delight. Rita was predeceased by her loving husband Oscar and her adored son Bruce. She is survived by her beloved daughter, Ivy and her husband Barry, her cherished grandchildren, Becky and her husband James, Gabriel and his wife Rebecca, and Samantha, and her dear great grandson, affectionately referred to by Rita as Mr. Miles. Funeral services were held Friday, April 25, 2014 at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to Johns Hopkins Project Restore, 550 North Broadway, Suite 731, Baltimore, MD 21205, or to a charity of your choice.

Salomon and his wife Joan. Dear sister-in-law of Gerry and Diana Gutenstein. Aunt of Michelle Hinz, her husband Timothy and Lauren Gutenstein. Great-aunt of Gabriella and Seamus Hinz. Services Monday, April 28, 12:00 noon at the Barnert Temple, 747 New Jersey Route 208, Franklin Lakes, NJ 07417. For directions and additional information call 212-288-3500. GOLDMAN--Paul, on April 26, age 85. His family always came first. TODD--Suzanne Williams, 97, passed away peacefully in New York City on April 26, 2014. Beloved wife of David F.M. Todd from 1942 until his death in 2008, and beloved mother of Gregory F.W. Todd, who survives her. Born in Richmond, IN of Quaker roots, she attended Westtown School and Bryn Mawr College, where she majored in Archeology. She and her husband moved to New York from Allied-occupied Korea following WWII. She was a case worker, then director, of the Girls Service League, obtained an MSW from Columbia in 1959, and then worked on research in the fields of child development and juvenile justice. From a first visit in 1988 to a final visit in 2008, she and her husband spent part of each year in Venasque, France, a small village which they grew to love as a second home. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. As a professional, a mother, a neighbor, and a friend, she will be deeply missed by all.

VOUTSINAS--Spiros. The Board of Directors, The Greek Division, Volunteers and Staff of Ronald McDonald House New York wish to express our sincere sympathy on the passing of Spiros J. Voutsinas, dedicated volunteer and benefactor of the Greek Division. We send our sympathy to the entire Voutsinas family on their significant loss. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman of the Board, and Michael Bapis, Chairman- Greek Division, and William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer, Ronald McDonald House New York

DeFelice, President

YAVARKOVSKY--Ira. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of Ira Yavarkovsky, formerly an active member and most recently an Honorary Member of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work Board of Overseers. A long time YU Benefactor together with his late beloved mother, Rose Yavarkovsky, of blessed memory, he was a Founder of the Sy Syms School of Business and they established in their names scholarships for deserving and needy students in all YU's undergraduate schools as well as in the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, Fellows of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work, the Yeshiva University High Schools, and supported the Yeshiva University Women's Organization. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his siblings, Rhoda (and Richard) Spiegel and Jerome Yavarkovsky. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus

HOLMYARD--Harold Roy Jr.,age 92, died in Greenwich, Connecticut on April 27, 2014. He was born in Cincinnati, Ohio on April 15, 1922 to Ellen Webb and Harold Roy Holmyard. He attended The Wyoming School in Wyoming, Ohio and graduated from Williams College with the Class of 1944 after serving as a commissioned Naval aviator during World War II. He began his career at Champion Spark Plugs and later worked at Libby Owens Corning before entering the world of investment management. He was a broker and investment advisor with Hayden Stone, Newhart and Cook, and, most recently, Gabelli Asset Management Company. He was a member of The Weeburn Country Club of Darien, Connecticut, The Field Club and The Belle Haven Club of Greenwich, and The River Club of New York City. He served as a Board member of the Coalition for a Secure Drivers License. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Alexandra Todd Holmyard; two children: Harold Roy Holmyard III of Dallas, Texas and Page Ellen Ferrell of West Palm Beach, Florida; and two step-daughters: Alexandra Tanner of Old Greenwich, Connecticut and Fredericka Tanner of Sudbury, Massachusetts; five grandchildren: William B. Ferrell III of Bradenton, Florida, Graham S. Anderson of West Palm Beach, Florida, Jacob F. Levinson of London, England, Matthew A. Levinson of Minneapolis, Minnesota and Alec B. Russell of Boston, Massachusetts; and a great-grandson William B. Ferrell IV of Bradenton, Florida. He was pre-deceased by his younger brother Mark A. Fuller of Ashville, North Carolina and his grandson Robert B. Ferrell of West Palm Beach, Florida. A celebration of his life will be held at a future date to be determined.

FIELDS--Harry. Died on Monday April 28, 2014 at the age of 90. Born in Cologne, Germany, his family fled the rise of the Nazis for the Netherlands. They remained there until the war when they were taken and interned at Bergen Belsen concentration camp. Harry Fields, his father Isaac, mother Gisela, and brother, Alfred, miraculously survived the horrors of the camps as well as the notorious "Lost Transport" that followed their liberation. After earning a chemical engineering degree from the University of Amsterdam, he came to New York City in 1947 to work as a bottle washer for a small firm that later became the Fortune 500 company International Flavors and Fragrances. He worked at IFF for 44 years, and rose to serve as EVP of IFF Inc. and President of Flavors. In a life marked by equal measures of enormous strife and tremendous luck, his greatest good fortune was to have been married to Barbara Fields for 64 years. They raised two beloved children, Pamela and Michael, and he was equally devoted to his son-in-law Andrew, daughter-in-law Jessamyn, and grandchildren Daniel, Emma, and Willa. An accomplished linguist, he traveled to remote corners of the world and relished many adventures including Amazonian explorations, a submarine voyage to the Antarctic, and treks through the Borneo rainforest. He loved good bread and cheese, the sound of the violin and reading fine writing. An author late in life, his books include the wartime memoir "Turbulent Times." Harry Fields was knighted in 1996 by Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands as an Officer in the Orde van Granje Nassau.

HIGIER--Ross Harold. Of Gloversville, NY and Boca Raton, FL passed away on April 27th of complications from pneumonia. He was born on July 9, 1923 in New York City but moved to Gloversville when he was nine years old. The only child of Jules and Edna Higier, Ross attended and graduated from Worchester Academy, Dartmouth College and Tuck Business School. After graduating with honors, Ross enlisted in the Navy. He was sent to Harvard Business School and then deployed to the South Pacific on a destroyer escort where he rose to the rank of Lieutenant Commander. After the War, Ross returned to Gloversville and began his long and distinguished career at Crescendoe and Superb Glove Companies. He eventually became President employing over 3,000 workers in factories throughout the world. He was extremely active in community affairs. He was elected to head the United Way Board and the UJA drive, President of the Jewish Community Center, on the Board of the City National Bank and Trust Company, and the Knesseth Israel Synagogue. He was also appointed as a New York State GOP Committee member and attended the inauguration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower. He was also an officer and board member of the Pinebrook County Club and a board member of the Gloversville Chamber of Commerce. He was married to the absolute love of his life, the former Dorene Schine for 64 years and they had three wonderful children; Donna, Thomas (and wife Kathy) and Louis. He was fortunate in life to have had seven grandchildren whom he had very special relationships with. Ross died peacefully in his Boca Raton home with his wife by his side. He was 90 years young. Service will be held at the Knesseth Israel Synagogue on Thursday, May 1st at 11am with Rabbi Rose Durbin officiating. Funeral services have been entrusted to Walrath & Stewart Funeral Home, 51 Fremont Street, Gloversville, NY. Please visit the family online guestbook at www.brbsfuneral.com.

GOLDMAN--Paul, on April 26, age 85. His family always came first. Remarkably devoted husband to his late wife Edith, children Ingrid Kahn (Lou) and Joette Mindlin (Mitch); grandchildren Tammy Fennell (Matthew), Amy (Dennis), Cara Weiss (Greg), Marielle Bernstein (Matt) and great-grandchildren Ella and James. His love, generosity and wisdom enriched the lives of colleagues at Bakertowne, which he founded, and legions of friends from business, government, Kips Bay and the Coney Island boardwalk. The funeral will be held at Plaza, Amsterdam and 91 St. Contributions may be made to Visiting Nurse Service.
