TODD--Suzanne Williams, 97, passed away peacefully in New York City on April 26, 2014. Beloved wife of David F.M. Todd from 1942 until his death in 2008, and beloved mother of Gregory F.W. Todd, who survives her. Born in Richmond, IN of Quaker roots, she attended Westtown School and Bryn Mawr College, where she majored in Archeology. She and her husband moved to New York from Allied-occupied Korea following WWII. She was a case worker, then director, of the Girls Service League, obtained an MSW from Columbia in 1959, and then worked on research in the fields of child development and juvenile justice. From a first visit in 1988 to a final visit in 2008, she and her husband spent part of each year in Venasque, France, a small village which they grew to love as a second home. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. As a professional, a mother, a neighbor, and a friend, she will be deeply missed by all.

McMURRAY--Barbre L.,84, died peacefully in her home in Roswell, GA on April 26, 2014. She was born in Brooklyn, NY on July 26, 1929 to Donald F. McMurray and Alice D. (Grady) McMurray, both also from Brooklyn. Barbre attended Baldwin High School in Baldwin, NY. She then earned her BS in Nursing from Northern Essex Community College in Haverhill, MA. Barbre was married to Harold C. Schneider of Baldwin, NY and had seven children together. While still raising her children and working full time, Barbre returned to college in the evenings to earn her Nursing degree. She was employed for a number of years as a geriatric nurse at Rockingham County Rehabilitation and Nursing center in Brentwood, NH. She spent time as a psychiatric nurse at Hampstead Hospital in Hampstead, NH and eventually retired from Portsmouth Hospital in Portsmouth, NH. In her early retirement, Barbre was actively involved in the lives of her grandchildren. Later, at her home at St. George Village in Roswell, GA, Barbre was an active organizer and participant in her community prayer group. She was a constant and compassionate advocate for those in her community who could not speak for themselves. She was also an avid gardener, accomplished seamstress, cat fancier, dog lover and prolific reader. Barbre is survived by her seven children; Rev. Thomas D. McMurray, S.J. (Jesuit priest) of Portland, ME; Michael Ann Grady of Sunapee, NH; Harold C. (Katherine) Schneider Jr. of Cumming, GA; Daniel P. (Julie Belmer Spencer) Schneider of Groveland, MA; Kathleen M. (Ed Lennon) Phillips of Seekonk, MA; Timothy P. (Maritza) Schneider of Raymond, NH; Megan J. (John) Gorman of Flanders, NJ; and her sister Jean Ann McMurray of Summerfield, FL. She is also survived by nine grandchildren; Joshua and Matthew Phillips; Daniel Jr and Connor Schneider; Brandon and Naomi Schneider; Ryan, Brandon and Michael Flaherty; and is predeceased by her beloved granddaughter, Erin Elizabeth Schneider. Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 11:00am on Friday, May 2, 2014 at St. Brigid Church in Westbury, NY, with Thomas McMurray of the Society of Jesus, officiating. Graveside service will follow at Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury, NY. SAVRAN--Bernice, of the Bronx passed away April 28, 2014. She is survived by two children and six grandchildren. Bernice worked at Wor- king Woman/Working Mother Magazines in the Advertising Department for many years. Funeral services under the care of the Garlick Funeral Homes in New Rochelle are private. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Heart Association.

KNOWLTON--Claire Martwick April 28, 1924, died April 11, 2014. Beloved wife of Robert Knowlton and mother of four sons. Lifelong advocate for environmental, conservation and educational causes. Private service held Peru VT

LEONE--Dr. Armand F.,90, of Franklin Lakes passed away on April 28, 2014. Beloved husband of the late Dr. Rita Girolamo-Leone (2007). Born in Paterson he lived in Glen Rock before moving to Franklin Lakes in 1963. He served his country honorable in World War II and as a Captain in the United States Army in the Korean War. He graduated St. Peter's University and New York Medical College. He trained at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital and was a Radiologist at Paterson General and Wayne General Hospital until his retirement in 2004. A Fellow of the American College of Radiology, American College of Nuclear Medicine, American College of Breast Cancer and American College of Ultrasonography. Armand was a parishioner of St. Gerard's Roman Catholic Church in Paterson. Beloved father of Mark, Peter and Armand, devoted father-in-law of Jane, Marcella and Alison, loving grandfather of Christina, Peter, Michael, Matthew, Mark, David and James, dear brother of Alberino Leone and unwavering friend to all. He gave without limitation to everyone he met in his life. The family will receive family and friends on Thursday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Vander Plaat-Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes. Funeral Services Friday 10:30am at the funeral home followed by an 11:00am Mass of Christian Burial at St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Hawthorne. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Totowa. For further information please visit www.vpmemorial.com or call (201) 891-4770.

FOOTE--Richard Stuart, 50, of New York, NY. Beloved husband of Suzanne Girard, devoted father of Thomas, James and Darcy, and brother of Sally H. Foote. Richard was a managing director at Berkshire Capital Securities, LLC for 20 years, and the CEO of HF2 Financial Management, Inc. He was a graduate of Harvard University, 1985. Richard lived life to the fullest, and was a loving and dedicated son, brother, uncle, father and husband. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 1, at 10am at Christ & Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church, 122 West 69th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Foote Family Fund at Saint David's School and The Nightingale-Bamford School, New York, NY.

OSSER--Abe. The Officers and Members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of dear friend and fellow member, Mr. Abe Osser. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his entire family. Ben Kirschenbaum, President

SCHWARTZ--Frederic, a world-renowned architect who pursued his trade with an unbridled passion, purpose and conviction, died April 28 at age 63. He is survived by his wife Tracey Hummer, mother Charlotte, sister Barbara Schwartz Glicksman and her husband Steven, nieces Meryl and Rachel Glicksman, and uncle Marvin Doblin. Thursday burial private. A service celebrating his life and work will be announced shortly. To honor his memory, contributions may be made in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering and UC Berkeley's College of Environmental Design.

KERNER--Oliver JB, a renowned Chicago psychologist, died peacefully at his home on April 16 at the age of 96. His life was guided by two abiding passions: his loving devotion to his wife, Jane, of 56 years with whom the honeymoon never ended; and his consuming dedication to the teaching and training of psychoanalytic therapy for clinical psychologists. At the city, state, and national level, no single person did more to advance the cause of professional psychologists in achieving legal parity with psychiatrists, eligibility for insurance reimbursement, access to psychoanalytic training, and professional legitimacy in the eyes of the American public. In so doing, he was instrumental in widening the availability of psychotherapeutic services for everyone. Generous, witty, and wise, he leaves behind an indelible legacy of leadership and service to the profession in which he remained active to the very end.

GOLDBERG--Lisa Ellen. When you were born on this day the world received a gift which all who knew you, most of all us, came to treasure as a unique blessing. John, Katie, Jed.

KONCIUS--David .The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Naomi and the entire family. Frederic Krieger, President

ROSENTHAL--Nan, age 76, died peacefully at home on Sunday, April 27, 2014. Beloved wife of Henry B. Cortesi, she was born in New York City on August 27, 1937. She graduated from the Fieldston School, Sarah Lawrence College and earned a PhD from Harvard. She began her career in journalism but turned to the study of art history focusing on post-WWII American artists. She excelled as a scholar, curator, teacher, and mentor. Nan was Senior Consultant of 20th Century Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art until her retirement in 2008. Before moving back to New York after her marriage to Henry in 1991, she was curator of 20th Century Art at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and before that, a professor at the University of California at Santa Cruz. Over her long, varied and highly distinguished career, she accumulated a very large, diverse and devoted group of friends who enlivened and enriched her life as she did theirs. We are all deeply grieved and diminished by her death. A memorial for Nan will be held in September. In lieu of flowers, the family request that contributions be made in Nan's memory to the Financial Aid Fund of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, 33 Central Park W. NY, NY 10023.

GREIF--Norman L.,who spent a long and varied career in the cosmetics industry, died in Ossining, N.Y., on April 28 at 83 due to complications from Alzheimer's. He was a long-time resident of Manhattan. Norman was born in 1930 on the Lower East Side to Martin and Anna Greif. Growing up in Brighton Beach, he attended Lincoln High School where he met his future wife, Annette Moskowitz. Earning his bachelor's of science in chemistry at City College, his first job was at Colgate-Palmolive. Starting as a lab technician at Revlon, he was eventually promoted to vice president and director of research. Later he ventured out on his own, creating private label perfumes and cosmetics. The ocean was an integral part of the family's life, from Norman's early years selling hotdogs under the Brighton Beach boardwalk to their happiest times entertaining friends and family at their home in Sagaponack, Long Island. A loyal, quiet and hardworking man, Norman was gifted in his professional life and humble in his personal life. He is survived by his three daughters, Paula Greif, Elaine Wine and Andrea Greif, and two grandchildren, Alexander Fitz-Gibbon and Anna Zanes. He was predeceased by his wife, Annette, who died in 2008.

DUKE--Anthony. Anthony "Tony" Drexel Duke (1918-2014). It is with a heavy heart that we say goodbye to our beloved founder, Anthony "Tony" Drexel Duke, founder and president of Boys & Girls Harbor. Tony died on April 30, 2014 after a long battle with cancer. He was 95. The entire Harbor community, while grieving Tony's death, will observe his passing by celebrating his extraordinary legacy. Tony spent a lifetime educating children, growing Boys & Girls Harbor, the education and performing arts nonprofit he founded in 1937, from a small summer camp for 12 inner-city boys to an arts and education organization that serves 1,000 students and their families from Harlem and surrounding communities. To date, more than 50,000 young people have attended the Harbor. Tony's compassion and generous gifts were widely known among New York's charitable circles, but he was far more than just a patron. From the Harbor's early days until a few years before his death, Tony was a fixture at the organization, developing personal relationships with Harbor staff, students, and alumni. He made sure that the Harbor served as a real home and learning environment for students. The Harbor deeply mourns the loss of Tony, a true living legend.
DUFFY--John L. "Jack" MD, Born: January 26, 1927 Huntington, Long Island. Died: April 29, 2014 Middlebury, VT

GARSON--Dr. Howard S.,86, died suddenly Tuesday, April 29, 2014. Beloved husband of Bettijane Sills Garson, devoted father of James Garson and step-daughter Frances Garson Trocki, grandfather to David, Peter, James, Susan and Henry, and great-grandchildren Nora and Ellen. After serving in the United States Navy from 1945-1947, Dr. Garson went to NYU on the G-I Bill, attended medical school in Bern and Zurich, Switzerland and opened a private practice in Pediatrics in Bronxville, NY in 1960. He served as Director of Pediatrics and was President of the Medical Staff at Law- rence Hospital. After retiring from medicine Howard enjoyed life and lived it to the fullest playing tennis and golf and attending dance performances whenever he could. His kindness and humanity as a physician and human being will long be remembered. He was a true gentleman and will be deeply missed by all. A funeral service will be held on Friday, May 2, 2014 at 10am at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery.

DEL CASTILLO JARDINES--Luis, died Monday, April 28, 2014 at his home in New York City. He is survived by spouse Lourdes; children Miguel, Miguelina, Jose (Jessica), Liz (Randy); siblings Luz, Nena, Julieta, Margot, Lina, Horacio, Else; grandchildren Vic, Julio, Patty, Michelle, Julissa, Melissa, Marilu, Raquel, Erik, Mikey, Jagger. Family to receive friends and relatives atFrank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, NY on Thursday, May 1, 2014, 4pm-8pm. Funeral Mass: Friday, May 2, 10am, Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 E. 62nd St., New York.

DANWITZ--Sister Winifred, Ursuline died peacefully at Andrus on Hudson on Tuesday, April 29, 2014 at 93. Her notable achievement was founding in 1961 the Mount St. Ursula Speech Center, for children with speech and hearing disabilities. Sr. Winifred earned a MA from Brooklyn College and her Ph.D. from CUNY. She entered the Ursulines in 1945 and taught at the College of New Rochelle, the Academy of Mt. St. Ursula, Fordham University, Hunter College, and Iona College. She was a director of speech therapy, Archdiocese of NY, and professor of special education at CNR. In 1997 she founded Angela House, a transitional residence and place for homeless women and their children. Winifred served on several boards and received numerous awards for her teaching and service. She was predeceased by her parents, Eric and Winifred (O'Shea) Danwitz, and her sister Lillian; she is survived by several nieces and nephews. Wake will be held at the Ursuline Provincialate, 1338 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY, on Friday, May 2, 3-5pm and 6-8pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be there at 10am on Saturday, May 3. Interment, Holy Sepulchre Cemetery. Gifts may be sent to the Ursuline Retirement Fund, 1338 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10804. www.lloydmaxcy.com

GUTSTEIN--Lester, The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed member. We extended deepest sympathy to his wife Jan, to his son Ryan and to the entire family. Aubrey L. Glazer, Rabbi Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Israel Singer, Cantor Abby Mendelsohn, Martin Rogowsky, Co-Pres.

AMERMAN--Patricia. April 30, 2014, New York, NY. Patricia Amerman, beloved friend and colleague. Together with her friends and family, Rubenstein mourns the loss of Pat Amerman, a dedicated and beloved employee of the agency for 17 years. Pat was a warm, joyful, and positive person who always had a smile on her face. A skilled publicist, she won the respect and friendship of clients, colleagues and reporters alike. Whether she was overseeing publicity for clients at the New Year's Eve celebrations in Times Square, garnering wide coverage for Marble Collegiate Church in response to its "yellow ribbon" campaign honoring U.S. troops in Iraq, or helping to publicize the fundraising campaign for the renovation of St. Patrick's Cathedral, Pat was a master public relations strategist the utmost professional who gave her all to making every project a success. Even through her long battle with cancer, Pat insisted on working. She truly loved what she did. Pat had a wonderful network of friends and family that meant the world to her. She was dedicated to her parents and extremely proud of both her Irish and Greek heritages. Pat also was involved with community affairs in her Queens, NY neighborhood. The wake will be on Sunday, May 4, from 3:00 to 8:00pm at O'Shea-Hoey Funeral Home in Astoria. Pat relished life and made the most of her time. We will greatly miss our dear colleague and friend. Howard J. Rubenstein, Founder Steven Rubenstein, President

HAUGE--Helen Resor. The Board of Directors and staff of Henry Street Settlement mourn the loss of Honorary Board Member Helen R. Hauge, who served as a long standing supporter and tireless advocate of our social service programs. We extend our deepest condolences to her family.
HAUCK--Walter Frederick, born October 30, 1928, died April 8, 2014, of Queens, NY. Memorial service on May 4, 2014 from 2-4pm, Holiday Inn-Manhattan View, Long Island City, NY.

KEIDAN--Juliet. Harvard Hillel notes with sadness the passing of Juliet Keidan, mother of our dear friend David Keidan. Our hearts are uplifted hearing of her long and fruitful life. We wish David and his family comfort and consolation in Juliet's memory, amid all mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

MELNICK--Gisele. 10/27/1935 - 05/02/2006. The world is diminished without her.
PRAH--Joseph David, D.D.S. 2/27/1931 4/29/2004 Greatly loved and always in our thoughts.
BURKE--Matthew B. May 2, 1969-February 26, 2002. He lives on in our thoughts and dreams. Linda and John, Chris and Lou, Alison and Ryan

KRAFT--Leo, died on Wednesday at 92. Prolific composer and Professor Emeritus at Queens College, creative to the end. Survived by companion Drora Pershing Maynard, brother Arthur, sons David and Evan and grandson Sasha Benderly-Kraft.

SWANSON--David Warren, Jr.,Hendersonville, NC, died April 28, 2014 of cancer at Duke Medical Center. He was 65 years old and the loving husband of Deborah Barry. David was born in Brooklyn Heights, NY and lived most of his life in the New York area. He graduated from Blair Academy Blairstown, NJ, and Hobart College, Geneva, NY then earned a Masters in Journalism from Ohio University in Athens and an MBA from Columbia University in New York. David spent his whole life in publishing, retiring as VP of the International edition and Publisher of the Latin America edition of Newsweek. Dave was an avid sports fan rooting enthusiastically for the Mets, Yankees, Rangers and Giants. David is survived by his wife, Deborah Barry, and by his daughter, Rebecca Urban of Lancaster, MA and his four grandchildren, Leo, Julius, Joan, and Adrian. He is also survived by his sisters, Judy Redway of Marion, MA and Janet Stewart of Jamaica Plains, MA. Interment will be at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn, NY.

SHORE--Robert, 90. Painter, illustrator, sculptor. Educated at Cranbrook Academy of Art, Boro Polytecnic London, and Art Students League. Staff artist for Stars and Stripes during WWII; paintings commissioned by NASA include the Mercury Atlas rocket liftoff; recognized for illustrating works of Conrad, Melville, and Verne for Limited Editions Club; awarded Society of Illustrators Gold Medal 1966. Fulbright fellow in painting; permanent collections of Smithsonian and NASA. Beloved husband of Marietta, father of Evan and Gigi, cherished teacher for generations of New York City art students.

SCHWARTZ--Frederic, a world-renowned architect who pursued his trade with an unbridled passion, purpose and conviction, died April 28 at age 63. He is survived by his wife Tracey Hummer, mother Charlotte, sister Barbara Schwartz Glicksman and her husband Steven, nieces Meryl and Rachel Glicksman, and uncle Marvin Doblin. Thursday burial private. A service celebrating his life and work will be announced shortly. To honor his memory, contributions may be made in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering and UC Berkeley's College of Environmental Design.

DUKE--Anthony Drexel. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee are deeply saddened by the loss of our colleague Tony Duke. A distinguished naval officer who became a highly accomplished civic leader, executive and advocate for the education of underserved children and young people, Tony was also a champion of refugees and uprooted people. He played a key role on our board and executive committee from 1974 to 1996 and was notably active in our response to crises involving Vietnamese and Cuban refugees. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board Glenda Burkhart and Scott Pelley, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers David Miliband, President

ROCHE--John Geoffrey. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan on Sunday at age 75. He was a former partner at Whitcom Investments, Director of World Film Services, and owner of Telecommunications Inc. He attended Georgetown, Oxford, and Harvard Business School. John devoted his later years to his life-long love of film, forming Petunia Productions and serving on the boards of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the TriBeCa Film Institute, and the Phoenix Theater. He is survived by his wife, two brothers, two children, and a fierce enthusiasm for life that will live in the hearts of all who knew him well and loved him. "And say my glory was I had such friends". A memorial is planned for the evening of May 27th at the Century Club.

SHULMAN--Sidney. Sidney Shulman, Ph.D.,90, 1923 - 2014. Distinguished Bio-chemistry school professor: New York Medical College/University of Buffalo - Extensive research/publications in the field of immunology and human infertility, followed by a lab practice. He is survived by his beloved wife, Irma, and children, Katharine, Michael, Stephen, Andrew, Rebecca and Elizabeth - grandchildren, Noah, David, and Jemsea. Dr. Shulman was a devotee of opera and classical music, a polyglot and an avid reader. Apart from his piercing intellect, he was known for his wit, charm, entertaining personality and as a dear Friend to many. He will be missed! Services Sunday, May 4, 2014 at 12:00 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (Amsterdam Ave. and the corner of West 91st St.).

GREIF--Norman L.,who spent a long and varied career in the cosmetics industry, died in Ossining, N.Y., on April 28 at 83 due to complications from Alzheimer's. He was a long-time resident of Manhattan. Norman was born in 1930 on the Lower East Side to Martin and Anna Greif. Growing up in Brighton Beach, he attended Lincoln High School where he met his future wife, Annette Moskowitz. Earning his bachelor's of science in chemistry at City College, his first job was at Colgate-Palmolive. Starting as a lab technician at Revlon, he was eventually promoted to vice president and director of research. Later he ventured out on his own, creating private label perfumes and cosmetics. The ocean was an integral part of the family's life, from Norman's early years selling hotdogs under the Brighton Beach boardwalk to their happiest times entertaining friends and family at their home in Sagaponack, Long Island. A loyal, quiet and hardworking man, Norman was gifted in his professional life and humble in his personal life. He is survived by his three daughters, Paula Greif, Elaine Wine and Andrea Greif, and two grandchildren, Alexander Fitz-Gibbon and Anna Zanes. He was predeceased by his wife, Annette, who died in 2008.

NEUHAUS--Alexander. Park East Synagogue is in shock and mourns the death of Alexander Neuhaus, beloved child of our devoted members Leonard and Beth Neuhaus. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

WINTERS--Bernard J. Age 90. Lovingly remembered by daughter Heather and son-in-law Cary Holcomb, son Mead and grandchildren Taylor and Ben Holcomb. Predeceased by his wife Sylvia. Bernie was born in Brooklyn, a veteran of WWII, received his BS and MA from NYU and was the owner of Sportcrafts in Bronxville, NY for over thirty years. He was a lover of travel, the arts, french cuisine, a superb tennis player and dedicated golfer. A passionate liberal democrat and supporter of the causes he believed in. Father, grandfather and friend--he was deeply loved and will be sorely missed.

GRANT--Roseanne (nee Zerner), April 30, 2014 of Wynnewood, PA; wife of the late Dr. B. David Grant; mother of Julia Barol (David), Betsy Kaperonis (George) and Kate Webster (Peter); grandmother of Jared, Morgan, Galen, Lilly, Callie and Zoe. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services Sunday 2pm at Adath Israel, 250 N. Highland Ave., Merion Station, PA 19066. Interment at Haym Salomon Memorial Park. Shiva will be observed at the late residence. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Bach Choir of Bethlehem (610-866-4382, ext. 13 or cheryl@bach.org) Services handled by Joseph Levine & Sons. www.levinefuneral.com.

HILL--Margaret G. (Peggy)- January 3, 1925 - March 9, 2014, left us to be in heaven with her beloved husband, Bob, her parents Luke and Margaret, her sister Patricia and her brother Bill. Including many cousins, Peggy is survived by 10 nieces and nephews. A longtime Manhattan resident, Peggy was the first woman to be promoted to VP in NY Bell Telephone. She spent the latter part of her career successfully negotiating labor agreements with the labor unions. Peggy and Bob traveled the world extensively during their vacations, and always sent postcards from exotic locales. They moved to Rochester, MN so that Bob could get the benefit of Mayo Clinic medical care. After Bob left us in 1998, Peggy stayed in Rochester for the remainder of her years, active in Catholic based services. Despite her many accomplishments, Peggy remained modest. Peggy's love of family was a constant. A Funeral Mass was celebrated at St. John The Evangelist Church in Rochester, MN, at 9:00am, Saturday, April 26, 2014. On Friday, April 25 2014, from 4:00pm to 7:00pm with a prayer service at 4:30pm, family members received friends at River Park Chapel, Macken Funeral Home, 1105 12th St SE, Rochester, MN 55904. Online condolences are welcome at mackenfuneralhome.com

LEVKOFF--Janet J.,on April 30, 2014 at age 100. Founded Bill Levkoff, Inc. with her late husband, Harold (Bill) Levkoff in 1946. She was one of the few woman owner/executives in the male dominated apparel world. Later on she opened retail store, What's What in White Plains, NY. Known for her incredible wit and generosity, she will be deeply missed. Mother of the late Robert Levkoff. Survived by her children Jon and Arlene Levkoff, James and Cheryl Levkoff, William and Barbara Levkoff; her grandchildren, Brett and Jennifer Levkoff and Jodi and Andrew Buchbinder; her great-grandchildren Amanda, Dylan and Ryan Levkoff and Samantha, Justin and Evan Buchbinder.
GLUCKSON--Herbert J.R.,10 years missed, loved, quoted. Dorothy, Sally, Jimmy and Barbara

BERNSTEIN--Irving. We mourn the passing of our dear friend and respected client of many years. Irving, the father-in-law of our senior partner, Myron Bloom, and father of Barbara Bloom, was a successful businessman and a leader in the Jewish community. He will be remembered for his astute approach to problem-solving and his unwavering friendship. We offer our deepest condolences to his wife, Phyllis, his children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The Partners and staff of Bloom Hochberg & Co.

KERNER--Oliver JB, a renowned Chicago psychologist, died peacefully at his home on April 16 at the age of 96. His life was guided by two abiding passions: his loving devotion to his wife, Jane, of 56 years with whom the honeymoon never ended; and his consuming dedication to the teaching and training of psychoanalytic therapy for clinical psychologists. At the city, state, and national level, no single person did more to advance the cause of professional psychologists in achieving legal parity with psychiatrists, eligibility for insurance reimbursement, access to psychoanalytic training, and professional legitimacy in the eyes of the American public. In so doing, he was instrumental in widening the availability of psychotherapeutic services for everyone. Generous, witty, and wise, he leaves behind an indelible legacy of leadership and service to the profession in which he remained active to the very end.

WHITE--Richard. Richard (Dick) Booth White, 83, of New Canaan, CT died on Sunday, April 27, 2014. A graduate of Phillips Academy and Yale University, Dick served as an infantry and intelligence officer in the US Marine Corps before joining the advertising firm of BBDO in 1955. During his years at BBDO he served as Executive Vice President, Board Member and Chairman of the Executive Committee. After retiring in 1984, he joined Spencer Stuart, where he became a Senior Director/Partner in 1989. Dick retired from Spencer Stuart in 1998. Throughout his life, Dick was involved with numerous civic activities, serving as a member of the New Canaan Town Council, as well as the Board of Directors of the Stamford Symphony Orchestra. He also served as President of the Executive Board of Waveny Care Center, was on the board of the Madison Square Boys and Girls Club of New York City, was a member of the Session of the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, was a Chairman of the Board of Vitam Center in Norwalk, a Trustee of the New Canaan Country School and a Board Member of the New Canaan Inn. For forty six years, Dick lived in New Canaan with his wife of fifty two years, Mary Kane White. Together they raised their three daughters, Katherine White Marsland, Anne White Collard and Leslie White Siek and their deceased son Richard Booth White Jr. They also have six grandchildren. In addition, Dick and Kane own a home in Quidnet on Nantucket Island, where they relaxed with their family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Waveny Care Network or The First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan's Friends of Music. There will be a Memorial Service at 11:00 on Saturday, May 3rd at The First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, 178 Oenoke Ridge Road.
APPEL--Alfred Jr. 5 years have passed, but never forgotten. In loving memory. The Family

EINHORN--Marvin D. August 30, 1920 to April 30, 2014. Actor, television director at NBC, husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather. Much beloved by his family and his theater family. So sad to lose him, full of joy for having known him. Funeral on Friday, May 2nd at 1pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

KONCIUS--David. We note with sorrow the passing of our member David Koncius and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City
CAPLOW--AIvin. Thoughts of you bring back countless thoughts of pleasures. M

BERNSTEIN--Irving. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Irving Bernstein, a beloved long-time leader of our Long Island community. His exceptional philanthropic traditions live on through the generosity of his cherished family. We extend our condolences to Irving's wife, Phyllis; his children, Barbara Bloom (Myron) and Steven (Diane); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

BEHRMAN--Fay. Passed away at 93 years of age in New York. Her extraordinary life spanned ten decades and three continents. She was a nurse for the Red Cross during and after World War II, during which time she cared for Holocaust survivors in the Dachau concentration camp. She was whip-smart, elegant, opinionated, vivacious and deeply loyal. Fay loved South Africa (where she was born and raised her family), the arts, fine meals, her walks in Central Park and, above all, her family - to whom she was incredibly devoted. She adored them; and they adored her. Foremost among her devoted admirers were her late husband, Errol, her late son, Darryl and her son, Grant, who survives her. She is also survived by her daughters-in-law, Janine (Alan) and Shelley; her grandchildren Doug (Andrea), Kimmie, Amanda (Zac), and Greg (Caitlin); and her great-grandchildren Josh, Julia, Charlie, and Claire. All of them will miss her dearly, will forever cherish their precious memories of love and laughter with her, and will be graced with the honor of always being able to carry her indomitable spirit with them.

BERNSTEIN--Irving. During our 50-year association, I cherished my business and personal relationship with my friend, Irving. It included countless meetings and deliberations involving professional, business, and charitable endeavors. He was always the gentleman; the calm and deliberate negotiator, and the peacemaker. I am grateful to Irving for teaching me these qualities of leadership. Rest in peace, my friend. Irwin Hochberg

BERKE--Arnold, born November 15, 1923, died April 27, 2014 in Redding, CT. Son of the late George and Ella Berkowitz. Survived by his wife Marjorie; children George, Gregory and Debbie (Fitts); granddaughter Lyndsey Fitts and sister Regina Brauer and children. His spirit sails free on gentle wind. Service Saturday, May 3, 2014, 4:30pm, Unitarian Church of Westport, CT.

BERNSTEIN--Irving. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Barbara and Steven. Loving grandfather of six, and great-grandfather of nine. Services Sunday 12pm at RiversideNassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY.

DUKE--Anthony Drexel Sr.,died peacefully in Gainesville, Florida, on April 30. He was 95. Tony Duke Sr. founded Boys and Girls Harbor in 1937 and served as its president and board chairman for many decades. The values he instilled in Harbor alumni were inspired in him at an early age at St. Paul's School, in Concord, NH, where he was a leader of the class of 1937. He later attended Princeton University, cutting his education short to join the US Navy. In his distinguished military career he was Commanding Officer of the USS LST 530 at Normandy and an LST Division Commander in the Pacific. He was awarded three battle stars and the Bronze Star. He later made missions to Vietnam for the International Rescue Committee, of which he was a board member. In 1980 he sailed to Cuba during the 1980 Mariel refugee crisis. Mr. Duke was a former vice chairman of the board of trustees of Duke University and a board member of many organizations throughout his life. He was the recipient of numerous honors, including honorary doctorates from Duke, Drexel, Adelphi and Long Island Universities. He received several Presidential citations for his leadership of Boys and Girls Harbor. Mr. Duke was a tireless advocate for inner-city youth and their families. He was a former commissioner of the New York City Youth Board and was active with Big Brothers, the Henry Street Settlement and many others. He was the son of Cordelia Drexel Biddle and Angier Buchanan Duke, and the brother of Ambassador Angier Biddle Duke. They were the grandsons of Benjamin N. Duke, who with his brother, James, heavily endowed Trinity College, which became Duke University. Mr. Duke is survived by his widow, Maria de Lourdes Alcebo, and ten children: Anthony Drexel Duke, Jr., Nicholas Rutgers Duke, Sr., Cordelia Duke Jung, Josephine Duke Brown, December Duke McSherry, John Ordway Duke, Douglas Drexel Duke, Lulita Duke Reed, Washington Alcebo Duke, and James Buchanan Duke. His son, Barclay Robertson Duke, died in 1989. He had 22 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren. A private family funeral service will be held on May 12 at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, LI. There will also be a memorial celebration of the life of Tony Duke in New York City on a date later this spring to be announced. Contributions in memory of Tony Duke may be made to: Boys & Girls Harbor, One East 104th Street, New York, NY 10029.

EDELMAN--Dorothy Pearlman, May 26, 1930April 17, 2014. She leaves behind her husband of sixty-one years, Jack; her children, Jonathan, Daniel, and Amy; daughter- and sons-in-law, Barbara, Ivan, and Brett; her grandchildren, George (and wife, Kim), Alexander, Violet, Lily, Jonah, and Miller; her sister, Marge Scheuer; sister- and brother-in-law, Esther and Bud Rowland; and seven nieces and nephews. She was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Croton-on-Hudson, New York, and Manhattan, attending the Hessian Hills School in Croton, the Walden School in Manhattan, and Bennington College. She devoted her life to making things better for others, whether tutoring underserved immigrant children in the public schools or helping preserve women's right to choose. She was devoted, most of all, to her husband and her children and grandchildren, imbuing them with a love of art, music, literature, travel, and nature. She believed in following your own path, being patient when pursuing a heart-felt goal, and sticking to your principles, and lovingly encouraged her children and grandchildren to do the same. She will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her name to First Graduate, a San Franciscobased program that helps students finish high school and become the first in their families to graduate from college. http://firstgraduate.org/donate.

STRAUS--Melville. We mourn our dear friend Mickey whose love and friendship has been part of our lives for over 40 years. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Lelia, Scott, Alexandra and Ben. Susan and Bob E Klein The Entire Klein Family

STRAUS--Melville. Guild Hall's Trustees and Staff mourn the loss of Melville "Mickey" Straus who served as our beloved Board Member and Chair for more than 20 years. Among many significant successes, Mickey led the capital campaign to completely renovate our building and facilities. A passionate supporter of the arts, he was an inspiration to all. We will miss his smile and enthusiastic spirit. We extend our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences to his wife, Leila, and family. Ruth Appelhof, Exec. Director Martin Cohen, Chair

STRAUS--Melville, I will miss my "Uncle Mickey" and his generous guidance, friendship, mentorship, love and support. His passing will leave a gaping hole in my life but his contribution will endure forever. I admired him and loved him deeply. Jeff Klein

GUIDA--Edward. It is with great sadness that the Marshals Association of New York says goodbye to our dear friend and colleague Edward Guida-an extraordinary individual and a marshal's marshal. Eddie will be sorely missed and our thoughts and prayers are with his wife Mary and his son Edward Jr. Family to receive friends and relatives at Guida Funeral Parlor, 47-20 104th Street, Corona, NY on Saturday, May 3rd from 5-9pm and Sunday, May 4th from 29pm. Funeral Mass on Monday, May 5th, 10:45am at St. Leo Parish 4801 104th Street, Corona, NY 11368. In lieu of flowers, send donations to St. Jude's Children's Hospital or the American Diabetes Association.

SORENSEN--Marjorie M.,died in New York City on Sunday, April 13, age 92. Born Marjorie Joyce Mattson on a farm outside of Holdrege, Nebraska, she met her husband, Robert C. Sorensen, at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln. They lived in Chicago, where she completed her studies at Northwestern University while active in liberal A.D.A. Democratic Party politics, and Washington, D.C., before moving to Munich, where Dr. Robert Sorensen worked for Radio Free Europe for five years. Marjorie ran the household, learned fluent German, took courses at the Art Academy, and was an active volunteer in efforts to support handicapped children through the German-American Women's Club. Returning to the U.S. and to New York City in 1958, Marjorie created the family home in an Upper East Side brownstone. She was an early behind-the-scenes actor in a variety of nascent causes including public television, international education, environmentalism, and the rights of women and the elderly. Marjorie and Robert were parents of three children: Chris, Katherine, and David. Marjorie is mourned by her surviving sons, Chris (Robert C.A. of New City, N.Y.) and David (of Copenhagen, Denmark), and grandchildren, Hannah and Stephen Simpson and Nicholas and Axel Sorensen.

FERN--Donald G.,83 years old, died peacefully on May 2, 2014. We mourn the loss of Don; a warm, witty, generous and honorable man. Beloved partner of Helene; loving father of Lisa, Keith, Craig and Sharon; devoted grandfather of Ashley and Jack. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him. Services Sunday at 12:15pm at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

SCHWARTZ--Frederic, a world-renowned architect who pursued his trade with an unbridled passion, purpose and conviction, died April 28 at age 63. He is survived by his wife Tracey Hummer, mother Charlotte, sister Barbara Schwartz Glicksman and her husband Steven, nieces Meryl and Rachel Glicksman, and uncle Marvin Doblin. Thursday burial private. A service celebrating his life and work will be announced shortly. To honor his memory, contributions may be made in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering and UC Berkeley's College of Environmental Design.

EDRICH--Joseph George, May 27, 1927 - April 28, 2014. Beloved husband and soul mate of Helaine, dearest son, adored brother and father. A great and gifted writer, director, and mentor. His wit, charm and intellect inspired all who had the pleasure of knowing him.

ROCHE--John Geoffrey. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan on Sunday at age 75. He was a former partner at Whitcom Investments, Director of World Film Services, and owner of Telecommunications Inc. He attended Georgetown, Oxford, and Harvard Business School. John devoted his later years to his life-long love of film, forming Petunia Productions and serving on the boards of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the TriBeCa Film Institute, and the Phoenix Theater. He is survived by his wife, two brothers, two children, and a fierce enthusiasm for life that will live in the hearts of all who knew him well and loved him. "And say my glory was I had such friends". A memorial is planned for the evening of May 27th at the Century Club.

DELOGU--Adriana, died peacefully in her home in Greenwich, CT on April 30th. Born 1931, she earned her BA from St. John's University. She received her Masters in American History from New York University. She founded and was President of Adriana Associates LTD, an advertising agency in New York City. Ms. Delogu is survived by her sister Antoinette Romano and nieces Celeste Wilson and Gina Romano. She was loved by many and will be missed. Church Service to be held at St. Mary Church, 178 Greenwich Ave. in Greenwich, CT at 10:30am, Monday, May 5th. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Jude Children's Hospital. Servicess handled by Thomas M. Gallagher Funeral Home. To send condolences to the family, please visit: gallagherfuneralhome.com

LOWENBRAUN--Solomon Mortimer, 93, died April 29, 2014. Devoted husband of Florence for 69 years; inspirational and esteemed patriarch for children Dale Boyle (Chuck), Cathy McKeon (Bob) and Leslie Weitzman (Jeffrey); grandchildren Ted (Cathy), Jennifer (Patrick), Andrew and Bethany; and four great-grandchildren. Graduate of Townsend Harris High School, CCNY, and Fordham Law School. WWII veteran and retired Lieutenant Commander in US Naval Reserve. Sole practitioner and litigator for 63 years in New York City. Funeral services private.

HILL--Margaret G. (Peggy)- January 3, 1925 - March 9, 2014, left us to be in heaven with her beloved husband, Bob, her parents Luke and Margaret, her sister Patricia and her brother Bill. Including many cousins, Peggy is survived by 10 nieces and nephews. A longtime Manhattan resident, Peggy was the first woman to be promoted to VP in NY Bell Telephone. She spent the latter part of her career successfully negotiating labor agreements with the labor unions. Peggy and Bob traveled the world extensively during their vacations, and always sent postcards from exotic locales. They moved to Rochester, MN so that Bob could get the benefit of Mayo Clinic medical care. After Bob left us in 1998, Peggy stayed in Rochester for the remainder of her years, active in Catholic based services. Despite her many accomplishments, Peggy remained modest. Peggy's love of family was a constant. A Funeral Mass was celebrated at St. John The Evangelist Church in Rochester, MN, at 9:00am, Saturday, April 26, 2014. On Friday, April 25 2014, from 4:00pm to 7:00pm with a prayer service at 4:30pm, family members received friends at River Park Chapel, Macken Funeral Home, 1105 12th St SE, Rochester, MN 55904. Online condolences are welcome at mackenfuneralhome.com

STRAUS--Melville "Mickey", died peacefully at home in New York City on May 1. He was 75. Mickey was a lifelong investor and supporter of the arts. He earned a BA at Dartmouth College, was a Lieutenant in the Navy, and graduated from Harvard Business School as a Baker Scholar. He became a partner at Weiss, Peck, and Greer and founded Straus Asset Management in 1998, both of New York. Mickey was a passionate and dedicated philanthropist. He was Chairman of the Board of Trustees at Guild Hall in East Hampton and Chair Emeritus of the American Ballet Theater. He was active with the Museum of Modern Art, the Independent Curators Inc, and Dartmouth College, among other institutions. Mickey loved people and was a great optimist. He was warm, generous, driven, perceptive, precise, and kind-hearted. He loved great hotels, restaurants, events, and beautiful landscapes. He was the beloved husband of Leila; devoted father of Scott, Alexandra, and Ben; loving father-in-law and grandfather of Sara, Sadie, and Solomon; dedicated brother to Margie, John, and Mary; and companion to Tiggy. He eagerly awaited the arrival of granddaughter Phoebe Quinn. He will be missed by many. There will be a memorial celebration on May 15.

SMITH--Howard. Distinguished journalist, radio host, film director, mental health advocate and my dear friend. Always energetic, sensitive, generous and kind. RIP. David Chowes, Adjunct Professor of Psychology, CUNY

STRASSBERG--Linda Wolf, 77, after another courageous battle with cancer, succumbed on May 1. Devoted wife to the late Louis, Linda was the mother of Todd, Robert (Allison) and Stacy (Allen). She enjoyed golf, dancing, art and travel, and the company of her many friends. Linda is survived by her brother Walter (Doris) Wolf, eight adored grandchildren and her very dear friend, Walter Fessler. Services 10am, Sunday, Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., RVC. Family will receive friends Sunday, Monday and Tuesday at her home.

SMITH--Howard. Distinguished journalist, radio host, film director, mental health advocate and my dear friend. Always energetic, sensitive, generous and kind. RIP. David Chowes, Adjunct Professor of Psychology, CUNY

STEWART--Bhob. Died at 76 on February 24 in Plymouth, MA. Born in Meridian, MS, on November 12, 1937, Bhob graduated in 1959 from Sam Houston State. Bhob is widely credited with inventing the term "underground comics" in 1966. In 1969, Bhob curated the first exhibition of underground comic art, at the Corcoran Gallery. Bhob worked as an editor at Topps Chewing Gum and created Wacky Packages. Bhob edited the magazine Castle of Frankenstein, was a contributor to The Realist, Roxy Funnies, The Comics Journal, Heavy Metal, wrote Against the Grain: Mad Artist Wallace Wood (2003) and penned an underground pastiche, Tales from the Fridge (1973). In his later years, he wrote a blog, potrzebie.blogspot.com, and over 1,000 Wikipedia entries. Bhob is survived by his brother Joe B. Stewart of Arlington, VA. A memorial service will be held May 4, at 2pm at the Butler Library, Room 523 at Columbia University.

FRANKLIN--Frederic June 13,1914-May 4, 2013 Freddie, Fortune smiled and lent you to us; then she grew jealous of our happiness and took you back. I love and miss you, every instant of every day with every fiber of my being. Bill To celebrate Freddie's life please give to the Frederic Franklin Scholarship Fund at American Ballet Theatre's JKO School, 890 Broadway, NY, NY 10003, or at the ABT web site under "Membership and Support," so that talented young dancers can carry on his lagacy.

SHINDLER--Kurt, 83, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of New York, NY, passed away Wednesday, April 23, 2014. Kurt is survived by his loving wife of 60 years, Elaine Shindler; sons Steven (Barbara) Shindler and David (Debra) Shindler; grandchildren Michael, Megan, Stefanie and Alex Shindler; brother Everett Shindler. Services were held Friday, April 25, 2014.

STRAUS--Melville "Mickey", died peacefully at home in New York City on May 1. He was 75. Mickey was a lifelong investor and supporter of the arts. He earned a BA at Dartmouth College, was a Lieutenant in the Navy, and graduated from Harvard Business School as a Baker Scholar. He became a partner at Weiss, Peck, and Greer and founded Straus Asset Management in 1998, both of New York. Mickey was a passionate and dedicated philanthropist. He was Chairman of the Board of Trustees at Guild Hall in East Hampton and Chair Emeritus of the American Ballet Theater. He was active with the Museum of Modern Art, the Independent Curators Inc, and Dartmouth College, among other institutions. Mickey loved people and was a great optimist. He was warm, generous, driven, perceptive, precise, and kind-hearted. He loved great hotels, restaurants, events, and beautiful landscapes. He was the beloved husband of Leila; devoted father of Scott, Alexandra, and Ben; loving father-in-law and grandfather of Sara, Sadie, and Solomon; dedicated brother to Margie, John, and Mary; and companion to Tiggy. He eagerly awaited the arrival of granddaughter Phoebe Quinn. He will be missed by many. There will be a memorial celebration on May 15.
PRAH--Joseph David, D.D.S. 2/27/1931 4/29/2004 Greatly loved and always in our thoughts.

SHULMAN--Sidney. Sidney Shulman, Ph.D.,90, 1923 - 2014. Distinguished Bio-chemistry medical school professor: New York Medical College/University of Buffalo - Extensive research/publications in the field of immunology and human infertility, followed by a lab practice. He is survived by his beloved wife, Irma, and children, Katharine, Michael, Stephen, Andrew, Rebecca and Elizabeth - grandchildren, Noah, David, and Jemsea. Dr. Shulman was a devotee of opera and classical music, a polyglot and an avid reader. Apart from his piercing intellect, he was known for his wit, charm, entertaining personality and as a dear Friend to many. He will be missed! Services Sunday, May 4, 2014 at 12:00 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (Amsterdam Ave. and the corner of West 91st St.).
STRAUS--Melville "Mickey", We've lost our best friend but we will cherish his legacy and love of life forever. Sherry and Gene Zuriff
HAUSMAN--Richard Andrew, 5/1/1960- 5/5/2008 Cherished in our hearts and thoughts, forever missed. Your Family

STRAUS--Melville. Guild Hall's Trustees and Staff mourn the loss of Melville "Mickey" Straus who served as our beloved Board Member and Chair for more than 20 years. GOLDSMITH--Dolores. May 2, 2009. I Am Not There. Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there I do not sleep, I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sunlight on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn's rain, When you awaken in the morning's hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circled flight, I am the soft stars that shine at night, Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die.

ZAKS--Dr. Arthur, of Tenafly, NJ, passed away at the age of 75, on April 26, 2014. He was born in Brooklyn, NY to Henrietta and Fredrick Zaks. He graduated Stuyvesant High School (1956) and Brooklyn College (1960, Phi Beta Kappa). Dr. Zaks earned his medical degree from New York University School of Medicine (1964). He completed his internship at Lenox Hill Hospital (1965) and his residency in psychiatry at New York Medical College, Metropolitan Hospital Center (1968). After he became board certified in psychiatry with an interest in drug addiction therapy, he went on to establish South Brooklyn Medical Services. Dr. Zaks was also a member of the U.S. Army Reserves from 1964 1970 where he held the rank of Captain. He loved to travel, teach, and had a passion for history, politics, and the New York Jets. He is survived by his loving wife Mary L. (nee Rega); his brother Herbert (Kay); his three children, Zosia, Karen (Brad) and Laura (Ulises); and five grandchildren, Ruby, Eislyn, Tiago, Luka, and Arthur. He will be dearly missed by his family and friends. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations may be made in his memory to the New York University School of Medicine Scholarship Fund (https://onlinegiving.nyumc.org/scholarships).
SCIMECCA--Joseph. 5/6/1936. Remembering your 78th Birthday. Always in my heart. Marcia

WINTERS--Bernard J. Age 90. Lovingly remembered by daughter Heather and son-in-law Cary Holcomb, son Mead and grandchildren Taylor and Ben Holcomb. Predeceased by his wife Sylvia. Bernie was born in Brooklyn, a veteran of WWII, received his BS and MA from NYU and was the owner of Sportcrafts in Bronxville, NY for over thirty years. He was a lover of travel, the arts, french cuisine, a superb tennis player and dedicated golfer. A passionate liberal democrat and supporter of the causes he believed in. Father, grandfather and friend--he was deeply loved and will be sorely missed.

STRAUS--Melville, I will miss my "Uncle Mickey" and his generous guidance, friendship, mentorship, love and support. His passing will leave a gaping hole in my life but his contribution will endure forever. I admired him and loved him deeply. Jeff Klein

WEISS--Malcolm Arthur, of Boston, Massachusetts died April 25, 2014 at the age of 88. He was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1926, the only child of Joseph Weiss (born Tosko Weitzenburch) and Rose Ellenbogen Weiss. He graduated from Brooklyn Technical High School, and received BS, MS, and PhD degrees from Columbia University, all in chemical engineering. From 1944-1946 he served in the US Navy. In 1948 he began work in research and development at the Exxon Corporation. His assignments began in research, and later moved to increasing management responsibility. At various times he was responsible for work on ramjet missile propulsion, rocket fuels, polymers, fuel cells, biological production of edible protein from oil, and underground combustion for recovering thick crude oil. In 1977, he moved from Union, NJ, to Boston, and joined the Energy Laboratory at MIT in Cambridge, MA. There he was the first Executive Director of the Center for Energy Policy Research, later the Deputy Director and subsequently co-Director of the Energy Laboratory and the founding Director of the Synthetic Fuels Center. He returned to personal research in 1988, concentrating on transportation fuels and biofuels, and their environmental effects. In 1948 he married Carol Hirschon Weiss, who died in January 2013. He is survived by his three children, Janet, Daniel, and Judith, and four grandchildren, Benjamin, Samuel, Jacob, and Delilah. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Boston Public Library Foundation (bplf.org).

STANTON--Timothy Scott, 56, of Manhattan, died April 24, 2014. Born in 1958 to World-Wide Volkswagon pioneer, Arthur Stanton and his wife, actress Joan Alexander Stanton, Tim died at peace after a long illness. He attended St. Bernard's School (1973), Dwight Prep (1977) and NYU, from which he graduated in l981. He was a man of grace and charm, curiosity and generosity, who pursued life with joie de vivre: "What we give the world, we have borrowed from no one; it is ours. It may be taken from us, stolen from us, but imitated?--never" (Julien Green, Paris). Tim is survived by his wife, Agnes, two sons, Liam, 19, and Conrad 3, a sister, Jane, a half-brother, Jonathan, cousins, James, Michael and Alexandra, and an extended family.

SHORE--Robert, 90. Painter, illustrator, sculptor. Educated at Cranbrook Academy of Art, Boro Polytecnic London, and Art Students League. Staff artist for Stars and Stripes during WWII; paintings commissioned by NASA include the Mercury Atlas rocket liftoff; recognized for illustrating works of Conrad, Melville, and Verne for Limited Editions Club; awarded Society of Illustrators Gold Medal 1966. Fulbright fellow in painting; permanent collections of Smithsonian and NASA. Beloved husband of Marietta, father of Evan and Gigi, cherished teacher for generations of New York City art students.

McGILL--Helen Louise Hutchinson, of New York City and Carmel, NY, on April 25, 2014. Born in 1927 to Leland and Mildred Mickey Hutchinson, she grew up in Fostoria, Ohio. She graduated from Fostoria High School in 1945, and Vassar College in 1948. In Paris, she attended the Sorbonne and studied les ondes Martenot. Helen later performed with Musica Sacra and the New York Philharmonic, among others. With an M.A. from Teachers College, she taught at The Cathedral School of St. John the Divine. Kind and generous, with a genuine concern for others, Helen actively participated in her communities, including Gipsy Trail Club and Quaker Hill Country Club. Helen treasured her family. Predeceased by her husband Richard C. McGill, she is survived by their beloved daughter, Margaret Lauren McGill, of New York. She is also survived by nieces Ellen Hartzler (William Allen) and Susan Hartzler, nephew Richard Hartzler (Chris), and great-nieces Patty Allen-Stott (Christopher) and Christen Allen. Memorial service at The First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York, 12th St. and 5th Ave., on May 13, at 1pm. Please consider contributions to Lighthouse International.

KERR--Barbara, died on April 28, 2014 after a brief illness. Born in New York City, Barbara studied at Pratt Institute. She was an artist, a graphic designer and studio manager. In 1951 she co-founded Kerr Studios, a commercial photography business, with her husband Justin. She was an expert restorer of Maya ceramics. She had an exquisite sense of aesthetics and boundless creativity which she applied to all aspects of her work and life. She is survived by her husband Justin, her sister Sandra, her nieces and nephews and many, many friends.

She leaves behind a legion of close friends who meant the world to her. The funeral services will be held at The Episcopal Church of Bethesda by the Sea on Palm Beach on May 7, 2014 at 2:00pm.

PETERSON--Bruce. The entire Edmund Hollander Design family mourns the passing of Bruce Peterson. He was a generous man who loved to help others, whose heart knew no bounds. RIEHLMAN--Franklin E.,Art dealer Franklin Riehlman, the proprietor of Franklin Riehlman Fine Art, located at 24 East 73rd Street in New York City, passed away tragically on the evening of April 22 at the age of 61. To the unsuspecting, Franklin was known to identify himself as a used canvas salesman. In actuality, he was widely admired for his expansive knowledge in the field of 19th and 20th-century American art and his passion for early 20th-century art in general, including British modernism, and many other related fields. He was especially proud of his expertise in the work of the artists George Bellows, Clarence Carter, Konrad Cramer, Adolph Dehn, Charles Goeller, Leon Kroll, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Michael Lenson, Frank London, Edmund Lewandowski , Walter Murch, Priscilla Roberts, Harold Shapinsky and Hans Weingartner, along with many other artists of the early 20th-century, particularly those of the Woodstock Art colony. He was just as proud of his relationships with all who shared those interests. He also represented work of contemporary artists such as Leslie Gabosh, Walter Hatke, Robert Kipness, Simeon Lagodich, David Olenick, and Martin Weinstein. Franklin's prior lives included excelling as tight end/linebacker for the Pleasant Valley Vikings, induction into the Butte College Sports Hall of Fame as linebacker for the Butte College Roadrunners, a heavyweight wrestling champion, a painter of new canvases exhibited on both coasts, a student of art history at Hunter College, the Institute of Fine Arts and California State University at Chico, a scholar of ancient Greek vase painting, a salesman of LeRoy Nieman prints at Knoedler Publishing, Inc., a slide curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he was also a lecturer, a paintings expert at Phillips, Son & Neale, Inc. in New York, an associate at H.V. Allison Galleries, a business partner of Andrea Scully-Keogh and of Megan Moynihan, a published author of art historical catalogues and essays, a bridge player and a golf addict. He preferred research at the Frick Art Library to the internet and loved books. He was born in Safford, AZ and raised in Utah, Nevada, Santa Barbara, the California Bay Area, and Chico, CA, which he left for New York City in 1977. He is survived by his partner and lover of 30 years, Mary M. Walsh, of New York City, his mother Margaret Whitaker Riehlman, his siblings Mark (Liz), Troy (Mary Ann), Ann (Pat) Patterson and Donald, his uncle, Charles Whitaker, nieces and nephews and many, many friends and colleagues. All of whom are heartbroken and will cherish his memory. He was preceded in death by his father Peter and his nephew Josh. Franklin Riehlman Fine Art will continue as a company under the direction and ownership of Mary M. Walsh. A generous group of colleagues, friends and admirers are holding a memorial service to celebrate his life and compare tales on May 22 at the Lotos Club on 66th and 5th in Manhattan. Contact Franklin Riehlman Fine Art if you have not received an invite and wish to attend. A quote from one of Franklin's many pocket notebooks: "Let us endeavor so to live that when we die, even the undertaker will be sorry."

GNERRE--Anthony (Tony) C.,74, died on April 29, 2014. He was beloved by his friends, and was known for his great stories. He will be very much missed. Tony was born June 14, 1939 in the Bronx and later moved to Yonkers. He attended college in Massachusetts and then became a registered account rep. After working on the Street since 1961, he retired as vice president from Oppenheimer & Co. in 2004. Tony is survived by his best friend and wife of 49 years, Freya Anderson Gnerre, his sister JoAnn Waldrop (Florida), brother-in-law Joseph Polese, sister-in-law and husband Cheryl and Edward Daw, niece and nephews and many cousins, and many, many friends. He was predeceased by his parents, Anthony and Justine Gnerre and his sister Ann Marie Polese. A private cremation has taken place. In lieu of flowers, friends who wish may contribute to the North Shore Animal League or the Ruth Gottscho Kidney Foundation. To sign the online guestbook, please visit Westchesterfuneralhome.com

KINGSON--William, "Bill" World record setting pilot, martial artist, and international businessman, passed away on Monday, April 28th. He was surrounded by his family as he listened to jazz. Known for his sharp suits and wit, he traveled around the world doing business in places where no one thought it could be done. From the Middle East in the 1980s to Asia even before that, Bill was not afraid of the unknown and often brought suitcases filled with his exercise weights. He never stopped traveling and working on new businesses as he always sought out the next great adventure. Bill once remarked, "I've done it my way and no one has had more fun doing it." He is survived by his loving family wife, daughter, son and two grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to The Browning School, in memory of William S. Kingson, at 52 East 62nd Street, New York, NY 10065 . . . .

FERN--Donald G.,83 years old, died peacefully on May 2, 2014. We mourn the loss of Don; a warm, witty, generous and honorable man. Beloved partner of Helene; loving father of Lisa, Keith, Craig and Sharon; devoted grandfather of Ashley and Jack. He will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved him. Services Sunday at 12:15pm at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

LERNER--Jerry, 70, of Brighton Beach and Delray Beach. Beloved husband of Barbara Joan Fried, devoted father of BeBe and lifelong fan of the New York Giants. Jerry's successful sales career began at 20, at The Shoe Box in New York. He relocated to Florida and started his own business, completing his career at LexisNexis. A graduate of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brighton Beach and Baruch College. Jerry fell madly in love with Barbara at a Coney Island singles dance in 1964; they were inseparable for 50 years.

ROSENTHAL--Nan, age 76, died peacefully at home on Sunday, April 27, 2014. Beloved wife of Henry B. Cortesi, she was born in New York City on August 27, 1937. She graduated from the Fieldston School, Sarah Lawrence College and earned a PhD from Harvard. She began her career in journalism but turned to the study of art history focusing on post-WWII American artists. She excelled as a scholar, curator, teacher, and mentor. Nan was Senior Consultant of 20th Century Art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art until her retirement in 2008. Before moving back to New York after her marriage to Henry in 1991, she was curator of 20th Century Art at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and before that, a professor at the University of California at Santa Cruz. Over her long, varied and highly distinguished career, she accumulated a very large, diverse and devoted group of friends who enlivened and enriched her life as she did theirs. We are all deeply grieved and diminished by her death. A memorial for Nan will be held in September. In lieu of flowers, the family request that contributions be made in Nan's memory to the Financial Aid Fund of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, 33 Central Park W. NY, NY 10023.

FIELDS--Harry. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Mr. Harry Fields, an honored member of the Harmonie Club for over 25 years. The Harmonie Club wishes to extend its deeply heartfelt condolences to his wife Barbara and the entire Fields family in their time of sorrow. Stephen Brecher, The Harmonie Club President

LOWENBRAUN--Solomon Mortimer, 93, died April 29, 2014. Devoted husband of Florence for 69 years; inspirational and esteemed patriarch for children Dale Boyle (Chuck), Cathy McKeon (Bob) and Leslie Weitzman (Jeffrey); grandchildren Ted (Cathy), Jennifer (Patrick), Andrew and Bethany; and four great-grandchildren. Graduate of Townsend Harris High School, CCNY, and Fordham Law School. WWII veteran and retired Lieutenant Commander in US Naval Reserve. Sole practitioner and litigator for 63 years in New York City. Funeral services private.

GILBERT--Sidney Irwin, born February 17, 1925, Died peacefully on April 30, 2014. He leaves behind his loving wife of 63 years, Betty, his devoted daughters Enid and Leslye, his sons-in-law, Richard Katze and Mitchell Funk, and his adored grandchildren Samantha, Josh and Courtney.

MATES--Jack Kenneth. Died April 19th, 2014. Formerly President and CEO of Velcro USA. Formerly President, Chairman, Chairman Emeritus of Distinguished Flying Cross Society (DFCS). Donations in lieu of flowers, to DFCS Scholarship Fund, PO Box 502408, San Diego, CA 92150.

GOLDSMITH--Marilyn. November 28, 1926, on April 6, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Will Goldsmith. James Madison HS, LIU (BA, MA, Teacher). Award-winning poet. Taproot, Performance Poets Assoc., L.I. Writers Guild. Lovingly remembered: Nancy, George, Steve, Kate, Lauren, Dan, Rafaella, Eli, Sarah, Lydia, Hannah. Donations: Marilyn Goldsmith Poetry Award c/o James Madison H.S., 3787 Bedford Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11229.

NEWBERRY--Samuel R.,departed peacefully on April 22, 2014 in Queens, NY. He is predeceased by his wife Alberta, parents and 13 siblings. Mr. Newberry came to Jamaica, NY at age 16. He was passionate about his antique shows, and business "Ye Old Treasure Shoppe." View: 10am. Funeral: 11am, May 7, New Apostolic, 9914 Francis Lewis Blvd., Hollis, NY. May his soul rest in perfect peace.

BERKE--Arnold, born November 15, 1923, died April 27, 2014 in Redding, CT. Son of the late George and Ella Berkowitz. Survived by his wife Marjorie; children George, Gregory and Debbie (Fitts); granddaughter Lyndsey Fitts and sister Regina Brauer and children. His spirit sails free on gentle wind. Service Saturday, May 3, 2014, 4:30pm, Unitarian Church of Westport, CT.

BEHRMAN--Fay. Passed away at 93 years of age in New York. Her extraordinary life spanned ten decades and three continents. She was a nurse for the Red Cross during and after World War II, during which time she cared for Holocaust survivors in the Dachau concentration camp. She was whip-smart, elegant, opinionated, vivacious and deeply loyal. Fay loved South Africa (where she was born and raised her family), the arts, fine meals, her walks in Central Park and, above all, her family - to whom she was incredibly devoted. She adored them; and they adored her. Foremost among her devoted admirers were her late husband, Errol, her late son, Darryl and her son, Grant, who survives her. She is also survived by her daughters-in-law, Janine (Alan) and Shelley; her grandchildren Doug (Andrea), Kimmie, Amanda (Zac), and Greg (Caitlin); and her great-grandchildren Josh, Julia, Charlie, and Claire. All of them will miss her dearly, will forever cherish their precious memories of love and laughter with her, and will be graced with the honor of always being able to carry her indomitable spirit with them.

BAER--Theodore, 87, passed away peacefully April 26th in Southold, NY. Loyal and caring husband for 65 years to his beloved soulmate, his heart, his everything, the late Bertina Baer. In each other's arms again, with extraordinary grace and beauty, they dance together to songs that now only they can hear. "Teddy Baer" as he was affectionately known, served a distinguished clientele for over 50 years as a jeweler where he was esteemed for his integrity, generosity and skill. His handsome elegant attire, heart-warming smile and many kindnesses will live long in the memories of those who knew him. He is survived by sons Andrew and Nolan, daughter-in-law Colleen Griffin, cousin Alan Baer, nephews Jeffrey and Barry Neichen, and half-siblings Arlene and Arthur Isaacs. Memorial service to be held in Manhattan at a future date. For information please call (212) 397-4822.

BRILL--Betty, born April 17, 1921, died April 28, 2014. Wife of the late Martin Brill. Survived by her sons Walter, Peter, and Steven; daughters-in-law Gerrilyn, Krista, and Elaine; grandchildren Rachel, Natalie, David, and Lauren. Betty lived a wonderful life for an extraordinary 93 years. She was a lover of New York culture, travel, and most of all family and friends. All of them will miss her dearly, will cherish their precious memories of love and laughter, and forever remember her spirit of always caring for others.

BERNSTEIN--Phyllis. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Phyllis Bernstein, beloved wife of the late Irving. Her commitment to the Jewish community has impacted many lives. We extend our deepest condolences to Phyllis's children, Barbara Bloom (Myron) and Steven (Diane); her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

BRINKMANN--Elisabeth RSCJ, educator at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, died Tuesday, April 29. Born June 12, 1960 in Geneva, Switzerland, to Leo and Ursula Brinkmann, she is survived by her mother, Ursula Brinkmann of Austin, her sister, Anne Birch, and two brothers, Peter Brinkmann and Johannes Brinkmann. Her father predeceased her. Visit www.rscj.org. Funeral Mass 10:00am, Friday, May 9th, Convent of the Sacred Heart, 91st Street, New York. Burial in the Society of the Sacred Heart Cemetery at Kenwood in Albany, May 10.

DELOGU--Adriana, died peacefully in her home in Greenwich, CT on April 30th. Born 1931, she earned her BA from St. John's University. She received her Masters in American History from New York University. She founded and was President of Adriana Associates LTD, an advertising agency in New York City. Ms. Delogu is survived by her sister Antoinette Romano and nieces Celeste Wilson and Gina Romano. She was loved by many and will be missed. Church Service to be held at St. Mary Church, 178 Greenwich Ave. in Greenwich, CT at 10:30am, Monday, May 5th. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Jude Children's Hospital. Servicess handled by Thomas M. Gallagher Funeral Home. To send condolences to the family, please visit: gallagherfuneralhome.com

EDRICH--Joseph George, May 27, 1927 - April 28, 2014. Beloved husband and soul mate of Helaine, dearest son, adored brother and father. A great and gifted writer, director, and mentor. His wit, charm and intellect inspired all who had the pleasure of knowing him.

BOKAL--Diane, on April 25. Devoted mother of Nicole Fuller. Loving mother-in-law of Clarence Fuller. Cherished sister of Sharon and David. Family will receive Friday, May 9, 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Mass of the Resurrection on Saturday, 1:30pm from St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

DONOHUE--James John, of Wellington, Florida passed away on April 11, 2014. James is survived by four sons, James, Edward, Thomas, and Christopher; two siblings, Thomas and Marion, three grandchildren, Alana, Peter, and Robert; a former spouse Carolann, and many in-laws, nieces, and nephews. James was predeceased by his wife Elizabeth. A memorial service will be held in his honor at Church of the Assumption, 55 Cranberry Street, Brooklyn, NY on May 17, 2014 at 11am.

DIETZE--Jean Sturges. August 6, 1930, died April 30, 2014. Beloved wife of John and mother to David and Katherine (Wendy). Mother-in-law of William Heyman and Claire Toth; grandmother of Erika Kahn, John Courage, William Dietze, and Elizabeth Dietze.

EDELMAN--Dorothy Pearlman, May 26, 1930April 17, 2014. She leaves behind her husband of sixty-one years, Jack; her children, Jonathan, Daniel, and Amy; daughter- and sons-in-law, Barbara, Ivan, and Brett; her grandchildren, George (and wife, Kim), Alexander, Violet, Lily, Jonah, and Miller; her sister, Marge Scheuer; sister- and brother-in-law, Esther and Bud Rowland; and seven nieces and nephews. She was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Croton-on-Hudson, New York, and Manhattan, attending the Hessian Hills School in Croton, the Walden School in Manhattan, and Bennington College. She devoted her life to making things better for others, whether tutoring underserved immigrant children in the public schools or helping preserve women's right to choose. She was devoted, most of all, to her husband and her children and grandchildren, imbuing them with a love of art, music, literature, travel, and nature. She believed in following your own path, being patient when pursuing a heart-felt goal, and sticking to your principles, and lovingly encouraged her children and grandchildren to do the same. She will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her name to First Graduate, a San Franciscobased program that helps students finish high school and become the first in their families to graduate from college. http://firstgraduate.org/donate.
