FISHBEIN--Benjamin, 89, passed away May 1, 2014. Loving husband of Eugenia for 35 years, devoted father of Susan, Amy, Daniel, Andrew and Remy. Father-in-law to Robert and Dena. Loving grandfather of Michael, Julie, David, Rachel and Lisa. Among many significant successes he was the developer of the Landmark Eagle Warehouse in Brooklyn and owner and proprietor of the Figaro Cafe in Greenwich Village, where he was also a long-time resident. To honor his memory, contributions may be made in his name to a charity of your choice.

BIENENSTOCK--Arthur,At 95, and in his 67th year of marriage to Elaine, Arthur Bienenstock passed away peacefully on May 3, as the last surviving child of Morris J. and Fannie Bienenstock. Although Arthur built an amazing real estate business starting with the $2000 he sent home for his mother while serving in World War II, what gave him the most satisfaction was his support of and leadership positions in The Jewish Theological Seminary, UJA, Park Avenue Synagogue, Federation, and many New York City causes for the needy and the arts. Arthur's greatest joys were his wife Elaine and his pride in his children and their spouses (Gloria and Richard; Martin and Barbara), grandchildren (Jessica, Jonathan, Jarett, and Allison), and great-grandchildren (Ian and Maia).

VANDERKLOOT--Frederic John, on May 1. Dearest husband and hero to Miriam. Devoted father to Kathryn VanderKloot and Pamela Bartel (William). Proud grandfather to Nicholas and Alexander Perkins, and Zoe and Zachary Bartel. Fond stepfather to Marisa Jaffe (Jeffrey Sirlin) and Sara Jaffe (David Ostroff). Grandpa Fred to Noah Sirlin, and Hannah and Nora Ostroff. A loyal and grateful son of Yale, he was co-chairman of his 55th reunion at his death. Fred will be remembered at the Class of 1959 memorial service on June 1. Please consider contributions to Yale University or Planned Parenthood in Fred's memory.

FINKELSTEIN--Phyllis Liniado. Dear Mother, Grandmother, Sister, Aunt and Wife of the late Robert Finkelstein. At 76, Phyllis died peacefully at home after a long illness. She was a loyal friend and always generous with her time and herself. A woman of exquisite taste, Phyllis worked for clients and friends as an interior designer, always wanting to make things beautiful. She is survived by her daughter, Jennifer Komitee, her son-in-law, Eric Komitee, her grandchildren, Evan and Emily; her sister, Marion Cuba; her niece, Stephanie Cuba (Lawrence); and sister-in-law, Cynthia Ader. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Phyllis' honor to the Alzheimer's Association. Services will be private.

FRIEDMAN--Alan J.,71, who died on May 4th after a short illness, was admired and adored in the world of informal science education both here and abroad. For 22 years he directed the New York Hall of Science, guiding it to international prominence. He nurtured a generation of science educators who revered him. He is survived by his wife Mickey and his sister June Entman. There will be a memorial service. Contributions may be made to the Alan J. Friedman Fund at the New York Hall of Science.

GOLDSTEIN--Mortimer D.,100, Merrick, NY. Devoted and adored husband of the late Rita for 67 years. Beloved father of Marcia and Les Ratcliff, Amy Goldstein, and Jane and Ron Jackson. Incredibly proud and loving grandfather of Blake and Jordan Ratcliff and Ben and Evan Jackson. Services at Gutterman's Rockville Centre on Monday, May 5th, at 1pm. A sweet and wonderful man, he will always remain in our hearts.

KERN--Frederick Abraham, 87, of W. Palm Beach, FL on Saturday, May 3. Much admired New York State Supreme Court Clerk for over 40 years. Devoted husband, father and grandfather. www.clarkassociatesfuneralhome.com

STRAUS--Melville. We mourn our dear friend Mickey whose love and friendship has been part of our lives for over 40 years. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Lelia, Scott, Alexandra and Ben. Susan and Bob E Klein The Entire Klein Family

HOCH--Eli, PhD, The Board of Directors and Staff of New York Psychotherapy and Counseling Center mourn the passing of Dr. Eli Hoch on May 2, 2014. Eli served with distinction as Director of Clinical Services and as a member of the Governor's Mental Health Services Council. He was a warm, generous, loyal friend and colleague. He was a gentle and wise man beloved by all who knew him. His humanity, compassion, optimism and genial nature will be missed. His leadership and vision guide us to this very day. We extend sincere condolences to his entire family. Devora Brickman, President, Board of Directors Elliott Klein, Executive Director
STRAUS--Melville "Mickey", We've lost our best friend but we will cherish his legacy and love of life forever. Sherry and Gene Zuriff

STRAUS--Melville, I will miss my "Uncle Mickey" and his generous guidance, friendship, mentorship, love and support. His passing will leave a gaping hole in my life but his contribution will endure forever. I admired him and loved him deeply. Jeff Klein

BORTS--Professor George Herbert. Died on May 2nd in Providence, RI. He was a son of the late Elias Alexander and Etta (Silberg) Borts, husband of Muriel "Dolly" (Levenson) Borts, and brother of Lawrence (Beverly) Borts. He was the father of David (Lucia Fontes) Borts, Richard (Paulette York) Borts and Robert (Erin O'Cain) Borts. He was the grandfather of Alexander, Andrew and Liana Borts. Professor Borts was born in New York City on August 29, 1927, and educated at Columbia University. George Borts received his AM in 1949 and his PhD in 1953 from the University of Chicago, studying under Milton Friedman. Professor Borts spent 63 years at Brown University, where he joined the Department of Economics in 1950 at the age of 23. During his career, he served as chairman of the Department of Economics at Brown, as the managing editor of the American Economic Review and as a visiting professor/research fellow at Hokkaido University, London School of Economics and the National Bureau of Economic Research. Professor Borts was an expert in international finance and transportation. He testified frequently before US and Canadian regulatory commissions. During his long and distinguished career, he published numerous scholarly books, articles and monographs, as well as commentary for the Providence Journal. A tireless advocate for the free market, Professor Borts was also a dedicated educator and teacher. He advised both undergraduate and graduate students with equal dedication and led Brown's Phi Beta Kappa chapter for many years. Professor Borts served on many boards, including the Rhode Island School of Design, Dartmouth's Amos Tuck School of Business, Rhode Island Blue Shield, Junior Achievement of Rhode Island and Temple Beth-El. He also advised several political candidates on economic and tax policy. His funeral will be held on Monday, May 5th, at Sugarman-Sinai Memorial Chapel, 458 Hope St., Providence, RI at 1:30pm, with burial to follow. Shiva will be at the Borts residence, Barrington, from 5-8pm on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. For information and condolences, www.SugarmanSinai.com.

BERNSTEIN--Irving. The Open University of Israel mourns the passing of Irving and his recently deceased wife Phyllis. Irving for decades was a supporter of The Open University and helped underprivileged students to get an education which changed their lives. We fondly remember with great admiration the enormous contribution that the three Irvings, Irving Bernstein, Irving Rosenbaum, Irwin Hochberg made to the state of Israel as dedicated and servant Zionists. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mimi Perlman, Chairman Ingeborg Rennert, President

WEITZMAN--Arnie, passed away in Dutchess County at age 57 on April 27, 2014. Arnie is lovingly remembered by his wife Suki Hertz, son Alex, parents Gloria and Marty Weitzman, sister Robin, brother-in-law Ira, brother Michael, nieces Alyssa, Jenna, Lindsey, Marissa, and Labrador Retrievers Georgy and Chino. A graduate of University of Pennsylvania, Arnie was an associate at Hazen & Sawyer in New York City, and in his spare time a passionate and talented woodworker. Arnie will be missed by many for his kind and generous heart, clear thinking, and always being "the voice of reason."

JOYCE--Dr. Walter E.,on May 4, 2014. Beloved husband of Marjorie, loving father of Mary-Elizabeth (Fritz), Walter, Timothy (Stella), Mat- thew and Megan, grandfather of five. Dr. Joyce was a former Professor and Dean at Pace University. Services by Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY.

ROCHE--John. The Board and staff of the Film Society of Lincoln Center are profoundly saddened by the death of John Roche, one of its most devoted and enthusiastic Board members for more than 35 years. John was an avid moviegoer and passionate supporter of our organization and all of its programs, especially Film Comment magazine, which thrived under his knowledgeable guidance. We will miss his unique humor, his kindness and his generosity. We send our love and sympathy to his wife Brenda, his children and family. Ann Tenenbaum, Chairman, Daniel Stern, President, Lesli Klainberg, Exec. Director

CROMARTY--Arthur Martin. A war hero whose reputation was synonymous with sterling public service on Long Island, Arthur Cromarty, one of New York's longest sitting Administrative Supreme Court Justices and namesake of the Arthur M. Cromarty Suffolk County Court Complex in Riverhead, died on May 1, 2014. With family members at his side, he passed away from heart failure at the age of 94. He is survived by his daughter, Alice Cromarty of Lindenhurst, NY; two sons, Ross Cromarty of Scottsdale, AZ; and Peter Cromarty of Manhattan and Palm Beach, FL; two grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Friends may visit at Boyd Funeral Home in Babylon, May 7 and 8; Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, in Lindenhurst, May 9th, 9:45am. Donations to St. John's University Law School.
CARDINALE--Kathleen. May 3, 2014. Loving wife of Tony, beloved aunt to many. Former VP Director of Nursing Cabrini Hospital. For information: andrettfuneralhome.com or 212-475-2024.

JOHANSEN--Robert Joseph, FSA, 91, Yonkers, NY, died on May 1, 2014. He is survived by his beloved wife, Mary, children, Mary Carroll, Robert (Karlam) and David (Chrisanne), and grandchildren. Wake, May 6, 7-9pm, Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, Bronx; Funeral Mass, May 7, 3pm, St. Margaret of Cortona Church, Bronx.

BIENENSTOCK--Arthur. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed honorary life member, Arthur Bienenstock and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Elaine, his son Martin and his family. Barry N. Winograd, President Donald Capelin, Secretary

KATZ--Sam. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Sam Katz. He leaves behind a loving family to carry on his legacy of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sam's children, Susan Held (Jonathon), Joan Katz (Arthur Aaframe), Debbie Mann (Jeffrey); grandchildren; great-grandchildren; and entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

BIENENSTOCK--Arthur,At 95, and in his 67th year of marriage to Elaine, Arthur Bienenstock passed away peacefully on May 3, as the last surviving child of Morris J. and Fannie Bienenstock. Although Arthur built an amazing real estate business starting with the $2000 he sent home for his mother while serving in World War II, what gave him the most satisfaction was his support of and leadership positions in The Jewish Theological Seminary, UJA, Park Avenue Synagogue, Federation, and many New York City causes for the needy and the arts. Arthur's greatest joys were his wife Elaine and his pride in his children and their spouses (Gloria and Richard; Martin and Barbara), grandchildren (Jessica, Jonathan, Jarett, and Allison), and great-grandchildren (Ian and Maia).

KERN--Frederick Abraham, 87, of W. Palm Beach, FL on Saturday, May 3. Much admired New York State Supreme Court Clerk for over 40 years. Devoted husband, father and grandfather. www.clarkassociatesfuneralhome.com
STRAUS--Micky. EHTC would like to express its condolences to the family of our dear friend and member. He will be missed.

EDELSACK--Pyser Sherman. A dedicated and beloved educator, husband, father, uncle and friend, Pyser Edelsack died of lung cancer on May 5 in New York City. In nearly 40 years of teaching he trained more than 1,500 students as Director of Field Education at the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education at City College, which offers talented high school students -- many of whom are low income minorities -- free tuition and a guaranteed place in medical school in return for a promise to practice for at least two years in underserved areas. His involvement with Sophie Davis grew from his service as an Assistant Professor at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Field Education Coordinator at the Department of Social Medicine at Montefiore Medical Center. Mr. Edelsack was also a board member and former board chairman of the Charles B. Wang Community Health Center. Earlier in his career, he was the principal of The Alternative Learning Space, a middle school for troubled students in the Bronx. As a youth worker for Riverdale Neighborhood House, also in the Bronx, he directed teens in building the first geodesic dome sanctioned by the New York Department of Buildings. Born in Los Angeles in 1943, he graduated from UCLA before joining the Peace Corps, working with farmers and villagers in a remote corner of India. He is predeceased by his sister, Marcia Richman, and survived by his wife, Susan Cole, his son Mack Cole-Edelsack, his nephew Joshua Richman, nieces Heidi Richman and Beth Cole Hale. Funeral will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Thursday, May 8. Send donations to Chinatown Health Clinic Foundation or Sophie Davis.

FERRIS--Alan Edwin, died suddenly on April 30 in Houston, Texas, a tragic loss for all who knew him. His love of family inspired his life, which he led with intelligence, humanity and warmth. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College, Phi Beta Kappa, and of Harvard Business School. He was co-founder and CEO of Arruth Associates, Inc., a Texas-based real estate acquisition, management and development company. He is survived by Madeleine Sherman Ferris, his wife and partner of 46 years, two children, Greg and Katie, their spouses, his grandchildren, nieces and nephews. He was adored by all. Services: Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY, 2pm, Friday, May 9th and later this month in Houston.

FRIEDMAN--Alan J.,71, who died on May 4th after a short illness, was admired and adored in the world of informal science education both here and abroad. For 22 years he directed the New York Hall of Science, guiding it to international prominence. He nurtured a generation of science educators who revered him. He is survived by his wife Mickey and his sister June Entman. There will be a memorial service. Contributions may be made to the Alan J. Friedman Fund at the New York Hall of Science.

MARGOLIS--Karl L. Karl L. Margolis, 97. Died on his own terms: at home, independent, mentally sharp and close to family. Graduate of Erasmus Hall, Brooklyn College and Harvard Business School, where he was a George F. Baker Scholar. Served in Japan as an Army captain. CEO of Lerner Stores Corp. and later vice chairman of McCrory Corp. Enthusiastic tennis player, gardener, history buff and sports fan. Lover of ideas, words, a good joke, a rare steak, a stiff drink. Predeceased by wife, Marjorie, and daughter Kate. Survived by devoted children Laurie, Seth (Carole), Jane (Bruce) and Dan (Carole), beloved grandchildren Christie, Molly, Jacob, Maggie, Ben, Drew, Jack and Anna, and many loving nieces and nephews and their families. Services private.

FRIEDMAN--Alan. J. The Trustees and staff of the New York Hall of Science (NYSCI) extend their deepest sympathies to the family and friends of our former Director, Alan J. Friedman, especially his widow, Mickey. Alan was a matchless science educator, museum director, and leader in the informal science community. His legacy will live on at NYSCI in the exhibits and programs he created, including the groundbreaking Science Career Ladder, and in his writings, his powerful support for free and open inquiry and expression, and the lives and careers of those he inspired. His passing was sudden and devastating. He left us too soon but he left us so much.

KLIMPL--Evelyn I.,died May 4, 2014, at the age of 95, surrounded by her family. Evelyn was the matriarch of the Klimpl, Glickstein and Newman clan. She lived a life she recently described as "wonderful". She was the widow of Emanuel Klimpl, mother of Judith (Paul Berger), Michael (Susan) and Kenneth, sister of Howard Glickstein and Helaine Newman (Lawrence), grandmother of Brian Blitz (Yana), Jason Klimpl (Anne), Rebecca Winerman (Evan), Timothy Klimpl (Blake), Dr. David Klimpl and Richard Klimpl; great-grandmother of Benjamin Blitz, Samuel Blitz, Matthew Winerman and Emanuelle Klimpl. Aunt of Debra Kochman (Ronald), and their children, Alex, Jenny, Emily and Samantha; Daniel Newman (Shari) and their children, Hannah, Rachel: and Karen Newman and her daughter, Allison. Evelyn set the standards for her family. She was intimately involved in everyone's life and her caring was reciprocated by universal respect and deep love. Services Tuesday 1pm at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Interment Maimonides Cemetery. Shiva will be held at the home, following interment, from 5:30-9:00 pm.

GOLDSTEIN--Jerome, "Jerry" on May 5, 2014. Predeceased by his wife Adele. Father of Jamie Frey and Louis Goldstein. Grandfather of Jacob Frey, Asa Frey, Alida Frey,. Jesse Goldstein, Kyle Goldstein. Great-grandfather of Asher Frey. Served in WWll CBI. Professional musician and arranger. Class President of the first graduating class of The High School of Music and Art. Services at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Queens, on Tuesday, May 6, 12:45pm.

HIDEEN--Charlette, passed away on April 17th. We will miss her gracious, loving, and independent spirit and the welcoming kindness she showed to others.

NELSON--Jack. We, at the Mount Sinai Health System, are deeply saddened by the passing of Jack Nelson, a former colleague and cherished friend who served with distinction as Senior Vice President and Chief Information Officer of The Mount Sinai Hospital and Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. An integral member of our strategic team for eight years, Mr. Nelson strengthened the Information Technology department, bringing with it an aggressive financial turnaround for the institution and the implementation of the Electronic Medical Record. He served as a role model for IT leadership, created strong business partnerships, and defined operational excellence. He also excelled at music, playing bass guitar in a New Jersey rock band on weekends and having extensive knowledge of the history of rock and roll. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Barbara, his children and family, colleagues, and many friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD, Chief Executive Officer and President, Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System Kumar Chatani, Senior Vice President and Chief Information Officer, Mount Sinai Health System

CHELNIK--Martin, September 10, 1919 - May 6, 2014 of New York and Palm Beach. Formerly of Scarsdale. Born and raised in the Bronx, the son of Pauline and Charles Chelnik. A Dewitt Clinton graduate, decorated WWII veteran and Purple Heart recipient. Philanthropist and long time contributor to NYU Medical Center. Avid golfer and member of Brae Burn and The Falls. CEO and President of Chelnik Parking Company. Predeceased by devoted wife of 67 years, Harriette, and sister Mildred Goldman. Survived by sister Vera Roseman, children Roberta (Jerry) Roth, Peter and Marc Chelnik. Beloved "Phuffy" of Amy (Jim) Hall, Melissa Jurist and Charles Chelnik. Great-grandfather of five. Funeral services Thursday May 8, 11:15am Riverside Memorial Chapel. Interment to follow at Sharon Gardens. Shiva following funeral at his apartment; Friday and Sunday. Donations can be made to Wounded Warriors Project.
BIER--Bernard H.,You are the warmth of the sun on my face, the gentle breeze at my back. With love, Your Family

EDELSACK--Pyser Sherman. A dedicated and beloved educator, husband, father, uncle and friend, Pyser Edelsack died of lung cancer on May 5 in New York City. In nearly 40 years of teaching he trained more than 1,500 students as Director of Field Education at the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education at City College, which offers talented high school students -- many of whom are low income minorities -- free tuition and a guaranteed place in medical school in return for a promise to practice for at least two years in underserved areas. His involvement with Sophie Davis grew from his service as an Assistant Professor at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Field Education Coordinator at the Department of Social Medicine at Montefiore Medical Center. Mr. Edelsack was also a board member and former board chairman of the Charles B. Wang Community Health Center. Earlier in his career, he was the principal of The Alternative Learning Space, a middle school for troubled students in the Bronx. As a youth worker for Riverdale Neighborhood House, also in the Bronx, he directed teens in building the first geodesic dome sanctioned by the New York Department of Buildings. Born in Los Angeles in 1943, he graduated from UCLA before joining the Peace Corps, working with farmers and villagers in a remote corner of India. He is predeceased by his sister, Marcia Richman, and survived by his wife, Susan Cole, his son Mack Cole-Edelsack, his nephew Joshua Richman, nieces Heidi Richman and Beth Cole Hale. Funeral will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Thursday, May 8. Send donations to Chinatown Health Clinic Foundation or Sophie Davis.
WAYNE--Adele, 95, Widow of Oscar Wayne, passed away peacefully on May 2nd. Memorial service at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY on June 8th at 12:30 PM.

ELY--Matthew Griswold Jr. The governors, members and staff of the Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Matthew G. Ely, Jr. who served as a REBNY governor from 1966 - 1970 and was a member of REBNY's Management Board of Directors. Matthew's father, Matthew G. Ely, was REBNY's Chairman from 1946 - 1948 and served on the Board of Governors in the 1940's and 1950's. We express our sincere condolences to his sons, Matthew III, Timothy and Dwight and the entire Ely family. Rob Speyer, Chairman Steven Spinola, President

THALER--Phyllis. Beloved wife of the late Jerry. Loving mother of Robert (Traci) Thaler and Ellen (Ron) Saslow. Dearest grandmother of Joey, Charlie, Danny, Jolie and Mitzi. Funeral services will be held in New York City. For information: Piser Funeral Service 847-679-4740

OWEN--Lynn Rasmussen, 80, died peacefully on April 26 in New York City after suffering for some time with Alzheimer's. Daughter of Robert and Lillian Rasmussen of Kenosha, Wisconsin, Lynn graduated with honors from the Julliard School and the Vienna Academie. While at Tanglewood, she met the love of her life, Judge Richard Owen, at that time a young lawyer and budding composer, for whom she would later sing the leading role in many of his operas. Lynn sang over 50 leading soprano roles in major opera houses in North and South America and Europe, including the Metropolitan in New York, Vienna and Bellas Artes, under the baton of James Conlon, Julius Rudell and Christopher Keene, among others. She also was on the voice faculty of the Manhattan School of Music, Barnard and Columbia University and left a significant legacy to hundreds of young singers who have gone on to musical careers. Lynn is survived by her husband, two sons and five grandsons all of whom share her passion for music. Those interested in honoring Lynn's teaching legacy may wish to consider making a contribution to the Carl Owen Scholarship at the preparatory division of the Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Ave., NY, NY 10027.

GALLOGLY--Florence E (Giblin), of Wakefield, RI, and formerly of Providence, RI, died on May 5, 2014, at age 92 surrounded by her family. Mother of 11, grandmother of 28, great grandmother of four, mother-in-law, aunt and friend, she was predeceased by her loving husband, Edward P. Gallogly, Chief Judge Emeritus of the Rhode Island Family Court. She was also predeceased by her dear sisters, Mary Giblin and Margaret (Peg) Tedeschi, and her brother Joseph Giblin. Florence is survived by her children and their spouses: E. Peter, Jr., Paul V., and Brian P. (Joanne Brasil Gallogly), all of Providence; Michael L. (Carol Whitney) of Richmond, VA; William J. (Rosemary Booth Gallogly) of Wakefield, RI; John P. (Mary Garripoli) of Los Angeles, CA; Robert E. of Oak Park, IL; Margaret R. (Albert Krieg) of Phoenix, AZ; Mark T. (Lise Strickler) of New York, NY; Mary M. Dickerson (David) of Melrose, MA, and Patricia E. Harris (Ray) of Phoenix, AZ. She is also survived by her grandchildren: Jessie (Paul Bennett), Michael, Patrick, Brendan, Terrance (Erin Callahan), Liam, Nora, Martin, Conor (Jen Wenschhof), Ann, Bridget, Caitlin, Eddie, Owen, Katharine, Grace, Nell, Tory, Katie, Ryan and Erin Gallogly; Austin and Ellen Harris; Jamie and Collin Dickerson, and Joseph, Anna and John Krieg. She is also survived by her great grandchildren: Liam and Sara Gallogly, and Desmond and Sage Bennett. Florence was a communicant at St. Francis of Assisi Church of Wakefield, RI, and the De La Salle Christian Brothers in Narragansett. Growing up in Providence, Florence graduated from Classical High School in 1938 and Rhode Island College of Education (now Rhode Island College) in 1942. After college, Florence worked as a social worker in RI and during WWII she worked on Staten Island for the Red Cross assisting returning veterans, before marrying Ed in 1946. She volunteered at South County Hospital for many years and supported Ocean Tides and the Christian Brothers in Narragansett. She was also an enthusiastic supporter of her husband Ed's legal, political and judicial careers while at the same time providing a loving home for her family. She enjoyed many other activities with family and friends. Visiting hours will be on Thursday, May 8, 2014 from 4 to 8pm at Gallogly Family Funeral Homes, 5 Eddy Street, West Warwick, RI. You are invited to attend a Mass of Christian Burial for Florence on Friday, May 9, 2014 at 10:00am at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 128 High St. Wakefield, RI. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to Ocean Tides of Narragansett or South County Hospital.

WINTER--Marvin S. We remember you each day with love. Your Family

ROBERTS--Michael A.,peacefully at home on May 6, 2014. Beloved husband of Mimi, devoted father of Alec and Judy. Adored grandfather of Jessica, Molly and Benjamin. Dear brother of David. Service private.

KNIGHT--Thomas S.,Jr., 83, of Greenwich, CT, died May 4. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Princeton University; served active duty with the United States Army during the Korean War; and worked for decades in advertising in New York. Among his extensive community and philanthropic work, his greatest passion was Orbis International. He is survived by his wife, Kathleen; four sons and daughters-in-law, and 12 grandchildren. Calling hours held Thursday, May 8, from 4-7pm, Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Greenwich, with a funeral service Friday, May 9 at 11am, St. Michael's Church, Greenwich.

MCBRIDE--Terence Anthony, 65, of Franklin Lakes passed away on May 6, 2014. Born in Paterson he has lived in Franklin Lakes for 30 years. He was the Chairman and a "Master Plumber" of the Frank A. McBride Company in Hawthorne and co-owner with his wife, Mary, of Urban Farms Landscape and Design in Franklin Lakes. Terence was a graduate of Stanford University and Captain of the Golf Team. He was a nine time Club Champion at Arcola and Westhampton and seven times at the National Golf Links. He played in numerous U.S. Amateurs and Mid-Amateurs. A parishioner of Most Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church in Franklin Lakes, Terence was a volunteer at "Eva's Kitchen" as well as a member of various clubs and charitable organizations. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Purdy) McBride of Franklin Lakes. Devoted father of Scott B. McBride and his wife Heather of Chatham, John J. McBride and his wife Mary of Chatham and Laura Parkinson and her husband Mason of Kingsburg, California. Loving grandfather of eight grandchildren. Dear brother of Michael X. McBride of Ridgewood, Dr. Mark J. McBride of Madison, the late Sheila James and loving uncle of twelve nieces and nephews. Terence will be sadly missed by his beloved dogs "Murph" and "Friday". The family will receive family and friends on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Vander Plaat-Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes. Funeral Services Saturday 9:30am at the funeral home followed by a 10:00am Mass of Christian Burial at Most Blessed Sacrament Church. Interment Christ The King Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in Terence's memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Lung Cancer Research, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106. For further information please visit www.vpmemorial.com or call (201) 891-4770.

BAER--Theodore, 87, passed away peacefully April 26th in Southold, NY. Loyal and caring husband for 65 years to his beloved soulmate, his heart, his everything, the late Bertina Baer. In each other's arms again, with extraordinary grace and beauty, they dance together to songs that now only they can hear. "Teddy Baer" as he was affectionately known, served a distinguished clientele for over 50 years as a jeweler where he was esteemed for his integrity, generosity and skill. His handsome elegant attire, heart-warming smile and many kindnesses will live long in the memories of those who knew him. He is survived by sons Andrew and Nolan, daughter-in-law Colleen Griffin, cousin Alan Baer, nephews Jeffrey and Barry Neichen, and half-siblings Arlene and Arthur Isaacs. Memorial service to be held in Manhattan at a future date. For information please call (212) 397-4822.

CROMARTY--Arthur Martin. A war hero whose reputation was synonymous with sterling public service on Long Island, Arthur Cromarty, one of New York's longest sitting Administrative Supreme Court Justices and namesake of the Arthur M. Cromarty Suffolk County Court Complex in Riverhead, died on May 1, 2014. With family members at his side, he passed away from heart failure at the age of 94. He is survived by his daughter, Alice Cromarty of Lindenhurst, NY; two sons, Ross Cromarty of Scottsdale, AZ; and Peter Cromarty of Manhattan and Palm Beach, FL; two grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Friends may visit at Boyd Funeral Home in Babylon, May 7 and 8; Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, in Lindenhurst, May 9th, 9:45am. Donations to St. John's University Law School.
CARDINALE--Kathleen. May 3, 2014. Loving wife of Tony, beloved aunt to many. Former VP Director of Nursing Cabrini Hospital. For information: andrettfuneralhome.com or 212-475-2024.

COMISSIONA--Robinne, passed away on May 5, 2014. Born in Romania. She was the beloved wife of the late conductor, Maestro Sergiu Comissiona, who died in 2005. She studied ballet from the age of nine and toured extensively with the Romanian State Ensemble, the Romanian State Opera Ballet and the Israeli National Opera. She made her debut in 1963 as a choreographer with the Harlequin Ballet in London and was acclaimed by critics as a "dedicated and imaginative choreographer." In 1973, with Elspeth Udvarhelyi, she co-founded Pointe-on-Strings, a public grant assisted ensemble in Baltimore, Maryland. In 1976 her company merged with the Maryland Ballet Company with whom she had been an advisor. In 1977 she founded the College Dance-Mime Theater, a dance pantomime group in Baltimore. She was awarded the Freddel Lack Award in 1983 for outstanding contributions to the enrichment of young people through art and education. Services will be held Thursday, 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
HODES--Jacquline. May 6, 2014. Resident of Manhattan. Interment Thursday, 1pm at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

HILL--Marianne D. Passed away peacefully May 4, 2014, at Greenport, NY. Born Marianne Fahys Dean in Garden City, NY, on October 6, 1922, to Howard Brush Dean and Maria Cook Dean. A lifelong New Yorker, she was brought up in Manhattan, North Haven, and East Hampton. She attended school at Chapin, Miss Porter's, and Bennett Junior College; worked in childhood education in New York City; and was then a longtime resident of Cold Spring Harbor where she raised her family and taught nursery school for many years. Her joys included her church, gardening, tennis, volunteer work, Labrador retrievers, and fishing with her husband and boys. Devoted to family, friends of all ages, and her beloved students, Mair met each day with a positive outlook, a great sense of humor, and a deep and genuine kindness for all. The exceptional generosity of her spirit and the warmth of her character never wavered. Predeceased by her husband Lucien Hill, son Lucien Hill III (Tony), brother Howard B. Dean, Jr., and sister Nancy D. Felch; she is survived by her son John H. Hill, daughter-in-law Renee A. Richards, grandson James L. Hill, sister-in-law Andree M. Dean, and her many nieces, nephews, and cousins. A Memorial Service will be held at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, on Monday, May 12 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Employee Appreciation Fund at Peconic Landing, Greenport, NY.

GARTENBERG--Patricia A. (Moriarty), PhD, on May 3, 2014. Daughter of Timothy and Elizabeth (Gargan) Moriarty. Beloved wife of the late Max J. Gartenberg. Loving mother of Anne G. Devlin and her husband Robert. Cherished grandmother of William A. (Janai) and Paul J. Devlin (Lauren). Sister of Rosemary Armstrong (Francis), Patrick Moriarty (Sandra) and Timothy Moriarty (Denise). Also survived by eight nieces and nephews, 14 great-nieces and nephews, and four great-great-nephews. She lived her life with passion and integrity and was named Teacher of the Year at Rutgers University in 1980 and 1993, where she was also Chair of the English Department. Friends may call May 12th from 8:30-9:30am at FitzGerald-Sommer Funeral Home, Yardley, PA. Funeral Mass 10am at St. John the Evangelist Church. Burial at Washington Crossing National Cemetery.

GALLOGLY--Florence E (Giblin), of Wakefield, RI, and formerly of Providence, RI, died on May 5, 2014, at age 92 surrounded by her family. Mother of 11, grandmother of 28, great grandmother of four, mother-in-law, aunt and friend, she was predeceased by her loving husband, Edward P. Gallogly, Chief Judge Emeritus of the Rhode Island Family Court. She was also predeceased by her dear sisters, Mary Giblin and Margaret (Peg) Tedeschi, and her brother Joseph Giblin. Florence is survived by her children and their spouses: E. Peter, Jr., Paul V., and Brian P. (Joanne Brasil Gallogly), all of Providence; Michael L. (Carol Whitney) of Richmond, VA; William J. (Rosemary Booth Gallogly) of Wakefield, RI; John P. (Mary Garripoli) of Los Angeles, CA; Robert E. of Oak Park, IL; Margaret R. (Albert Krieg) of Phoenix, AZ; Mark T. (Lise Strickler) of New York, NY; Mary M. Dickerson (David) of Melrose, MA, and Patricia E. Harris (Ray) of Phoenix, AZ. She is also survived by her grandchildren: Jessie (Paul Bennett), Michael, Patrick, Brendan, Terrance (Erin Callahan), Liam, Nora, Martin, Conor (Jen Wenschhof), Ann, Bridget, Caitlin, Eddie, Owen, Katharine, Grace, Nell, Tory, Katie, Ryan and Erin Gallogly; Austin and Ellen Harris; Jamie and Collin Dickerson, and Joseph, Anna and John Krieg. She is also survived by her great grandchildren: Liam and Sara Gallogly, and Desmond and Sage Bennett. Florence was a communicant at St. Francis of Assisi Church of Wakefield, RI, and the De La Salle Christian Brothers in Narragansett. Growing up in Providence, Florence graduated from Classical High School in 1938 and Rhode Island College of Education (now Rhode Island College) in 1942. After college, Florence worked as a social worker in RI and during WWII she worked on Staten Island for the Red Cross assisting returning veterans, before marrying Ed in 1946. She volunteered at South County Hospital for many years and supported Ocean Tides and the Christian Brothers in Narragansett. She was also an enthusiastic supporter of her husband Ed's legal, political and judicial careers while at the same time providing a loving home for her family. She enjoyed many other activities with family and friends. Visiting hours will be on Thursday, May 8, 2014 from 4 to 8pm at Gallogly Family Funeral Homes, 5 Eddy Street, West Warwick, RI. You are invited to attend a Mass of Christian Burial for Florence on Friday, May 9, 2014 at 10:00am at St. Francis of Assisi Church, 128 High St. Wakefield, RI. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to Ocean Tides of Narragansett or South County Hospital.

KNIGHT--Thomas S.,Jr., 83, of Greenwich, CT, died May 4. He was a graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Princeton University; served active duty with the United States Army during the Korean War; and worked for decades in advertising in New York. Among his extensive community and philanthropic work, his greatest passion was Orbis International. He is survived by his wife, Kathleen; four sons and daughters-in-law, and 12 grandchildren. Calling hours held Thursday, May 8, from 4-7pm, Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, Greenwich, with a funeral service Friday, May 9 at 11am, St. Michael's Church, Greenwich.

LANDERS--Jennifer. We at Grey are deeply saddened by the passing of our much loved colleague and cherished friend Jennifer Landers at the young age of 45, surrounded by her family, on May 6th. She is survived by her loving parents, John and Jane Landers, her sister and brother-in-law Alyssa and Christopher Gillen of Los Angeles and their children, Chloe and Eamon Gillen and her brother and sister-in-law Mark and Lisa Landers of Franklin Lakes, NJ and their children Charlie and Annabel. Jennifer was born in Teaneck, NJ on October 27, 1968 and grew up in Wyckoff, NJ. She graduated from Ramapo High School in 1986 and Skidmore College in 1990. Jennifer was a public relations natural whose wit, sense of fun, megawatt smile, kindness and work ethic captivated clients, colleagues and the press. She began her career at the Walt Disney Company's Hyperion Books, responsible for national publicity campaigns for best-selling authors and spent a decade there, graduating from the Disney Management program. She joined ad agency Kirshenbaum Bond and Partners and spent eight years making major contributions in public relations, business development and agency communications for many blue-chip clients. She came into her own and the hearts of Grey's 1,000 person office as Senior Vice President, Director of Reputation Management in 2010 overseeing marketing, social media, special events, and big projects no one else would dare take on. Her passing leaves a void in our hearts. A Funeral Mass will be held on Friday, May 9th at 10am at St. Elizabeth Church in Wyckoff, NY.
CHARNELLE--Leonard H.,MD, and Phyllis T. Charnelle. In love and remembrance Susan and Marshall

ROSENBERG--Rose, 98, beloved wife of the late Harold Rosenberg for 76 years, died peacefully May 6th. A resident of Lake Worth, Florida and formerly of Lido Beach, New York. A stunning force of nature, she is survived by her children Jane Stein (Rick), Liz Rosenberg Citron (Phil), Gale Bayer and the late Stephen Bayer; grandchildren John, Maggie, and Johanna Stein, Kate Stein Hilliker, Kim Bayer Olthoff and Jesse Bayer; and great-grandchildren John Stephen, Ruby, True and Cole. Funeral services will be private.

ZIMMERMAN--Charles, M.D.,passed away peacefully from natural causes May 3rd, 2014 in Annapolis, Maryland. He was born in Brooklyn in 1931 to Bella Horn Zimmerman and Louis Zimmerman. He attended Stuyvesant High School, Columbia College and Downstate Medical School. In 1955 he married Roslyn Riegel. He completed his Radiology residency at Jacobi Hospital. He served as a Captain in the United States Army at Fort Gordon, Georgia from 1959-1961. He and Roslyn then moved to Northern New Jersey where he practiced Radiology and Nuclear Medicine. He obtained his board certification in Nuclear Medicine in the late 1960's. As an Associate Professor of Radiology at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, he published many original studies in his field in various professional journals. He was President of the Medical Staff of the Barnert Memorial Hospital in Paterson, New Jersey in the early 1980's and served for many years on the hospital's Board of Directors. In addition to his professional accomplishments he had an encyclopedic knowledge of Civil War history and was an active member of the New York City and South Florida Civil War Roundtables. He had many other deeply explored intellectual pursuits throughout his life which included opera, classical music, ballet, wine appreciation, extensive travel, current affairs and was also an avid reader of classic literature. One of his great talents, which he maintained until the end, was his ability to engage and learn from people he encountered from all walks of life. He was an active member of Congregation Kneseth Israel in Annapolis. He is survived by his wife Roslyn Zimmerman, brother Arthur Zimmerman, of Sacramento, CA, and daughters Susan (William) Zimmerman of Annapolis, MD, and Gloria (Matthew) Zimmerman of New York City and four grandchildren, Stephen, Natalie, Maxwell and Lucy. He was devoted to his immediate and extended family who all cherished him and will miss him greatly. In the words of his granddaughter, Natalie, "people are only truly gone when the memory of them fades, but Grandpa's memory isn't going anywhere anytime soon."

KASH--Shirley Black, 92, died of natural causes on Monday, May 5, 2014 in Paradise Valley, Arizona, where she lived for 20 years. Her son Leon Black, his wife Debra and their four children Benjamin, Joshua, Alexander, and Victoria; and her daughter Judy Black and her husband Richard Schlosberg mourn the loss of a beloved mother and grandparent. Born Shirley Lubell on June 20, 1921 in New York City, she grew up in New York City and lived in Westport, Connecticut as well. She pursued a life-long interest in the arts. She was an accomplished water colorist and her works of art were shown at the Alonzo Gallery in New York City. Often inspired by nature, her love of flowers and plants was realized in her vibrant gardens and paintings. She was married to Eli Black for 29 years, who passed away in 1975. Her second husband, William Kash, died in 2010, after 28 years of marriage. She was also predeceased by her sister, Grace Borgenicht, and her brother, Benedict Lubell.
RAUCH--Peter. As Irving Berlin said: "The song has ended, but the melody lingers on." We will always love you.

BROMBERG--Marvin William, a longtime New Yorker, died May 5, 2014, after a two year battle with glioblastoma. He was 88 years old. Born January 13, 1926, in Brooklyn, Dr. Bromberg was the only child of Velvo (William) and Ruchel (Rose) Bromberg, immigrants from Ukraine. A graduate of New York University, Dr. Bromberg served as a dentist in the Air Force, and for over fifty years, his practice was a magnet for artists, writers and creative thinkers throughout New York. A loving, dedicated husband, father, and grandfather, Dr. Bromberg is survived by his wife of 62 years, Penny Derris Bromberg, their two sons, Craig and Todd, their wives, Hilary and Veronika, and four grandchildren. A private graveside funeral will be held at New Montefiore Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in Dr. Bromberg's memory to Voices Against Brain Cancer.

BIENENSTOCK--Arthur. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Mr. Arthur Bienenstock, an honored member of the club for over 43 years. The Harmonie Club wishes to extend its deeply heartfelt condolences to the entire Bienenstock family in their time of sorrow. Philip Cowen, President

BLOCH--Thelma, 83 on May 5, 2014. Devoted wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Peter. Her loving heart, kind spirit and passion for the arts will always be remembered. Services Thursday May 8, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to www.cancercare.org

BLOCH--Thelma. Our wonderful friend passed away May 5th. She enjoyed exploring new locales. We have fond memories of summers and weekends together. We will miss her smile and elegance. Marilyn & Peter Rosenblatt

BIENENSTOCK--Arthur H.,The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Arthur H. Bienenstock, longtime member of the JTS Board of Directors and its Executive Committee, and former chair of the JTS Real Estate Committee. Mr. Bienenstock worked closely with several chancellors and vice-chancellors, received the Louis Marshall Memorial Medal in 1975, and was inducted into the JTS Society of Fellows for his dedication and generosity. Devoted to his wife, Elaine, and their children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, he was a model of involvement in the Jewish community. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair
